title: It's time for our nation to pray
author: T. D. Nichols; Denton Church Of Free Seventh Day Adventists
content:
It's time for our nation to pray

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T. D. Nichols; Denton Church Of Free Seventh Day Adventists | Page: 5A | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If My People which are called by My name, shall humble themselves, and pray, and seek My face, and turn from their wicked ways; then will I hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal their land. - 2 Chronicles 7:14The Bible tells us in Ecclesiastes 3: 1-8: "To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven" There is a Christian hymn, "The Time For Praying Won't Be Long." Benjamin Franklin is said to be responsible for a usage that many of us have spoken or heard now and then, "Don't put off until tomorrow what you can do today." My friend, neighbor, fellow citizen, please consider the times in which you now live.In the true essence of things, no matter one's age, even if one is blessed to live to be a centenarian, in relation to eternity, one really does not have too much time to make sure as it is put by the Apostle Peter in 2 Peter 1:10," to make your calling and election sure: for if you do these things, you shall never fall." Think about it.Yet, if you are reading this, by the special grace of Jesus Christ, there is still time for you and for our God-given USA to turn to God.In this troubling, violent and irreverent age, we must call ourselves to the order of the God of Creation, and to the accountability and repentance for our declining spiritual condition and pray in humility and commitment to experience the promised healing of our person and of our nation.

title: Pushing too far
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pushing too far

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 130
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to news reports, Gov. Moore is recommending an increase in Maryland's capital gains tax and an increase in the personal income tax. In each instance, the increase will only be for higher levels of income. Of course, such a tax will primarily affect those with the largest stake in the state's economy.In contrast, Canada's new prime minister recently announced he will not propose or support an increase in Canada's capital gains tax. While this may not seem especially perspicacious since the Canadian capital gains rate is already at 50%, it certainly does recognize a limit to what is economically sensible. It's wishful thinking but would be nice, therefore, if Canada's experience helped educate Gov. Moore and Maryland about the pitfalls of pushing the private sector too far.
ART CECIL
Easton

title: Meeting, discussions at Cambridge YMCA heat up
author: Jim Johnson jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Meeting, discussions at Cambridge YMCA heat up

 June 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jim Johnson jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Columns 
 
 1318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The gym was hot. Not unbearably hot, but close enough.Members of the Pauline F. and W. David Robbins Family YMCA in Cambridge filed into the gym on a blistering hot day to hear about plans for a new YMCA from the Y's leadership.
"Welcome to the world's largest sauna," somebody said as people picked up a bottle of water the Y provided for attendees.
Hundreds attended. Many of them were hot — not just because of the heat in the gym — but because they had heard about plans to move the YMCA to the proposed Cambridge Harbor site that is being developed by Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.
They liked the Y right where it is on Talbot Avenue in Cambridge.
At the microphone was Robbie Gill. Much of the crowd's heat was directed at Gill, who is the CEO of the YMCA of the Chesapeake, the organization that oversees and runs not just the Cambridge Y but the 11 Eastern Shore YMCAs from Elkton in Cecil County to Pokomoke City and Salsibury on the Lower Shore.
I must say, Gill was cool. He was chill. People were angry, and they let him know it. I didn't see him sweating. He patiently answered questions after the crowd moved from the hot gym to the better air-conditioned lobby.
Let's say that a good part of the problem was self-inflicted.
The meeting was held less than two weeks after an email was sent out by the YMCA of the Chesapeake that led people to believe the organization had reached a deal with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. to build a new YMCA on the Cambridge Harbor site.
Both Gill and CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard told the Star Democrat after that email landed in members in boxes that there is no such deal to build on Cambridge Harbor at this time.
The YMCA is advocating the need to build a new YMCA, Gill said in his interview with Star Democrat reporter Maggie Trovato. He said the existing site is not sustainable over the next two decades and can't provide certain programs, amenities and services.
He repeated that at the meeting with Cambridge Y members last Tuesday. I am not sure he changed many minds at the meeting.
Gill gave a presentation on a market study that tested three different sites for a new Cambridge YMCA facility. Two representatives from Triangle2, the firm that completed the market study, presented with Gill.
The three sites tested in the market study were the current YMCA location on Talbot Avenue near Gerry Boyle Park, Cambridge Harbor and a parcel on the corner of Maple Dam Road and Route 16, which is near Cambridge-South Dorchester High School.
Triangle2 CEO Lori Swann said 814 households were interviewed for the market study.
Swann said the current site and Maple Dam Road site did not test as well as the Cambridge Harbor site did.
According to the presentation, 73% of the interviewed county residents that were interested in joining the YMCA would be "very likely" to participate in a YMCA at Cambridge Harbor. The presentation showed that 61% felt that way about the current location and 42% felt that way about the Maple Dam Road site.
Gill said the market study made it clear that the community is in need of amenities that the current facility cannot provide.
During the question and answer portion of the meeting, member Phil Reed said his impression from the meeting was that Gill and the YMCA are sold on the waterfront site.
Kathy Abend, who has been a member of the YMCA for several years, said in an interview that she didn't think Gill seemed open to rebuilding on the current site.
"He was shutting this down," she said.
For the record, my wife and I are members of the Cambridge YMCA and work out there daily. We walk from our home to the facility, which we would not be able to do if the Y moved to Cambridge Harbor.
With that said, there are good reasons to build a new facility, and statistics from Y's elsewhere on the Eastern Shore support the contention that new facilities result in increased membership. Gill repeatedly brought up the experience in Chestertown, where a new facility resulted in a huge increase in membership, far exceeding projections when that project was started.
Gill also mentioned donors who have pledged the millions of dollars it will take to construct a new facility in Cambridge. Donor dollars are essential to a successful project..
Part of the problem the YMCA faces is its association with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. That organization has been shrouded in secrecy, secrecy that worries many in Cambridge that deals made behind closed doors may not be in the best interest of the town and its tax-paying residents.
While CWDI has shown more openness since Angie Hengst became president of the board this year, there is wariness dealing with the organization. You could see that wariness in the questions asked at the Cambridge Y meeting last week.
Probably the biggest fear — which may be unfounded but is still a fear — is that a backroom deal has been reached between the two organizations for the development of the Talbot Avenue YMCA property following a move of the facility to Cambridge Harbor.
"There has not been talk of a deal with the YMCA," CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard said in an interview with reporter Maggie Trovato earlier this month, adding that the two groups do have conversations from time to time about the YMCA's interest in being a part of the project to develop space along the Choptank River.
Leonard said CWDI has had those kinds of conversations with multiple respondents of a July 2022 request for proposals. The YMCA was one of the respondents to that request.
The June 7 email the YMCA sent out included a "facility update" about banners the organization is replacing at its current Cambridge location on Talbot Avenue.
"As we work to highlight all the positives that come with building a new Robbins Family Y at Cambridge Harbor, we wanted to give you a sneak peak of the new banners," the email reads.
After the email was sent out, people on social media shared concerns about the YMCA's plans. Cambridge Association of Neighborhoods President Chuck McFadden said in an interview that when he saw the email, he was "taken aback," and he said the news was "buried" in an email about banners.
Gill, who has received emails and phone calls from concerned residents since the email went out, said the YMCA is advocating the need to build a new YMCA. He said the existing site is not sustainable over the next two decades and can't provide certain programs, amenities and services.
"We are trying to help frame a narrative because, right now, you have other people that are framing narratives that are just wrong," he said.
My opinion: I think the YMCA of Chesapeake should look closer at building new facilities on the existing site. In previous communities where I have been an editor, I have seen voters defeat bonds for new school buildings but then come back and approve bonds for projects where additions were built on to existing buildings.
The existing Cambridge YMCA is on 7 acres and offers space for sports fields and community gardens. Those would not be available with a move to Cambridge Harbor.
At the same time, a Cambridge Harbor location would be closer to U.S. Route 50 and would attract members from North Dorchester County and areas east of Cambridge, members who would not be interested in the current location deep in town.
I think either location with added amenities would attract members. It would be easier to build on a new location while keeping the existing facility operational, but with planning, the same thing could be accomplished at the existing location.
Members need to keep an open mind about a Cambridge Harbor location. At the same time, YMCA leaders need to listen to the concerns of its existing membership.
Jim Johnson is the executive editor of The Star Democrat.

title: Nothing more difficult than taking lead on change
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Nothing more difficult than taking lead on change

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 771
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Well before and since his swearing in on Jan. 20, President Trump has been moving aggressively to secure Senate approval of a team of cabinet and sub-cabinet members to implement his Make America Great Again agenda.To date he has achieved significant, but not yet universal, success on those approvals.
As I write this there are at least three of his nominations where final Senate approval is increasingly likely but not certain.
They are are Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for secretary of Health and Human Services, Kash Patel for FBI director, and Tulsi Gabbard for national intelligence director.
Earlier last month Trump's nomination of Pete Hegseth to serve as secretary of Defense was approved in the Senate by the narrowest of margins.
Following contentious committee hearings on his background and competence, Hegseth was confirmed only after Vice President JD Vance broke a 50-50 tie vote with a "yes" vote for him.
If any of the pending Trump nominations fail to receive full Senate approval it will be the first time since 1925 when a Republican controlled Senate rejected a Republican president's cabinet nomination. The president then was Calvin Coolidge and the failed nominee was Charles Warren for attorney general.
Trump's immediate Democratic predecessors — Barack Obama and Joe Biden had all their cabinet nominations approved by the Senate. In both cases there were Democratic majorities in the Senate and some of their more controversial nominations were withdrawn from consideration before full Senate consideration of their nominations.
The reasons for resistance to Trump are not surprising.
Over 500 years ago political observer and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli wrote the following timeless observation on change:
"It must be remembered that there is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or more uncertain in its success, than to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things. Because the innovator has for enemies all those who have done well under the old conditions, and lukewarm defenders in those who may do well under the new. This coolness arises partly from fear of the opponents, who have the laws on their side, and partly from the incredulity of men, who do not readily believe in new things until they have had a long experience of them."
In 2024 Trump ran and won on a change platform and his commitment to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things in Washington.
That is similar to the goal that former President Obama expressed when he first ran for the presidency.
Early and often on the campaign trail Obama said, "Washington is broken. My whole campaign has been premised from the start on the idea that we have to fundamentally change how Washington works."
After the election to his first term, Obama said with confidence that he had not miscalculated how difficult it would be to change Washington.
He said, "I didn't overpromise. And I didn't underestimate how tough this was gonna be."
After four years in office and his election to a second term Obama acknowledged with a combination of frustration, regret and self-reflection, that he had in fact miscalculated and underestimated how hard making changes was going to be.
He said "I'm the first one to confess that the spirit that I brought to Washington, that I wanted to see instituted, where we weren't constantly in a political slugfest … I haven't fully accomplished that. Haven't even come close in some instances. And, you know, if you ask me what's my biggest disappointment [it] is that we haven't changed the tone in Washington as much as I would have liked."
Time will tell if Donald Trump acknowledges and says much the same thing after the end of his second term.
The first test of success or failure for Trump will occur in less than two years.
In November 2026, all the seats in the House of Representatives and one third of the seats in the Senate will be up for election.
Historically, but not always, these elections are largely a referendum on a president's performance and agenda.
If the Republicans do lose control of the House or the Senate in 2026, any unapproved elements of Trump's MAGA agenda will likely be stalled, if not stopped completely.
Conversely, if that does not occur, the odds for success for Trump in continuing to advance his MAGA agenda are greatly increased.
It also increases the odds for Vice President Vance securing the Republican nomination for and winning the election as president in 2028.
Going forward, only one thing is certain.
Either way, we will soon be better able to affirm or challenge the thinking that in the political world, pursuing real change is often an exercise in futility, no matter who is elected president.

title: Scheffler storms into lead
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Scheffler storms into lead

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland — The rain pounded Royal Portrush right when Scottie Scheffler poured in a birdie putt on his first hole Friday in the British Open. No matter. Nothing stopped the world's No. 1 player on his way to a 7-under 64 to build a one-shot lead going into the weekend.Scheffler made eight birdies on another wild afternoon of weather at Royal Portrush, and his 15-foot birdie attempt on the 18th stopped inches short for another.
The result was a one-shot lead over former U.S. Open champion Matt Fitzpatrick, who made four straight birdies to start the back nine until he cooled on the home stretch and had to settle for a 66.
The rain was heavy at times but never lasted long. The wind was breezy but never at strength that can cause fits. The scoring was lower, nearly two shots easier than the opening round.
Except for a few chasers, Scheffler made it look like it wasn't enough.
He was at 10-under 132 as he chases the third leg of the career Grand Slam, having won the PGA Championship by five shots in May.
Brian Harman got the best of the weather — surprising sunshine — and took dead aim in his hunt for another claret jug. Harman played bogey-free for a 64 that left him only two shots behind, along with Li Haotong of China, who had a 67.
Everyone else was five shots behind or more.
That includes Rory McIlroy, who went around Royal Portrush in his native Northern Ireland with plenty of cheers but only a few roars. McIlroy had a 69 but lost a lot of ground because of Scheffler, Fitzpatrick and Harman.
He started the second round just three shots behind. He goes into the weekend seven shots behind the top-ranked player in the world.
Fitzpatrick was at his lowest point just four months ago when he changed his caddie and coach and began pulling himself up. And now he takes that into the weekend against Scheffler.
"He's going to have the expectation to go out and dominate. He's an exceptional player. He's world No. 1, and we're seeing Tiger-like stuff," Fitzpatrick said. "I think the pressure is for him to win the golf tournament. For me, obviously I hope I'm going to have some more home support than him, but it's an exciting position for me to be in given where I was earlier this year."
Fitzpatrick was rolling along until a pair of short putts he missed, from 5 feet for par on the 14th and from 3 feet for birdie on the 17th. Even so, he holed a 25-foot par putt on the final hole and assured him being in the last group at 9-under 133.
Scheffler was sharp from the start. He hit eight of the 14 fairways — compared with three in the opening round — though his misses never left him too badly out of position. But he is seeing the breaks on smoother Portrush greens, and he looks confident as ever.
None of his eight birdies were closer than 7 feet. Five of them were in the 10-foot range and then he threw in a 35-foot birdie on the sixth. His lone bogey came on a drive into deep grass on the 11th that kept him from reaching the green.
The statistics led to a shrug.
"Overall, I'm hitting the ball solid," Scheffler said. "The tournament is only halfway done. I got off to a good start."
Harman was called the "Butcher of Hoylake" when he won the claret jug at Royal Liverpool two years ago because the British press was fascinated by the Georgia native's love for hunting. Now it's about his golf, and it was superb.
Harman played bogey-free, only once having to stress for par as Royal Portrush allowed for some good scoring in weather that again did not live up to its expectation.
Not that anyone was complaining. Temperatures were warm, at least by Irish standards. The breeze was noticeable without being overly punishing.
"They're very different golf courses, but the golf is similar," Harman said. "You've got to be able to flight your golf ball. You've got to know how far everything's going. Then you can't get frustrated. You're going to end up in funny spots where it doesn't seem fair, and you just have to kind of outlast that stuff."
The group at 5-under 137 included Harris English (70), Harman's former teammate at Georgia; Tyrrell Hatton of England (69) and Chris Gotterup (65), who wasn't even planning to be at Royal Portrush until winning the Scottish Open last week.
Also still around is Bryson DeChambeau, who made a 13-shot improvement from the first round with a 65. Still, he was 11 shots behind.
McIlroy wasn't at his best in the opening round and was pleased to be only three behind. Now he has a real mountain to climb. But at least he's still playing, unlike in 2019 at Royal Portrush when he shot 79 and then had a terrific rally only to miss the cut by one shot.
"I didn't have this opportunity six years ago, so to play an extra two days in this atmosphere in front of these crowds, I'm very excited for that," McIlroy said. "I feel like my game's definitely good enough to make a run."
That was before Scheffler began to run away from so many except a small collection of challengers. But this is links golf. And this is the Emerald Isle, where the weather seems to have a mind of its own.
Still, Scheffler has gone 10 tournaments without finishing out of the top 10 and would appear to present a challenge every bit as daunting as Royal Portrush.

title: Everybody has a role in suicide prevention
author: Andrew Moon
content:
Everybody has a role in suicide prevention

 September 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrew Moon | Page: A10 | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For All Seasons is hosting a free community event, "We All Have a Role to Play in Suicide Prevention," from 7 to 8:30 p.m. on Thursday, Sept. 7, at the Avalon Theatre in Easton.The event is part of a powerful speaker series presentation led by suicide expert and leader within the Veterans Affairs' National Suicide Prevention Program, Dr. Andrew Moon, and facilitated by For All Seasons President and CEO Beth Anne Dorman. Participants will strengthen their awareness around the topic of suicide prevention, and learn how to reduce suicide risks, leaving attendees with the hope, readiness, and strategies to make a difference in their community.Moon will share his invaluable experience in averting crisis points before suicidality. He is a clinical psychologist with a career focus on trauma, suicide prevention, and education, and is currently the senior advisor for partnerships, engagement and education for the Department of Defense Suicide Prevention Office. He will share insights into national, state and local mental health data, specifically how suicide impacts specific groups, including veterans, first responders, LGBTQ+ populations, and youth.In addition, he will outline the pivotal role each one of us plays in suicide prevention, offering practical strategies for recognizing signs of struggle and responding effectively.Moon will share how to foster an environment of safety for those in your circle to prevent suicide and support those you care about.The month of September is No Matter WhatYou Matter Suicide Prevention Month and For All Seasons urges all citizens to actively work toward the prevention of suicide and to reach out to one another and ask - "Are you OK?" listen - without judgment, and share - vital resources to promote an inclusive and mentally healthy community.In the U.S., suicide is the second leading cause of death for people ages 10 to 14 and 25-34.In Maryland, suicide is the third leading cause of death for 10 to 34-year-olds. In 2021, 1 in 5 Maryland Mid-Shore teens ages 14 to 17 attempted suicide at least once.These statistics are staggering, and these deaths are often preventable.Checking in with someone could help save a life. If someone you know is showing signs of depression, withdrawal or unusual behavior, take time to check-in. Reach out to your circle of friends and family. Be attentive to those whom you have concerns about, and connect them to resources. There are proven treatments to help those with suicidal thoughts and behaviors.Someone experiencing a crisis may not recognize that suicidal thoughts are often temporary, and with professional support, hope and healing are within their reach.Ask: "Are you OK? Are you having suicidal thoughts?" Be direct and compassionate.Research shows that asking this question will not put the idea into someone's mind.Share: "You are not alone. Help is available." Connect them to services.For All Seasons is just a phone call away.Listen: You don't need to have all the answers. Be fully present without judgment. Allow the person to share their story.Most importantly, if you need suicide prevention resources and a step-by-step conversation guide visit: NoMatterWhatYouMatter.org. For All Seasons' 24-Hour Crisis Hotlines are English 410.820.5600 and Español 410.829.6143. English/Español Text is 410.829.6143. For the National Suicide & Crisis Hotline: Dial 988.For All Seasons provides the highest quality mental health and victim services to children, adults, and families across Maryland's Eastern Shore. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach, and community education.For information about For All Seasons walk-in hours, contact For All Seasons at 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org.Caption: Pictured is Dr. Andrew Moon, suicide expert and leader with the Veterans Affairs' National Suicide Prevention Program, who will help facilitate the upcoming For All Seasons talk on suicide prevention on September 7 from 7 to 8:30 p.m. at the Avalon Theatre in Easton.

title: ‘A gem’: State and local leaders celebrate Port Street Commons project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘A gem’: State and local leaders celebrate Port Street Commons project

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 596
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A multi-use property bringing affordable housing and behavioral health services to Easton is officially complete.Port Street Commons, a 24,000-square-foot project led by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, celebrated the end of construction with a ribbon-cutting ceremony that included local and state officials. The space houses nine apartment units as well as a headquarters for The Arc, complete with offices and a behavioral health suite.
Speaking to more than 100 attendees Thursday morning, The Arc President and CEO Jonathon Rondeau said the organization is "building a future where equity and inclusion are the norm."
"There will be people whose lives change within these walls because of the services they receive, the connections they make, the housing they can afford," Rondeau said.
The $11 million project, financed through a capital campaign, received $2.5 million in investment from the state and $750,000 in federal funding, Rondeau said. Chesapeake Neighbors, a housing subsidiary of The Arc, held a lottery in September for potential tenants that fell within the income requirements, with more than 250 people entering.
There are seven two-bedroom units and two three-bedroom units, all of them featuring free Wi-Fi and appliances. Two of the first-floor units are tailored to accommodate tenants with disabilities.
Members of the Easton Town Council and Talbot County Council, along with Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), attended Thursday's ceremony.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said the project is a fit for the town's goal to revitalize the area next to the Tred Avon River. She noted Port Street Commons is the first project to fall under the town's mixed-use waterfront zoning.
"We're eager to encourage mixed-use facilities such as this, allowing for exciting new businesses in tandem with more affordable housing, both of which are critical for growth in our community," she said.
The site at 480 Port Street was identified in July 2021, and construction began just under two years later. In an interview, Rondeau said the quick timeline helps The Arc fulfill the community's immediate housing needs, adding that the town was a crucial partner.
"There's a lot of development happening here in Easton," Rondeau said. "It's a small town, only so many inspectors and things like that. The town has been great. They've really worked with us to help meet those timelines when we had a problem."
Rondeau said four families who were randomly drawn have been confirmed, with the first of those moving in Dec. 2. All nine apartments should be occupied by March, he said.
Julia Glanz, deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Housing & Community Development, and Carol Beatty, secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities, both complimented the housing project during the ceremony.
Beatty said the apartments tackle "one of the most common concerns" she hears from Marylanders with disabilities — a lack of accessible housing that is also affordable.
Glanz was excited about the project and hopes it can be an example for other mixed-use housing endeavors.
"It is, I think, a gem across the state," Glanz said in an interview. " … From what I've seen in the last year and a half, this is very unique. And it's bringing so many different facets of life into one space."
The deputy secretary noted that the House Expansion and Affordability Act of 2024, which encourages higher-density affordable housing projects, reduces government barriers. However, Port Street Commons completed most of its three-and-a-half year turnaround before that act was passed.
"The Arc being able to do that without that legislation … is a testament to the community effort here in Easton and Talbot County, which we don't see everywhere," Glanz said.

 David DuchovnyQ: It's been interesting to see David Duchovny back in the public eye for the movie he made with Meg Ryan. How long was he on "The X-Files"?A: The actor's run as FBI Agent Fox Mulder began in 1993, and he has said that he didn't expect the Fox series (now repeating on Comet) to last as long as it did, nor to be as popular as it became. His regular weekly run on the show went through the seventh season, when headlines were made by a lawsuit Duchovny filed against 20th Century Fox Television, alleging that it sold rights to repeats of the show to Fox-affiliated stations for less than they were worth thus costing him some profits.The suit was settled, but Duchovny's contract for the show was up, so he left as a full-time cast member (with Robert Patrick assuming the role of a Mulder surrogate, John Doggett). However, Duchovny returned for part of the eighth season, with the explanation that Mulder had been abducted by aliens.He also came back for the presumed series finale in Season 9, but as it turned out, he wasn't done with the show yet.Fox gave "The X-Files" revivals as a limited-run program in 2016 and 2018, which were deemed to be the 10th and 11th seasons of the show. Series creator-producer Chris Carter has inferred that there are more stories in that universe to be told, but any discussions of a continuation of the franchise haven't come to fruition. The show also yielded two theatrical films in which Duchovny played Mulder (opposite Gillian Anderson's Agent Dana Scully), "The X-Files: Fight the Future" (1998) and "The X-Files: I Want to Believe" (2008).

 It is usually important, when you are writing, to ensure your meaning is crystal clear. For example, I have seen many road signs claiming "Slow Children Playing." Presumably the quick children are at home studying. Also open to misinterpretation was this sign in Northern Ireland: "If you find the service in this cafe unsatisfactory, you should see Mr. Wilson the manager." The correct play in today's deal should be crystal clear to an expert.After a straightforward auction to four hearts, West leads the club king. How should South plan the play?Declarer has nine top tricks: six hearts, two diamonds and one club. If East has the spade ace, everything will be smooth sailing, but is that likely? West made a two-level vulnerable overcall.Surely he has the spade ace.The next thought is to play three rounds of diamonds, hoping both that they break 3-3 and that West has to win the third round. That is a faint hope against defenders with any acumen.The only way to benefit from a 3-3 diamond break is not to lose a diamond trick. South achieved this by calmly playing low from the dummy at trick one.South won the second trick with dummy's club ace, discarding a low diamond from his hand. He then cashed two top trumps in hand. Declarer continued with the diamond ace, a diamond to the king and a diamond ruff. When they split 3-3, South played a heart to dummy's jack and discarded a spade loser on the 13th diamond.After congratulating South on his play, West commented, "Sorry, partner. title: Best way to honor legacy of Anne Frank is simple
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Best way to honor legacy of Anne Frank is simple

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 725
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent chain of events led me to think about another chain of events during World War II for a young girl who once aspired to be a famous writer.She ultimately achieved that goal, but not in a way that she had ever dreamed about or ever aspired to do.
Her name is Anne Frank.
Anne died at age 15 along with most of her family in a Nazi concentration camp.
Before she and her family were sent to the concentration camp, they spent two years hiding from the Nazis in a secret sealed apartment in Amsterdam. During that time, Anne kept a written diary now known as "The Diary of Anne Frank."
Her diary was published posthumously in 1947. Translated into almost 70 languages, it is one of the most widely read accounts of the Holocaust.
I had largely forgotten about Anne Frank and her diary until a series of unexpected events unfolded during a recent weekend.
On a Saturday afternoon, my wife and I drove to St. Michaels to enjoy a beautiful early spring day. It was a by all measures a perfect day.
The next morning was far from perfect.
It started when my wife launched a frantic search for her wallet. Like most wallets it contained her driver's license, credit cards and health insurance cards. It also included a substantial amount of cash for a Monday bank deposit to be used to pay for long-planned and much needed home improvement project.
After retracing all her Saturday steps, we concluded her wallet likely fell out of her back pocket while we were sitting on a park bench in St. Michaels.
I called the St. Michaels police to ask if anyone had turned in a lost wallet. The answer was no, not yet. The officer volunteered to go to the park and search for it. When he called back, he told us there was no trace of it. He also told us some who find lost wallets take the cash and throw the wallet into a trash can. He was kind enough to search the trash can in the park, but with no success.
Once we accepted that reality, I started to write a list of all the onerous tasks that follow the loss of a wallet.
Angry and frustrated, I said to my wife, "This is what the world has come to. No one cares anymore except about themselves. You lose a wallet, and no one turns it in. Worse yet, they probably took your cash and credit cards with no remorse telling themselves it was an unexpected stroke of 'good luck.'"
Minutes later, there was knock at our front door. A couple from Washington, D.C., whom we had never seen before told us they were also visiting St. Michaels on Saturday. They discovered her wallet. Using the address on my wife's driver's license they drove to our house on their return to Washington and delivered it.
They refused any reward other than accepting a heartfelt thank you.
As I reflected upon that unexpected random act of honesty and kindness my thoughts turned to Anne Frank and words she wrote in her diary.
With a wisdom and eloquence well beyond her years she penned, "It's difficult in times like these: ideals, dreams and cherished hopes rise within us, only to be crushed by grim reality. It's a wonder I haven't abandoned all my ideals, they seem so absurd and impractical. Yet I cling to them because I still believe, in spite of everything, that people are truly good at heart."
With all due respect to the memory of Anne, I cannot fully embrace her thinking that people are truly good at heart. Many are, but some are not and never will be. This was confirmed by her death, the deaths of most of her family (all but her father who saved her diary) and at least six million other innocent people who perished in concentration camps during the holocaust.
That said, our experience with a lost wallet was a reminder the best way to honor the legacy of Anne Frank is simple. Not always easy but a most meaningful way.
In difficult times like these when dreams and cherished hopes rise within us, only to be crushed by grim reality, we can and we should strive very day to be people who are "truly good at heart."
David Reel is a public relations and public affairs consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Bridge - The play allows you to save the day
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The play allows you to save the day

 January 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 7 | Section: News

 There are two types of holiday: Those in which you rest, lying on a sun-drenched beach getting a tan; and those in which you are up and about, visiting places and seeing things. You return home from the former bored but refreshed. From the latter, you are enlightened but exhausted. You feel as if you need a holiday to recover from your holiday.In bridge, there are declarers who play as if they have their heads buried in the sand, and those who are all eyes open and aware of the possibilities.
Their differing approaches are highlighted in today's deal.
North's raise to three notrump was correct, especially as East's opening bid had marked where the opposing cards lay.
The head-in-the-sand South won the first trick with the heart ace and immediately took the diamond finesse.
However, East won with the king and cleared the heart suit. Declarer, with only eight tricks (two spades, two hearts and four diamonds), had to attack clubs. But East won immediately with the ace and cashed three heart tricks to defeat the contract.
The eyes-open declarer, who realized that East rated to have the club ace and diamond king for his opening bid, saw the right line. He crossed to dummy's spade king at trick two. Then he led a low club toward his king. East had to duck his ace, else declarer would have nine tricks via two spades, two hearts, one diamond and four clubs. After winning with the club king, South took the diamond finesse, setting up nine tricks: two spades, two hearts, four diamonds and one club.

title: Time can be the great reaper
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Time can be the great reaper

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 18 | Section: News

 Words

 Although it feels as if summers run and winters crawl, time moves at a steady pace. However, maybe you agree with Eugene Ionesco: "We haven't the time to take our time."At the bridge table, though, we should take our time.When the dummy appears, all three active players should pause to plan the campaign.Sometimes we must judge the right time to win a particular trick.Today's deal was declared by Roger Trezel, a Frenchman who died in 1986. How did he time the play in five spades after West had led the diamond king? West's bidding isn't recommended. First, why preempt when you might be able to make three no-trump? A two-diamond overcall is normal. Second, having jumped to four diamonds, West shouldn't have bid five.If he was willing to go to five diamonds, he should have bid it on the first round.Despite West's sacrifice, Trezel wasn't willing to assume that East had the club ace. To try to establish the heart suit without risking East's gaining the lead, Trezel ducked the opening lead.When West continued with a diamond to dummy's ace, declarer discarded a low heart. South drew trumps, cashed the heart ace, played a heart to dummy's king and ruffed a heart. Back to dummy with a trump, Trezel discarded two club losers on dummy's heart winners.Nicely done.At another table, South won the first trick with dummy's diamond ace. However, after drawing trumps ending in the dummy, he called for the diamond two. When East failed to put in the 10, South discarded a low heart and recovered from his earlier error.

 EASTON - A Federalsburg man was sentenced Friday, Oct. 27, to eight years in prison for robbing the Bank of America in downtown Easton in April.Presiding Senior Judge C. Carey Deeley, Jr. sentenced Todd Holtzman, 57, to 15 years in prison and suspended all but eight years of active incarceration after he pleaded guilty to robbery.The case against Holtzman stemmed from his role in robbery reported shortly after 12:30 p.m. on Monday, April 17.Police said a man, later identified as Holtzman, entered the Bank of America from its rear entrance on Goldsborough Street and confronted a teller, demanding bills in certain denominations.The teller told police that the man put a black grocery bag under the sneeze guard at the counter and asked for money without dye packs or alarms, according to charging documents. The teller also told police that the man said he would not hurt her.After the teller gave the man the money, the man exited the bank from the same entrance on Goldsborough Street.The total amount stolen was $3,210, police said in charging documents.Holtzman will have to pay Bank of America the full stolen amount as restitution.Video surveillance reviewed later showed Holtzman discarding the hoodie and sunglasses in the area of 25 N. Harrison Street, police said.A K-9 team from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office tracked him to the area of the Walmart on Elliott Road near the bus stop, but did not find him.A Delmarva Community Transit bus driver told police they recalled picking up the man from Walmart about 45 minutes after the robbery and dropping him off in Cambridge 30 minutes later.In the same hearing in Talbot County Circuit Court, Holtzman also pleaded guilty to fourth-degree burglary in connection to an incident at Walgreens about a week before the bank robbery. He received a three-year sentence, all of which was suspended, according to court filings.Following his release from prison, Holtzman will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He is barred from entering the Bank of America and Walgreens.

title: Rankin and Davis: The Star Democrat's picks for Wards 2 and 4
author: Staff Writer
content:
Rankin and Davis: The Star Democrat's picks for Wards 2 and 4

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Star Democrat recommends votes for Robert Rankin in the Ward 2 Easton Town Council Election and for the Rev. Elmer Davis in Ward 4.ROBERT RANKIN
Robert Rankin is a newcomer to Easton politics, yet he displayed a firm grasp of the issues facing the town.
We liked his stands on issues, and most importantly, we liked that he admitted when he needed more information before voicing a conclusive opinion on issues we asked about.
Rankin's professionalism was evident. He called for a multi-faceted approach to increasing affordable housing in Easton, stressing the need to get more housing that is affordable for young families. His suggestions included working with developers to provide incentives, looking for more projects with townhomes and apartments, and redeveloping existing properties. It was a thoughtful answer.
Rankin also talked about his concerns on how new residential developments impact traffic, parking, schools and public safety. He wants an emphasis on a more strategic approach to approving future projects.
He wants to see more pedestrian-friendly and traffic calming features throughout the town. One suggestion included more crosswalks and sidewalks to better support pedestrian safety.
He was the only candidate to talk about increasing recreational opportunities on the east side of Route 50 where the majority of Ward 2 is located.
He suggested looking at retirement packages to assist in recruiting and retaining police officers in Easton.
One last note: Rankin has managed trade associations during his career. He knows what it is like to build consensus among many competing interests. Those will be valuable skills on the council.
THE REV. ELMER DAVIS
The Rev. Elmer Davis has long been a voice for people in the 4th Ward. He is also a voice of reason in the city during council meetings. Davis is not afraid to speak his mind, but his background as a preacher and pastor helps him look for common ground.
Davis noted his position on the Town Council dais. As the Ward 4 council member, he is the last one called to voice an opinion on discussion topics. This gives him a chance to hear all of the other council members. Often his message is one of finding consensus in disparate views.
"I aim to continue bridging the gap between the council and the people I represent, ensuring every voice is heard and valued," he said.
Davis was prophetic when he asked the question in our interview: "What do we want Easton to be?"
His multi-part answer is a walkable community with sufficient traffic infrastructure to keep the town moving. He suggested a bus service from hotels to downtown to get visitors to the shops that make Easton special. He was solution oriented.
Davis called for ensuring that first responders have the equipment and resources to respond to any incident.
He offered the best option we have heard for building affordable housing in the community — having the town purchase land and then partnering with organizations such as Habitat for Humanity to build the homes, involving the future homeowner in the process.
He said the town needs affordable housing "that people working at WaWa and McDonald's can afford."
He wants the council involved in approving housing projects in Easton. The Planning Commission, he said, should be making recommendations, not granting approvals.
One of his two opponents, Moonyene Jackson-Amis, would be our pick if Davis had not been doing such a fine job during his five years on the council. She is a former council member, an attorney and a community leader with multiple college degrees. She spoke passionately in our conversations about underrepresented communities in Easton. She continues to be a foundational rock in our town.
But Davis is our pick to continue his work on the council. He has done well these past five years, and he has become the face of Ward 4 with deep connections throughout the community.
Davis has experience, civility and strong ties to the community. He talks about his close-knit connection to his roots in the community shaping his values.
"I believe there is still much work to be done to enhance the quality of life for our residents," Davis said. We agree, and the reverend is the person to do that.

"The result was a quintessentially American sound."
"Seth Kibel is one of the Mid-Atlantic's premier woodwind specialists, working with klezmer, jazz, swing, and other bands. title: Why are decoys so expensive? Artists, collectors share the value of carvings, community
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Why are decoys so expensive? Artists, collectors share the value of carvings, community

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 653
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON – Decoys have long been used in hunting communities, but to the crowd at the Waterfowl Festival, the wood carvings serve more than just a utilitarian purpose.According to Cooper Rossner, a Talbot County decoy carver, the imitation birds and mammals can also be used as historic art pieces for nature lovers.
As a teenager in south New Jersey, Rossner was mesmerized by a carving demonstration in a natural sciences high school class. Rossner said right before his eyes, a carver turned a piece of wood into a Canada Goose.
This demonstration would be the first step into his lifelong passion for carving decoys. The carver at his school would soon become his mentor, and the following weekend he met an additional mentor during a Ducks Unlimited event.
"I was probably 15 years old, and here I am turning 30 in a week, and I'm still obsessed with it, still carving every chance I get," Rossner said. "... carving is my world, and is my mind, and is my heart and soul. It puts everything that I love together: working with my hands, artwork, the history of it, the wildlife, the hunting aspect — it wraps it all up."
The hours of labor and craft artists like Rossner put into the carvings mean sometimes decoys come with a hefty price tag.
Jon Deeter, co-owner of Guyette and Deeter, a decoy auction firm, said his firm surpassed $200 million in total sales during 2020. In his experience, decoys at his firm would minimally be sold at $300. The most his firm had sold a single decoy for was $480,000.
According to Deeter, pricing on decoys depends on a variety of factors. Vintage decoys made between 1850-1950 tend to be more valuable than contemporary decoys made after 1962. Additionally, the history and ownership of a decoy also impacts its value, similar to how provenance affects the value of fine art.
Rarity and originality also play a large role in the pricing of a decoy. The decoys made by renowned carvers like the Ward Brothers from Crisfield, Maryland can fetch prices in the six-figure range. Limited production, unique design or age can often command premium prices at auction, with the record being $1.144 million for a pair of decoys.
Deeter emphasized that decoy collecting is an expensive hobby, but many collectors are not purchasing the high budget decoys and are there for the simple pleasure and admiration of skilly crafted decoys and the history behind them.
Tyler Bryan, an Eastern Shore collector and hunter, said he has around 75 decoys and enjoys the story and history associated with the decoys he purchases.
Bryan said he came to collecting naturally, influenced by his upbringing on the Eastern Shore and his fascination with nature. But one of the main reasons he continues to collect is the close community of decoy collectors.
"The decoy collecting community is really a fantastic group of people," Bryan said. "It's tight-knit. Everyone knows each other. Most people know what everyone collects, and they're very helpful."
Bryan recommends decoy newcomers seek out a mentor because there are facets to collecting that will be much easier to someone if they have a trusted mentor to guide them along the way. According to Bryan, plenty of people within the decoy collecting community are happy to take on a mentee.
Rossner said decoy collecting often gets associated with much older people and can be seen as a "dying craft," but in his eyes, it deserves more recognition for the layers of complexity it holds and the community that has welcomed him.
Rossner said he encourages anyone interested to spend time with other carvers and collectors and learn more about the shared love this community has for decoys.
"There's lots of people still doing it, but not as many as there once were," Rossner said. "So you are living history when you're carving a decoy or you're doing an art form … you're doing something that's been handed down generation by generation."

title: 'We can turn lightbulbs on'
author: Staff Writer
content:
'We can turn lightbulbs on'

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thank you for Maggie Trovato's uplifting article, "We Can Turn Lightbulbs On." It offered a rare but welcome dose of hope.The piece spotlighted the work of three retired health care professionals — led by Dr. Judy Gieske — along with a team of volunteers launching Introduction to Careers in Healthcare (ITCH), a program designed to spark and sustain student interest in health care careers from middle through high school. It will serve Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
The timing couldn't be better. Construction has finally begun next to the Talbot Community Center on a long-promised, modern inpatient medical facility — expected to open in 2028. Yet even the most advanced hospital is useless without skilled, dedicated staff.
Our current Memorial Hospital depends heavily on traveling doctors and nurses. While competent and committed, they aren't rooted in our community. Many of us remember a time when our health care providers lived next door, when nurses were trained locally at the McQueen-Gibbs School, and when the hospital was the region's largest employer. The quality of care felt stronger because the staff had a personal stake in our well-being.
Memorial Hospital once helped drive local economic growth. Quality health care made Talbot County attractive to retirees, professionals, and families alike — people drawn to both the lifestyle and the peace of mind that came with reliable, community-centered care.
The ITCH program aims to reignite that connection by:
Introducing health care careers early.Supporting local students through their journey.Building a skilled, homegrown workforce.Reconnecting the hospital and the community.
These are long-term goals, but the potential return on investment is huge — economically and socially.
I urge my neighbors to support ITCH in any way they can. Whether through mentorship, donations or spreading the word, every effort matters. Let's bring the hospital back to the community — and the community back to the hospital.
Thanks to the Star-Democrat for shining a light on this promising initiative.
HUGH M. SMITH
Easton

Residents eager as St. Michaels considers dog park locations

 ST. MICHAELS — A dog park in St. Michaels has been in discussion for almost four years. Now, with a special meeting planned, the town and commissioners are turning their attention to finding a location where the dog park can properly serve the community.The commissioners want to take into account multiple factors when decided the location of the dog park, including cost of building and maintenance, liability concerns, who is allowed to use the park, and limiting the amount of people affected by the noise and traffic.
While a date is still being chosen for the special meeting, some dog owners in town said they were excited that the town is looking to get the ball rolling.
"It's exciting," said Jonathan Dietrich, St. Michaels resident and owner of two dogs, as he was walking his dogs through town. "It's exciting as long as the location is right and everybody approves of it. I know it's been a very long journey, and it's pretty complicated, but it would be great. It would be great if we could get one but we'll see what happens."
When dog park discussion started in St. Michaels four years ago, a group of lawyers in St. Michaels came together and created a group called "The Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park."
Member Devon Hewitt spoke at the August town meeting about donors for the dog park and potential locations.
According to Hewitt the group of lawyers did research and came up with multiple locations, but the conversations fell through. After the new commissioners were elected, conversations began again.
While determining the master plan for San Domingo Creek Park construction at the August Town Council meeting, discussion arose about a dog park being included in the master plan. The town commissioners decided not to include a dog park in the plan.
One of the reasons brought forward at the meeting was that if dog park plans were added to the master plan, the grant received from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources could be pulled back.
While the location for the potential dog park is unclear, St. Michaels residents say they are ready to see movement.
When Stacy Sass, a resident of St. Michaels, was asked how soon she would hope to see a dog park in St. Michaels for her dog Ginger to play in, she said, "tomorrow."

title: Bridge - How would you handle the trumps?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - How would you handle the trumps?

 August 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A8 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here is the second deal from a session partnering my wife last month at a Bridge Base Online casual table. It featured a textbook example for maintaining trump control.How should South play in four hearts after West leads the club king?Yes, I was the only North to rebid two hearts rather than one spade. However, I still like my call despite the poor trumps. It backfires when partner is 4-4 or 4-5 in the majors and not strong enough to bid again.Otherwise, she will rebid two spades, and I will raise. I win when she has five hearts and a weak hand. This way, we find our eight-card fit.Also, if she were to rebid two clubs over one spade, I would have to pass. Two hearts would promise some 16 high-card points. Note also that my wife's jump to four hearts promised at least five trumps. With only four, she would have rebid three notrump or fudged somehow!Finally, yes, she might have rebid three diamonds or four clubs (a splinter bid). I would have signed off with such useless trumps.The danger to four hearts is a bad trump break, which is almost a certainty at BBO!The correct technique is to win the first trick and to duck a round of trumps. You ruff West's club continuation and now cash the heart ace to see the expected 4-1 division. However, you play on diamonds to set up your side suit and cruise home, losing only three trump tricks.Starting with the heart ace and another heart is fatal here. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Chris Moore has many titles to his name: Harvard University Graduate, director, producer of "American Pie" and "Good Will Hunting," and one of his favorites: Talbot County native.Moore, after making his name in Hollywood, is coming back to the Eastern Shore to hear from the locals who helped him fall in love with film.
At the Oxford Community Center Thursday, Nov. 21, he will seek to engage in valuable dialogue with residents to better understand what movie lovers from across the country are wanting to see from the film industry.
"I could have been originally from somewhere else where, honestly, I wouldn't care what they had to say, but the thing about Talbot County, and what I love about coming back to it… is that it's a real slice of America," Moore said.
Moore said he grew up going to the Avalon and loving the world that TV and movies took him to.
After studying American history at Harvard, where he met and worked with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, he left for California, where he worked in the mailroom at an agency and later got promoted to literary agent before selling several scripts, including "The Stoned Age," "PCU," "Airheads" and "My Girl."
He later went on to produce 1999 film classic "American Pie," a breakout hit that launched Moore's career as a Hollywood producer.
But for Moore, a lot has changed since the 1990s, including the way that people watch films. Subscription-based streaming services have changed audiences' consumption of content by "over producing" content and making it difficult to gauge what people actually want to see, he said.
Moore said he wants to take a step back and go back to his roots to better understand how to give audiences quality content. And for him there's no better sounding board than the people of the Eastern Shore.
For Moore, the event on Thursday will be interactive, funny and most importantly informative of what he believes best represents American culture and audiences.
"I don't want people to think this is like going to a college lecture," Moore said. "We're going to have some fun and talk about movies and talk about entertainment, talk about fun stuff and in a way that people laugh and can engage and it can be a lively night."

title: Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 39th Festival of Trees will take place in Easton on Nov. 29 through Dec. 3. Events include the Festival of Trees, which is held in the Tidewater Inn, as well as Carols by Candlelight, Santa's Workshop, Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk and a jewelry raffle.Every year, there is a theme for the festival, which is put on by the Friends of Talbot Hospice. This year's theme is "Holiday Traditions." The trees will be decorated based on that theme, festival chairman Karla Wieland-Cherry said.
"It takes a year to plan. It's a lot of work," Wieland-Cherry said. "It's all volunteer work, all volunteers. And this is our 39th year. The big thing is the trees, so we have the trees sponsored by various businesses, organizations and individuals. And they can either choose to decorate the tree, or we also have a list of volunteers who will come in and decorate the tree."
The festival raises funds for Talbot Hospice. Wieland-Cherry emphasized the work of volunteers in raising hospice funds, as well as the family aspect of the weekend-long event.
"My children are involved, my son comes and volunteers, my daughter used to sing, my husband, he's the music chairman," Wieland-Cherry said.
" ... It's just a wonderful way to kick off the holiday season," she continued. "I have such a blessed team of volunteers that work so hard to make this such a success."
On Friday night, the Preview Gala will kick off the festivities. From 6 to 8 p.m., guests will have the first opportunity to view 100 exquisitely trimmed trees of varying sizes. Tickets to the gala are available in advance for $125 per person or $200 per couple.
While the larger trees are sponsored in advance, gala guests get the first opportunity to purchase the smaller trees, from 12 inches to three feet and in varying price ranges.
The Gold Ballroom at the Tidewater Inn opens to the public Saturday morning and remains open through Tuesday. As always, local performers will be cycling throughout the event to provide music and singing.
Also Saturday morning, participants will hit the pavement at 9 a.m. for the Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk. There will be on-site registration starting at 8 a.m. at Idlewild Park in Easton and advance sign-ups will be available online.
Later in the day, Santa's Workshop opens. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on both Saturday and Sunday in the Tidewater Inn's Ballroom Garden, children will rotate through stations after being greeted by Santa and posing for photographs.
Children can write letters to Santa, participate at craft stations, play games and enjoy a selfie station with props for photo opportunities. Santa's Workshop is no additional charge to those that pay for admission to the Festival of Trees.
Returning for the fifth year, Carols by Candlelight is an event free for all families. On Saturday from 5 to 7 p.m. Families can sing along with choral groups, bell ringers and musicians while enjoying hot cocoa and holiday treats.
Santa will be located on the grounds of The Bullitt House at the corner of Washington Street and Dover Street in downtown Easton. Other visitors include The Grinch, Elsa and Buddy the Elf.
This year, the Festival of Trees introduces a Fine Jewelry Raffle, courtesy of Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry of Easton. A pair of satin ball earrings and a diamond bezel necklace will be offered in the raffle to benefit Talbot Hospice. One raffle ticket costs $25 and is available online at and at Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry on 27 South Harrison St. The raffle will be drawn at 5:30 p.m. on Dec. 3 at the conclusion of Festival of Trees.
New this year is the debut of one-of-a-kind, keepsake luminaries in honor of a loved one. Designed and created by Pat and Eric Harvey, a limited number of the metal luminaries will be sold online, then displayed in the Gold Ballroom. At the conclusion of the Festival of Trees, the luminaries will be available for pickup in time to enjoy for the holiday season.
As Christmas is a season for remembering, friends and family remember their loved ones in a very special way by purchasing a poinsettia. The name of someone dear is placed on a Memory Scroll next to a stunning 12-foot poinsettia "tree" in the Tidewater Inn's Gold Ballroom.
Friends of Hospice was formed in 1984 and began hosting the Festival of Trees in 1986 to raise money for the Talbot Hospice Foundation. To date, close to $4 million has been raised by the Festival of Trees to assist with Talbot Hospice's operating budget.
As a celebration of life for those who have received Hospice care during the past year, the continued success of Festival of Trees is made possible by the generous financial contributions from local individuals and various businesses. To get involved in any capacity, or to inquire about a sponsorship, contact Festival of Trees Co-Chairmen Karla Wieland-Cherry at dkcherry4@aol.com or 410-310-8421 and Denise Haddaway at 443-995-4431 or denise.haddaway@gmail.com.
To learn more about Talbot Hospice, visit talbothospice.org. Festival information can be found at festival-of-trees.org/.

title: King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy
author: JESSICA A. JOHNSON
content:
King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JESSICA A. JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 673
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I happened to catch the recent "CBS Mornings" news interview of Yolanda Renee King, the only grandchild of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Coretta Scott King. While promoting her new children's book honoring her grandparents titled "We Dream a World," Yolanda gave a profound answer when asked what she would say to them if they were alive today. "I think I would first start off with an apology," she said, which was surprising to CBS host Nate Burleson, who immediately asked the young activist what she meant by her response. Yolanda continued, "An apology to where we are right now, as a nation and really as a world."Yolanda is only 15 years old, and it is evident that she has a deep understanding of what her grandparents fought for as leaders of the civil rights movement. In August of last year, during the 60th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, Yolanda boldly declared that her generation would "be defined by action, not apathy."
As Yolanda is growing up before our eyes, she has the youthful exuberance of her grandfather's resolve and displays the dignified grace of her grandmother. Yolanda saying she would apologize to her grandparents for our nation not yet reaching the potential they believed in should make us thoughtfully reflect on how Dr. King also warned about becoming apathetic.
Apathy is a brutal paralyzer of life. It can cause us to be ensnared in a dangerous mode of stagnation emotionally, spiritually, and sometimes physically. Apathy also triggers entitled disinterest in our society. In 2021, Tom Nichols, an instructor at Harvard Extension School and the U.S. Naval War College, asserted in an interview with The Harvard Gazette that "narcissism and nihilism" are the primary threats to our country's democracy and societal relationships. Elaborating on the latter, Nichols said that many people ask why our society is "so mean and heartless and awful," but many of them do not contribute anything to make their communities better, or they will vote against policies that affect their well-being due to "narcissistic beefs."
"We have become surly villagers," Nichols maintained, "me, my family, my little plot of land, and everybody else can go to hell." This type of sullen attitude is what Yolanda is urging our country to overcome as she is an emerging voice on critical issues such as gun violence and homelessness.
As Yolanda continues to attentively study the Godly principles that enabled her grandfather to be that drum major for justice who changed the course of our nation, I am reminded of two of his sermons where he encouraged his followers to live with purpose and passion and to shower others with Christian love.
The first sermon is titled "But If Not," a 1967 message that King delivered at Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church. King expresses that the "ultimate test" of our faith is when we get to a "but if not" moment in life, a moment where we have to travel along an arduous journey with no other option but to lean on God's promises.
This passage stands out to avoid being gripped by apathy during a spiritual test: "... somewhere along the way [in life] you should discover something that's so dear, so precious to you, that is so eternally worthful, that you will never give it up." The second sermon is "Levels of Love," an Ebenezer address King gave in 1962. He implored the congregation to "rise to agape, to Christian love" because "[t]he greatness of it is that you love every man, not for your sake but for his sake. And you love every man because God loves him."
It is remarkable that Yolanda exemplifies the love and compassion her grandparents demonstrated as she diligently works to uplift others. She is blazing her own path, and it is truly inspiring to watch it unfold. She probably has not had a "but if not" moment yet in her young life thus far, but I have no doubt she is developing the character and strength to face the challenges she knows are coming.

title: Academy Art Museum gets new director
author: Tom McCall
content:
Academy Art Museum gets new director

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Arts 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Charlotte Potter Kasic, the new director of the Academy Art Museum, has a lot of ideas. But her first weeks, she said, will be dedicated to completing a listening tour.Her latest post was the Barry Art Museum in Norfolk, Virginia, where she was executive director. Now she has a new challenge with helming the Academy.
"Every time I see a challenge, I lean in," Kasic said.
She was not entirely unfamiliar with the Academy Art Museum before applying for the job.
"When Eric Neil left the Academy in 2012 or 2013, he became the director of the Chrysler Museum of Art, and I was the director of the Chrysler Museum Glass Studio, which was like an annex," Kasic said.
She's been impressed with the museum's existing work and potential.
"When you break it down, there are classes. There are programs and exhibitions. There is collections. There is fundraising. There are galas. It is wild how much happens here with so little. I think this place is doing a great job of hitting a lot of audiences," she said.
Kasic is excited to work with the staff to continue these efforts.
Kasic has past in glass blowing, in which she said she learned about collaboration and teamwork. She created Cirque de Verre (circus of glass), which traveled around the United States to museums and art spaces that had glass blowing furnaces.
"Glass I love because you work in teams. It is hot. It is visceral. There is a lot of strong communication skills," Kasic said. "I like things to be immersive, multisensory and interdisciplinary. When you think of olfactory, that is how you access your deepest memories. Music can change your mood in a minute. Art can do that as well."
Kasic has a masters degree from Rhode Island School of Design and has done residencies at Penland, Oxbow, Pilchuck and in Australia.
After the Chrysler she moved to Vermont to start a family. She ended up being the director at the Yestermorrow Design Build School, which celebrates sustainable design and craft.
The siren song of Norfolk brought her and her family back to the Chesapeake, where she joined the team at the Barry Museum. She says it has become the glass art capital of the East Coast. There, Kasic helmed a 25,000 square foot expansion and closed out a $23 million campaign.
Now at the Academy Art Museum, she sees a collaborative community that brings Plein Air, The Craft Show and the Waterfowl Festival into the institution. She also has a clear-eyed approach to what the Academy can offer the community.
"I would like to see more of our permanent collection on view. We have so much that exists but people don't get to see," she said.
Even with these plans, she realizes that there is a lot of collaborating to be done.
"It is important to say how invested the board is in this place. I have seen more board involvement and more community investment than any other organization I have been in. People are so dedicated. It is really remarkable and it speaks to the strength of this place," she said.

author: Maggie Trovato

 EASTON — Quacks, squeals and honks reverberated through Easton High School's auditorium Saturday night.The World Waterfowl Calling Championships, the final event of the Waterfowl Festival's Saturday schedule, brought waves of camo to the school for the event's seven competitions: the Jr. World Live Duck Calling Championship, the Jr. World Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Goose Calling Championship and the World Goose Calling Championship.
Winners of the different competitions took home a variety of prizes including plaques, money and — of course — decoys.
Contestant John Walls took home the big title of the night, World Goose Calling champion, which came with a $5,000 check. This is Walls' third World Goose Calling Championship win.
After yelling for joy with his fists in the air, Walls told emcee Dave Bloodsworth, "It's the Super Bowl, man." He thanked his friends and family before talking about celebration plans.
"I'm going to have a lot of fun tonight," he said. "It's a bad night to be a Busch Light."
Other champions of the night include Logan Heibner, 16, named Jr. World Live Duck Calling champion; JT Johnson, 15, named Jr. World Goose Calling champion; Chandler Martin and Slayton Gearin, named World Team Live Duck Calling champions; brothers Bryan and Bobby Heim, named World Team Live Goose Calling champions; Seth Fields, named World Live Duck Calling champion and Chance Wadsworth, named World Live Goose Calling champion.
After his win, Fields thanked his wife.
"For listening to all my routines in the kitchen," he said.
Bloodsworth said five judges in the back of the auditorium graded contestants on their routine, flow and sound throughout the night.
Before the competition began, junior callers Carter Whaley, 14, and Peter Aul, 16, sat on the stage, feeling both nervous and excited for the final competitions of the night to begin.
For Aul, who traveled from Pennsylvania for the championships, it was his first time at the Waterfowl Festival. He said he found out about the festival through buddies.
As for how he got into calling: "I just got a call and started running it better than everybody in my area and decided, you know what? I'm going to throw my name in."

title: St. Michaels announces gingerbread contest, ornament
author: Staff Writer
content:
St. Michaels announces gingerbread contest, ornament

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Bakers and pastry chefs of all ages and talent levels are encouraged to get their gingerbread house games on with the return of the Christmas in St. Michaels Gingerbread House competition this December and a purse totaling $2,000 in prizes up for grabs.The competition is an important component of the fundraising the all-volunteer organization achieves with the annual event, with the creations highlighted and on display at the Gingerbread "House" Preview Cocktail Party at the Woman's Club of St. Michaels on Thursday, Dec. 12, beginning at 5 p.m.
"We are encouraging participants to donate their creations for our silent auction, to be held the evening of the cocktail party," says this year's Gingerbread House Competition Co-Chair Michele Lowe. "All auction proceeds support the beneficiaries of Christmas in St. Michaels."
Entrants can pick their category for participation, which includes master chefs and caterers, adults, young adults, children, children with adults, kit-made houses, and non-profit organizations. Participation is free, with pre-registration needed at christmasinstmichaels.org/events.
The 2024 Christmas in St. Michaels Collectors Ornament has also been announced and is the 21st in the series. This year's ornament depicts the Chesapeake deadrise workboat with its crew and a friendly canine companion. The image was provided by St. Michaels artist Sherry Smith.
The boxed ornament is available for purchase at select local retail shops and the weekend-long Christmas in St. Michaels Marketplace and Sweet Shoppe. Online purchases can be made at www.christmasinstmichaels.org/ornament.
The deadrise workboat has been a staple among Chesapeake watermen for decades. "Deadrise" refers to the almost flat, V-shaped hull that provides a shallow draft to accommodate the waters in creeks and rivers of the Eastern Shore. Boats range from 25-45 feet in length and are powered by large, inboard four- or six-cylinder engines, usually diesel-fueled.
Workboats typically sport women's names on the transom or bow, paying tribute to wives and daughters. Others, such as the one in this ornament, refer to the town, river or creek the boat calls home port.
"It is typical to see dozens of these deadrise workboats plying the waters of the Eastern Shore in the wee hours of the morning as they seek the day's catch, returning to the pier in the early afternoon to get their catch to market," says Christmas in St. Michaels Chair Pat Martin. "We're honored to add this limited-edition ornament to our collection to pay tribute to watermen and their boats in the St. Michaels area and the Chesapeake Bay region at large."
Event details, online ticket and ornament purchases, and more about Christmas in St. Michaels are at christmasinstmichaels.org.
