title: Chesapeake Multicultural after-school program lets students learn through taste
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake Multicultural after-school program lets students learn through taste

 April 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday evening, over a dozen fourth and fifth graders walked through Bonheur Ice Cream and Pie in downtown Easton and learned from local chefs of the profession of devoting themselves to sweets.These students are part of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center After-school Program, a program designed to enrich Hispanic elementary school students of Talbot County.
During the program, students focus on science, technology, engineering and mathematics; reading skills; and food supplement nutrition education to ensure they are educated and well prepared for lessons inside and outside of the classroom.
Estela-Vianney Ramirez, assistant director of the after-school program, said she has been working with the program for over a decade, and it is a beautiful experience to help expand the world for these students.
"It's very rewarding to teach the class," Ramirez said. "Those memories really stick in their, the students', minds and enable them to actually give out to the community, too, because some of our volunteers in our after-school program were our students who went through the program 10 years ago."
Ramirez notes that she sees her former students working in offices and throughout the Eastern Shore, and she is happy to be a part of their development.
During the tour of Bonheur, Chef Tyler Heim brought the students to the kitchen and explained the process of making ice cream and the work that goes into every pint. One by one, students were moved throughout the kitchen and shown the behind-the-scenes of sweet treats and rich desserts.
Julia Foxwell, director of community engagement for Bluepoint Hospitality, said it was a delight for the chefs to share their passion for sweets with the students.
"We have been working with the Chesapeake Multicultural Center for some time on how best to support their initiatives while also providing enriching experiences to their students," Foxwell said. "Bringing the girls and boys in to learn kitchen basics — from prep to final product — exposes them to new concepts, flavors and perhaps a future passion of their own. Chefs (Harley) Peet and Heim loved hosting the kids in the kitchen and even got a few ideas for new flavors."
Victoria Gomez Lozano, Hispanic outreach coordinator for Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said this program is important in reaching out to community members who may not know about the center's services.
"We started this program to give the underserved children of this community the opportunity to have extracurricular activities and to be exposed to a lot of things that they may not have the opportunity to," Gomez Lozano said. "It's also a good way to contact their parents and the families in the community as well so they can open up to us and so we can give them our services."
At the end of the tour, every student was given a scoop of ice cream and a choice of toppings to create their own flavor.
Each student enjoyed the ice cream while laughing with friends.
Student Yerelin Fuentes said she has been in the after-school program for a few years now and loves the chance to learn new things and spend time with her friends outside of class. But what she loves most, she said, is the ability to learn to be a good person.
"They show us how to be a hero," Fuentes said.

title: Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Life 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons, was honored with Rotary's highest award, the J. Howard Anthony Community Service Award.For All Seasons is a behavioral health and rape crisis center. They are also the only agency in Talbot County doing this work in Spanish and English.
They bring in 20 to 25 new people a week for their new no wait five-days-a-week services. Because of COVID-19 they got skillful at telehealth and now offer services in all 24 jurisdictions in Maryland.
According to Beth Spurry, the president and owner of Wye Finanicial Trust and a mentor of Dorman's, in the past decade, Dorman has taken the organization from just 24 employees to over 100, most of whom are women.
"Because those nearly 100 employees that are meeting the mental health, the rape crisis needs of our community are the employees that are handling the toughest of the tough and doing it with a smile on their face. I have a smile on my face because of them. So thank you for this award," Dorman said.
A few days after the award was announced, she reflected.
"It is their largest award. I was first a part of Rotary when I first got out of college. It was called a group study exchange," Dorman said. "The group study is a professional exchange. I was given the opportunity to apply to be a part of a group that traveled to Japan. I was there for six weeks. I visited higher ed places in the Ibaraki Prefecture."
It is a specialized award. You cannot have been in Rotary for 10 years. You have to have lived and worked in the community in which you were serving for 10 years.
"It is a big deal for them. They have an opportunity to pick one person from the community. So I was blown away when he (Tom Hill) called me and told me that it was going to be me," Dorman said.
"I think it brings to light the importance of living through service in your community. That is the core of who I am, as far as servant leadership. I am as good as the team I have put together. We continue to serve in the community. It spurs a conversation about the importance of service no matter how big or small," Dorman said.
For All Seasons hosts many events throughout the year, like the backpack giveaway and Frosty's Holiday Village, that reach thousands of people.
"In all of that, the biggest piece for me is providing an example for my children, for women, for girls, for young people. My kids know I am busy and on my phone all the time, but they always know I am doing really important work. And that plants in them that they can be someone in the community," Dorman said.
She said she has a supportive team that helps her. Starting with her husband and her kids, Dave and Melinda Finley at Anchor Church on Goldsboro, Alice Ryan of the Women and Girls Fund, and Spurry.
"I was given a huge gift at the awards ceremony in having her (Spurry) be the person to present me the award. Beth has not only been a guiding light, but a pretty strong mentor. She will say, 'I think you can do better and here is why.' She has been an incredibly encouraging mentor," Dorman said.
She said this was a really important moment in her career.
"If all fell away tomorrow, this is the community that has supported me as I am supporting them. I will have a part of the Anthony family legacy forever and be able to say here is the impact I had in the community, which I call home," she said.

 Eric Hoffer, who thought his best book was "The Ordeal of Change," wrote, "The hardest arithmetic to master is that which enables us to count our blessings." At the bridge table, if you are playing for money and master the counting of suit lengths and high-card points, at the end of the session, you will be counting your winnings.In today's deal from a match pointed duplicate, how should South plan the play in five spades after the defenders begin with two rounds of hearts?North's negative double showed four spades. Playing for money, North would have doubled five hearts and collected 300 points.However, worried that most pairs would buy it in four spades, North pushed on to five spades.Clearly, South had to avoid a club loser, and he knew to leave the key suit as late as possible. He ruffed the second heart, drew one round of trumps and played a diamond to the king. East took that trick and played another trump. Declarer won on the board, cashed the diamond jack, crossed to the spade queen and played off the diamond queen and 10, pitching clubs from the dummy.It was time to work out the club position. What had South learned?East was known to have started with three spades and five diamonds. The bidding also strongly suggested that East had four hearts. If so, his hand distribution was 3=4=5=1.Singularity rules. Declarer cashed his club king and ran the club jack, chosen to encourage an unwise cover.Well counted.

title: Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On May 11, a river of blue-shirted cyclists flowed down Market Street.All of these police officers on bicycles stopped at the Chesapeake Culinary Center for lunch on their Police Unity Tour, which starts in Portsmouth, Virginia, and ends in Washington, D.C.
The Police Unity Tour is a bicycle ride that raises awareness about officers who have died in the line of duty. The event raises money for the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial. Their motto is "We ride for those who died."
Anyone on any level of law enforcement can make the ride. Although Denton is a nice spot in the middle of their ride, there were no law enforcement officers from Caroline County in the ride.
"The Denton Fire Chief and Town Manager have all been great to us, opening doors. The vo-tech kids cooked lunch for us. The Culinary Center fed us," said Marlboro, New Jersey, Police Department Lt. Nicholas Szymanski.
"In 16 years, we have ridden through Denton every year. We had 650 on bicycles and another 150 or so on support. We started in Lewes, Delaware, and stopped just short of the bridge in Kent Island," Szymanski said.
These men and women have lots of visible support, not just from massive American flags hoisted between two fire truck ladders, but mini flag waving children who offer high fives along the way.
"We have chapter trucks and trailers that bring Gatorade, waters, snacks. We have a full mechanic's truck, ambulances and motor units. Believe it or not, we had the commissioner of Highway Patrol in California ride with us this year. We had about 50 motorcycles in our group alone. They will stop intersections for us. Once we start pedaling we don't stop," Szymanski said.
Their efforts have raised a lot of money over the years.
"Our chapter had 440 riders, and we raised over $400,000. We raised over $2 million overall. It is for fallen police officers. Our responsibility it to make sure that the names of the former police officers aren't forgotten," Szymanski said.
All the money goes to the National Law Enforcement Museum and the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial.
"All the names of the fallen officers are enshrined on (the memorial). There are 25,000 names on there at least. We did an expansion last year for more stones to have room for more names. We add five or 10 names to that wall every year," Szymanski said.
The names are important. But supporting the families who have lost loved ones is essential, he said.
"The most important of it — the reason we do this is we bring survivors along with us. That is somebody's family member that was killed in the line of duty. We have their wives, their kids, their family members, fathers, mothers ride with us. We had 50 survivors ride with us this year," he said.
What started with 18 riders in 1997 has grown exponentially. Since then, the Unity Tour has raised $35 million.
To learn more, go to policeunitytourchapterten.com

title: Ward 4 candidates talk property taxes, housing
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ward 4 candidates talk property taxes, housing

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 734
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for the Ward 4 seat on the Easton Town Council have offered varying opinions on the town's property tax rate.Incumbent the Rev. Elmer Davis, Moonyene Jackson-Amis and Cameron Keefe are squaring off in the town's election May 6. Each discussed their views on property taxes, housing and more in interviews with The Star Democrat's editorial board last week.
Currently, the town levies a tax on real property at 52 cents per $100 of assessed value. That mark hasn't changed since 2008. It's higher than Talbot County's other towns, but relatively low compared to Eastern Shore towns such as Cambridge, Denton and Salisbury.
Property values, though, have increased significantly in recent years. The state's 2025 reassessments showed the value of Group 1 residential and commercial properties in Talbot County increased by 22.1% from 2022. The town's proposed fiscal year 2026 budget projects $13.6 million in real property tax revenue, slightly up from last year. It was a tight and "lean" budget, Mayor Megan Cook has said.
Davis, who's been on the council since 2020, said the property tax rate should be increased.
"I think the mayor's playing around a little bit. … They're not fiscally responsible," Davis said. "We have not raised taxes, and here's the problem. We got that COVID money. We've been living high on the hog, and now we have to pay the piper."
Jackson-Amis, Ward 4's representative from 2001 to 2008, says the Town Council should have conversations with professionals about potential tax breaks.
"I think the property tax is a little steep," Jackson-Amis said. "It seems like the idea is to get, to have a money funnel. A funnel as opposed to exacting what's necessary to support the budget."
Keefe in his interview emphasized fiscal responsibility, while adding he understands new initiatives cost money.
"They make a lot of decisions that don't affect their wealth, but it affects everybody else's wealth," Keefe said of the council. " ... We need to dismantle this ivory tower thing."
HOUSING
The Ward 4 hopefuls each touched on plans to improve Easton's affordable housing stock. Keefe said "we need to make Easton not just survivable, but livable."
"We can say all the buzz words we want, but I would love to see specifically starter homes in Easton, things that draw young families here," Keefe said.
He said he hopes to sit down with town planners to discuss their proposed inclusionary zoning ordinance that would require residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable.
Jackson-Amis says she's "all for inclusionary zoning." She hopes to revisit the requirement that developers include 25% low or middle-income units in projects, an effort she supported in her prior stint on the council.
"If you're getting a benefit from the town, we need to be able to exact a benefit from you," Jackson-Amis said. "If you're creating housing, we ought to know what our housing needs are, and that it shouldn't just be for the financial gain of wealthy people."
Davis said he's "not 100% sure" current housing legislation in the works will answer all of Easton's housing needs. He advocated for the town to buy a piece of land and work with nonprofits.
"The town should buy a piece of land," Davis said. "And the town should partner with Habitat (for Humanity) or some other organization to … ensure that we deal holistically with the person and the property."
EXPERIENCE
The Ward 4 candidates bring different experience levels to the table.
Davis, 58, said he focused on constituent representation during his time on the council, such as when he supported a seafood odor ordinance last year.
"I'm in the position as the council member because of the people," he said. "I represent those individuals in my ward. I'm not the end-all, be-all. So if my constituents say that this is what they want, then I represent them well."
Jackson-Amis, 77, said "we should look toward wisdom."
"Right now you need people with some seasoned ability to ferret out issues and help bring solutions to problems," she said. "So I don't think age really should be that important, but I think the experience is what should matter."
Keefe, 25, said he wants more youth involvement in the town.
"I know I'm young. That is by no means any reason to take this lightly," Keefe said. "I think this is important. I think there's a lot of potential for good that can happen from this. And above all of those things, I want to be a representative who listens."

 Last evening I attended the candidates' forum at the Avalon, moderated by Craig Fuller and sponsored by the Talbot Spy.It was well attended, and I'm glad that it will be available for viewing by those who missed the live event, because the upcoming May 6 election should be — and is — important to every single resident of Easton. It will impact town spending, how development takes place and whether we can work together to plan and achieve shared goals.
While I don't doubt all the candidates are devoted to their families, kind to their neighbors, happy to live in Easton, and aware of the issues, we should all expect a great deal more from public servants.
Only one candidate, Moonyene Jackson-Amis — running to represent Ward 4 on the council — was truly impressive to me. This highly educated woman — a practicing attorney, compassionate activist and experienced local public servant — spoke in specifics, rather than generalities. It was clear that she understands the needs of the residents of Ward 4 and the town at large.
She talked about practical ways to help wage-earners qualify for licensing in their various trades by incentivizing contractors to take advantage of their skills, thereby facilitating their advancement. She called for a study on repurposing the current hospital as a regional medical center for military veterans. She advocated for updates to a program she initiated during her prior term on the council so that residents can afford to stay in their homes. She suggested a new tourist attraction that would make use of an unused existing building. And she had other practical ideas as well. It's clear she has a well-thought-out action plan ready to go if she's elected.
What's more, Moonyene obviously knows how to leverage all the elements needed to bring plans to fruition. That is the essential asset drawn from her knowledge of the law and wealth of experience, an asset that others appear to lack. She wants to serve constituents, not herself.

MACo and Talbot County Council discuss fiscal pressures facing state

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 490
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When entering last year's General Assembly, the fiscal situation Maryland faced needed serious attention. In some ways, that fiscal pressure has increased since.Michael Sanderson, the executive director of the Maryland Association of Counties, briefed the Talbot County Council on those financial troubles and more during a special meeting Tuesday.
He told council members a budget shortfall of potentially $600 to $800 million could be facing lawmakers in Annapolis. Fixing that is "not easy, but not impossible," he said.
"There are a couple of years of that in our forecast, and then it gets really serious," Sanderson said.
When fiscal year 2028 arrives, Sanderson warned that the state will run out of money in its trust fund that's been used for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive and optimistic education initiative.
Many counties have been under significant financial pressure due to state requirements stemming from Blueprint. Sanderson says the state will be feeling that level of pressure soon.
"The counties are feeling it now," he said. "The state doesn't really feel it for a couple years down the road, and that has been a meaningful disconnect."
Without significant timeline adjustments for Blueprint from the state, MACo feels there will continue to be that disconnect between the fiscal situation of the state versus the situation counties are facing. State funding for transportation, though, is already causing serious impacts, Sanderson said.
"The canary in the coal mine that's already chirping is in transportation," he told the council members. " … The conversation in the summer time is sometimes ambiguous and hazy and that sort of thing. But this year, not so much. They were just saying, 'If there aren't already shovels in the ground, we can't afford the next thing.'"
The Maryland Department of Transportation has been forced to delay many statewide projects amid a significant budget deficit. Earlier this month, the department released a draft plan that showed $1.3 billion in cuts from the state's six-year transportation plan.
Sanderson noted the "state's transportation challenge is not a function of the Key Bridge" rebuild, which is set to begin next year.
At the county level, council Vice President Pete Lesher said Talbot County is "finding itself in a slightly different place" than others.
"We are going through a number of capital construction projects, our health department, our sheriff's office, our 911 center," Lesher said, emphasizing some of those projects are receiving "pandemic-era related funds" from the federal government.
"The pinch that a lot of counties are feeling right now, the income tax, is not yet being felt in Talbot County," Lesher said. "We can look around at our neighbors and see what is coming, even though we are not yet in that position now."
Lesher thanked Sanderson and MACo President Johnny Olszewski Jr. for their work to represent the counties at the state level year-round.
"We know that we are stronger together in Annapolis," Lesher said. "And we see every year what a powerful voice MACo is for all of us jointly."

title: Family holding out hope for turf field project at Easton High
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Family holding out hope for turf field project at Easton High

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The prospects of an artificial turf field at Easton High School are uncertain as the school year approaches.Jen Hawley's 18-year-old daughter, Elgin, has been a champion of the turf field. Elgin asked for it to be added to the school district's budget request last year as part of her wish with the Make-A-Wish Foundation.
Jen Hawley hoped to see the project take shape before Elgin left for college this summer. She asked Make-A-Wish to maintain its commitment to the project until July 31 before the nonprofit needed to begin working on a new wish for Elgin.
Talbot County Public Schools received $1.5 million from the county meant to allocate towards outstanding capital projects this fiscal year, such as the turf field, which has an estimated price of $1.8 million.
At the end of July, Hawley said she was told the Board of Education is passing on partnering with Make-A-Wish for the turf field project.
"We're right back to where we started," Hawley said.
In mid-August of 2021, on the third day of field hockey tryouts, Elgin had an aneurysm on the field. It took almost two weeks after she collapsed before she began talking again, and it wasn't until February 2022 that she returned to school.
Elgin, who graduated this spring, hasn't been able to play field hockey since the aneurysm. When Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic granted her one wish, she asked for a turf field to be put in at Easton High.
With support from Make-A-Wish and a group of supporters known as "Elgin's Army," the turf field was requested at a board meeting in July 2023 and later added to the budget by the board in December 2023.
At a Board of Education work session in June, President Emily Jackson said while she's a "vocal proponent" of the turf field project, she wasn't committed to allocating funds towards it this fiscal cycle.
"I am not necessarily saying, no, never let's not do it," Jackson said. "But I'm saying that I think there are a lot of questions to be asked. Is turf the best option? Should we be going with really high-quality grass instead? What is going to cause the least number of injuries?"
The board has not made an official decision allocating the $1.5 million. Capital projects that are vying for the funding, such as new auditorium lights at Easton High and a playground replacement at St. Michaels Elementary, total to around $3.3 million.
Hawley believes if the district had acted sooner and actively partnered with Make-A-Wish, the $1.8 million estimate for the turf field could have been significantly lowered by donations, as well as a potential contribution from a turf field supplier.
"Having Make-A-Wish on our team … we could've gotten the field for much less," Hawley said.
County Council Member Dave Stepp has been a proponent of the efforts of Elgin's Army and a potential turf field installation during the past year.
"Just from the overwhelming support of coaches and players who have shown up to express interest in how great that would be for our local athletes, I think that speaks for itself," Stepp said.
"I do know that they do have funds in reserve that they can make up the difference between the $1.5 (million) that we had given this fiscal year and the cost of the actual estimate," Stepp said regarding the Board of Education. "So they can do that at any time they're ready to do so, and I'm optimistic that they will, and I hope so personally sooner than later."
Lesli Creedon, president and CEO of Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic, said the organization is fully committed to providing Elgin another wish. Creedon said the average wish granted by Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic is around $10,000, and that the foundation was prepared to contribute around that mark toward a turf field installation.
"While I am disappointed that the BOE passed in the partnership with Make-A-Wish and do think (it's) shortsighted, I am hopeful that the county and its citizens will do more to support its young athletes and instill pride in our public schools," Elgin Hawley said in an emailed statement to The Star Democrat. "And whatever they decide they continue to think of me and my story to move the field forward as a priority."

title: Old Christmas - History, traditions and celebrations of Jan. 6 holiday
content:
Old Christmas - History, traditions and celebrations of Jan. 6 holiday

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You might have thought Christmas was over. You might also associate Jan. 6 with the political events of 2021.But Jan. 6 is actually the end of traditional 12 Days of Christmas celebrations.
The 12 days marks the birth of Jesus (Dec. 25) through the Coming of the Magi (the Three Wise Men).
Some customs count the 12 days from sundown Dec. 25 until the morning of Jan. 6.
Early Christians celebrated Christmas on Jan. 6 until the Roman Empire moved the holiday to Dec. 25 in the 336 A.D. during the reign of Emperor Constantine. The late December date took the place of pagan holidays celebrating Roman gods and the Winter Solstice.
Still, Jan 6. continued to be celebrated as Christmas by Britons and other Europeans in the Julian calendar.
The changeover to the Gregorian calendar in 1582 moved Christmas to Dec. 25 and closer to the Winter Solstice.
It was adopted by the British and Irish in 1752 which helped bring the calendar change to the American colonies.
Other European countries, including Russia and its Eastern European neighbors, did not switch over until the early 20th Century. Orthodox Christians still celebrate Christmas on Jan. 7.
Still, Jan. 6 holds a place in Christmas celebrations for Armenians, the Irish as well as folks in Appalachia and some Christian believers such as the Amish and Mennonites.
Armenians - who are among the earliest in the Christian faith - still celebrate Christmas on Jan. 6.
In Ireland, the Jan. 6 celebrations have included women getting together for their own holiday festivities and the men of their households handling the cooking, cleaning and other chores for a day.
In Appalachia, Old Christmas still has a place for some with traditions such as getting together with family and friends, putting candles in windows and holiday food such as versions of fruitcakes (including apple stack cake), mincemeat pies and Christmas hams and serenading friends and neighbors.
There are also Appalachian superstitions that animals can speak at midnight on Old Christmas Day Jan. 6.
That superstition is on top Appalachians' holiday traditions such as eating ham hocks, black-eyed peas and greens on New Year's Day for good luck.
The Amish and Mennonites also celebrate Old Christmas with cakes, pies and other holiday foods as well as religious services. 
 
 Caption: AP PHOTO/JENS MEYER

 Old Christmas is celebrated Jan. 6 in Appalachia and by the Amish, Mennonites, some Irish and other Christians. The birth of Jesus Christ was originally celebrated on Jan. 6 by many Europeans in the Julian calendar before being changed to Dec. 25. Jan. 6 is also the end of the 12 Days of Christmas, according to various customs.

 AP PHOTO/CZAREK SOKOLOWSKI

 Christmas was long celebrated on Jan. 6 in Great Britain, Ireland and other part of Europe until the changeover from the Julian to Gregorian calendars. Armenians still celebrate the birth of Jesus on Jan. 6 and Old Christmas is still commemorated in Appalachia and by the Amish and Mennonites.

title: Bridge - Which should be the trump suit?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Which should be the trump suit?

 August 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A8 | Section: News

 Words

 To start today, look only at the West hand. On your right, South opens one heart, you pass (I assume!), North responds one notrump (forcing or nonforcing, it doesnâ€™t matter), partner doubles (a takeout double of hearts), and righty rebids two hearts.What would you do?This problem faced four players at Bridge Base Online. You might pass, but that seems a tad cautious.Once you decide to do something, which suit would you prefer to be trumps: hearts or clubs?It seems clear to me that the answer is hearts. You cannot even guarantee an eight-card club fit, and you would have to win nine tricks. If so, surely you can take six or seven tricks in a heart contract for plus 200 or 500. Note the vulnerability.All four BBO players advanced with three clubs.Nine other Wests saw South open two hearts and East double in fourth position.Everyone ran to three clubs (using Lebensohl to warn of a weak hand).Now look at the full deal.How do two hearts and three clubs fareftIf the defenders are careful against two hearts doubled, they can take one spade, two hearts, two diamonds, one club and a diamond ruff for down two, plus 500.However, it isnâ€™t so straightforward. The play might well begin diamond, diamond, diamond ruff, a club to the king and another diamond. Then, though, South discards his spade loser and escapes for down one. East must shift swiftly to a spade, which is not obvious.Still, plus 200 would have been a cold top!

content:
Waterfowl Festival soaring to new heights

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials

 Read News Document

 Congratulations to the many people who made this year's Waterfowl Festival a success.The annual celebration of wildlife, art, music and history brought between 25,000 and 30,000 people to Easton last weekend.
Congratulations, too, go to Deena Kilmon in her first year as executive director of the festival. She is definitely at the top of the list for a rookie of the year award.
If there was any fear of a drop-off with new leadership, Kilmon put those fears to rest and set a high bar for success in coming years.
"We know we broke every record we've ever broken," Kilmon said on Monday.
"We had the highest attendance ever," Kilmon said. "It's hard for us to gauge because not everyone buys a ticket. But we do know that every parking space was full and every bus had about 45 minutes to an hourlong wait, and we had to add three buses on Saturday to accommodate the people."
Kilmon got a helping hand from Mother Nature who blessed the weekend with lovely weather and temperatures approaching 80 degrees under sunny skies for several of the days.
The executive director said multiple vendors — many of whom are already asking about next year — sold out or had record days at the festival.
If you have a 2025 calendar already, mark the weekend of Nov. 14-16 for the 54th Waterfowl Festival. We have no doubt that Kilmon will improve upon the tremendous success of this year's festival.
The success of the Waterfowl Festival is a success for the town of Easton and Talbot County too.
Downtown Easton shops were packed all three days of the festival, and restaurants had waiting lists for tables.
Kilmon called the relationship between the festival and local businesses "incredibly important."
"We're symbiotic," she said. "So if they succeed, we succeed and vice versa."
The three-day festival has an economic impact of more than $3 million each year, Kilmon said. It benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers and even local nonprofits.
"It's typically one of the biggest fundraising events of the year because a lot of the food vendors and people involved in the festival, they are nonprofits," Kilmon said. "And they're allowed to keep their proceeds, so it's extremely important to a lot of people."
At a breakfast Friday morning, Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassadra Vanhooser extolled the virtues of the business community that makes the "wonderful things" that happen in the county possible.
"It's that private investment along with the public investment that builds the community," she said. "And it's the festivals like the Waterfowl Festival — the granddaddy of them all — that weaves that fabric of the quality of life that we all love so much."
The festival may have just celebrated its 53rd anniversary, but it continues to grow and evolve.
Throughout the festival venues music filled the air and complemented the many duck and geese calls typical of the festival. Overall there were 38 musical acts on multiple stages.
"That made the festival have a different vibe this year, I think," Kilmon said, "just made it more of a friendly family party on every corner."
Feedback has been "incredibly positive," and Kilmon is excited to begin work on continuing Easton's Waterfowl tradition.
"Fifty-three years of our community coming together just gets better every year," Kilmon said. "And we're already working on next year, believe it or not."
It is good that Kilmon and her team are already working on the 2025 show. This year's show will be tough to top. We have no doubt they will rise to the challenge.

title: Talbot County considering new cannabis legislation
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County considering new cannabis legislation

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County is reviewing regulations on cannabis operations, but drafted legislation drew concerns from prospective business owners at a recent meeting.As drafted, legislation would bar cannabis growing and processing operations from locating within 500 feet of residential properties. That mark could be reduced for a specific project only if all property owners within that radius agree.
At a County Council meeting on July 8, a public hearing on the legislation was opened, during which two state license holders raised concerns. Discussion centered on changing the 500-foot setback to 200 feet.
Dave Ferraris, winner of a cannabis-processing license from the Maryland Cannabis Administration, which are awarded via a lottery, said the proposed restrictions would be "detrimental."
"It's not the wild west," Ferraris said of cannabis operations. "It's agriculture with oversight."
Easton resident Lori Yates received a license for cultivation. She said on July 8 that passage of the county legislation would hinder her progress toward acquiring a property in Cordova, the now-closed Triple Creek Winery.
"It really would pull the rug out from us trying to work with the current owners," Yates said.
On the prospect of a 200-foot setback, Yates said she feels it would still allow for proper space "to have it off of the public access road."
Brennan Tarleton, the county's planning and zoning director, noted that in the original draft legislation, there's already a written-in opportunity to reduce the setback to 200 feet if the affected property owners agree. But he said moving the starting point down from 500 feet is a possibility.
"Two hundred feet isn't a pie-in-the-sky idea for a setback," Tarleton said.
If passed, the legislation would require processors and growers to obtain site plan approval from the county and operate on a lot of at least 20 acres. Additionally, operators must procure professional testimony that cannabis odor is not "detectible from adjacent properties or public rights-of-way."
Ferraris voiced opposition to the "no odors" regulation, citing it is too extreme of a rule.
"Talbot County will realistically and effectively be disqualified from participating in cannabis processing and growing endeavors," Ferraris said.
He added that prospective cannabis operators aren't looking to exploit the county. "We're not asking for a blank check. We're just asking for a fair chance," he said.
Tarleton noted the county mostly mirrored Easton's cannabis ordinance in regard to the odor requirement. He said Easton restricted to just indoor growing operations, though. Tarleton said council could consider exempting open-air growing operations from the "no odors" rule.
Talbot's draft cannabis legislation also lays out standards for cannabis dispensaries to follow, largely falling in line with the state's recent legislation effective in July, 2024.
Dispensaries cannot be located within 500 feet of schools, child care centers, playgrounds, recreation centers, libraries, public parks or places of worship. They also can't locate within 1,000 feet of one another; that standard is present in Easton town limits, too, and in one case created competition between businesses.
While Talbot County's potential regulations stick with the state, local jurisdictions are permitted under state law to change those distance requirements.
The county's cannabis legislation wasn't eligible for a vote on July 8. It may return to the council at its July 22 meeting or later in August.

title: New exhibition at AAM features artist Darlene R. Taylor
author: Staff Writer
content:
New exhibition at AAM features artist Darlene R. Taylor

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 613
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new art exhibition from multidisciplinary artist Darlene R. Taylor has debuted at the Academy Art Museum in Easton.The HEIRLOOMS exhibition runs through July 14.
Taylor is an artist who is based in Washington D.C. and the Eastern Shore.
"In HEIRLOOMS, Darlene R. Taylor (b. 1960) affirms the resonance of memory in material culture as she imagines portraits of Black women obscured in historical archives. History is a muse that guides Taylor to know the past from the women who lived it. HEIRLOOMS examines the presence of Black women in Maryland's Talbot County communities and Taylor's own ancestry and follows the artist's experience researching and interpreting photographs found in archives and family albums. Taylor employs mixed-media collage using vintage linens, laces, cottons, and buttons collected and handed down from mother to daughter, friend to friend," according to an announcement from the museum.
"I've been using antique textiles for some time, many of which I found in antique stores locally in Maryland. But the works in HEIRLOOMS have an even more resonant history. I had been thinking about the way the handkerchief holds so many emotions and experiences—sweat and tears, joy and sadness. When I shared that thought with my friend circle, they responded by giving me handkerchiefs and linens passed down through their own families. In this way, my work is becoming its own archive of Black women's lives. The cloth holds memory, and when it is given to me, I am connected to an ancestor through that exchange," Taylor said.
According to AAM:
"Her use of women's personal effects also draws inspiration in part from artifacts unearthed during two excavations commissioned by the Museum at the former home of Henny and James Freeman, one of the earliest- documented free Black landowning families who lived on the Hill Community site from 1787-1828. This site was gifted to AAM in 2023, and the Museum has plans to rehabilitate the existing structure on the site and connect it to new construction of an annex that will provide needed administrative space, as well as commemorate the historical significance of Easton's Hill Community. Part of the annex will be named The Henny and James Freeman Wing and showcase the objects unearthed from the excavations in outdoor displays that tell the story of the family and neighborhood. Of the more than 6,000 historical artifacts unearthed, the most remarkable finds were personal items including buttons, jewelry, children's toys, a woman's shoe buckle, and a hair comb. These unique objects offer a rare connection to Black domestic life in the eighteenth century— particularly the lives of Black women and children, whose stories were frequently lost to history."
"In trying to imagine these lives, I am always asking what is behind each woman's gaze. Much of my work is based on photographs of women I find in historic archives. Even though we can see their faces, we often know more about the objects pictured in the room than we do about the women. So I try to stand with each woman, to look at what she is looking at. I'm not staring at her; I'm seeing the world as she sees it and observing those elements that make up her world," said Taylor.
A handmade paperback book HEIRLOOMS is available for purchase in AAM's Museum Shop as well as a limited-edition fine art print of the image The Storyteller with an excerpt of the poem Porch Telling written by Darlene R. Taylor.
"Taylor's HEIRLOOMS stitches together the forgotten stories of Black women, weaving memory and material into a vibrant tapestry of resilience and remembrance. We are thrilled to showcase Taylor's beautiful works on paper and to amplify voices that have historically been silenced," said. interim director Jennifer Chrzanowski.

title: Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BROAD CREEK — Police and firefighters teamed to locate a lost juvenile kayaker last weekend in Talbot County.On July 4 around 10 p.m., Maryland Natural Resources Police were informed of a lost kayaker in the Broad Creek area, which is on the west side of the county south of St. Michaels. Officials said he was on the water for "several hours" and around three miles from home.
Using thermal imaging cameras, a Natural Resource Police aviation unit quickly found the lost person — in around five minutes, according to Sgt. John Buchanan, chief pilot for NRP. Buchanan was in the aircraft with tactical flight officer Christian Helwig.
Buchanan said the kayaker left out of Grace Creek.
"I think it got dark on him, and he didn't know where he was," Buchanan said.
Once located, police used a spotlight to direct a rescue boat from the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company toward the juvenile.
A video posted to Facebook by Natural Resource Police shows the aircraft hone in on the kayaker and direct the fire boat to retrieve the juvenile.
Buchanan said such a rescue isn't too common, but it become somewhat prominent during boating season.
"(The) Chesapeake Bay and the tributaries are very large," Buchanan said. "When you start thinking about the different rivers and creeks and stuff off the Chesapeake Bay, we go out on different search missions like that probably a few times a month."
The pilot emphasized Helwig's expertise is crucial to such rescues. Helwig handles the thermal imaging camera, which can expose subjects in dark conditions, as well as a mapping system to pull up addresses and latitudes and longitudes.
"He's gotten really good with it, he's worked really hard at it," Buchanan said. "He's made us as a team very successful going out and doing these search missions."
Buchanan advises those going out on the water, especially alone, to be prepared with a charged cell phone and other equipment in case of emergency.
"Have a life jacket if you're out at night," he said. "Obviously have some kind of flashlight. And know the area, that's probably the biggest thing."

title: Where has grace gone in winning?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Where has grace gone in winning?

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I understand competition — athletic, business and political. I've engaged in them all, and I value each for the lessons they teach. Losing, when it happens, can even make you stronger.In debate or sport, you must prepare. You must know your opponent's strengths and weaknesses, and you must have a strategy. And win or lose, you are judged not only by the outcome but by how you carry yourself. I learned long ago: You lose with honor, but you win with grace.
So I ask — where has grace gone? Where has decorum gone? Today it seems acceptable to shout down opponents, to sneer and label, to point fingers instead of making points. These are tactics we would scold in children, yet they are now common currency in our politics.
I always valued the end of a contest, when you could shake hands, smile and respect the person across from you — even if you didn't like them. The best opponent was never the one I agreed with, but the one I could respect.
The true test of character, in debate or in life, is simple: Would I welcome this person as my next-door neighbor? Increasingly, I fear too many of today's loudest voices would fail that test.
DAN McKEW
Easton

title: Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education had its first look at the district's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 Monday.During a board work session Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones presented the draft budget, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars — an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025, Jones noted.
Jones provided the year-to-year budget changes by looking at 12 different categories of expenditures. The areas in which increases were highest are fixed charges ($2.23 million increase), instructional salaries ($1.7 million increase) and other instructional costs ($1.47 million increase).
Jones added that while $9 million to $10 million in grants are expected next year, anticipated grant funding is more than $5 million less than last fiscal year. That drop in grant funding precipitated a portion of the rise in the requested unrestricted budget.
In Annapolis, it still remains to be seen how Maryland's expected $2.7 billion deficit is tackled and if legislative decisions will impact funding for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative.
Talbot school leaders say budgeting will be a fluid process in the coming months as they keep an eye on state legislation and the Accountability & Implementation Board, an entity that ensures the state and county governments are correctly implementing Blueprint.
"There's one area where I did do a little bit of hedging our bets, on the conservative side," Jones said of the proposed budget. "I don't think we'll know any of that until April or May. But as certain pieces of legislation gather steam and seem to gather support and seem likely, then I think we will work behind the scenes to figure out how we will address this if this comes to fruition."
In creating the draft budget, Jones and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district considered its top priorities: academic equity in math, an engaging environment for students and staff, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.
Monday's discussion included a breakdown of 33 proposed additional positions for the next fiscal year. The proposed budget includes a $3.6 million jump in salaries and wages.
"This list is whittled down, if you can believe it, from a longer list of wants and desires," Jones said. "And it was very much informed by school administration. This is what they felt they needed in their buildings."
ADDITIONAL POSITIONSJones outlined the 33 additional positions that are in the requested budget. Six of those positions are for English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants or coaches.
She cited the district's need to serve its multilingual population, along with the state funding for multilingual learning, for adding the positions.
"Our (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program) data … demonstrates that we do consistently underserve our multilingual students," Jones said. "And so, we just need to provide more resources there."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson asked if those English for Speakers of Other Languages positions will be difficult to fill.
"Because I know we've had problems — specifically with ESOL in the past — finding people who are qualified and had a desire to do that," Jackson said. "And that's a quarter of the positions we're looking for."
Zulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies, said it's a challenge both in Talbot County and statewide. She said recruitment and retention are key aspects.
"We have to definitely start promoting earlier and just doing the best that we can," Jarmon-Horsey said. "And doing things that are unconventional, like our on-site career fair that's going to be happening here this week."
Other requested positions in the budget include: an art teacher at Easton Middle, a high school math coach, a middle school reading coach, four special education positions at Easton Elementary and a special education teacher at Easton Middle.
One athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School was also on the proposed list.
"I'm happy to see that at the top of the list," Jackson said of the athletic trainer role. "I would be in favor of two … making sure that we have coverage for all of our athletic events. I know sports parents, they have eyes on that."
The draft budget will be discussed again at Wednesday's monthly Board of Education meeting before the board hosts its joint meeting with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 22. On Feb. 10, the board will host a public hearing on the budget.

 EASTON — The Eastern Shore Community Rowers (ESCR) are back on the water with a new season, new shells, and new times.ESCR is an adult (18-over) rowing team based at Evergreen on Port Street, supporting a wide range of skill levels, ages, and experience. The group is committed to sharing its passion and knowledge of rowing to anyone interested in learning.
ESCR has scheduled two free information sessions: April 12 and April 19 from 8:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. at Evergreen 770 Port Street. The sessions will be a chance to meet coaches and team members, learn about the 60-foot, eight-person rowing shells to singles, and how rowing is a super fun, sweaty good time.
ESCR will host two full Learn-to-Row clinics, April 28-May 1, from 5:30-7:30 p.m., and Saturday, May 3, from 8:30-10:30 a.m. Clinics will also be offered May 12-15 from 5:30-7:30 p.m., and Saturday, May 17, from 8:30-10:30 a.m. The cost is $400 for these 10-hour sessions.
ESCR is dedicated to teaching our community to row and offer more access area rivers. Scholarships are available to encourage everyone who may be interested. Beginners are encouraged to join the Learn-To-Row clinics, or to take private lessons from one of ESCR's accredited rowing coaches to acquire the skills needed for practices.
"The only criteria," said Board Safety Officer Terry Gleim, "is that you be able to swim and (are) strong enough to properly hold an oar. If swimming is an obstacle, ESCR will assist in helping you learn."
The rowing season runs from April-December with afternoon sessions for novices, 5:30 p.m. workouts Monday, Wednesday and Friday, and 7 p.m. rows on Tuesday and Thursday for more advanced rowers. There will also be a 7:30 a.m. row on Saturdays for all members.
"ESCR is open to anyone over 18 interested in having fun, getting healthy, and appreciating our beautiful waters," said Chloe Tong, the executive director. "The health of our rivers, as well as personal health, is an intrinsic part of our conversation."
As a non-profit, ESCR raises money through private donations, grants, and modest membership dues needed to fund the additional boats and necessary equipment for next year's rowing season.

title: Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cheers filled the BAAM Center on election night as dozens of local Democrats watched votes roll in for the 2024 general election and celebrated the end of a highly divisive election campaign.To be in community among like-minded residents, Talbot Democrats hosted an election watch party filled with food, drinks, guests dressed in their best campaign gear and deep discussion about hopes and fears for the future.
Patrick Firth, chair of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said this celebration was needed for the community on the Shore. Firth said the people gathered on Tuesday are the heartbeat of the Democratic community and more than anything deserved a celebration and to feel appreciated for all their work.
"We had a record of over 200 individual volunteers helping us throughout the election, from greeting voters to canvassing, to phone banking," Firth said. "Talbot led the Eastern Shore this past weekend in canvassing, knocking on over 1000 doors in Talbot County."
Lined around the room were political signs showing support for Vice President Kamala Harris, Maryland Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks and Talbot County candidate for Board of Education Candace Henry.
Kathy Hostetter, resident of Wye Mills, said she was feeling hopeful Tuesday night though she understood the presidential race would be close. Hostetter shared her enthusiasm for Alsobrooks, who hours later would win a U.S. Senate Seat in Maryland.
"Talbot County is one of the most beautiful places," Hostetter said. "We have a great state here in Maryland, we've got a great blue state. So tonight, we're very hopeful, and we want to keep it blue."
Hours after the party ended, former president Donald Trump triumphed over Democratic opponent Kamala Harris. Though initially expected to be a close race, Trump flipped several swing states in his favor and won the popular vote for the first time as a candidate.
Election night was a mix of triumphs and defeats for Democrats in Maryland. Alsobrooks claimed victory over incumbent Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan. Additionally, Maryland voters overwhelmingly supported an amendment to Maryland's constitution for reproductive freedom.
Michele Dappert, president of the Talbot County Democrat Party, said though Maryland is a famously blue state, this year's election has divided voters, especially in Talbot County.
According to the State Board of Elections' unofficial 2024 General Election Results for Talbot County, over half of voters chose former President Donald Trump as their presidential candidate and an overwhelming number of residents voted for Republican candidate Larry Hogan for U.S. Senate.
Dappert said though there is political separation among those on the Eastern Shore, all voters have essentially the same end goal: to have their values understood, heard and put into practice.
"Look, I get it, politics can be contentious, but when you meet people locally at the door, most of us are just trying to get by, and we're just trying to send our kids to school, have clean water, be able to walk outside and feel safe no matter what you look like and who you are," Dappert said. "And those are all very universal values, so I find it very important to defend them."
Sitting next to Dappert in a Kamala Harris camo cap and a blue shirt, which showed "CLXXVII Minutes" on the front and "11,780 Votes" on the back, was her father George Dappert. George Dappert explained the meaning behind his shirt.
The front represented, in roman numerals, the 186 minutes Trump watched TV during the Jan. 6 insurrection. The back represented the number of votes Trump was trying to find in Georgia to turn the state in his favor during the 2020 Presidential Election.
George Dappert said the Democratic Party has done everything they could in terms of getting out to vote, talking to people and getting the message out there for others to vote. For him, practicing the political right of voting is essential to democracy and he urges everyone to continue to be politically active regardless of major elections.
"It is what generations of our forefathers and foremothers have fought for, bled for, marched for, done everything that they could," George Dappert said. "To willfully not vote is an abdication of your responsibility and what they have given from their past to our future."

title: Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Around 180 people attended the For All Seasons presentation on human trafficking on Tuesday night at the Avalon Theatre, where a panel of experts painted a picture of a changing landscape for trafficking crimes.With the increasing use of social media, traffickers find and groom their victims at home, a more methodical trust-gaining method than before the advent of the internet, they said.
According to Thomas Stack, anti-human trafficking and sexual assault response manager for Mayor's Neighborhood Office of Safety and Engagement for the City of Baltimore, because young people's lives are so transparent online, traffickers can target individuals who are alone, mad at their parents and not doing well in school. Low self esteem is the target, he said.
"It is all about getting the word out there. Human trafficking has been around a long time, but the awareness has probably only been around for the last 20 years," Stack said. "Maryland has a toxic mixture of both poverty and wealth. The poverty is a major risk factor for exploitation and the wealth is the buyers of sex, the people who are willing to purchase people for their pleasure."
Maryland is also geographically vulnerable to trafficking, the experts said.
"We are two hours from Philly, three hours from New York, we have a lot of sporting events, we have two major cities, and we have airports and casinos, everything a trafficker wants," Stack said. "Like we have the Preakness coming up. There will be a lot of males who have traveled here. The traffickers know that and will bring their victims of sex trafficking to service those males."
The speakers made it clear that human trafficking happens in the Mid-Shore community.
"There was a 15-year-old trafficked in Denton, so it is here," Stack said.
By becoming more aware of the problem, they said, community members can identify victims and reach out.
Heather Amador, deputy director of victim services policy and programs for the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, was one of the speakers. She said members of the community can look for signs of trafficking, like bruises, new tattoos and new suggestive clothing.
Red flags can also appear online, Stack said, like if a teenager has multiple Facebook profiles with some that have nothing to do with their family or friends.
"Human trafficking is here. People don't want to believe that their neighbors are capable of such things," Amador said. "A lot of human trafficking victims don't even identify as a victim. They see themselves as voluntarily engaging in it. They don't see the coercion that goes along with it. They are deceived to go down this path or forced into addiction. They think they are helping someone else out."
Amador had one victim in her office who simply said she needed to make money. She was a runaway and had nowhere to go, Amador said, and she needed housing.
Amador came across a case where a child had to perform a sex act to get lunch money in her lunch account and emphasized that that is trafficking too.
For All Seasons offers a host of services around human trafficking, from trainings, to getting the word out, to psychological services, to addiction services.
Beth Anne Dorman, CEO and president of For All Seasons, says it takes a village to combat trafficking.
"Our anti-human trafficking efforts focused on a team-based approach," she said. "We collaborate with law enforcement, first responders, Department of Social Services, child advocacy centers, school administrators, teachers and the hospital, officials from the towns and counties we serve."
Then she introduced a video of Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman, who created and helped pass legislation to make the Maryland Regional Navigator program when she was a legislator. This program supports survivors of trafficking. For All Seasons is a participant.
"Maryland recorded 118 cases of human trafficking involving 173 victims. This figure includes sex and labor exploitation. Child sex trafficking is also a concern. Since 2012 over 500 children have been identified by Child Protective Services as reportedly being trafficked in Maryland. This remains vastly under reported," Lierman said in the video.
She said she was committed to ensuring access to services for every survivor of sex trafficking in Maryland. She highlighted For All Seasons as "essential to the safety and wellness of our communities."
The night ended with a call to action for the audience.
"It is a hidden crime so we all have to be alert," said Susan Ahlstrom, regional navigator at For All Seasons. "We all have to be vigilant."
For more information on human trafficking and available resources, visit missingkids.org, polaris.com and netsmartz.com

title: Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — County Republicans continued to push the Talbot County Board of Elections to equal its selection of election judges during the board's monthly meeting on Wednesday morning.The breakdown by party was 62 Democratic judges, 50 Republican judges and 11 unaffiliated judges in September, according to Election Director Tammy Stafford. Local officials have indicated at meetings that the number of judges for each party may now be closer to equal, but this has not been confirmed by the Board of Elections.
Election officials have said the makeup is "fluid" and will change up until Election Day. During Wednesday's meeting, Stafford said "judges are always needed" and that her office "continuously" accepts interest forms.
According to Sept. 18 meeting minutes read aloud Wednesday, staffing for the election began in June of 2023. Training for those who filled out interest forms began in early 2024.
In the last month, concerns have circulated regarding a party imbalance of election judges, or those who staff polling places on Election Day.
Local officials, including Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and Talbot County Council Member Dave Stepp, have cited that the board is not in compliance with state law.
Maryland election code states "each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges" from "the majority party" and "the principal minority party."
State election law permits judges not affiliated with either party for precincts with six or more judges, as well as "one or more election judges who are minors." The number of unaffiliated judges "may not exceed the lesser of" the majority or minority party, law states.
These concerns led to a flurry of responses from state agencies emphasizing the security of the electoral process. In an Oct. 2 statement responding to a letter sent by Gamble to the Talbot Board of Elections, State Board of Elections Administrator Jared DeMarinis said voters should feel "confident" in the state's election security and "compliance with the law."
Attorney General Anthony Brown weighed in as well, writing a letter to Gamble on Oct. 7.
"Even at the individual polling place level, while all local boards make best efforts to achieve exact party balance, this is not always possible for reasons outside the local board's control, including the number of judges from each party who volunteer," Brown wrote.
Stafford stated at the Sept. 18 meeting that the training for election judges can no longer be done after Oct. 8 since the room used for training is also used for canvassing.
During Wednesday's public comment, Gary Judy, a member of the Talbot County Republican Central Committee, said he's heard from Republicans who applied to be an election judge but were not told there are no vacancies for this year's general election. He said the fact that the board did not achieve exact party balance is "extremely alarming to Talbot County voters."
"We decided to keep close track on it this year," Judy said, "and can confirm that there were more than enough Republicans who signed up to be election judges to fill the available Republican positions of the equal representation required by Maryland election law."
On Wednesday, Judy provided board members with copies of a letter written by the Maryland Republican Party addressing election judge concerns in Talbot County. Adam Wood, executive director of the Maryland Republican Party, later told the Star Democrat that the letter was a "draft" letter and had not been sent to the state board.
Shari Wilcoxon, also a member of the Republican central committee, spoke during public comment, asking the board to ensure "parity" of election judges.
"I think that it is an actual embarrassment that this board is allowing the executive director free rein to break the law," Wilcoxon said. "It is your duty to hold her feet to the fire, and that she does what is Maryland law."
Wilcoxon questioned why election judge applications were denied in February and March.
"February and March had to do with the primary," Stafford responded. "Let's be specific here. That was the primary. Those were the first people who were contacted for the general (election)."
This led to tense back-and-forth between Wilcoxon and Stafford.
Board President Susan MacKinnon stepped in, asking Wilcoxon to stop speaking.
"You have had the opportunity to speak, you are now being disruptive," MacKinnon said to Wilcoxon. "You are being disruptive, and if you continue being disruptive, I will call a recess and have you removed."
Wednesday's meeting was the board's last regularly scheduled meeting before the election Nov. 5. During Stafford's report to the board, she said "logic and accuracy testing on the electronic equipment was completed" on Sept. 16. The Board of Elections will have its logic and accuracy testing documentation available for public inspection Friday at 10 a.m. at 215 Bay Street in Easton.

title: 13th annual Watermen’s Appreciation Day draws a crowd
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
13th annual Watermen’s Appreciation Day draws a crowd

 August 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Hundreds of people enjoyed boat docking contests, steamed local crabs, live music and family activities to celebrate the 13th annual Watermen's Appreciation Day hosted at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on Sunday.Watermen's Appreciation Day brings people together to celebrate the longstanding history of watermen on the Eastern Shore, as well as fundraise for the Talbot Watermen's Association.
Jeff Harrison, president of the association, said the event began in 2010 and has grown throughout the years. For Harrison, the number of people attending every year shows the local community's support for watermen.
"There is this appreciation for the local watermen in this area and, of course, all over the Bay," Harrison said. "And we are actually trying to grab a hold of that in some of our fundraisers and to let people know that we do appreciate them and that we're glad that they appreciate us also."
Harrison, dressed in a yellow volunteer shirt, was part of a team of over a 100 volunteers assisting attendees and contestants.
The Harrison family were all part of the volunteer team. Ashley and James Harrison, along with a group of five boys under the age of 13, stood behind a volunteer table near crowded bleachers awaiting the boat docking competition.
Ashley Harrison said volunteering at the Watermen Appreciation Day event is a family tradition she married into and has decided to establish in her family. This tradition stems from her husband, who comes from a family of watermen and who began volunteering when he was a young boy.
"We like doing stuff for the children," Ashley Harrison said. "We have three of our own, and we love seeing them have fun at events as well. And we like helping our community and showing our visitors that come here that this is a really great place to come and we're a tight knit community."
Under the sun, hundreds of people crowded and squeezed together to catch a glimpse of the boat docking contest. Boat owners of all ages showed off their skills and embraced cheers and support from the crowd.
Shannon Mitchell, vice president of engagement for the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, said this event is a part of a partnership between the museum and local watermen to benefit the watermen in their fundraising, sponsorship and silent auction work. The museum benefits from the admission intake, she said.
"This one is very much mission-focused in supporting our local watermen," Mitchell said. "It's a big piece of why the museum exists to begin with. They tell a big story about the Chesapeake Bay and our region, so it's really exciting to see everyone come out and support them."

 WHCP (91.7 FM) has just come on as a full-service NPR member station for the Mid-Shore with Morning Edition, All Things Considered, and 80% of its schedule devoted to being a "Music Discovery Station." The station offers a diverse lineup of musical styles - big band, neo-soul, blues, indie music, jazz, folk, classic country and deep tracks from the Boomer Tunes era.In addition, the station offers Mid-Shore news updates on Mid-Shore Mid-Day, some of which are provided by partners at the The Star Democrat.Additionally, every day the WHCP Community Calendar is updated, presenting events throughout the Mid-Shore region, along with 20-20 Marine Weather, which offers up-to-date forecasts twice each hour.To support all of these public radio offerings, WHCP is holding a membership drive through Nov. 11."A generous anonymous local donor has made a matching gift of $10,000 so that membership support is automatically doubled until we reach the $10,000 level," said Mike Starling, founder, president and general manager of WHCP."We are excited our new signal on 91.7 reaches roughly 75,000 people on the Mid-Shore (Talbot, Dorchester, and portions of Caroline, plus over 100,000 more in Wicomico and Southern Maryland)," he said. "We are now touting signal coverage, but more importantly the program upgrades as a grassroots community station carrying NPR's most popular programs too." During the station's very first fall membership drive, WHCP said it is proud to be among a select group of 17 NPR member stations that can offer the NPR+ podcast bundle of 16 podcasts as a thank-you gift to those joining or renewing their membership of at least $96 annually ($8 per month).Additionally, Premier Movie Theaters in Cambridge and Easton have partnered with WHCP, and the station is making two passes available to any current members (new, returning or sustaining at the $60 family membership level and above). Passes can be picked up at WHCP's Cambridge studio."New and renewing members are critically important to our program plans for the year ahead," said Starling. "Individual annual memberships start at just $35, and you can become a sustaining monthly member for less than $7 a month, at whcp.org/donate." In addition to its regular programming, WHCP also operates a free public service with the Mid-Shore Reader, a round-the-clock radio reading service for those who cannot read the printed word on their own.Fresh daily readings of books, newspapers and magazines, including The Star Democrat, are read each week by local volunteers, as well as the monthly Attractions, Shore Monthly and Tidewater Times magazines."If you or someone you know suffers from vision loss, or who otherwise cannot see, hold, or comprehend the printed word, this service is available free of charge," said Starling. title: YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires

 January 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Peter Hyman was in his gym clothes and already on his way to the YMCA on Peachblossom Road around noon on Saturday when he learned there had been a fire at the Y.When he arrived moments later, Hyman, who is president of the YMCA's board, said he saw members of the community and Y staff gathering, many visibly upset by the event.
"The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation," he said Sunday morning.
The fire, which involved a second-floor closet at the Y, was one of two that the Easton Volunteer Fire Department and other departments responded to at the YMCA Saturday, according to Easton Fire Chief JR Dobson.
At around 5:30 p.m., firefighters were once again called to the Y, where an HVAC unit was on fire on the building's roof.
Neither fire resulted in any extensive damage to the building, according to YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill.
Dobson said the first fire was extinguished by the Y's sprinkler system before firefighters arrived at the scene. The second fire was quickly extinguished by firefighters using a fire extinguisher after gas feeding the HVAC unit was shut off, the fire chief said.
The fires closed the Y for the remainder of Saturday, but regular operations resumed Sunday morning with all facilities but the racquetball courts open for use. The racquetball courts were largely undamaged, Gill said, but due to their proximity to the first fire, a sprinkler had gone off over them, meaning they had to be closed Sunday while staff worked to dry the area.
"We were fortunate there wasn't a substantial amount of damage to the building," Gill said. "And now we're working with local authorities to provide any information we can to help them investigate."
While the second fire's cause was ruled by the Office of the State Fire Marshal to have been a mechanical failure with the HVAC unit, Dobson said, the cause of the first fire is still under investigation.
Gill said the first fire is not believed to have been caused by any mechanical or similar failure.
Though the fires did not cause extensive damage to the facilities, Hyman said the events were particularly upsetting for Y staff and regulars because of the role the YMCA plays in the Easton community.
"We're lucky," he said. "Our YMCA is not just a place to work out and exercise. It really is a community. It's a very wonderful group of people… I've been a member of the Y for years, and it really is a community across cultures, all kinds of folks. And it's a really special place."
Dobson said multiple departments, including the Easton, Oxford and Trappe volunteer fire departments and Talbot County Emergency Services, responded to the events Saturday. These departments worked with staff and others on the scene to evacuate the building and secure the area.
Gill said although Saturday was "a little bit of a traumatic day," the coordinated community response to the fires served as a reminder of the importance of the YMCA.
"The Y has been around for 168 years, so it's an institution in the community that serves one in three people, and it's wonderful to see so many people care for it at that level," Gill said.

title: 'How Lucky Is This Community' - Connect Talbot Project Celebrated For Its Success
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
'How Lucky Is This Community' - Connect Talbot Project Celebrated For Its Success
