 CORDOVA - More than 60 representatives from the U.S. Department of Agriculture took a field trip to the Eastern Shore Wednesday to celebrate the continued progress of Easton Utilities' Connect Talbot project.Headed by Easton Utilities, the Connect Talbot project is extending broadband to unserved portions of Talbot County. The USDA provided significant initial support for the rural connectivity initiative in July 2020 when the agency awarded Easton Utilities $13.1 million in grant funding for the project.Wednesday's activities kicked off at Triple Creek Winery in Cordova, where USDA representatives took in technical demonstrations and checked out stations designed to show broadband deployment.Guests enjoyed a hands-on experience with field crews showcasing their work, including all components from initial construction techniques, plowing, drilling, aerial lashing and the installation process connecting service to the side of the home.Demonstrations were followed by a customer panel sharing the positive impacts of broadband service made possible by the Connect Talbot and lunch on the winery grounds.In the afternoon, federal, state and local officials gathered to praise Connect Talbot's progress so far.Laurel Leverrier, the assistant administrator of the USDA's rural utility service telecommunications program, expressed gratitude for the opportunity to see the work being done on the ground in Talbot County - the first trip of its kind for her."It's very clear being here and meeting with you all and hearing from folks that you're serving of what a community focus your organization has," she said of Easton Utilities. "I think part of it is the type of entity you are - you're municipally owned and operated I think it's really unique, and I think, 'How lucky is this community to get to benefit from the services you provide.'" Sen. Johnny Mautz, R-37, emphasized the significance of prioritizing broadband accessibility for children in Talbot County."To put the power of the internet in the hands of our children is just phenomenal.And the investment that's been made; when we first talked about this, it would never pay for itself, you can't get the revenue or return out of the investment and what you're putting in - that's very true, that's not going to happen right away," he said. "But I will guarantee you over the years, we will see benefits beyond anyone's imagination for what you've been able to do for our area."Mautz thanked the USDA for providing supplemental funding for the project, the cost of which has now risen significantly.Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher acknowledged that prior to the project's kickoff, the county's 37,000 residents were divided between "digital haves and digital have nots." But with the USDA funding and efforts from local government and Easton Utilities, rural addresses across the county are being connected."This is our proudest moment," he said. "This is delivering on the American promise of a land of equal opportunity. This is transforming the lives in our community.This is creating prosperity in our corner of rural America."Also expressing gratitude was Easton Mayor Megan Cook, who emphasized the importance of the infrastructure in providing rural residents with connectivity and accessibility to enjoy the benefits of education, social interaction, health care, remote work, entertainment and more."Connectivity, interconnectedness, support, community - these are all pieces of the same puzzle, and they all become more important with each passing day," she said. "It's our ability to look out for each other, and help where and when we can, to reap what we sow - that is truly essential."Easton Velocity has made significant progress installing and providing broadband service to significant portions of Talbot County.As of early September, Easton Velocity has completed more than 50% of the mileage construction mileage and offered access to more than 1,750 locations.According to Easton Utilities, 920 of these locations have already subscribed to service and are enjoying the benefits internet service offers.Since the initial grant funding in 2020, various grant funding sources now total over $30 million. The project will now provide access to 4,400 locations and is estimated to cost $40 million.The scope and timeline of the project are reflected on a real-time interactive map.The project is on track for completion in advance of the grant requirement deadline of Dec. 31, 2026, according to Ted L. Book, vice president of Easton Velocity.Hugh Grunden, Easton Utilities' president and CEO, closed out the celebration with appreciation for the wider community effort to bring broadband to the county's rural areas."It's about partnerships - we could not have done this alone, the county couldn't have done it alone," he said."So when you partner with the likes of the USDA, the state of Maryland, Talbot County, the Town of Easton, Easton Utilities, whether it be for the engineering, the funding or the execution, that's how it works."

title: Local health care 'excellent'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Local health care 'excellent'

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We've all heard negative comments about our local health care facilities. I'm writing to relay my recent firsthand experience with our local health care system.On Aug. 17, I experienced symptoms of a stroke and called 911. The ambulance arrived within minutes, and the EMT assessed my symptoms as a suspected stroke. They asked me if I had a preference of where they took me, and I asked their recommendation. Based on the severity of my symptoms they suggested University of Maryland Medical System Chester River Hospital. The EMT remained vigilant through the entire trip.
Dr. Lukas met us in the vestibule at Chester River Hospital to evaluate my condition and determine whether I should stay or go to another facility for more intense care. It was recommended I remain at Chester River for continued evaluation. Nurse Agnes provided constant monitoring. Dr. Lukas checked back every few minutes to make sure I was stable. The staff welcomed my husband and daughters who remained at my bedside.
Dr. Lukas said I would be transferred to a more acute-care facility and asked for my preference. They found me a bed in Easton hospital.
Best Care Ambulance transported me to Easton promptly the next morning. The EMT who rode with me had extensive military and over 25 years professional EMT experience. Our driver was a retired Black Hawk helicopter pilot. I knew I was in great hands.
The nurses, doctors and staff at Easton Hospital were exceptional, highly skilled professionals with a pleasant, caring attitude.
I was not a likely candidate for a stroke. I exercise regularly, eat right and have no pre-existing health conditions. Easton hospitalist Dr. Devkota and neurologist Valentin knew this and ordered extensive tests to find the cause of my stroke. They found I have a rare genetic blood disorder that causes blood clots, hence the stroke.
To all the naysayers and critics I say, acute care doesn't get better than the experience I just had. I often get asked by real estate buyers, "How is your local health care"? Now I have firsthand experience to tell them; it's excellent.
Thanks to all who helped with my care and recovery.
CINDY GENTHER
Rock Hall

title: St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News

 Words

 ST. MICHAELS — After months of controversy surrounding its creation, the St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board held its first meeting at the Boy Scout Cabin in St. Michaels Thursday morning.During this meeting, members of the board, the St. Michaels Business Association and residents of the town came together to discuss the future and current condition of the tourism industry.
The board discussed potential budgets, marketing and branding strategies including combining various websites, and getting a better understanding of the tourists who are visiting and the tourists the board would like to bring to St. Michaels.
Timothy Law, the representative of retail businesses on the board, said as a business owner he is really excited for the work the board will produce.
"I love St. Michaels, and today was a huge stride forward to really understanding tourism and promoting our spectacular destination. I think it's a great group of people and we've got a great diversity of thought and diversity of background. It was just a very positive first step."
The idea of a tourism board was brought forth during a commissioners candidate forum hosted by the St. Michaels Business Association last April, when representatives of the Business Associations stated a need for marketing assistance due to a decrease in revenues within the last year.
The purpose of the board, according to a town memo, would be to assist the town in its efforts to encourage businesses to locate or remain in the town and to make recommendations to the commissioners. The board would also "work closely with the Talbot County Tourism Board on a unified, regional marketing approach."
The board has seven members serving four-year terms, all appointed by the commissioners. Membership includes residents not associated with a business and representatives from the lodging, eating/drinking, retail or service, marinas, museums and nonprofit sectors.
The members of the board were elected by the Commissioners of St. Michaels and include:
Brian Ball, managing director for the Wildset Hotel, to represent lodging.
Chris Agharabi, chief executive officer of Ava's Hospitality Group, to represent restaurants.
Katie Blaha, advancement manager of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, to represent nonprofits/museums.
Michael Morgan, owner and president of St. Michaels Marina LLC, to represent marinas.
Timothy Law, owner of American Holiday Shop, to represent retail.
Craig Bertolett, chief operating officer of COLUMBIA Technologies, and Michael McMillan, associate clinical professor of accounting at the University of Maryland, as two representatives for the residents of St. Michaels.
Included in the board is St. Michaels Commissioner Katrina Whittington as acting representative for the commission.
On Thursday, the board discussed the importance of a unified marketing message and the potential benefits of public Wi-Fi for data collection. Board members emphasized the need for a clear target audience and suggested a short-term plan to focus on digital marketing.
Ball said it's important for people to understand how tourism effects all aspects of the town's economy.
"St. Michaels is very much a tourism-based economy and it really affects everything we do from local government to all the businesses and all the restaurants and hotels," Ball said. "I think that this (board) is a very valuable economic tool to use to help the town grow."
Plans were made for the next meeting to include presentations on budget allocation and marketing strategies. The next meeting will be held on Jan. 30.

title: Waterfowl Festival looks forward
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Waterfowl Festival looks forward

 May 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Deena Kilmon, the new executive director of the Waterfowl Festival, is excited to bring fresh energy and invite a new generation into the mission of the organization.Some changes are already visible. The Waterfowl Festival has welcomed a new staff and opened a new gift shop at the Armory, which houses the festival organization.
"We are laying the foundation for the future. If you think you know the Waterfowl Festival, I bet you don't. I invite people to come down to learn not only about the work we have done, but the work we want to do," Kilmon said.
For three days every November, about 20,000 visitors come to Easton for the annual Waterfowl Festival, which features art sales, demonstrations, educational events and more.
But the Waterfowl Festival is a year-round effort, with the organization also hosting a variety of events and supporting conservation nonprofits.
More new developments can be expected soon, Kilmon said, some of which are with the Armory building itself.
One of the big ways she wants to begin a new era for the Waterfowl Festival is by revitalizing the Armory's massive space.
There is a walled off stage at one end, and Kilmon wants to bring the proscenium arch back into use.
There are also rows of historically accurate new windows that will surround the Armory's drill space. They give the whole auditorium a kind of face lift.
"These are what the Maryland Historical Trust paid for. So it looks the same on the outside as it did to the 97-year-old building. We have just applied to the county to fix the roof. Once we fix the roof, the vision is to fix the stage," Kilmon said.
Kilmon's Assistant Director Sammie Mooney, who has a background in professional and community theater, wants to invite a whole new generation of the community into the building and maybe even rent it out.
Mooney is excited to connect with younger members of the waterfowl festival scene.
"I don't think I am trying to develop anything brand new, but bringing in newer people, the younger generation for the longevity of the festival," she said. "We want to do so many things with the building because it kind of sat here. It is an amazing building. We want it to become kind of a community center where events are always going on."
One such event is inviting in photographer Kristin Rutkowski, who created the portrait project "Her Helm" of women captains who ply the waters of the Chesapeake.
"It is all about the water and literally fits right in our mission," Kilmon said. "She will be here June 7, and I have another guy who wrote a book about raptors. He should be here in July. That is the kind of stuff we are bringing in. We could show a film here."
Organizers' passion to attract people to the Waterfowl Festivals' activities comes from the festival's mission and from the land itself.
"I love the Eastern Shore, the culture. When I was 14, I read James Michener's "Chesapeake" and totally fell in love with the romantic version of the Chesapeake Bay," Kilmon said.
She said her whole family loves to get out on the water and enjoy the open spaces.
"At the festival that is what we do. Try and conserve those spaces and make them available to and accessible to everyone," Kilmon said.
The organization does this through more than just hosting the annual festival and hosting events. The Waterfowl Festival has also invested millions of dollars into conservation efforts.
"We support organizations that do that work. There have been three or four dozen organizations over the years. It is well over $5 million since 1971," Kilmon said.
Their latest gift was to the Wellington WMA in Somerset County. They are taking farmland and turning it back into wetlands, partnering with private donors, the state and Ducks Unlimited.
Kilmon mentioned that there is a grant program for conservation organizations.
"It is a mini grant program for up to $5,000, and we are awarding about five of those. Say you are a little organization with conservation and education and there is no other funding for a project they want to do. We have already set this money aside at the Mid-Shore Community Foundation," she said.
She invited interested individuals and organizations to go to the Waterfowl Festival website to find a 30-minute application to receive a grant.
Becoming the new executive director has widened her eyes as to what the festival has done, Kilmon said.
"The legacy is insane. People have forgotten some of the players have passed or moved away, but some of their children are still here. What we are doing now becomes even more critical to this generation. They thought it was a crisis in '71, but what is it like now? It is beyond a crisis," she said.
"What I think is critical is re-engaging with our community and bringing in a new generation to make sure that the legacy of the festival continues," Kilmon said.

title: Bridge - Deception by deduction
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Deception by deduction

 December 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A7 | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 John Ruskin, who was an English art critic, discussed painters when he wrote, "The essence of lying is in deception, not in words." In bridge, sometimes you lie in words when you make, for example, a psychic bid.During the play, sometimes you lie by false carding. In today's deal, a defender fooled declarer by dropping an unnecessarily high card. However, it helped that he had calculated his "generosity" couldn't cost a trick.
In four hearts, declarer won the first trick with his club ace and cashed the heart ace, "dropping" West's queen.
Worried that East had four trumps, South immediately ran the diamond 10. East kept up the good defense, ducking his king. Suddenly fooled, South repeated the diamond finesse, but East won with the king and gave his partner a diamond ruff.
West cashed the club queen, and the heart jack was the fourth defensive trick.
Cool - but how did West know he could afford to play the heart queen? Well, if South had started with A-Jx-x of hearts, he would have played a heart to dummy's king and taken the trump finesse. So, when South started with the heart ace, East was marked with the jack. Dropping the queen was safe. Also, it couldn't mislead East, because South was marked with four hearts from the auction. (If South had opened one no-trump with five hearts, he would have drawn two rounds of trumps before taking the diamond finesse.)
However, remember, when trying a deceptive defense, be careful not to deceive your partner more than declarer.

title: Commissioners of Oxford table voting resolution
author: Maggie Trovato

Commissioners of Oxford table voting resolution

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 OXFORD — Although at the start of a Commissioners of Oxford discussion Tuesday Commission President Norm Bell recommended the commissioners vote that evening on a resolution to clarify the town's voting registration requirements, the commissioners tabled the resolution in a two to one vote."In order to get this right, I think we need more time," Commissioner Katrina Greer said. "I think it would be better to do nothing and write some rules for the election committee, which we can do without a charter change."
The now tabled resolution would amend the town's charter to clarify a person must register with the Talbot County Board of Elections to qualify as a voter in the town. This means a resident would not be able to vote in Oxford town elections if they aren't registered with the county board.
Before the vote was taken, Bell expressed concern that if the resolution is not voted on at the meeting, it could be delayed to the point where, if the resolution is passed, it is not in effect for the town's upcoming election in June when Commissioner Tom Costigan's term is set to expire.
But Bell, who ultimately voted in favor of tabling the resolution, acknowledged the commissioners should not rush into making amendments to the charter regarding voting.
At a public hearing for the resolution Feb. 25, residents shared thoughts on who should and shouldn't be considered eligible to vote in town elections. The discussion, which opened the doors to potential additional charter amendments, led commissioners to hold a work session March 5.
Greer said the work session brought a lot of input, and she said there were still a lot of questions.
"I do not want to pass this in a rush tonight," she said Tuesday.
Costigan, the only commissioner to vote against tabling the resolution, said he felt the resolution addressed a "flaw" in the charter's verbiage.
"All that it did was recognize that the Talbot County system was the most logical way to assure that people are eligible and can vote," he said, adding that the concerns around who is eligible to vote would need to be addressed in another section of the charter.
After the resolution was tabled, Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan suggested the commissioners write rules for the Oxford Election Board regarding registration, absentee ballots and poll watching.
"The last election we had a livestream for individuals to watch," she said. "If you're going to follow that process again, we should have something established."
Greer said they should hold a work session on the matter, and Bell agreed that a work session should be scheduled.

title: Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton has been and is blessed with an extraordinarily number of exceptionally talented individuals engaged in a wide range of community service endeavors.One of them is Rabbi Peter Hyman DD (Doctor of Divinity) who is retiring in October after serving 18 years as the first full-time rabbi at Easton's Temple B'nai Israel.
Rabbi Hyman has a long history in walking his talk on promoting greater understanding of and respect for individuals with different religious beliefs and different faith journeys.
There is no more enduring symbol of Rabbi Hyman's commitment to respect for other religious beliefs than a Persian rug he bought in Israel 40 years ago. It is now on display in his office. That rug includes 99 names of God in Arabic. Rabbi Hyman views it as a metaphorical bridge connecting people of different faiths.
He once asked the leaders of a mosque if they could help him translate some of the Arabic words on his rug. They did so, amazed that such an inclusive rug was owned and displayed by a rabbi.
For Rabbi Hyman, it was simply his belief that "building relationships not only creates friendships, but they also cement ties."
A partial list of his local efforts to improve the quality of life in our community and beyond, includes serving as a member, program vice president and president of the Talbot Association of Clergy and Laity. He received an Award of Appreciation for Outstanding and Inspiring Interfaith Work in Talbot County for a Temple B'nai Israel February Lecture Series: "Introduction to Islam."
He was a recipient of the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and a recipient of a Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award. He was a member of The Frederick Douglass Celebration Committee and delivered the sermon at the Community Interfaith Worship Celebration, which was a part of the "Douglass Returns" statue dedication.
An author and teacher, he served as a presenter and instructor at Chesapeake College's Institute for Adult Learning and collaborated with Bishop Joel Marcus Johnson to launch a "Downtown Lunch and Learn" program. He was elected to the board of directors at the YMCA of the Chesapeake and appointed chair of the board at the Easton YMCA.
Support for Scouting has been a huge part of Rabbi Hyman's life since he earned his Eagle Scout award, as did his two sons. That is an achievement that has been earned by only 6% of all Scouts since 1912.
He has served as a scoutmaster and a chaplain at Scout World Jamborees in Thailand, England, Sweden and Japan and a National Jamboree in the United States. He was the first national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA, after having served as a national chair of the Jewish Committee on Scouting and as national Jewish chaplain — Boy Scouts of America. He was the keynote speaker at a national annual meeting of the BSA "Duty to God Breakfast" in Washington, D.C.
He is a recipient of the Silver Buffalo Award for distinguished service to youth awarded by the National Council of Boy Scouts of America. He is also a recipient of the Bronze Wolf Award, which is the Scouts' highest honor. It is presented by the World Scout Committee to recognize the service, commitment and contributions of volunteers to the Scout movement. Not surprisingly Hyman received the award for his interfaith activities and his lifelong commitment to "building bridges between people and nations."
Rabbi Hyman represented the BSA in Saudi Arabia at Saudi Nation Day when they received an award for the work of the BSA with the Messengers of Peace Program. This program promotes service projects through social media in effort to achieve world peace.
Hyman recalls that trip as the most amazing experience of his life because he was welcome in a Muslim country.
While the news of Rabbi Hyman's impending retirement is bittersweet, there is some good news.
He is not planning to leave the Eastern Shore.
Whether he stays here for the short term or long term, one thing is certain. He has made countless selfless contributions to help make Easton, Talbot County, and our world a better place.
Each one of them has earned Rabbi Hyman a well-deserved thank you and Godspeed.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant based in Easton.

title: Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With less than two weeks until the Talbot County Council adopts its budget ordinance for next fiscal year, education funding hangs in the balance.Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million in additional funds for fiscal year 2026 — $600,000 to fill nine new positions and $500,000 for teacher and staff salary increases. The former would add to the district's multilingual and special education staff, while the latter aims to inch the district closer to state-mandated $60,000 teacher salary minimums by fiscal year 2027.
District leaders say it's a "scaled-back" request from its $5.7 million ask of the county earlier this budget cycle.
"We recognize the financial pressures you face," Board of Education President Emily Jackson said at a May 6 budget hearing. "This ask is lean, deliberate and rooted in what's most necessary to keep moving forward."
In the county's budget already is $55 million for TCPS as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council members are left to mull the best option as they prepare to vote on final amendments to the county's draft $161 million budget. So far, there's no clear decision.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher supported fulfilling the district's full $5.7 million request last month and maintained that stance for the pared down ask at a budget deliberation Tuesday.
"We're going to have to do it sooner or later," Lesher said. "I think it makes sense to do it this year and reduce the pain next year."
President Chuck Callahan said he feels comfortable with honoring the $600,000 part of the request to cover the new positions.
Council members Keasha Haythe, Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp have all indicated they need more time to consider options.
Any additional funding granted would result in an education supplement to the property tax rate, which is 79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
Talbot County is already mandated by the state to pay $440,000 for teachers' pensions, which will be collected through a supplement of less than half a cent per $100 of assessed value.
Three potential scenarios for tax supplements have been laid out by county staff:
Teachers' pensions only: 0.0045 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $500,000 for salary increases: 0.0096 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $600,000 for new positions: 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value.
Haythe said Tuesday she's trying to balance helping the school system with preventing tax increases for residents on fixed income, such as seniors.
"I am in no way, shape or form trying to discount the great work that the school system does and what the teachers do in the classroom," Haythe said.
At last week's hearing, teachers and parents advocated for the council to include the $1.1 million. Lisa Hayes, a parent of three TCPS graduates, said past education investments are paying off now as her children enter the workforce.
"You cannot not fund a budget for our children's education because there is nothing more important than that," Hayes said.
Andy Burke, president of the Talbot County Education Association, which functions as the teachers' union, made his case.
"We continue to see too many educators migrate away to the higher wages and salaries paid in neighboring public school systems," Burke said.
In an emailed statement, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district made "very difficult choices" to reduce its request to the county.
Jones noted staff will present the Board of Education with a budget amendment package in June, which will adjust the $86 million unrestricted budget the board OK'd in February.
"We will eliminate most of the new positions we had requested," Jones wrote. "We will scale back our requests and defer programs that will have the least direct impact on our goals for our students."
A final decision by the county on the $1.1 million in question, as well as the entire FY26 budget, is expected at the council's May 27 meeting.
While no clear choice was made during Tuesday's deliberations, county and district leaders did agree that state mandates and formulas are creating the tricky fiscal situation.
"It's just become screamingly clear that there's a disconnect at the state level between the requirements that they're putting on local schools across the state, and the funding formulas that are articulated to county governments to pay for their education," said County Manager Clay Stamp.

 I don't believe in any of the superstitiousnonsense? thatseemsto be going aroundthese days. Some people have a fear of numbers like 13 and 666. What in the wor l ddoes anumberhavetodowith anything?Not being superstitious, there are times I am slightly confused about life. Something happens that I don't feel I'm in charge of.For example, the other morning, the gracious mistresslof the parsonage entered the living room, where I was sitting on myl easy chair drinking coffee. With alhuge smile, she said, "I got you an apple fritter for this morning." And she gave it to me, smiled at me and then walked away.The following day, I got up and got my coffee, went out to my easy chair in the living room, and started to sip it very carefully.As I was getting situated, the gracious mistress of the parsonage walked in, and I saw in her hand another apple fritter.Again, I got up the following day, went and got my coffee, and sat in my easy chair. In a few mo me nts, in walks lthe grfccio Bs mistress of the parsonage, and in her hand is another apple fritter."Here's an apple fritter for you this morning. I think you'll enjoy it today." She smiled at me, turned around, and returned to the kitc hen.It's not that I can't handle an apple fritter because I can. It's the fact that someone is bringing these apple fritters to me who does not like apple fritters. Something is happening behind the scenes, and I'm anxious to find o ut.The next day, the same thing happened. Now I'm getting to be suspicious. What in the world am I missing here?Not wanting to sabotage my good luck the last four days, I kept silent and enjoyed the fritter. Whatever is behind this, I may never know, but I w ill enjoy it for whatever it is worth.I couldn't help thinking of a Bible verse, "And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not" (Galatians 6:9).Sometimes, the best thing to do is NOTHING and let God have it.Dr. James L. title: Said before, but rarely
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Said before, but rarely

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 10A | Section: News

 Who wrote: "Nothing has yet been said that's not been said before."?Today's critical suit combination has appeared in print before, but only rarely. Most players get it wrong. Without peeking at the East-West hands, how would you play the club suit for at most one loser in notrump?North's sequence showed four hearts, at least five clubs and game-going values or more. He announced the "or more" when leaping to six no-trump on round three.South starts with 10 top tricks: two spades, four hearts, two diamonds and two clubs. Clearly, he can afford one club loser but not two. All plays work if the missing clubs are divided 3-2. So you must maximize your chances against a 4-1 break.It looks normal to play the club king and another club, winning when East has the singleton nine, jack or queen.However, there is a better play. You should win the diamond lead with dummy's ace and immediately call for the club 10! If East plays the two or three, you play low. If East plays the nine or an honor, you win with the king and return a club, planning to cover West's card.This line works whenever East has the singleton nine, jack or queen, and when West has the singleton nine.The opening sentence was penned by Terence, a second-century B.C.Roman comic poet who wrote in remarkably pure Latin. What I would like to know is: Who said it before Terence? ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: celebrity profile - Julianne Moore
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
celebrity profile - Julianne Moore

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: Someone told me that Julianne Moore started her career on a soap opera. Is that true?A: Yes two of them, in fact. Her earliest professional credit is "The Edge of Night," on which she appeared for several episodes in 1984. Soon afterward, she joined "As the World Turns," playing the dual roles of Frannie Hughes and her look-alike relative Sabrina. She earned a Daytime Emmy Award for her work on that show, which she did continuously from 1985 to 1988; she then made a return appearance in 2010.
Moore began doing primetime TV parts during her "As the World Turns" run, notably opposite Valerie Bertinelli in the 1987 miniseries "I'll Take Manhattan," then she was hired for TV-movies including "Money, Power, Murder" and "The Last to Go." Around the same time, she also moved into theatrical films with "Tales From the Darkside: The Movie" and "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," and that became her principal venue from the early 1990s forward, with her eventual win of an Academy Award for best actress for "Still Alice" (2014).
After doing guest stints along the way on "Saturday Night Live" and "Sesame Street," Moore made a particularly significant return to TV by playing former Alaska governor and vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin in the 2012 HBO project "Game Change." She won a Primetime Emmy Award for the dramatization of the 2008 election season, with Ed Harris playing Sen. John McCain, who chose Palin as his running mate

title: Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.91 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland.Prices in Maryland are 26.5 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 18.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.472 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.63 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.16 per gallon.
The falling prices may be coming to an end.
"As we edge closer to the end of the year, we're seeing momentum for falling gas prices weaken, which is typical as the national average generally bottoms out between Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising back above $70 last week, gas prices may have less potential to drop much further, though there may be a second window of lower prices in January or February in some areas, but even that won't last long."
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.98 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.5 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 7.1 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Dec. 16, 2023: $3.10 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.05 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2022: $3.18 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.13 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2021: $3.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.32 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2020: $2.34 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.20 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2019: $2.45 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2018: $2.33 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.36 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2017: $2.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.43 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2016: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.23 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2015: $2.02 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.01 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2014: $2.63 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.51 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.84 per gallon, down 5.5 cents per gallon from last week's $2.90 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.15 per gallon, down 0.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.00 per gallon, down 6.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.06 per gallon.
"While several states saw gas prices cycle last week, marked by a big jump in prices after a large decline, those that did see hefty jumps should see prices drift a bit lower, potentially making a second run at the season's lowest prices," De Haan said. "The West Coast, including California, should continue to see prices drift lower, but with just a few weeks left in 2024, all attention turns to 2025. GasBuddy's 2025 Fuel Outlook, among the nation's most accurate fuel price forecasts, will be released in the coming weeks, offering motorists a glimpse into gas prices for the coming year."

 On Oct. 2, 1967, Thurgood Marshall joined the U.S. Supreme Court at its first African American justice; he would serve on the bench for 24 years until his retirement in 1991.Also on this date:
In 1919, President Woodrow Wilson had a serious stroke at the White House that left him paralyzed on his left side.
In 1944, German troops crushed the 2-month-old Warsaw Uprising, during which a quarter of a million people were killed.
In 1970, one of two chartered twin-engine planes flying the Wichita State University football team to Utah crashed into a mountain near Silver Plume, Colorado, killing 31 of the 40 people on board.
In 2006, an armed milk truck driver took a group of girls hostage in an Amish schoolhouse in Nickel Mines, Pennsylvania, killing five of them and wounding five others before taking his own life.
In 2016, Hall of Fame baseball broadcaster Vin Scully signed off for the last time, ending 67 years behind the mic for the Dodgers as he called a 7-1 loss to the Giants in San Francisco.
In 2018, journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed by Saudi Arabian officials at the Saudi Embassy in Istanbul, Turkey.

title: Kids show their skills at the Talbot County Fair
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Kids show their skills at the Talbot County Fair

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Fair celebrated its 41st annual event this week. Hundreds of residents came together to experience the various activities put together by organizers, volunteers and sponsors.The five-day celebration included events such as fashion shows, games, bouncy castles and vendors. Many of these events were hosted for young people with an interest in leadership, community service, arts and agriculture.
The opening ceremony was held on Thursday evening, kids held flags at the center of the Main Show Ring, Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) presented a citation of recognition to organizers of the fair and John Coleman, officer from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, sang "God Bless America."
Linda Brown, host of the opening ceremony, said in the past, Talbot County had to share its fair with other counties because of how small the county was. Today, Brown is proud of the work that the community does to make the fair possible.
"The big thing about this fair is that our community comes together," Brown said. "(I) couldn't count the volunteers that come and do their piece. It could be shavings in a cow barn so that we can have animals. It could be taking a leaf blower and blowing the leaves out of our pavilion. Everybody just jumps in and works together to put on this amazing fair."
Brown said she is proud of the work done by children and young people across the county, which was on full display at the fair.
This included the work of her granddaughter Annette Clougherty, who brought three of her cows for show this year.
Clougherty, 12, said she has deep love for animals and hopes to one day become a veterinarian. Her cows, Reba, Andy and Dolly huddled near a giant fan to cool off from the hot weather.
Clougherty encourages any kid who has an interest in animals to raise the animal of their choice and bring them to a local fair.
"Do your research, learn and don't just chase your dreams so you can get the money and be done with it," she said. "Actually get into it because these guys (her cows), I don't ever imagine them going to the market, they're always mine in my heart."
Clougherty is proud to announce that she is taking her cows to Queen Anne's Fair, which is a big step for her family.
In a different stall, Bailei Caldeira, a young pig farmer, brushed her two pigs before a showing. It is her second year showing her pigs, and she said she is better prepared to make an impression. Caldeira said she has always loved pigs.
When asked what advice she would give to kids who would like to raise pigs, she said working hard is the key to caring for pigs.
"Don't be scared, just do it," Caldeira said. "Don't care about anyone else. Just care about your pig and you."
Following the animal showing, dozens of kids from all age groups showcased their self-created outfits during the Talbot County 4-H Fashion Show.
The 4-H program is a local club teaching kids new skills, such as sewing, photography and more. Each kid had a moment to shine as dozens of parents took photos and cheered for their stylish outfits.
Brown, a former home economics teacher, said she was so proud of all the work that the young contestant did for this year's show. For her, as host of the fashion show, she is impressed by the 27 outfits being modeled in the show and the work of the volunteers who make the event possible.
"It's just a culmination of hundreds of people working together and everybody doing their part in order to come up with this little event," Brown said. "We are not a big state fair. We don't have squeaky rides and all that. We're not big enough, but we have people in the community that just come out and enjoy, socialize, marvel at what the kids are doing."

title: Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1895
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Holy Land war between Israel and Hamas is birthing increased police and government surveillance of social media, prompting calls for more Americans to report "hate crimes" and proposals to require all social media accounts to have public name verifications amid concerns about increases in antisemitism and terrorism threats.There are also pushes to deport some anti-war, pro-Palestinian foreign college students deemed supportive of U.S. designated terror groups and expel and ban Palestinian refugees from entering the country.The efforts are born out of security concerns stemming from U.S. support for Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 terror attacks. But they are also sparking concerns about stunting or intimating dissent, privacy and other free speech protections.There is also a new social media battle over Twitter/X owner Elon Musk's support for a social media post that talked about anti-white sentiments among "Jewish communities." A number of major media and technology advertisers, who also compete with social media platforms and some of Musk's technology ventures, have paused advertising on X. That includes Disney (which owns ABC and ESPN), Apple, Paramount Global (which owns CBS and Comedy, IBM, Comcast/NBC Universal (which owns NBC and MSNBC) and Warner Bros/Discovery (which owns CNN).Musk said he agreed with a post from a Twitter who said "Jewish communities have been pushing the exact kind of dialectical hatred against whites that they claim to want people to stop using against them." "You said the actual truth," Musk said in a reply Nov. 15, latter adding that his concurrence was geared toward progressive activist groups and the Anti-Defamation League.The Biden administration condemned Musk's statement Friday. "We condemn this abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate in the strongest terms," the U.S. administration said in statement drawing parallels to the beliefs of the Robert Bowers, who faces the death penalty after the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh left 11 congregants dead.The ADL on Nov. 16 also criticized Musk. "it is indisputably dangerous to use one's influence to validate and promote antisemitic theories, said ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblalt, who on Friday then praised Musk for his condemnation of pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas phrases 'from the river to the sea' and 'decolonization.' Musk said Saturday some of the critics are dangerously using the episode to squelch free speech and that. he plans on suing progressive activists he claims inaccurately showed neo-Nazi and antisemitic posts next to Twitter/X advertisers' promotions."I am sticking to my principles. As for any fake advocacy groups who seek to suppress free speech, they should remember that karma is real," Musk said on his social media platform.EXPELLING FOREIGN COLLEGE STUDENTSThere is a GOP push to expel foreign college students deemed to be supporting Hamas, Hezbollah and other groups on the U.S. government's list of terrorist groups.A group of 21 GOP attorneys general - including Ashley Moody of Florida and Austin Knudsen of Montana - want the federal government to "vigorously renew vetting of foreign students' and deport those deemed to have endorsed or provided "material support to foreign terrorist organizations." "It is possible that renewed vetting of foreign students already admitted to the United States may reveal activity that renders them ineligible to hold a student visa and liable to deportation," Knudsen, Moody and their cohorts wrote in a letter Nov. 8 to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the U.S.Department of Education.Free speech and civil liberties advocates say the reactions to anti-Israel war protests (some of which have seen antisemitic rhetoric) can bleed into censorship as well as quieting and punishing voices of dissent."Free speech means protecting speech you don't like. Sometimes it even means protecting speech you find abhorrent and hateful," said U.S. Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Kentucky, after voting against censure measure aimed at U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan, over her anti-Israel rhetoric and use of a pro-Hamas slogan.BANNING PALESTINIAN REFUGEESA group of congressional Republicans - including U.S. Reps. Andy Thomas, who represents the Eastern Shore, along with U.S. Reps. Ryan Zinke of Montana and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, are also leading efforts to keep Palestinian refugees from the war out of the U.S. Zinke, Harris and Greene also wants to kick out Palestinians who entered the country on or after Oct. 1 in the aftermath of the Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that sparked the war in Gaza.They say said he does not trust the Biden administration or Palestinian authorities to adequately screen potential refugees.Critics say the proposal is xenophobic.Similar sentiments related to refugees and college students have been echoed by 2024 GOP presidential candidates such as former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has suspended pro-Palestinian students' groups in his home state deemed extremist and favored restrictions on public library and school curricula content deemed inappropriate or offensive.While conservatives press universities, who have sometimes aggressively banned right-wing voices from their campuses, to condemn and crackdown on pro-Palestinian student protesters, the American Civil Liberties Union wants them to uphold free speech principles."It is precisely in times of heightened crisis and fear that university leaders must remain steadfast in their commitment to free speech, open debate, and peaceful dissent on campus.These principles are the bedrock of academic freedom at all universities," the ACLU said in a statement."The First Amendment protects all people who live in this country, whether they're here as citizens, foreign nationals, or visitors," the civil liberties group said.ENCOURAGING MORE HATE CRIME REPORTINGDaines and a bipartisan senators including U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, have also recently written to FBI Director Christopher Wray and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security asking for more investigative and enforcement resources to be dedicated to addressing antisemitism.The Anti-Defamation League reports a 300% increase in anti-Jewish threats, vandalism and violence since the start of the war, which has seen more than 1,400 Israelis and more than 11,000 Gazans killed.In a separate letter, U.S. Sen Jon Tester, D-Montana, also said FBI and DHS efforts should also be focused on white supremacists echoing past and current Biden administration efforts to go after alt-right groups.The Biden White House, which has put a focus on going after right-wing groups since taking office in 2021, has also launched a new task force to go after "Islamophobia" during the war.On Tuesday, the FBI said it added Oregon to a nationwide effort aimed at encouraging getting more Americans to report "hate incidents' ' with billboards posted in Eugene, Medford and Corvallis as well as digital signs at Portland International Airport.Similar hate crime billboards have been put up across the country, including last month in North Carolina, along with ads on public transit systems, social media platforms and local media outlets.Last month, the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI released new data showing there was a 7.3% increase in reported hate crimes in 2022 (11,634 cases versus 10,840) in 2021.There were more than 6,500 racially motivated incidents - 52% of them aimed at Blacks - and more than 2,000 cases related to religion - with 55% targeting Jews, according to DOJ.SOCIAL MEDIA SURVEILLANCE, FORCED VERIFICATIONSA state law in Montana backed by Knudsen and GOP Gov.Greg Gianforte banning Chinese-owned social media app TikTok is also one of the central fronts in efforts to restrict social media platforms and content.Montana lawmakers worry about TikTok's data security and ties to the Chinese government.The ban is being mirrored in other states.The Montana prohibition is being challenged by TikTok and free speech advocates in court.But there are also other efforts to increase government regulations and scrutiny and law enforcement surveillance of social media.New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said Nov. 13 that state police have ramped up social media surveillance and will reach out more to individuals and groups posting hate speech online."We're very focused on the data we're collecting from surveillance efforts. What's being said on social media platforms.And we have launched an effort to be able to counter some of the negativity. and reach out to people when we see hate speech being spoken about on online platforms," Hochul said. "Our media analysis, our social media analysis unit, has ramped up its monitoring of sites to catch incitement to violence; direct threats to others." The New York governor said the rise in extremist and violent threats after the start of the war in the Middle East "poses a clear and present danger." But the idea of more aggressive police surveillance of social media posts raises some concerns.Gerard Kassar, chairman of the New York Conservative Party, said police social media monitoring is potentially "chilling to the core"."Law enforcement authorities can and should monitor legitimate terrorism suspects online, but spying on everyday citizens is unconstitutional and wrong," Kassar said.Republican presidential candidate and former South Carolina governor and U.S. ambassador Nikki Haley wants to require all social media accounts be verified by name thus eliminating anonymous online speech on major platforms."Every person on social media should be verified by their name," said Haley, who is increasingly being promoted as an establishment and neoconservative 2024 alternative to former president Donald Trump."First of all, it's a national security threat. When you do that, all of a sudden people have to stand by what they say. And it gets rid of the Russian bots, the Iranian bots and the Chinese bots. And then you're going to get some civility when people know their name is next to what they say, and they know their pastor and their family members are going to see it," Haley told Fox News.Haley also backs a TikTok ban pointing to the recent viral traffic of a letter criticizing Israel and the U.S. from Osama Bin Laden.Harris told Fox News Nov. 16 that Congress could soon take some actions related to TikTok and the issue will come down to speech versus national security, citing the platform's Chinese ownership.The verification push sparked a backlash from free speech advocates, particularly on the right who have already been upset over social media bans and content restrictions over coronavirus vaccines and challenges to the 2020 election results.They say it will eliminate anonymous dissent and speech."Nikki Haley is 'openly' pushing for the government to use private tech companies to censor speech. This is a flagrant violation of the Constitution and straight out of the Democrats' playbook.Any politician who thinks it's OK for the government to use the private sector as its censorship bureau shouldn't be allowed anywhere near the White House," said Vivek Ramaswamy, who has frequently sparred with Haley over TikTok and other issues.

title: Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 722
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Pioneers in Talbot County's advanced life support services gathered this week to reminisce on the 40-year anniversary of their revolutionary effort to improve emergency response on the Mid-Shore.Five Easton firefighters began volunteering to man a new advanced life support, or ALS, program on Aug. 13, 1985. They had just one vehicle from the fire department. They sacrificed time at home and kept up constant communication to ensure someone was ready to respond to a cardiac emergency at any given moment.
The "first five," as they're often called, were Wayne Dyott, Kevin Knussman, Marc Stockley, Ray Taylor and the late Gary Jones.
Wednesday afternoon inside the Harrison's Harbour Lights restaurant in St. Michaels, the four men shared laughs and memories of the effort they spearheaded four decades ago to the day.
"It was quite a haul," Stockley recalled. "And unfortunately, in the past five years, I've been able to use this (ALS) system several times. And seeing the changes. It's been interesting to see the advancements. The care level is always there."
They were joined by others integral to the early success and soon-to-come expansion of paramedic services in Talbot County: Margie Callahan, then-nurse coordinator at Easton Memorial Hospital, and Buddy Harrison IV, former County Council president and the first director of Talbot County Advanced Life Support.
They all took time to reflect on Jones' integral role in the effort.
Jones, former director of cardiovascular services at the Easton hospital, died in 2021. Dyott said Jones joined the fire company in the 1980s knowing the ALS program was about to kick off.
"Ultimately, he was a good bridge between hospital staff, them accepting us and bringing the whole program together," Stockley said.
'SKEPTICISM AT FIRST'
Jones and others worked to show people the importance of pre-hospital cardiac care and why countywide ALS services were needed.
A half-decade ago, response times for heart emergencies could sometimes be 20 to 30 minutes. First responders typically reported to the fire station, then traveled to the location of the emergency.
Taylor said it was hard at first for fire companies to even accept EMTs back in the 1970s. The five men, certified as cardiac rescue technicians, aimed to change that.
"We kept hearing the same thing: 'you're not doctors, you don't need to play doctor on the ambulance,'" Taylor said.
Fire department and hospital leaders eventually warmed up to the ALS program, Taylor said. It didn't come without questions from the community, Stockley noted.
"I think there was skepticism at first, but I think it came around eventually when they started seeing positive results," he said.
On Wednesday, Taylor recalled what may have been the first of those positive outcomes. In 1985, he and Dyott rode in the ALS vehicle to the scene of an overturned truck and a man lying down. Taylor successfully defibrillated the man, and that began to turn heads in the right direction.
"It's a good feeling," Taylor recalled.
IMPACT FELT TODAY
Since 1985, the modest five-person, volunteer venture in Easton has transformed to a countywide staple. The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services operates six ALS units and one "chase vehicle" for rapid response. Over 50 paramedics and EMTs staff the units, some full-time and others volunteers.
The hard work of the original five was done with the hope of having a comprehensive system like the one that exists today, Dyott said.
"That's what we started. That was our goal, our ambition," he said.
Tina Kintop, Talbot's EMS division chief, said the division's current success and bandwidth wouldn't be possible without those pioneers. Crews responded to around 6,800 calls last year, she noted.
"We are better prepared and educated more than ever in the life-saving business," Kintop wrote. "Thank you to the visionaries 40 years ago and to those advancing ahead today."
Callahan similarly credits the first five for persevering through the doubts and paramedic funding struggles in 1985 and the years after.
"They were a part of seeing this all come to fruition," she said.
Over the last 40 years, it has always been about saving lives, said Talbot County's original ALS leaders. Knussman said all the vehicle swaps and early morning phone calls were well worth it.
"I think all of us would agree that the people on the street today are better trained, better educated, better equipped and better organized," Knussman said. "That's something that all four of us, and Gary if he were here, that's something to be proud of."

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — J.R. Dobson grew up around the fire house, always knowing he wanted to be a firefighter.In his teenage years, Dobson joined the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company as a junior cadet, and by 16 he began riding the fire trucks. He fondly recalls the "everybody knew everybody" aspect of the tight-knit community.
Dobson eventually moved to Easton, beginning his journey with the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in 2003. Over time, he's served in a number of roles, including most recently, assistant chief.
Now he's taking on the department's top role for the first time. Dobson was elected the department's chief in December.
With a wife and two daughters, timing was everything for Dobson when considering the commitment to assume a role as demanding as Easton fire chief. The timing is right, he said, and he's looking forward to leading and making a difference.
"There's a lot of tradition here," Dobson said. "It's certainly the biggest department in the county. It's got probably the most going on out of all the departments in the county. I think just being here, seeing how this department operates versus a small department. It's a business. And we're all here for free, none of us get paid."
Dobson officially began as chief this month. Sonny Jones just wrapped up his third two-year term leading the department.
Dobson, who volunteers at the fire department as all the firefighters do, is a patrol and operations commander at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. He believes his experience leading around 35 deputies across multiple divisions will translate to his duties in the fire house.
"I think that I bring a lot of management skills, leadership skills," Dobson said. "Just from my experience there, I think it helps you here."
Thus far, Dobson says the support he's received has been "overwhelming."
Past fire chiefs have reached out, and he hopes to pick up one thing from each of them to set himself up for success. For instance, Jones' ability as an incident commander is something Dobson admires.
"If there were ever a bad day anybody was having, he's who you would want there," Dobson said of Jones. "Just the way he kind of rolls through an incident scene. He's been there and done that kind of thing."
Similarly, Jones — who is remaining involved with the department — spoke highly of Dobson.
"I've known J.R. the entire time that I've been a member of the Easton fire department," Jones said. "J.R. is a first-rate guy. He's a terrific leader. He has many, many qualities which will bode well for him as the chief of the department."
Some of the ongoing projects the new fire chief has his eye on include purchasing a utility vehicle to use for Rails to Trails and woods fires, buying a new engine and updating box alarm assignments. He also wants to implement some new standard operating procedures.
Dobson said he hopes to nail down a handful of tasks for the year and keep circling back to see what progress is being made. At the top of his list is recruitment and retention of volunteers.
"I think it all starts with recruiting. I think it all starts with retention," Dobson said. "Those are things that we've done well in the past, although the last year or so we haven't gotten as many members as we would like. And sometimes we'll get members in and they don't realize the commitment."
While acknowledging the town's consistent support of the department over the years, Dobson believes Easton Fire can do better in attracting more volunteers amid struggles statewide and nationwide to fill volunteer fire departments.
"We got to get people in here," Dobson said. "We've got to get these trucks out. And I think that the way the town's growing, if we don't grow with it, then we're failing ourselves."

title: Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUNIS MILLS — A beloved bridge in the Tunis Mills community is moving toward reconstruction after months of resident input into the bridge's redesign.In recent years, the 345-foot-long Leeds Creeks Bridge and its wood planks have deteriorated. County engineers consider the bridge structurally deficient, necessitating a replacement.
Tuesday, the Talbot County Council agreed to move forward with the bridge replacement project. County Engineer Ray Clarke recommended the county work toward finalizing rights-of-way acquisitions and necessary permits so construction can be pursued later this year.
As proposed, the replacement would include a wooden deck and a timber wearing surface. The structures below the bridge supporting it, known as piles, would consist of concrete and steel materials.
Clarke told council members that in order to use federal funding for the project, the bridge replacement project cannot use timber piles per the State Highway Administration. He added that trying to build an all-timber replacement will cause significant delays and costs.
"The big disadvantage we have is that if we don't get the federal aid, we're probably going to need to request the council for additional funding for the project, local funding," Clarke said. " … This could be a $3 or $4 million ask."
The project costs around $6.5 million, with $1.5 million coming from the county. The rest is federally funded.
Advocates of a 100% wooden replacement have been in dialogue with the county, including at an August public meeting. Susan McDermott and John Tabori, two of those advocates, have lived in Tunis Mills next to the bridge for four years.
McDermott says the original proposal to rebuild the bridge many years ago "was just unacceptable to the community." The county's recent proposal matches more of what she and some other neighbors had hoped for.
"We're very pleased that the council has shown as much flexibility toward community views as it has," McDermott said.
Residents like McDermott previously expressed concerns that an asphalt wearing surface would encourage speeding across the bridge. The county's plans now include a timber wearing surface. Clarke said that change will amount to around a $250,000 increase.
The other main change based on community feedback is a reduction in the height of the safety railing from 42 to 36 inches.
McDermott, who leads a small group of neighbors called the Tunis Mills All-Timber Bridge Alliance, hopes to find answers to whether an exception can be made for the requirement that piles not be timber.
She adds that the bridge is an integral part of the community.
"I think the town feels that the wooden bridge of Tunis Mills — one of the last wooden-deck bridges in the county — is very much part of the community," McDermott said. "It's not just a bridge that occasional traffic goes across. We've got a lot of walkers in this neighborhood, a lot of kids and people just use that bridge as a foot path."
After a video of the bridge was shown during the meeting, Talbot County Council Member Lynn Mielke said it seems the replacement "needs to be done sooner rather than later."
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked Clarke and his team for their efforts to advance the replacement project.
"I appreciate the homework that you've done to investigate the alternatives as requested and appreciate that we really can't sacrifice the federal aid," Lesher said. "The economics of this project dictate that we absolutely need to go with the recommended steel concrete pilings and concrete cap."
Lesher motioned to approve the project as presented, and the rest of the council unanimously agreed. Lesher added that he hopes the federal funding for the project comes through, referencing President Donald Trump's temporary pause on federal grants and loans announced earlier this week and rescinded Wednesday.
"And we'll just hope that any suspension of federal grant aid for transportation projects is very short-lived," Lesher said Tuesday.

title: Maryland House and Garden tour lets visitors explore Talbot County properties
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Maryland House and Garden tour lets visitors explore Talbot County properties

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Standing in the foyer of Canterbury Manor in Easton, one's eyes might dart straight out the window to the luscious green grounds that look out onto Trippe Creek.Or their eyes might be drawn to the estate's light and airy living room, which boasts a Steinway Piano from the 1920s, English furniture, and French and Dutch paintings. But no matter where the eye goes first, it's undeniable that it won't take long to feel drawn into the 1906 colonial revival style home.
For Easton resident Summer Parrish, it was the design of the kitchen — complete with French copper pots hanging above a big kitchen island — and the large but cozy-feeling butler's pantry.
"Oh my gosh," she said, talking about various parts of the house. "The flower arrangements that are in (the) sun porch and on the kitchen table are the most beautiful I've every seen in my entire life."
Canterbury Manor was the second home Parrish and her family members, including her sister and mother, toured on the Saturday of Mother's Day weekend. The Talbot County tour is part of the Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage, which was started in 1937. Proceeds go toward the preservation and restoration of historically significant properties in the state.
Parrish's mother, Hope Leuchter, said comparing the first home they visited — a 1928 two-and-a-half story central brick mansion called Ellenborough — to Canterbury Manor is like comparing apples and oranges.
"The first one has the most magnificent trees," Leuchter said. "And if you're crazy for trees and their botanical names and love their lore, that would have been it. Here (at Canterbury Manor), the artistry, the effectiveness of colors and choices. The home is beyond words beautiful."
Every two years, the pilgrimage brings Marylanders from all over the state to ooh and aah at historic architecture, grand gardens and fragrant floral arrangements in Talbot County. Most of the flowers in the arrangements are from the gardens of Talbot County Garden Club members.
The money raised from the Talbot County tour "by and large" stays in the county, Talbot tour co-chair Kim Eckert said. This year, the Talbot County Garden Club, which organizes the tour, chose to put proceeds toward Scotts United Methodist Church and St. Paul's Episcopal Church, both in Trappe.
"We wanted to focus on houses in Trappe, and we thought the best thing to do was to put the money back into Trappe," Eckert said.
The funds raised from the tour will go toward fully fixing and preserving both of the more than 250-year-old churches. Eckert said Lane Engineering and McHale Landscape Design both donated or discounted services to help make this possible. She said the Garden Club will even have some money left over to put toward other projects, such as the Talbot Historical Society gardens.
Along with Canterbury Manor and Ellenborough, tour-goers also had the opportunity to visit Easton's 219 S. Hanson St. and Trappe's Chloras Point Farm, Ferry Farm House, Trappe Landing Farm and Lloyds Landing.
"You get a really neat collection of Talbot County's homes, from the grand estates to the regular, beautiful farm homes," said Jack Thompson, executive director of the Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage.
At Lloyds Landing, an 18th century house on the Choptank River in Trappe, Sherwood resident Kevin Carnahan took in the history of the property. The house, erected between 1720 and 1730, is one of the only eight remaining structures from that era in the county.
"They all have a lot of history," Carnahan said about the four homes he had visited so far. "But this one in particular."
Montgomery County resident Lynn Konefal talked about the pieces of history in the house, like the old family photos hanging on the walls.
And even though it's one of the oldest structures in the county, Lloyds Landing was built with air conditioning and heat in mind, Eckert said.
"Based on how the roof is pitched and how it's located to the Choptank," she said. "It's mind-boggling to me that they designed all that in 1729."

 EASTON — The 53rd annual Waterfowl Festival officially began Thursday evening at the Tidewater Inn, where Megan Cook, mayor of Easton, was welcomed onstage to officially open the festival with the banging of the duck gavel.This three-day festival welcomes thousands of waterfowl enthusiasts to Talbot County each year to appreciate local wildlife, art, heritage, food and community.
Throughout the Thursday evening ceremony, citations were given to organizers of the festival, longtime volunteers were honored for their service and a featured artist unveiled new work.
The ceremony began with opening remarks by Eric Milhollan, president of the executive board for the Waterfowl Festival. He welcomed all attendees, recognizing them for joining the festival and supporting conservation efforts.
In his speech, Milhollan shared his long history with the festival. Beginning with volunteering with his father and later becoming involved with his own family as an adult, Milhollan shared his pride for the countless families who have long-standing traditions of volunteering for the festival.
"I'm proud to have my oldest son cheering for the second year. He's joined by his two brothers and sister, all coming home from college to help for the weekend at the festival that's been part of my life and my family's life," Milhollan said. "I believe in the crowd and see that many who have similar stories in passing the tradition of the festival to their families. This is what allows us to celebrate 53 years."
Throughout the evening, several people were honored, including a memoriam for Kim Perry Whiteley and Hall of Fame presentations for Blenda Armistead, Ron Flohr and Butch Townsend. A waterfowl statue was unveiled by this year's Waterfowl Festival Featured Artist Ronnie Wells.
As Cook held the opening gavel in her hand, she looked to the leaders of the Waterfowl Festival, and they all smiled.
"Are we ready? All right, we're ready. Let's go," Cook said before banging the duck-shaped gavel against the podium and officially opening the Waterfowl Festival's 53rd year of celebration.

title: Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor
content:
Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor | Section: News 
 
 449

 Megan Cook, Russ Nelson and Ann Groves Lloyd are mayors of small towns in Maryland, Montana and Wisconsin.Nelson has been the mayor of Belgrade, Montana, for 20 years.
Karen Rose has been with Sarasota County Schools in Florida for more than three decades serving as a special education teacher, middle school principal and since 2020 on the local school board.
Over their tenures, the quartet and local officials across the country have seen the exponential growth of social media and its impacts on civil discourse, as well as the increasing intersections between divisive national politics and what's happening at the community level.
School board, city council and county commission meetings have all become venues for fights over controversial curriculums and books, COVID rules, drag shows at public libraries and national issues with advocates from the left and right looking for local debates on immigration, abortion and Israel's war in Gaza.
Rose said public comments at school board meetings can be very political and very partisan. "It's very organized," Rose said.
Social media, with its expansive reach, along with online meetings allow more residents and businesses to engage with and keep tabs on local governments and schools. That can also help bring more transparency to city halls, local law enforcement and school districts.
"The more information that we share with the public about what's happening in town, the better. We also have a live feed for all of our council, board and commission meetings. If residents aren't able to make it, they can always watch the recordings from our website," said Cook, mayor of Easton.
But social media also magnifies broader contemporary distrust of the media, government, politicians and other institutions. It can also bring rumor mills and coarse discourse.
"From a city perspective, we just wish people would pick up the phone and call us. We are constantly fighting the rumor mill," said Groves Lloyd, mayor of Lodi, Wisconsin (a small town near Madison).
Groves Lloyd identifies herself as a "progressive feminist" and "small town mayor" on her X/Twitter account where she is no fan of former president Donald Trump. But the Wisconsin mayor said she's pulled back on her progressive posts, especially on Facebook, because of the atmosphere of social media.
In Montana, Nelson, the mayor of Belgrade (which has a population approaching 13,000 people), worries all the political tensions at the local level discourages candidates for office and shortens tenures for staff and officeholders. He avoids social media altogether.
"I'm not on Facebook. I'm not on social media," said Nelson. "You can call me, or if you need me, you can text me. That's my technology."
For a more expansive look at the issue check out our story online and in our national e-edition on Monday, March 11.

title: Excellent customer service
content:
Excellent customer service

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Letters
