 Words 

 Read News Document

 My wife and I were born and raised in Baltimore. We are in our mid 70s and since our childhood we have always vacationed on the Eastern Shore. Twenty years ago we relocated to Northeast, Tennessee, but still annually come back to the Eastern Shore to get our "seafood and steamed crab fix." However, I am writing to you not about your delicious food but about the kindness shown to us by Brent Spurry, owner of the Spurry Tire Company.Our story: We had just finished four glorious days in St. Michaels and while gassing up the car for the 450-mile return trip home, I noticed the valence (or mud guard) located under my front bumper was hanging down. Concerned that it would completely break away while on the highway, I began looking for a repair shop. It was Saturday, and I learned many repair shops were closed. In desperation I asked a kindly person tending our hotel's lawn for help. He directed me to the Spurry Tire Company on Elliot Road. He said be sure to ask for the owner, Brent Spurry.After a 20-minute ride including through picturesque downtown Easton, I arrived at the Spurry Tire Company. It was a larger business than I anticipated with six bays (all full) and maybe a dozen employees (all very busy). The waiting room was also full of customers which I thought didn't bode well for an out-of-state vehicle with a hanging mud-guard being repaired anytime soon.I reluctantly asked to see Brent Spurry and to my surprise he appeared within a minute. I related my story, and he said his bays were full but when one became available someone would take a look. I walked outside to ponder my next move (should I risk the trip home).Just then I heard a pleasant voice say "We are putting your car in an open bay.Ten minutes later same voice says "all fixed you're good to go." Surprised and grateful I asked, "What do I owe you?"[[---]] see the office was the reply. I return to the waiting room (it was even more crowded)."Hello, I'm Mr. Townsend, you folks were kind to fix my car, what do I owe you?" Nothing was the reply from the counter clerk. I said obviously this is a busy place but can I see Mr. Spurry?Within minutes Brent Spurry appeared. I thanked him and politely insisted that I pay him for the work.He smiled and said, "No charge" [[---]] even though I'm from out-of-state and he will likely never see me again [[---]] He said, "No charge." In a flash he returned to the shop. I turned to leave and said to the crowded waiting room that they were fortunate to have a Spurry Tire Company in their city.A lady remarked for all to hear "we know." I wrote this letter because I wanted others to know about Brent Spurry and his kindness and business practices.He is a perfect example of practicing excellent customer service even to someone from out-of-state.JERRY AND PEGGY TOWNSENDNortheast, Tennessee

title: Museum celebrates oysters at OysterFest

 ST. MICHAELS - The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum will celebrate the Bay's favorite bivalve at OysterFest on Saturday, Oct. 28, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.CBMM's OysterFest features oysters served a variety of ways, along with other local fare, craft beer, and spirits, plus live music on two stages, an oyster stew competition, a full schedule of demonstrations and presentations, children's activities, and more.Guests can savor Chesapeake Bay oysters, with both raw and cooked options available, from the Talbot Watermen Association and other local oyster farms.There will also be a variety of Chesapeake delicacies and other food offerings via local vendors available for purchase, plus a beverage selection that includes specialty cocktails and an array of local craft beer options.For OysterFest, guests will enter campus through CBMM's new Welcome Center, getting a first look at the new building overlooking Fogg's Cove and the chance to shop in the new Museum Store inside. (Please note that the exhibition spaces within the Welcome Center are not yet open to the public.)Purchase your tickets in advance now for this rain-or-shine event and learn more at cbmm.org/oysterfest.The always-popular oyster stew competition invites guests to sample offerings from various local restaurants and then vote for their favorite to decide which chefs will claim the coveted title.There will be live music on both sides of campus all day long, with stages on both the Tolchester Beach Bandstand and Fogg's Landing. Swamp Donkey Newgrass will be playing the historic bandstand, bringing its unique "newgrass" sound with a combination of genre-spanning original songs and covers to OysterFest for the fifth time.Guests can head to Van Lennep Auditorium throughout the day to hear from a variety of guest speakers sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center through the Maryland Traditions Program of the Maryland State Arts Council. The offerings include a series of panels related to CBMM's special exhibition The Changing Chesapeake and a history presentation from Dr. Clara Small.The American Chesapeake Club will be on hand to discuss Maryland's official dog, the Chesapeake Bay retriever, and showcase its retrieving ability, while the 100 Hundred Shores Project will offer the opportunity for guests to dye their own shirts using water from the Miles River.There's also an oyster slurp-off contest to add to the friendly competition, plus a wide range of Chesapeake-themed children's activities, including games, model boat building, and story time.Guests can get in the festive spirit by purchasing OysterFest gear in the new Museum Store, showcasing this year's featured historic oyster tin from CBMM's collection. The one-gallon tin, packed in the 1940s by W.E. Rigging & Co., out of Crisfield, Md., is emblazoned on shirts and stickers, as well as the commemorative mugs that will be used for the oyster stew competition.This year, OysterFest is generously sponsored by M&T Bank with support from Eastern Shore Tents & Events, Kelly Distributors, and What's Up Media.OysterFest admission is $7 for museum member adults and active and retired members of the military (with ID); $19 for non-member adults; $16 for seniors (ages 65 and up) and college students (with ID); $7 for non-member children ages 6-17; and free for member children 6-17, and all children 5 and under. CBMM members at the Family & Friends level and above can also receive the $7 discounted admission for two adult guests.Tickets can be purchased online in advance or at the gate the day of the festival. Additional free event parking will be available at St. Michaels Middle/High School, with a complimentary shuttle service to and from CBMM running throughout the day.Food and drinks are available for an additional cost, with carry-on alcohol prohibited. For safety reasons, non-service dogs need to be kept home during museum festivals, including OysterFest.

title: Time for DeSantis to rock and roll with Trump - COMMENTARY
content:
Time for DeSantis to rock and roll with Trump - COMMENTARY

 August 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: Opinions 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's certainly about time for Ron DeSantis, who remains the main challenger to front-runner Donald Trump, to stop pulling his punches.On the campaign trail this week, responding to the latest indictment, DeSantis came closer than usual. In answer to a reporter's question, he actually acknowledged, "All those theories that were put out did not prove to be true." In other words, they were false.In other words, the election was not stolen.How long will it take for him to come right out and say that?.And if the election wasn't stolen, what does that say about the effort to overturn it?.Storming the Capitol to overturn an election that wasn't stolen? What do you say about that? Based on "theories that were put out (that) did not prove to be true." What is striking about DeSantis' move, however modest, is that it came on the same day as a new poll showing the race in Iowa to be closer than the nationwide contest, with DeSantis running second at 20% to Trump's 44%, still a double-digit lead but less commanding than in the national polls, where Trump enjoys majority support.This is according to the New York Times/Siena College poll of likely Iowa caucus participants. It suggests that DeSantis' efforts in Iowa are having at least some impact.Will he be willing to take on Trump's "theories" that did not "prove to be true" in the days ahead and actually hold him responsible for spreading lies?.And will that help him or hurt him with the voters, some of whom are currently leaning toward Trump, who he needs to persuade to win the Iowa caucus?.Obviously, from the care and the baby steps he has been taking, it is a difficult strategic dance for the Florida governor. He needs to win the support of Trump backers without losing his credibility entirely in the process.Of course the election was not stolen. Of course the claims of fraud were not true. The fact that we are even playing these games is a bit ridiculous in and of itself.But this is the dance for the nomination. Does it escape mention that Chris Christie, who has been the most outspoken of the Republican candidates in his criticism of Trump, does not break 1% in the Iowa poll?.One point to note from that survey: 67% of Iowa Republicans, when offered a choice, said they preferred a candidate who was focused on "restoring law and order in our streets and at the border" than one trained "on defeating radical 'woke' ideology in our schools, media and culture," which sounds like Trump over DeSantis - or, rather, it sounds like Iowa isn't necessarily buying what DeSantis has been trying to sell.Which raises again the question of what he should be selling: likeability, for certain; electability, for certain; and maybe, as the key component to both of those, traits of character and integrity that used to be the stuff of presidential campaigns, what contests were said to be all about, the measure of the man - exactly the sort of measure that Donald Trump seeks to evade at all costs.When it comes right down to it, the question about election fraud is a question about integrity, and there is only one answer. The answer is integrity, and that is, ultimately, what DeSantis needs to demonstrate, and what he needs to sell.

title: Hundreds compete in Quick Draw
author: Tom McCall
content:
Hundreds compete in Quick Draw

 July 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 485
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Downtown was filled with art and people Saturday for the Plein Air Easton's quickest event.The annual Quick Draw, in which around 200 artists were given two hours to create a painting of a scene around downtown Easton, has become a fan-favorite event of Plein Air since it was first held 20 years ago. Tourists flocked with their dogs to get a look at the creative process.
Neil Hughes, an artists from Medford, New Jersey, said he prefers having more time to work on his paintings but that "it's a great event, hard not to have fun."
Kaitlyn Hay an artist form Washington, D.C., said the event gave her the opportunity to appreciate work by many of the event's talented participants. "The quick draw is so fun. You just get into the zone. I am certainly nowhere near the level of some of these fellow painters, but it is just fun to participate."
One of the youngest painters at the event was 7-year-old Isabel Tilley. "I have been painting basically all my life," she said. "I painted a cream-colored fence. I am inspired by art."
Not only were there a lot of easels and paints moving around downtown, but there were art lovers waiting to find pieces that spoke to them.
"I have come for probably 15 years, and for 10 of those years, I have bought something," said Stephanie Saunders. "I usually come to the Quick Draw and see what is around."
Nancy Tankersley, the judge of the Quick Draw event, cruised through the work with a clipboard, looking for the best.
There were many volunteers moving art, handing out water and keeping time.
Nancy Espenhorst, a volunteer, said, "I have numerous jobs. I drive a golf cart. I sell art. I am at the information table, and I blow the horn. I like to stay active, and you get to see lots of people."
The event is organized by the Avalon Foundation.
Bill Witowski, the Avalon Foundation's chair, said art sales from the Quick Draw and other Plein Air events support the organization's efforts in the community yearound.
"Just look how many people have come out. It is just a magic time, and look at all the art sales," Witowski said. "That really helps the foundation, which feeds back into the community."
The quick draw is an award-driven paint off. Up to $1,500 is in the offering.
"There are only nine awards so sorry to those of you who didn't make the final list. I really like a strong sense of place," Tankersley said.
The grand prize for the quick draw with an invitation to compete in Plein Air Easton 2025 was given to David Orrin Smith from Seattle.
"That format of paint something from life in two hours at the scale that I work in, which is 30x42 and watercolor, that is what I do all year long all the time," Smith said. He was grateful to all the volunteers who made the event happen.

title: Damaged pipe causes sewage discharge in St. Michaels
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Damaged pipe causes sewage discharge in St. Michaels

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 234
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST.MICHAELS — On Monday, the Talbot County Sanitary District responded to a sewage discharge near the St. Michaels wastewater treatment plant at 25699 St. Michaels Road.The overflow was caused by a cracked force main pipe and was contained and repaired, according to a press release from the county.
The press release said the Sanitary District immediately contacted licensed haulers GoodLife and CHT Excavating to assist with containment and cleanup. GoodLife identified the damaged section of pipe, which was removed and replaced the same evening. The system was returned to full operation shortly thereafter.
An estimated 500 gallons of untreated wastewater were discharged, with 1,500 gallons recovered during the response effort, the press release said. The affected yard area was cleaned using vacuum trucks, and lime was applied by the Talbot County collection crew to stabilize and disinfect the impacted ground surface.
The event was reported to the Maryland Department of the Environment and the Talbot County Office of Environmental Health.
According to the press release, based on the location of the sewage discharge and the quick response, the discharge did not reach any navigable or shellfish harvesting waters. Environmental Health has determined there is minimal to no public health risk.
If the public has any questions regarding the public health determination, they may contact Brennan Greene, director of Environmental Health, at 410-770-6880. For questions regarding the discharge or the corrective action, contact Ray Clarke, county engineer, at 410-770-8170.

title: Equal means equal

Equal means equal

 There has been a great deal of consternation lately concerning election judges in Talbot County. In fact, many people have complained to Sheriff Gamble since Maryland election law is being violated. As a good citizen and duly elected law enforcement officer, the sheriff wrote a letter to the election director questioning the intent of violating the law.For months, the election director has been dodging questions made by the public and apparently has been manipulating the law; however, this issue of flagrant abuse of the law has gone national. As anticipated, our Maryland state attorney general finally decided to weigh in. The Attorney General sent a letter to duly elected Sheriff reminding him that, as sheriff, he has nothing to do with enforcing election law.
Of course, we citizens of all political parties have a responsibility to ensure fair and safe elections, and the sheriff, unlike the attorney general, was properly amplifying the disbelief of concerned citizens.
Intentionally breaking the law? Are you really?
After the slap, the attorney general quoted the law, which states each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges from Democrat and Republican parties. He then says that, although that is true at each polling place, the total number of judges need not be equal between the two parties. What? Where are these unequal judges on duty if not at a polling place?
In past years, the people of Talbot County were told by the director of the Board of Elections that there weren't enough Republicans who signed up to be election judges. Nonsense.
If judge totals must be equal at every polling place, then the totals across the county will be equal. There are now 61 Democrats, 53 Republicans and 10 "other."
In our 10 precincts, only four abide by the law. It appears that information has been withheld from Talbot voters.

title: A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time
author: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service
content:
A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 By 11 a.m., Jon Merryman had collected 45 tires, 38 bags of trash, packs of shingles, a mattress, a playpen and remnants of an accident swept under a guardrail near College Park, Maryland.Merryman, 62, was frustrated and restless. The Nov. 6 election hadn't gone his way. A veteran and a man of action, he turned to a lifelong passion to cope: picking up trash.
Over the following days, he cleaned up roadsides in 22 counties spanning Virginia and West Virginia.
"I call it channeling my anger," Merryman said, tone dropping.
Physical work helps him maintain his emotional and mental health. When he returned home to Catonsville, Merryman felt more rejuvenated and ready to face what came next. For him, cleaning up litter is a way to reclaim control, one piece of trash at a time, in a world that can feel overwhelming.
"I want people to feel like one person can make a difference," he said.
Merryman traces his passion for protecting the environment to campaigns from his childhood. Campaigns like "Smokey the Bear." "Woodsy the Owl." The 1970s commercial "Keep America Beautiful: The Crying Indian."
While controversial today, the "Keep America Beautiful" ad had a simple message for 7-year-old Merryman: "People start pollution. People can stop it." Inspired, he planned a post-Halloween mission to clean up wrappers and litter. With a full bucket, Merryman marched down to a storm drain, thinking that's where the trash should go.
"Thank God an adult was there," he said. The passerby explained how storm drains lead to rivers. He didn't know it yet, but Merryman would dedicate much of his adult life to rectifying this mistake.
The makings of a soldierMerryman's cousins, conservationists on Maryland's Eastern Shore, took him under their wings and ignited a passion for studying the environment. They invited him on bird banding and counting trips. Merryman remembers the sky filling with "rivers of birds" for 15 minutes at a time. Clicker in hand, he counted birds until his hand grew weary.
"You're witnessing the miracles of being on earth when you see stuff like that," Merryman said.
His cousins later dissuaded him from becoming a marine biologist.
"They got me geared up for this life of studying animals, then said, 'Oh, you don't want to do that. It's a life of chasing grants.'"
Merryman entered the University of Delaware as a biology major. Switched to geology. Jumped to civil engineering. His GPA plummeted. He pivoted to part-time status while working for the university. Eventually, he found his footing in geography while programming educational software. Also minored in photography.
His first summer out of college, Merryman worked as a volunteer ranger at the Grand Canyon, giving talks, leading groups and picking up trash in front of the visitor center. "Funny thing is, that's what I love to do now: pick up trash."
The staff liked him and encouraged him to apply for a seasonal park ranger job, but then Congress slashed funding, so the job didn't exist.
Merryman took on seasonal jobs. While working in the Everglades, he saw a billboard promoting the army's college fund.
It offered $20K for two years of service.
"Great option," he thought. He enlisted in the army and spent six years in the National Guard.
'My wife puts up with a lot'When Merryman returned to civilian life, he worked in instructional technology. "As it turns out, there's a lot of commonality between arranging the elements of a map and arranging the elements on a computer screen," he said.
But his passion for the environment remained. One day, while working at Lockheed Martin, Merryman came across a trash-strewn creek and park. He spent five years turning it into a sustainable habitat.
His hobby of picking up trash also found its way home. "My driveway was full, I mean seriously, full of scrap metal," he said. He sold the metal from cleanups to fund his kids' robotics team. "The things we do," Merryman chuckled.
Through it all, he said, it took a lot of patience from his wife, Kirsten. "The spouses that put up with it are angels, too. They are. My wife puts up with a lot."
Turns out, so do his kids.
Litter everywhere in the middle of nowhere
A common conundrum Merryman encounters is people acknowledging a problem but not taking responsibility. "Someone else is doing the littering. It's those people," they think.
Merryman became determined to show that littering is everyone's problem. During a road trip with his son to Los Angeles, an idea emerged, and they cleaned up trash in one county per state, adding two counties for Texas.
When they arrived "in the middle of nowhere" in Turkey, Texas, Merryman found "litter everywhere." He wanted people to realize that we are all responsible for this pile of trash because of all the things we buy and the resources we use.
To illustrate the extent of trash pollution, he started placing green dots on a map of counties he'd clean up.
"I'm a map geek," Merryman said. He had been tracking all the counties he visited for years, a hobby shared by fellow geographers. Now, he aims to pick up trash in every county for as long as possible.
Recently, he picked his daughter up from school in Ithaca, New York. As they left Ithaca and crossed over into the Chesapeake Bay watershed, an idea "dawned on me," he said.
He'd picked up trash in counties between Ithaca and Baltimore, having done this drive many times. "I put those on the map," Merryman said when he realized he was nearly halfway done. "I bet I could do them all" in the watershed.
He now focuses on watersheds rather than state lines. Water carries pollution across borders, so "state boundaries don't matter as much as the watershed," he said.
On Dec. 1, 2024, Merryman reached his goal. He picked up trash in all 206 counties in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Bringing his total count to 524. One-sixth of all counties in the United States.
Sharkey d'SharkOn February 2, 2022, at 2:22 p.m., Merryman retired — a moment he carefully planned. "I walked out the door," said Merryman. "I just thought it was funny."
A few months later, Merryman found his retirement buddy, Sharkey d' Shark, on the side of the road. The abandoned toy-turned-sidekick became a playful way to engage others in cleanups.
Sharkey has a social media presence. "It's a lot easier to have a back-and-forth conversation with Sharkey," Merryman said, "as opposed to writing posts and getting crickets in response."
Merryman hopes Sharkey can help educate and inspire younger generations to partake in cleanups. For now, "about 90% of Sharky's fans are middle-aged women," he laughed.
Nature is innocentWhen not traveling to pick up trash, Merryman volunteers with Lights Out Baltimore, searching for dead or injured birds hit by windows due to disorienting artificial lights.
"Nature, as far as I'm concerned, is all innocent," Merryman said. Migrating birds navigate at night using the moon and stars, but lights lead them to windows. "There's a reason it's happening. It's not because the bird's stupid," he said. The birds can't see the glass.
Not long ago, Merryman found an old Facebook post when he first joined the group and held a bird for the first time in decades. Now, he's active in several Facebook groups where he educates others about window strikes. Sharing photos of the dead birds tends to upset people, especially those who have already seen them.
On the one hand, Merryman speaks to newcomers who aren't aware of this issue and spreads awareness "over and over and over again." On the other hand, some people complain and don't want to see the photos.
"I'm sorry if it makes you feel squeamish," Merryman said, his tone serious. He paused. "Actually, I'm not. I'm not sorry," he said with a wry laugh. "I hope that it will make you care about it."
It is a difficult line to walk — getting people to care without turning them away. "I'm just not good at drawing that line personally," he admitted.
But he is good at showing up and doing the dirty work. "I'm happy to be the grunt, the foot soldier."
Merryman has a plan for the rest of his retirement. He is going to pick up trash in every county in the United States. Until he physically can't anymore. Then he hopes to write a book.
So far, he's crossed off Arizona, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, and New Jersey while nearing the finish line in Pennsylvania and Virginia.
Maybe he won't reach his goal. "But I'm gonna die trying." And maybe the world will be a little cleaner, with a few more birds in it.

title: Talbot keeps it simple on way to championship
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Talbot keeps it simple on way to championship

 July 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 426
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot manager Rich White's approach was fundamentally simple."Just play baseball," White told his Talbot team heading into the District 6 Senior League championship June 26. "We laid the groundwork with the practices and they knew what the expectations were. Just play baseball the way they know how, and don't do too much."
Talbot followed those instructions while riding the solid one-two pitching punch of Nathan Merchant and Couper Barletta on the way to a 5-2 title-clinching victory over Dorchester at Hog Neck.
Talbot was scheduled to play Brunswick on Saturday in the first round of the state tournament in Berlin.
"It's a fantastic group of kids," said White, whose team won the best-of-three series 2-1. "We're pulling them from three different high schools (Easton, St. Michaels, Saints Peter and Paul). But they jelled well. They've been accepting of, I don't want to say a diminished role. Let's say they were a shortstop at their school, but we're asking them to play left field. And everyone has bought into the team concept. Everyone has contributed."
Talbot won the series opener 13-3 in Hurlock on June 24. Dorchester knotted the series at one-all the following night with a 14-7 win, setting up the decisive Game 3.
Dorchester took a 1-0 lead in the top of the first inning of the title game on Jackson Nehring's RBI single.
But Talbot responded with a four-run rally in the bottom of the first for a lead it never surrendered.
Buel Jensen knocked in the tying run with a fielder's choice. Jace Elliott and Finley Carter each worked back-to-back bases-loaded walks to make it 3-1. Brody McDaniel, Talbot's No. 9 hitter, then laid down a two-out RBI bunt single to give Talbot a three-run lead after one complete.
Merchant got the starting nod on the mound for Talbot and yielded two unearned runs and two hits over four innings, striking out two and walking three. Barletta came on in relief to seal the victory.
"It was very effective," White said of his team's pitching combination. "Both guys. Different styles. Merchant gets a lot of weak contact, and then Barletta comes in and he's more of a strikeout, power pitcher.
McDaniel finished 2 for 3 with a pair of RBIs, and Elliott also drove in two runs. Talbot finished with 10 walks, with Ben White and Carter each drawing two. Jensen added two stolen bases.
Nehring, Dorchester's clean-up hitter, finished 2 for 3. Dorchester totaled seven stolen bases, led by Ryan Robinson, who had three.
Carson Weber started on the mound for Dorchester, allowing four runs but no hits in 2/3 of an inning.

In 1892, the Sierra Club was founded in San Francisco by naturalist John Muir.
In 1918, American troops fought their first major battle during World War I as they launched an offensive against the German-held French village of Cantigny; the Americans succeeded in capturing the village.
In 1959, the U.S. Army launched Able, a rhesus monkey, and Baker, a squirrel monkey, aboard a Jupiter missile for a suborbital flight which both primates survived.
In 1972, burglars working on behalf of the Nixon White House broke into the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate Hotel in Washington, D.C., installing surveillance devices on telephones and taking photos of DNC documents.

title: 4,000 gallons of sewage overflows into Windmill Branch
author: Contributed
content:
4,000 gallons of sewage overflows into Windmill Branch

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A gravity sewer line along South Washington Street in Easton discharged 4,425 gallons of untreated wastewater into Windmill Branch, headwaters of the Tred Avon River, on Wednesday, Easton Utilities reported.The cause of the backup was due to the sewer line being clogged with a combination of grease, rags and "flushable" wipes. Easton Utilities immediately reported these overflows to state and local health authorities and promptly treated the areas affected with lime to disinfect the surfaces around the points of discharge.Easton Utilities strongly urges the public and food service establishments to be mindful of what they release to the sewer lines.Only human waste and toilet paper should be flushed - disinfecting and "flushable" wipes and other items should be properly disposed of in the trash, not the toilet.These wipes and other items do not break down in sewer or septic systems and can damage the internal plumbing in homes as well.In addition, everyone should keep fats oil, and grease out of drains to prevent blockages or backups."Easton Utilities remains committed to the safe, sanitary removal of wastewater while minimizing the impact to our environment," said Doug Abbott, Easton Utilities' engineering, water and wastewater department manager.No customers were impacted by this event. While the Talbot County Health Department has confirmed there is minimal impact on public health, regulation requires a press release be distributed to notify the general public.

 The Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton has an upcoming slate of shows that includes reggae stalwarts The Wailers, New Jersey rockers Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes and other performances. The music and performing arts venue is located at 40 E. Dover Street in Easton. Here's a rundown of upcoming shows with performance descriptions from the Avalon.For ticket prices and more show and venue information at the Avalon and its Stoltz Listening Room online check out avalonfoundation.org.
The Met: Live in HD Madama Butterfly

Extraordinary soprano Asmik Grigorian tackles the demanding role of Cio-Cio-San, the loyal geisha at the heart of Puccini's devastating tragedy. Tenor Jonathan Tetelman stars as the callous American naval officer Pinkerton, whose betrayal destroys her. Mezzo-soprano Elizabeth DeShong reprises the role of the steadfast maid Suzuki, and baritone Lucas Meachem is the American consul Sharpless. Acclaimed maestro Xian Zhang takes the podium on May 11 to conduct Anthony Minghella's vivid production. Saturday, May 11

Avalon Theatre
Dar Williams' lyrics contain bouquets of optimism, delivered on melodies alternating between beguiling lightness and understated gravity.
Always in the right place at the right time for the success she's had over a 25+year career, Dar rose out of the vibrant mid-90's Boston scene, inspired by the eclectic influences of alt-rockers, Berklee jazz musicians, slam poets, and folk artists like Patty Griffith, Melissa Ferrick, the Throwing Muses, Vance Gilbert, and Jonatha Brooke.
Through all the ups and downs, however, it's always been about staying true to herself. "Good and bad things happen, and it's not necessarily a reward or indictment. I've just got to meet it," she observes. "Like, I'm bringing my whole life to this moment; it will surprise me, challenge me, show me where I was wrong, even make a fool out of me, but my job is to show up and not take adversity personally. Real happiness doesn't have to feel like Snoopy dancing with Woodstock; it can just be knowing you have the resilience to meet whatever comes to you. I will call that a good life."
Dar will be joined by special guest Heather Maloney, a Massachusetts-based singer songwriter whose voice is her "not-so-secret weapon" (Boston Globe) and whose "lyrics cut to the chase" (Huffington Post).

With dynamics ranging from the intense restraint of campfire intimacy through to open-throttle abandon, Minor Gold delight and enthrall as they weave masterful harmonies and deft guitar playing around unforgettable, stripped-back performances.
Since releasing their critically acclaimed self-titled debut album in August 2023, the duo have been on the road—recently returning from a 30-date North American album tour with supports for The Teskey Brothers and an official showcase at AmericanaFEST in Nashville, as well as the 2024 Folk Alliance International in Kansas City. https://www.minorgoldmusic.com/

https://boybandreview.com/

Their performances meticulously capture the sleek, synth-heavy, steady-beat and driving-guitar sound that made the one-and-only Cars so awesome.
A Carpool show helps you "shake it up it" and takes you right back to when the Cars were (and continue to be) the soundtrack of our lives, reminding us all of why the Cars hold a very special place in our hearts and minds. https://carpooltributeband.com/
Mutlu

title: Make your groceries last longer

 A recent column on the proper storage for fresh fruits and vegetables generated a lot of great reader feedback - plus dozens of new tips and tricks to make all grocery items last longer. I love this stuff so much, I must admit to being slightly compulsive - gathering, testing and assessing techniques. Here are a few of my new favorites: BERRIESAre you familiar with that sick feeling that comes when you notice that the berries you bought yesterday are already showing signs of mold and turning brown? Here's the remedy: As soon as you bring them into the kitchen, prepare a mixture of one part vinegar (white or apple cider) and 10 parts water. Give the berries a bath in the mixture.Swirl them around a bit and then gently drain, rinse and place in the refrigerator.Don't worry. The solution is so weak, you will not taste the vinegar. This treatment should give your strawberries an additional two weeks of useful life and raspberries a week or more. Vinegar retards the growth of bacteria that causes berries to spoil so quickly.POTATOESTo keep potatoes from growing big ugly sprouts before you have time to use them up, store them with a couple of apples. For some reason, that really works to halt the sprouting.ALUMINUM FOILLet me just say that I'm a believer! It drives me crazy that I do not know why this works, but it certainly does: Wrap celery, broccoli and lettuce in a single layer of aluminum foil before storing in the refrigerator. Celery will stay crisp and fresh for up to a month stored this way. It's simply amazing.MUSHROOMSStore mushrooms in a paper bag. Now the air can circulate and the mushrooms will remain dry and lovely for weeks.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living."

title: Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It began as a challenge for an already established cook.Tricia King, owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, said that during her time as a personal chef, she had a client with rheumatoid arthritis who needed to avoid gluten in her diet. King undertook the task of creating tasty gluten-free recipes.
Now, about 20 years later, she is the owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, an entirely gluten-free bakery on the Eastern Shore.
King centers the health and well-being of her customers in everything she does, and that includes making sure all her baked goods are not only safe but also a delight to eat.
The passion for tasty food has been a long love of King's. She has been cooking almost all her life, and even when she wasn't cooking, she was studying and watching other cooks like Julia Child and her mother. She said that cooking just came naturally to her.
"When you have a passion for it, it's easy to do it," King said. "I've loved food my whole life."
After studying interior design, she decided to open a personal chef business in Salt Lake City, Utah, called Purple Pomegranate. For two years, she traveled from house to house every day, doing the shopping and cooking for two weeks and then repeating the same cycle with different clients.
Then, she had the opportunity to be a sous chef in a hotel in Scotland.
It was there that she dove into baking. When she came back to the States, she trained under pastry chef Matt Ratliff in the Perry Cabin.
The work was intense, King said. Daily, the kitchen would produce 40 souffles, bake bread and cookies, and make wedding cakes.
In the back of her mind, she still yearned to open her dream bakery. So, she began using the back kitchen to try different gluten-free desserts.
Before she made the leap to establish her bakery, she shared her dream with one of her friends, and he said, "Oh, it's never going to work. A gluten-free bakery?" She smiles, recollecting the memory and how he has since taken back his words.
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl has been in business in St. Michaels for 12 years and will be opening in a bigger location in Easton. Its products can be found throughout Maryland, Delaware, D.C., Massachusetts, New York and other states nationwide.
King said the vast majority of her customers have celiac disease, an immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye. Due to this, it is of the utmost importance that there is no cross-contamination in her kitchen.
She operates in a 100% certified gluten-free facility and kitchen.
All products are individually wrapped to prevent any potential cross-contamination from other foods during shipping and sale, and all employees are only allowed to bring gluten-free food to work.
"People don't understand that you can't just bake in a kitchen and then wipe it down and then bake gluten-free," King said. "Twenty parts per million, which is a crumb of bread, is enough to make someone who has celiac disease sick."
More than anything, King wants to help people with celiac disease lead a more accessible and safer day-to-day life. King said her customers with celiac disease often feel that they need to miss out on treats for their health, but having the opportunity to provide people the chance to indulge in a baked good makes all the effort she puts in her bakery worth it.
King urges young girls thinking of starting a bakery or any business to have faith in themselves and allow themselves to grow outside their comfort zones.
"We women are the hardest on ourselves," King said. "We beat ourselves up the most. It puts blocks in front of us, but we have to know we can make it through. So, keep going. You have to keep going."

title: Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It was the No. 1 seed.It had won 11 of its last 12 games, and had already twice beaten its opponent.
But none of that matter to Saints Peter and Paul High boys head lacrosse coach Todd Wolters after the first half of Tuesday's Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference semifinal.
After mustering just one first-quarter goal and carrying a four-goal cushion into halftime, Wolters made clear to his team he wasn't happy.
"Coach pulled us over at halftime and told us that this could be the end of our season," sophomore face-off man Grant Messick said. "'We could be done here.' But none of us want that. I think he kind of brought that out of us, just saying we could be going to Navy this Friday to win a championship that hasn't been done in a decade."
The Sabres responded, outscoring No. 4 Gerstell Academy by three goals in a decisive third quarter, catapulting them to a 13-8 victory on a dreary Tuesday afternoon.
Sts. Peter & Paul (15-4) advances to Friday's MIAA B Conference championship game where it will meet second-seed and two-time defending champion Archbishop Curley (11-7) at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium at 5 p.m. The Sabres defeated Curley twice during the regular season.
"They were taking a team lightly, like they've already won," said Wolters, whose team won 7-6 at Gerstell on April 12, then routed the Falcons 16-3 on their home turf April 30. "And they've done that before. We just lose focus."
In his first game back from injury, JJ Rardin (five goals) gave the Sabres a 1-0 lead with 2:22 left in the first quarter, when he scored off an assist from Andrew Steinhardt.
Gerstell (6-10) tied the score on Bronson Peters' goal less than 2 minutes into the second quarter. Rardin gained possession out in front of the net and fired his second goal just under the crossbar to make it 2-1 just 18 seconds later. But the Falcons came right back with Ryan Ellis beating Sabres goalie Hank Wolters (11 saves) to make it 2-all.
Davis Kimminau whipped a shot in from the right side, and less than two minutes later, set up Vincent Dyer's goal to nudge Sts. Peter & Paul to a 4-2 lead. But Peters (four goals) scored at the midway point of the second quarter to make it a one-goal game again.
"They came out and they didn't want their season to end," Messick said of Gerstell. "They came out with nothing to lose. We're the one seed. They come out and they beat us, then it's a huge upset. And if they don't it's not what they were expected to do. So I think they had that mentality while we came out thinking, 'Well, we smoked them before. We're going to roll them this time.' But they didn't. They came out and they fought really hard."
The Sabres scored the last three goals of the half, as Liam Durnbaugh, Noah Zimmerman and Rardin each tallied to make it 7-3 at the break.
"Our guys were in it," Gerstell head coach Ryan Drenner said. "We stayed in the fight the entire game. That was the biggest difference. We were here a couple weeks ago April 30. Very lopsided. We try to learn a lesson from every game regardless of the outcome of the game. And so for that one it was we had to come up with a better plan of how to travel down here and be ready to go from the jump. So we changed how we warm up just to be a little bit more alert from the start. I thought our guys did that today and we played four quarters of a great lacrosse game."
Gerstell cut its deficit to 7-4 just 19 seconds into the third quarter on a goal by Peters. Zimmerman scored for the Sabres, but Matthew Schols answered for the Falcons.
Sts. Peter & Paul took control the remainder of the quarter, getting one goal each from Steinhardt (four assists) and Kimminau, and two more from Rardin for a 12-5 lead heading into the fourth quarter.
"We know how good we are," Wolters said. "The third quarter we go and we really just started opening it up. And then in the fourth quarter we thought it was done."
The Sabres extended their lead to 13-5 before Gerstell scored the game's final three goals.
"We weren't hustling," Wolters said of certain stretches. "We'd come down and throw it away and then they would go down and score on unsettled situations. They had eight goals and I know five to six were unsettled and we can't have that.
"It's a win. We'll take it," Wolters said. "You can't win a championship unless you're in the championship. And we're in the championship."
BASEBALL
COL. RICHARDSON 1, ST. MICHAELS 0
AMERICAN CORNER — Jack Walls walked, advanced to second and third on a pair of low pitches, and raced home on a wild pitch in the third inning for what proved to be the only run Tuesday, as Colonel Richardson blanked the Saints to win the Class 1A East Region II final.
Colonel Richardson winning pitcher Daniel Hesson hurled a two-hitter. Connor Wheeler and Henry Mullikin each had a hit for the Saints.
St. Michaels pitcher Jacob Seek allowed one hit, that coming with two outs in the sixth inning when Hesson singled.

Cordova Day celebrates town's history, culture

 Cordova Day, held March 9 at the Cordova Firehouse, welcomed a crowd of locals and visitors, all eager to learn more about the town's history and culture.The rain outside did not dampen the crowd inside, who browsed the many booths of local artisans and historical displays. The open house celebrated the 75the anniversary of the Ladies Auxiliary, and there was a scavenger hunt for the Children.
There were reunions of friends new and old, many from first grade at Cordova Elementary School 50 and 60 years ago. Parents and grandparents showed their children their history with the pride.
Despite the congenial atmosphere, there was a somber tone, with the passing of one of Cordova's own on March 2, Joseph Secrist Jr.
Well known to all, he was a life member and former president and chief of the Cordova Volunteer Fireman's Association. He was also past president of the Talbot County Fireman's Association. Secrist was an instructor for the Maryland Fire and Rescue Institute for several years. He also served six years in the National Guard.
Cordova Day was hosted by the Cordova Historical Society.

title: Easton passes ordinance to mitigate seafood processing odors
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton passes ordinance to mitigate seafood processing odors

 December 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton Town Council approved an ordinance Monday that aims to crack down on odors from seafood processors by requiring the installment of odor control technology.In a 4-0 vote, the town passed Ordinance 835, which was drafted following resident concerns about the odor emanating from Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue.
Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis was outspoken Monday evening about bringing his constituents relief from the odors they smell during crab season.
"Constituents in the neighborhood should not have to go through another season of having to endure that kind of odor," Davis said. "And if the business is friendly and working with the community, something of this nature should have been worked out prior to now."
The ordinance, which will go into effect later this month, requires that seafood processing operations install odor control technology "in such a manner that no odor from any product or by-product can be detected outside the building on the same property or on adjacent properties or public rights-of-way."
Zach Smith, an attorney representing Chesapeake Brand Seafood, said the business' concerns center the spray application system it plans to install — which will cost around $20,000 and may not fulfill the town's new requirements of "no odor" being detectable.
"We're confident it will address the issue, at least to some extent," Smith said. "But we're not confident, not necessarily confident, it'll meet that standard."
Smith requested a compromise, stating he thinks the ordinance should not retroactively apply to "existing, lawful seafood processing uses" such as his client. He submitted proposed revisions to the ordinance that were read aloud Monday evening.
Following a lengthy council discussion, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello said he was ready to pass the ordinance as written, without Smith's proposed changes. Council President Frank Gunsallus agreed those changes were "overly specific."
Abatiello made a motion to approve the ordinance, which was seconded by Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry. Gunsallus and Davis joined in voting yes. Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery was absent from Monday's meeting.
TIMELINE DEBATEIn the approved ordinance, businesses must comply with odor control and storage requirements by July 1, 2025. Prior to Monday, the compliance date on the draft ordinance was Jan. 1, 2026. The change stirred discussion Monday evening.
Davis pushed for that date to be even sooner — Jan. 1, 2025 — though he was outnumbered by Gunsallus, Abatiello, and Curry, who all voted in favor of amending the ordinance to the July date.
Curry maintained that it's important the town be fair to the business since it's planning to pay up for the new odor control system to address the problem.
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh said she had legal concerns about shortening the period, saying that "even January (2026)" is pushing it.
"They've had time to comply," Davis said.
"But they didn't have this ordinance," VanEmburgh responded. "The ordinance is what would be challenged."
"I mean the worst case scenario is that we go to court, and is that the end result? Then so be it," said Davis. " … If you say comply by 2026, just think about this for a moment. The same people who live in Ward 4 have to suffer through this this year again until January 2026."
"I have to stand on what I believe in, and I believe that they've already had enough time to do it," Davis later stated. "It seems to me that we're more worried about going to court than listening to the people. And I think we should listen to the people."

title: Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the final days before President-elect Donald Trump is sworn into office, Maryland's LGBTQ+ community is preparing for what could lie ahead."With the upcoming change in administration, the United States is poised to experience significant rollbacks in federal protections for LGBTQIA+ people, with transgender people squarely in the crosshairs," Delmarva Pride Center Board Chair Tina Jones said during a town hall event Wednesday evening.
Jones said that although state laws in Maryland provide more protections to LGBTQ+ people compared to many other states, protections in Maryland vary based on where people live, attend school and seek healthcare.
The town hall, which was held at the Waterfowl Building in downtown Easton, brought together a panel of experts to share their expectations for the next four years as well as their thoughts on what the state can do to ensure and expand protections for Maryland's LGBTQ+ community. Along with the Delmarva Pride Center, the event was hosted by DoCo Pride and the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus.
The four-person panel — which included Del. Kris Fair (D-Frederick), Fair's Chief of Staff Camila Reynolds-Dominguez, FreeState Justice Executive Director Phillip Westry and Maryland Office of the Attorney General Civil Rights Division Chief Jonathan Smith — answered questions related to schools and workplace, health care and family law.
Caleb Holland, an attorney and the chair of DoCo Pride, who moderated the town hall, said the goal of the event is "to prepare, not scare."
On the topic of education, Smith said he expects the Trump administration will try to push through executive orders around funding schools that are based on sports issues, bathrooms or the ability to deadname or misgender students. But Smith said there are "very significant responses" states can make.
"There's been a body of law that's developed that says the United States government cannot, through its funding powers, coerce states to take policy decisions that are not for the function of funding," he said.
Westry said organizing and getting active in politics, like school boards, is a good way to get involved.
Although part of Wednesday night's conversation focused on bracing for what could happen in the country, the panelists also talked about what gives them hope.
Fair, who is the chair of the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus, recalled the 2018 midterm elections. He said the country elected more women, more queer people and more people of color than ever before.
"In 2018, we figured out that in order to protect our rights, we need to do everything we can to put as many people who look like us into positions of power," he said. "What I am hopeful for is that 2026 looks just like that."
Reynolds-Dominguez, who was previously a policy advocate and legal impact coordinator at FreeState Justice, said that in the last couple of years, the state has taken an "aggressive stance" on doing everything possible to anticipate rollbacks. She said Maryland is "situated to weather this storm" and that should be used as a catalyst for doing long-term work.
"The core of all of this is shifting people's hearts and minds," she said. "And if we're not doing that work, we're spending our time in the wrong place."

title: Easton named host of second ever Maryland Main Street Conference
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton named host of second ever Maryland Main Street Conference

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Downtown Easton will welcome hundreds of local and state leaders this October for the state's second ever Maryland Main Street Conference.The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and its Secretary Jake Day, announced Easton as the host site during Day's tour of the town Wednesday.
The conference aims to bring stakeholders and local leaders together to network and discuss improvement efforts for Maryland's historic and downtown streets and neighborhoods.
This year's conference is slated for Oct. 7 and 8.
Easton Economic Development Corporation Executive Director Holly DeKarske said in a press release that the town is "honored" to host.
"Conferences like this play a crucial role in the ongoing success of the Main Street initiative," DeKarske said. "It's essential for us to celebrate our victories while also sharing our challenges, as this helps us learn from one another. Together, we can foster growth and nurture the next generation of Main Street leaders, paving the way for vibrant downtowns and thriving communities."
DeKarske said at a town meeting in March that the town sent a request for proposal to the state in hopes of being chosen as the conference's host.
"You need to make sure you have enough hotel rooms and places for them to eat because they have you go back out to town over those two days," DeKarske said in March. " ... It's a really good opportunity for us."
In 2024, Frederick hosted the inaugural Maryland Main Street Conference, which was a one-day event attended by more than 400 people.
Day said in a press release the conference is an opportunity for economic developers to learn how best to invest in Maryland's historic centers.
"The Town of Easton is a prime example of the payoff of that investment, and I'm so excited to recognize them as the host of this year's conference," Day stated.

title: Precedent has been set
author: Staff Writer
content:
Precedent has been set

 June 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Precedent hasbeen set
Our former president, Donald J. Trump, has been found "guilty" on 34 counts of what amounts to a misdemeanor under the usual circumstances. But since Trump is running for president of the United States, the circumstances are not usual, and so the law has been compromised in order to try to halt his campaign.
A precedent has been set for political enemies to dig up frivolous charges against each other in order to take the other out of the running. This could result in chaos and the complete collapse of our system of government. Are politicians going to begin assassinating each other, as they do in other countries?
I am reminded of Robert Bolt's play "A Man for All Seasons" about Sir Thomas More who refused to violate his conscience to please King Henry VIII. In a debate with his son-in-law, Thomas Roper, More claims that he would give even the devil the benefit of the law. Roper is appalled and wishes he could tear down every law which stood in the way of destroying the devil.
More responds thus: "Oh? And when the last law was down, and the devil turned round on you — where would you hide, Roper, the laws all being flat?"
Two hundred and fifty years later, one of our founders, John Adams, defended in a court of law several British soldiers who had shot his countrymen in what is known as the Boston Massacre. Adams was an expert on British common law and to him the defendants, whether he liked them or not, had the right to a fair trial; he made sure they had one.
What is British common law? It began with the seventh century laws of the Angles and the Saxons who began to have hearings in which evidence was presented. In the late ninth century, Alfred the Great codified the laws of the Angles and the Saxons, insisting that rich and poor, high and low, were equally treated. In 1215, the Magna Carta stated the presumption of innocence until proven guilty, which is one of the foundations of our judiciary.
We have taken our legal system for granted. When some people who commit crimes go free while others are hounded for much lesser offenses, then the laws become meaningless. The people who hate Trump are willing to destroy our legal system in order to ruin him.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary
author: Konner Metz
content:
Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.Sian Radaskiewicz-King, 32, was arrested Friday by Easton police on charges of malicious destruction of property and use of a hate symbol. She was later charged with defacing religious property and disturbing school operations, among other counts.
According to court documents, King allegedly spray-painted the transgender symbol on dumpsters, the sidewalk and a step outside the Catholic school off of Route 50. Other spray-painted symbols were found on a fence at the Hampton Inn next to the school, per court records.
The symbols were found elsewhere in town, including outside East End Liquors, The Market at Dover Station and other businesses. The transgender symbol, often used to encourage gender inclusivity, is a combination of the male and female signs.
At an unusually crowded bail hearing on Monday afternoon, Talbot County District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered King to be held without bond in the Detention Center. A trial is scheduled for Oct. 28.
Many parents and school officials from Sts. Peter and Paul filled the courtroom. School Board Chair Peggy Wilson asked Ketterman to not approve King's release. Wilson cited the Aug. 27 shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, which killed two children and injured 18 people, as a reason why the school community is concerned for the safety of students.
"Our fear is not the symbol itself, but the possibility of a copycat situation," Wilson said.
King, according to public legal representation, is transgender. She previously attended Sts. Peter and Paul School.
The Minneapolis shooter, Robin Westman, was referred to as transgender by federal officials. Westman's gender identity wasn't clear, according to The Associated Press.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said in a statement this weekend that the graffiti incidents are "especially painful" given the Minneapolis Catholic school shooting.
"It reminds us of the responsibility we all share to ensure our children's safety and well-being," Cook wrote. "We condemn such acts of intimidation, they have no place in our community."
In a statement Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center condemned the graffiti acts as a "misuse" of the international transgender symbol.
"We are deeply troubled that an LGBTQIA+ symbol was misused in a way that could be construed as hateful," the statement read. "Symbols such as the Transgender Symbol exist to affirm identity, celebrate diversity, and foster belonging — not to spread fear or division.
"This incident occurs at a time when Transgender people continue to face targeted attacks in society. We call on our neighbors, allies, and community members to stand together, to reject hate in all its forms, and to embrace the values of acceptance, compassion, and love."
On Monday, Easton Police Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the agency will increase patrol this week at Sts. Peter and Paul School and other schools in town. He said police "have no reason to believe that there was any attempt or desire to harm anyone."
BOND DECISION
Bridgette Lane, an assistant at the Talbot County public defender's office, argued in court on Monday that King should be granted release based on the low severity of charges, an otherwise clean criminal record and the Detention Center's recommendation.
Lane said King has "expressed remorse" and understands "she can't be acting out in these ways."
King, who is listed as having a Baltimore address, was recently staying in Easton with her mother, Lane said. If released, the expectation was for King to stay with her mother.
Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the graffiti incident is concerning due to the context of the Minneapolis shooting last month, as well as the fact that King's mother's house is close to the school.
"Here we have this clear warning sign," Coale said. " ... We don't know if the defendant is capable of carrying out something worse. But the state doesn't want to find out."
Ketterman said both sides made good points, but she hammered home that there are "no conditions of release" that would ensure the safety of the community. The judge said she's concerned about the location of the graffiti and King's documented mental health diagnoses, which include bipolar disorder and PTSD.
"I don't think the court has another choice," Ketterman said after ruling no bond and ordering the defendant complete a mental health evaluation.
Information from The Associated Press contributed to this report.

title: Townsend, Orrell lead Warriors
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Townsend, Orrell lead Warriors

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — They weren't together when they spoke, but all three struck a similar theme."We needed this win going into next week," Easton High head softball coach Ryan Brice said Wednesday after the Warrriors churned out 16 hits en route to an 18-0 feel-good victory in five innings over Wicomico.
"We needed it big time," said Olivia Orrell, who celebrated senior day by launching a two-run homer to center field that gave Easton a 3-0 first-inning lead.
"I think the whole team needed it," chimed junior pitcher Sammy Townsend, who registered a season-high 15 strikeouts while spinning a three-hitter.
One day after getting blanked for the first time this year by two-time defending North Bayside champion North Dorchester, Easton (7-4) faced a Wicomico team that has yet to win this season. Sure, the Warriors were a heavy favorite, and took care of business early on the way to just their second win in five games.
But with key dates looming with Kent Island and Cambridge-South Dorchester next week, Easton not only got a desired result against the Indians (0-9) but a much-needed boost of confidence.
"We needed all the hits today because the past couple games we haven't really been hitting," said Orrell, who finished 3 or 4 with three RBIs, four runs scored and her second homer of the season. "So I think that boosted our confidence level. And it definitely boosted the team morale."
Brice agreed, especially after last week's losses to Stephen Decatur and Colonel Richardson, and Tuesday's setback at North Dorchester.
"Dropping the couple games last week really affected us," Brice said. "So we really needed this one today so we can get some traction going into the meat of the season. We have Kent Island coming up. We have Cambridge coming up. Those are good ball clubs so we got to be on our toes."
Townsend (3-3) seemed to be on her game from the beginning, fanning the first two batters she faced before plunking Amber Moore, and then striking out Aleah Shah to end the first.
"I feel my curve was really tight today, and I feel my riser was good as well," said Townsend, who notched all 15 outs via strikeout. "I feel like I had a natural rise going on today and I got a lot of hitters out with that. I was focused. I feel like this is what we needed."
Joseline Gabriel singled through the left side of the infield with one out in the second inning for Wi-Hi's first hit. But Townsend fanned the next two batters to end the frame, then struck out the side swinging in the third.
The Indians had their best chance to spoil Townsend's shutout bid in the fourth. Shah hit a one-out single to right and advanced to second on an error. Townsend struck out Kennedi Hull. Gabriel then reached on an error, sending Shah to third. But the Indians' lone baserunner to reach third would remain there, as Townsend got an inning-ending strikeout.
"I can't say enough about Sammy," Brice said. "There was freshman sensation, then sophomore sensation. Now, she's a junior sensation. She needed this win as well. She had a couple of rough outings the past couple of games, but she needed the win."
Wicomico put two runners on in the fifth with two outs, but Townsend punctuated Easton's third shutout of the year with her 15th K.
After scoring three runs on four hits in the first, Easton batted around in the second, pushing six more runs across with five hits. Gemma Vogel (2 for 3) opened the inning with a double, stole third and scored on an error. Lyla Roe (2 for 3, RBI), Orrell, and Townsend (3 for 4) each stroked singles in the rally, and Lane Kennedy (2 for 4, 2 RBIs) doubled.
Easton widened its lead to 12-0 in the third before scoring six more in the fourth.
"We did what we were supposed to do today," Brice said. "I can't complain. We hit the ball very well today. We haven't in the past couple of games. So today hopefully going into next week we keep the bats rolling."

title: Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography
author: Maggie Trovato

Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 385

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty to four counts of possession of child pornography during a plea hearing on Thursday in the Talbot County Circuit Court.In June, Travis Schwaninger, 43, was arrested on eight counts of possessing child pornography following the execution of a search warrant where detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office found evidence of child pornography on Schwaninger's electronic devices.
Before his arrest, the Easton Police Department Criminal Investigations Unit had received several tips about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.
On Thursday, Maryland Circuit Court Judge Theresa Adams suspended all of the five-year sentences for each of the four counts Schwaninger pleaded guilty to. This means he will serve no jail time.
Adams said Schwaninger will have to serve five years of supervised probation, register as a Tier I sex offender and submit to supervision, meaning that he will have to comply with a sex offender management program.
The state agreed not to prosecute the remaining four charges Schwaninger faced.
Before handing down Schwaninger's sentence, Adams said that by obtaining and possessing the videos, Schwaninger was participating in the child pornography industry.
"The most important thing we can all do is protect children," she said.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale gave descriptions of the four videos that Schwaninger pleaded guilty to having. He said the children in the videos were real children, not created by artificial intelligence.
Coale said that although Schwaninger had not manufactured the videos, his "participation in that market allows the market to flourish."
Schwaninger's attorney Thomas Maronick Jr. said his client "looked at some pictures he should not have" and didn't distribute them. Maronick said Schwaninger has since met with a counselor experienced in treating sex offenders. Maronick said the counselor did not feel that Schwaninger had a problem that requires "lengthy" therapy.
This was "a crime of curiosity," Maronick said, later adding that Schwaninger didn't realize the industry he was supporting.
Schwaninger told Adams that he came across the videos on social media toward the end of 2023.
"It was like watching a train wreck," he said about the videos. "I know better."
Schwaninger said the videos were on an old phone and didn't realize they were on the phone he was using at the time of his arrest. He said he thought he had deleted the videos.

title: Easton follows great loss with victory
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Easton follows great loss with victory

 April 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 EASTON — Easton High assistant baseball coach Matt Blue died Friday night after a 17-month battle with cancer.Less than 24 hours later, the Warriors were back on the field, having decided to go forward with Saturday's home game against Southern-Anne Arundel.
And Blue's son Dustin wanted the ball.
"He wanted to pitch," Easton head coach Albert Pritchett said of his sophomore right-hander. "We talked before the game. He wanted to pitch."
Dustin Blue pitched three-plus innings of two-hit ball before running into a jam in the fourth inning, but by then the Warriors had built a lead that was never in jeopardy en route to an emotional 11-2 victory.
"He wanted to play last night," Pritchett said of Dustin Blue. "As soon as we knew (of Matt's passing), the kids, the players and families wanted to play. We felt that was the best way to honor Matt. Matt would have wanted us to play. I think we showed it was the right decision."
Matt Blue was a three-sport athlete at Easton High before graduating in 2002. He went on to play goalkeeper for Salisbury University's soccer team before returning to teach in Talbot County. The former boys' head soccer coach at Easton High, he was diagnosed with cancer in December, 2022. Matt continued teaching at Easton Middle School, and remained an assistant on Easton's varsity baseball team until he passed Friday. Matt Blue was 40 years old.
"I thought the kids responded," Pritchett said. "They loved Matt Blue. They loved the coach. The community has a tremendous loss. It's going to be hard to replace him. I don't think we will.
"So I thought the kids, in the face of a lot of emotion, a lot of feelings, and a lot of loss, they did a good job," Pritchett continued. "They were here together playing the sport they love, supporting Dustin, the family. I'm very proud of them."
Matt Blue gave a speech prior to last year's St. Michaels at Easton game on April 13. Before Saturday's game, the public-address announcer reminded players, coaches and the large home crowd settled behind the backstop of one of Blue's main themes of recognizing the moment.
His son did just that on a wind-chilled afternoon of gray clouds and big patches of blue sky.
"It's incredible," Southern head coach Kyle Lynch said of Dustin. "The effort. Obviously the emotion. You don't know what's going through his head, but he threw tremendously. He was great. We have a lot respect for them and coach Pritchett. But what Dustin did was truly pretty special. Been around baseball for a long time and haven't seen anything like that."
Dustin's first pitch of the game was a strike to Thomas Martin. He got Martin on a grounder to short, then hit JC Wilson with a pitch. Easton catcher Colin Moody threw out Wilson trying to steal second then watched Dustin get a called strike three on Gavin Crandall to end the inning.
Easton's starting pitcher issued a one-out walk to Owen Meyers in the second, induced Andrew Cook into a fielder's choice, then zipped a pickoff throw to first that led to Cook getting caught in an inning-ending rundown.
Southern's Brendan Hinkle was hit by a pitch to lead off the third. But Nick Youmans grounded into a fielder's choice, struck out Dylan Clarke looking before Martin hit a deep fly that Warrior left fielder Carter Mooney made a nice play on.
Wilson lined Dustin's first offering of the fourth sharply through the middle for Southern's first hit. Wilson was erased on a fielder's choice. O'Brien was then hit by a pitch before Meyers dumped a singled into shallow left, loading the bases. Cook hit into a fielder's choice to plate the Bulldogs' first run before Pritchett came out to relieve Dustin with Garrett Fink.
"I thought he threw great," Pritchett said of Dustin (2-0), who remained in the game at shortstop. "I think (he threw) 60-something percent strikes. He commanded all three of his pitches. Again under a tremendous amount of pressure and emotion. Just showed a lot of character; lot of grit. It's a tremendous effort again in the face of tremendous loss and emotion. He's a tough kid. I'm proud of him."
Easton (3-1) scored all the runs it needed during a six-run second inning — all with two outs — against Bulldogs starter Crandall (1-1). Carter Mooney began the scoring, lining a stand-up RBI double down the left-field line. After Cullen Murphy walked, Dylan Cassell roped another run-producing double to left. Murphy scored on a wild pitch. Josh Dressler (2 for 4) singled to score Cassell for a 4-0 lead. Dressler eventually scored on a wild pitch before Dustin capped the scoring with an infield, RBI single.
The Warriors tacked on another five runs with two outs in the third for an 11-0 bulge. Murphy singled to center off reliever Rhett Dorval and was lifted for courtesy runner Mikey O'Connor. Cassell was hit by a pitch. Dressler singled into the hole at short, plating O'Connor. CJ Dugan (2 for 4) delivered the inning's big blow with a two-run single. Dustin (2 for 4) followed with an infield single.
Fink, who escaped a bases-loaded jam in the fourth, yielded a run in the fifth, but didn't give up a hit in two innings. He was relieved with two outs in the bottom of the sixth by O'Connor, who struck out three of the five batters he faced to close the win.
"I think it's a healthy distraction," Pritchett said of playing the game. "I think the kids needed it. They wanted it. And they proved it was a good decision for all of them. I thought their energy was high. They were positive despite the emotion."
After the game, Pritchett handed the game-ball to Dustin.
"Dustin looked fabulous," Pritchett said.

author: Maggie Trovato

 EASTON — An Easton man was convicted of first-degree child abuse and related charges Thursday.According to a news release from Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, Earl Andrew Kautz, 31, was found guilty on all charges, which include two counts of first-degree child abuse, one count of second-degree child abuse, two counts of second-degree assault and one count of reckless endangerment.
The charges stem from the abuse of a one-year-old boy and the assault of a 13-year-old girl, both of whom lived with Kautz at the time of the incidents.
According to the news release, the trial included testimony of the 13 year old and her mother, and expert medical testimony by the medical director of Pediatric Urgent Care Services at Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Evidence used in the trial include a May 2023 interview with the 13-year-old that was conducted by Talbot County Department of Social Services, according to the news release.
After the interview, the 1-year-old boy — who was 18 months old at the time — was taken to Johns Hopkins Hospital for a skeletal survey that revealed healing fractures in both of his tibias. A second survey taken two weeks later showed the same thing. According to the news release, the fractures were "deemed highly indicative of non-accidental injury" by Johns Hopkins medical staff.
According to the news release, witnesses at trial testified they had observed Kautz shaking the 1-year-old boy on multiple occasions in 2022. Witnesses also testified to observing bruises on the child's body when he was returned from visitations with Kautz.
"These cases involve children who are too young to testify or to speak on their own behalf and are therefore difficult to prosecute," Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said in the news release. "We are extremely grateful to the investigators at the Talbot County Department of Social Services, Easton Police Department and to the doctors at Johns Hopkins who came together to achieve justice in this case."
Kautz's sentencing is scheduled for June 10.
