 EASTON — Lauren Rose and Giovanni Wynn were overcome with emotion Wednesday night when Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi called their names during the district's annual Talbot Stars celebration.Rose, band director at Easton High School, and Wynn, family service coordinator at the St. Michaels Judy Center, were named the 2025-26 Talbot County Public Schools Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year, respectively.
They were showered with hugs and applause from a room full of family, friends and fellow educators at the Easton Elks Lodge.
St. Michaels Elementary School principal Indra Bullock spoke of Wynn's passion and dedication in her role at the Judy Center, a family learning hub designed to prepare children up to 5 years old and their families for early education.
"She understands the unique challenges that each family faces and tailors her support to meet their specific needs," Bullock said. "Her compassionate nature allows her to build strong and trusting relationships with both parents and children, as well as staff, making them feel valued and understood."
In addition to Wynn, the finalists for Support Staff of the Year honored Wednesday included: Stacie Rice, special education secretary at Easton Middle; Jane Tillman, math and reading interventionist at Chapel District Elementary; and Christina Titz, instructional assistant at Easton Middle.
Rose was honored by Easton High School principal Sherry Spurry, who read aloud a student's nomination of Rose for the Teacher of the Year award.
"Mrs. Rose has a unique ability to transform the band room into a place where students feel safe, supported and encouraged to grow," the nomination read. "Whether it's a new decoration on the walls or a thoughtful conversation with a student, she makes the space her own, turning it into a welcoming environment for all of us."
The nomination stated Rose has been integral in facilitating band fundraisers and advocating for the band to be centrally located in the stands at Easton High football games.
"Mrs. Rose has been a guiding force in my own development," the student's nomination continued. "She has helped me overcome self-doubt, and has always been there to offer guidance during challenging times. Mrs. Rose's love for her students and her dedication to making our school a better place are truly inspiring."
Rose was one of four finalists for Teacher of the Year, alongside Rebecca Phillips, kindergarten teacher at Chapel District Elementary; Kathy Regan, third grade teacher at St. Michaels Elementary; and Holly Sump, kindergarten teacher at Chapel District Elementary.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, thanked the teachers for their hard work in the demanding field of education.
"Each of you exemplified the best of our profession, a profession that really is fraught with challenges, even on the best of days," Einhorn said. "Despite this, each one of you enter your schools and your classroom each day only seeing opportunities."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson said the staff and teacher finalists are life changers, motivators and inspirations.
"To all of our nominees, tonight is for you," Jackson said. "Thank you for everything you do, and I hope you feel celebrated and appreciated and seen for your unique and outstanding contribution."

title: How much growth is too much for Easton? Balance between housing needs, infrastructure unsettled
author: Konner Metz
content:
How much growth is too much for Easton? Balance between housing needs, infrastructure unsettled

 August 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1988
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The predicament on the minds of many Easton residents and leaders continues to be just how much the town can afford to grow.Easton is under a period of significant residential growth with multiple large-scale housing projects under construction. In 2000, the town's population was 11,708, according to census data. Ten years later, it rose to 15,945, and since, it's grown at a slower pace to 17,101 in 2020.
The boom has raised a litany of concerns, from increased traffic to a change in the town's small-town complexion.
Some residents, and a few officials, think Easton should press the brake pedal. But local real estate agents contend that a halt to growth could box out lower- and middle-class buyers and renters.
Martha Witte Suss, an associate broker for Coldwell Banker Realty and Easton resident, said the housing market has been in a crunch since the pandemic. She said there's not enough reasonably priced homes or rentals to satisfy employees who commute from outside Talbot County.
"We have plenty of housing that they can't afford," Suss said. Residential growth, if it focuses on affordability, could cure that dry spell, she added.
Michael Ports, vice chair of the Easton Planning Commission, poses the town's conundrum like this: "What are the housing needs of the people currently, and can we achieve that in a way that doesn't compromise everyone's needs for services?"
It's a question town leaders are taking on, even if there's no easy answer.
This fall, 136 apartments on Elliott Road will begin opening. Two large communities are under construction east of Route 50, combining for over 450 projected single-family homes. Near Easton's downtown, a developer plans to transform two former Perdue AgriBusiness sites into housing projects, totaling 144 units.
In all, roughly 1,127 units are recently finished, under construction or approved by the town's public bodies, according to information from town planners and developers of the 17 listed projects.
The pipeline of projects has yielded varying opinions from town leaders. Some don't want any new large housing projects approved in the next few years. Others prefer a case-by-case approach.
Mayor Megan Cook said the right answer is "probably somewhere in between." The town should focus on the current projects but not be too quick to disregard new ones, she said.
The mayor said growth is a charged topic and especially complicated due to affordable housing needs. No solution is a "silver bullet," Cook and others have repeatedly said.
"It is a balancing act," Town Council President Don Abbatiello said. "There would have to be a project come along that would fit that need, that workforce housing, that affordable housing piece."
In interviews with The Star Democrat, Easton officials weighed in on the town's current list of housing developments. When asked about infrastructure, the most recognized concerns included roads, fire and police services and schools.
They offered thoughts on where the town should focus its residential growth. Most leaned toward building from the inside-out. Planning Commission Chairperson Phil Toussaint is of that opinion. He hopes the sprawling, single-family developments are coming to an end.
"We wouldn't really want to support any development on the outskirts at all," Toussaint said.
And broadly, the 1,127-unit mark can be misleading since some units aren't under construction and may not be for years, Toussaint and others said.
"(People) think they're gonna appear tomorrow," Toussaint said. "They're not."
Single-family home neighborhoods typically take years to build out, such as Easton Village off of St. Michaels Road, a project of around 250 homes first approved in 2003 and just now reaching completion. So far, the 200-home Gannon Range and 252-home Four Seasons projects only have 18 and 11 building permits, respectively, according to Easton planning and zoning director Miguel Salinas.
"It's a daunting number. It's hard to hear," said Cook, who as mayor doesn't have a vote on housing applications. "But at the same time, you look at some of the examples as a community, the neighborhoods that we've had. They're built out over 20 years."
THE PIPELINE
Since town planners prepared a list of Easton housing projects this winter, chatter of "the pipeline" has been frequent at Town Council and Planning Commission meetings. Those two bodies are responsible for approving most of the projects.
The commission is made up of volunteer members and often can only make a recommendation to the council, whose members are elected. But sometimes, the commission holds final say, such as when it approved the 116-apartment Easton Crossing complex on Brookletts Avenue this year.
The five members of the council and six members of the commission offer a range of opinions when it comes to the town's growth.
Town Council Ward 3 representative David Montgomery provided perhaps the most rigid perspective.
"I want to stop for at least five years before we add anything more to this backlog," Montgomery said. "I want to see how fast it actually grows, it's actually built out."
Others were less firm on completely stopping growth, though all council members interviewed for this story said, at the very least, the town needs to be mindful. Some prefer a project-by-project approach, such as Abbatiello, who said future housing proposals need to be the "right fit" for Easton.
"I think right now, there's enough in the pipeline for us to say, 'Let's see how the projects impact the town's resources before we go adding a lot more to that list,'" Abbatiello said.
Planning Commission members have mixed thoughts, too.
Ports, the commission's vice chair, said Easton is "missing a good bit" even with the current project inventory. He said the missing units largely fall between expensive single-family homes and for-rent apartments — a sphere urban planners call "the missing middle."
"The reality is that the median sale price of a home right now is almost twice what a family of four making the absolute average income here in Easton can afford," Ports said. According to Maryland Realtors, the July 2025 median sales price in Talbot County was $545,000, the third highest in the state.
Tom Klein was the commission's lone vote against the Easton Crossing project, citing traffic and parking concerns. He said the need for more affordable housing is clear. But Klein would prefer to have a target number. At times, it feels like Easton is "chasing something" it doesn't know, he said.
"How many more do we need? Do we just keep assuming we keep needing more?" Klein asked. "That, to me, is something I don't really know the answer to. I think it would be helpful to know that so we don't just blindly build."
'MORE AND MORE CROWDED'
Town planners and engineers have processes to gauge the impacts residential projects will have on the town, such as traffic and environmental studies or reviews by the town's nonprofit utility, sewer and water company, Easton Utilities.
Even with project-specific studies, many town leaders believe traffic is a top-of-list concern, along with other infrastructure matters.
Montgomery said town staff should be "much more skeptical about the traffic impact studies" submitted alongside housing proposals. Ward 4 representative the Rev. Elmer Davis said the traffic issue is obvious to the human eye.
"I don't need a traffic study to tell me that the traffic in Easton, periodically, is a problem at best," Davis said.
Handling traffic backups is a tricky matter, Cook said, since some roads are state-run, others are under county purview and many downtown are maintained by town engineers and public works employees.
Off of Route 328, or Matthewstown Road, 136 apartments are opening soon, while 200 single-family homes will be built just down the road. It's an area residents have flagged during council and state transportation meetings.
"(Route) 328 is going to become busier and busier, and folks, I fear, are going to have more and more challenges getting out to (Route) 50," said Councilmember Robert Rankin, who represents residents in the Route 328 area.
A State Highway Administration planning and environmental study is underway to assess pedestrian and traffic needs on the busy state road that funnels onto Ocean Gateway. Previously proposed concepts by the state include adding left-turn lanes on Matthewstown Road and adding a second through lane on Goldsborough Road as drivers cross Route 50.
Traffic has consistently been brought up as a reason to lean away from annexing land for residential growth outside of Easton's core. Nearly all commission and council members interviewed for this story said they prefer to keep growth within the area encircled by Route 50 and Easton Parkway (322).
The Planning Commission has especially expressed that preference during workshops updating the town's comprehensive plan, which lays out the town's vision for handling growth in the next decade.
In July, the commission rejected the Fox Chase Estates, a 365-unit, mixed-use development proposed near a warehouse and industrial park north of Easton Airport and near the under-construction Shore Regional Health hospital. Town Council members maintain final voting power on the project, though it's unclear when or if it will come before them.
The Planning Commission voted unanimously to recommend against the development, citing a lack of connectivity as a main reason. The vote lines up with the commission's recent direction as they draft the new comprehensive plan: build from the inside-out.
"We'd rather see infill," Klein said. "We want to see connected neighborhoods."
That line of thinking, shared by many Town Council members, still leaves Easton with infrastructure challenges, such as downtown streets, utilities and safety. The latter was emphasized by Cook and council members as a chief priority.
Funding for the Easton Police Department and Easton Volunteer Fire Department makes up around 40% of the town's general fund budget. Abbatiello, who volunteers for the fire company, wants to hold off a massive increase in the cost for fire services by maintaining the department's volunteer status for "as (long) as possible."
"The biggest tax increase residents of Easton are ever going to see is if the Town of Easton needs to go to a paid (fire) department," Abbatiello said.
Easton Utilities evaluates water demands annually. According to a statement from Doug Abbott, director of engineering and water/wastewater departments, the utility is using 60% of its water and wastewater capabilities, leaving 40% "to accommodate future growth."
And as for downtown traffic, some town leaders are worried infill will do more harm than good.
"Our streets are becoming more and more crowded, and I am concerned the more that we have infill development, the harder it is to maneuver around this town," Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said at a comprehensive plan workshop Aug. 25.
"I just don't accept that assumption," Toussaint, the commission chair, later said. He argued that concentrating growth downtown will take cars off town streets and improve walkability.
Overall, the Aug. 25 meeting yielded a key takeaway: the new comprehensive plan is likely to include a preferred annual population growth rate around 1.75%. Planners initially proposed not to mark an annual growth rate in the plan, a change from the 2010 version, which stamped the rate at 1%.
Town Planner Lynn Thomas said at the meeting that without a growth rate, the plan would use historic projections to determine if the town should consider adopting policies to remedy growth trends either "significantly lower or significantly higher" than expected.
But Town Council members said a rate should be clearly stated to keep the town honest.
"I do think it would be helpful to have at least something to point toward," Rankin said. The Planning Commission will adjust the drafted plan later this fall, likely reinstating an annual growth rate, before hosting a public hearing.
The town's Affordable Housing Board and Attainable Housing Task Force are other bodies taking cracks at addressing the housing-growth debate. The task force is currently producing a list of recommended housing policies for the Town Council to consider.
Cook acknowledged that while town boards and discussions are great, "actionable items" — such as the comprehensive plan and policies — are on the way and will bring true benefits to residents. But nevertheless, she's happy Easton is addressing its growth problem head-on.
"No one else around here is having these conversations, but the Town of Easton is," Cook said. "They're difficult conversations. They're polarizing conversations, they're very emotional conversations. But we're having them."

title: Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fingers on buzzers! Which streamer premieres a brand-new comedy film starring Awkwafina ("Renfield," 2023) and Sandra Oh ("Grey's Anatomy") on Friday, Nov. 3? The answer is Hulu, and the film in question is "Quiz Lady," a buddy comedy about two sisters who come together to win a quiz show and save a dog.Awkwafina is Anna, the reliable, type-A sister who is called away from her work as an accountant when her mom's senior living facility reaches out to let Anna know that they had lost her mom - but not to the afterlife.The attendant corrects herself in the trailer, telling Anna, "Sorry, that was terrible phrasing. I meant we don't know where she is." After making it to the facility, Anna is joined by her estranged and distraught sister Jenny, portrayed by Oh, whose purple highlights, oversized sunglasses and flamboyant personal style contrast with Anna's head-to-toe grey wardrobe. Anna is clued in to her mother's whereabouts when a bookie informs her that her beloved pet pug, Mr. Linguini, has been kidnapped and is being held hostage over her mother's massive gambling debts.With the debts creeping up her back and seniors home infractions stacking up, Anna and Jenny's mom flees to Macau, leaving them to sort out what she owes and be reunited with Mr. Linguini. Anna's salary isn't quite generous enough to settle their mother's $80,000 tab, and Jenny's constant search for her latest passion hasn't resulted in financial stability. Two weeks is all they're given to cough up the funds.The siblings are at a loss for ways to get rich quick until Jenny sees Anna participate in her favorite game show, "Can't Stop the Quiz," from her sofa. The show is must-watch television for Anna, who tunes in daily, usually accompanied by her canine companion, and effortlessly answers every single question correctly. Seeing Anna in her element turns on a light bulb over Jenny's head.It's decided, then, that the pair will travel to Los Angeles, get Anna on "Can't Stop the Quiz," and all their problems will be solved when she wins. Leaving the safety of her routine life in Philadelphia behind, Anna joins Jenny on a wild road trip across the United States and embraces her sister's chaotic, adventurous way of life. Neither of them is completely certain that Anna's trivia skills will transfer from the comfort of her couch to the pressure of the game show's set, but this is the best chance they've got to scrape together enough money to bring Mr. Linguini home unharmed.Having spent years apart, estranged over their differences, Anna and Jenny have a lot of ground to cover - geographically and emotionally - on their road trip. Anna's strictly balanced life greatly differs from her sister Jenny's listless pursuit of purpose. They have things to learn from each other, whether it's how to let loose and go on an adventure or focus enough to successfully achieve a goal."The element that really attracted me was the sister dynamic," director Jessica Yu told Deadline at the world premiere of "Quiz Lady" at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. She added, "For one thing, I just haven't seen a lot of comedies about sisters, and the fact that at the center of this was two Asian-American sisters, made me think, 'Oh, this will be really fun to explore.'"

 The application process for the 2025-2026 Talbot County liquor licensing period is now available to the public.Businesses and individuals interested in applying for a new license, or renewing current licenses, can access the application on the board's webpage at talbotcountymd.gov/liquorboard.
All applications must be completed and submitted by March 31. Applicants are encouraged to review the application requirements and guidelines thoroughly to ensure compliance with local and state regulations.
In addition, in accordance with Talbot County Code, Article 2 — Alcoholic Beverages, "Renewal licenses shall be administratively approved without a hearing before the Board, unless a protest signed by not less than ten (10) residents or property owners in the voting district in which the place of business is located has been filed against the granting of a renewal license at least thirty (30) days before the expiration of the license for which renewal is sought." All protests for this license year must be filed on or before March 30, 2025. In the event a protest is filed, it shall be heard and determined as in the case of an original application."
All 2024-2025 alcoholic beverage licenses expire on April 30. The new license must be posted in the business by May 1.
"Our goal is to provide a streamlined and transparent process for applicants," said Victoria Bradley, secretary for the Talbot County Liquor Board. "We're here to assist individuals and businesses in navigating the application process successfully."
For questions or additional assistance, applicants can contact the Talbot County Liquor Board office at 410-770-8019 or via email at vbradley@talbotcountymd.gov. The office is open from 8 a.m. to noon and 1 to 4 p.m. Monday through Friday.

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I'm 28, and I live in a small apartment complex where everyone knows each other. My neighbor, a gentleman in his 50s, saw me smoking a cigarette the other day and decided to take it upon himself to lecture me on the dangers of smoking.Although I appreciated his concern, his lecture was unwelcome. I intend to quit smoking at some point, but I don't need my neighbor to intervene. I fear that the next time I bump into him, he will give me another lecture. What can I do to make him understand that his unsolicited advice is not helping? I'm a grown adult, and I don't need lectures. - Good IntentionsDEAR GOOD INTENTIONS: As you know, your neighbor expressed his concerns out of genuine care for you. Remember that when you speak to him. It is your right to do whatever you want with your life and your body. Provided that the cigarette smoke is not contaminating your neighbors' air, you should be able to smoke in peace.That said, it is likely that this man will either say something or scowl at you the next time he sees a cigarette in your hand. Can you say something?Yes, but be careful. You can thank him for his concern, but put up a guardrail. Tell him you know what you are doing. When you decide to quit, you will. Politely ask him to refrain from giving you advice on this topic in the future.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist andfounder of Dream Leapers, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. title: Sail Selina II to set sail in St. Michaels for final season
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Sail Selina II to set sail in St. Michaels for final season

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 661
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — After nearly a century on the water and more than two decades guiding passengers along the Miles River, the Sail Selina II will be sailing into retirement later this year.Following its upcoming season, which begins next week, Captain Iris Robertson will be retiring. But before it departs the Bay following the end of its season in November, Sail Selina II is going out with a bang.
The boat is joining the National Park Service's Chesapeake Gateways Network, a network of places that offer opportunities for visitors to learn about and enjoy the Chesapeake Bay.
Robertson said in the last 25 years, she estimates close to 60,000 people have stepped aboard Sail Selina II. Some of those passengers, she said, might not have gotten out on the water otherwise.
"The Bay is very fragile," Robertson said. "It's at risk right now. And (for) folks that live in Pennsylvania, (it's) out of sight, out of mind. But they're on the watershed. And Selina's just been a wonderful way for people to connect to something that they participate in even though it's not necessarily in their backyard."
On April 24, there will be a ribbon cutting ceremony at the Harbour Inn Marina in St. Michaels to welcome Sail Selina II into the Chesapeake Gateways Network for its final season. The event will include remarks from National Park Service Chesapeake Gateways Superintendent Wendy O'Sullivan.
GENERATIONS ON THE WATERAlthough Robertson, who lives in Royal Oak, has been the captain of Sail Selina II for 25 years, her history with the boat stretches back to before she was born.
In 1926, Robertson's grandfather had the boat commissioned. Her grandparents kept the boat for 36 years before passing it down to Robertson's parents in 1962. In 2001, Robertson became Sail Selina II's third steward.
"From the time I was about 12, even though I've got older siblings, everybody knew she would come to me," Robertson said. "I was the kid that was aboard, participating, had the interest."
Robertson made the decision to charter the boat so that she could afford to maintain it.
After Sail Selina II's final charter season, Robertson plans to pass the yacht down to her niece, who happens to live in Greenport, New York, where Sail Selina II was built.
"It's like a full-circle thing," Robertson said about the sailing yacht. "She's 100 years old. She's going back to the town she was built in."
Robertson said she knows her grandparents and father, who have since died, would be so proud of the boat's Chesapeake Gateways designation.
"I think they'd be tickled pink to know how much she has contributed to people's joy and experience over the last 25 years," Robertson said.
STEPPING ABOARDWith a 1,000-square-foot canvas sail, the 44-foot-long Sail Selina II is a "stable" and "regal" sailing yacht, Robertson said.
"We have a lot of guests that have never been on boats before, and they're a little bit nervous when they first step on," she said. "But by the time they get off, they go, 'Oh my God, this was like being on a flying magic carpet ride.'"
From wine and beer tasting cruises, to sunset sails, to engagement cruises, to weddings, to private sailing lessons, there are many options for those who want to set sail on Sail Selina II. Robertson said the standard two-hour tour takes passengers around St. Michaels Harbor before cruising out to the Miles River and putting up sails.
"We let the wind determine our course," Robertson said. "And before you know it, two hours has gone by."
Repeat passenger Gene Pisasale said he and his wife love sailing on Sail Selina II because they love being out on the water and they love sailing with Robertson.
"She's got to be the friendliest boat captain on the Chesapeake," said Pisasale, who lives in Pennsylvania. "And she is just a gem, a real gem. A pleasure to sail with."
To charter Sail Selina II during its last season, visit sailselina.com/ or call 410-726-9400. The season will go from April 18 through Nov. 2.

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Representatives from For All Seasons say the problem of human trafficking in Talbot County is persisting, though they are seeing positive gains in awareness and detection.During a Talbot County Council meeting Tuesday, Lauren Weber, the nonprofit's vice president of strategy and development, provided an update to council members regarding human and labor trafficking.
"It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case," Weber said. " … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries."
Weber and Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications, each said the organization has a special role given its wide reach. For All Seasons' presence in the five Mid-Shore counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — is critical to providing victims with essential services.
"We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders," Theeke said. "We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need."
Council Member Keasha Haythe asked if For All Seasons is seeing a decline in human trafficking numbers. Weber said it's a "double-edged sword."
"A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking," Weber said. " … That persists."
The organization has noticed a shift in how many people are recognizing signs of human trafficking and making those reports, Weber says.
"The folks that are self-referring, we're seeing a decline," she said. "But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'"
Weber said that since September, more than 120 people have taken For All Seasons' free, online anti-human trafficking course.
For All Seasons is an official regional navigator for the Mid-Shore area, Theeke said, meaning it works on task forces and serves youth and young adults that are victims of trafficking.
At the end of the discussion, council members thanked the For All Seasons representatives for their work and presented the organization with a proclamation Tuesday declaring January as National Human Trafficking Awareness Month.
"We know that even one victim is too many," council Vice President Pete Lesher said. "We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims."

 On May 24, 1935, the first Major League Baseball game to be played at night took place at Cincinnati's Crosley Field as the Reds beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-1.On this date:
In 1844, Samuel F.B. Morse transmitted the message "What hath God wrought" from Washington to Baltimore as he formally opened America's first telegraph line.
In 1937, in a set of rulings, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Social Security Act of 1935.
In 1941, the German battleship Bismarck sank the British battle cruiser HMS Hood in the North Atlantic, killing all but three of the 1,418 men on board.
In 1961, a group of Freedom Riders was arrested after arriving at a bus terminal in Jackson, Mississippi, charged with breaching the peace for entering white-designated areas. (They ended up serving 60 days in jail.)
In 1962, astronaut Scott Carpenter became the second American to orbit the Earth as he flew aboard Aurora 7.
In 1974, American jazz composer and bandleader Duke Ellington, 75, died in New York.
In 1976, Britain and France opened trans-Atlantic Concorde supersonic transport service to Washington.
In 1980, Iran rejected a call by the World Court in The Hague to release the American hostages.
In 1994, four Islamic fundamentalists convicted of bombing New York's World Trade Center in 1993 were each sentenced to 240 years in prison.
In 1995, former British Prime Minister Harold Wilson died in London at age 79.
In 2006, "An Inconvenient Truth," a documentary about former Vice President Al Gore's campaign against global warming, went into limited release.
In 2011, Oprah Winfrey taped the final episode of her long-running talk show.
In 2017, Ariana Grande suspended her Dangerous Woman world tour and canceled several European shows due to the deadly bombing at her concert in Manchester, England, two days earlier.
In 2018, Jerry Maren, the last surviving Munchkin from the 1939 film "The Wizard of Oz," died at a San Diego nursing home; he was 99.
In 2022, an 18-year-old gunman opened fire at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, killing 19 children and two teachers. The gunman, Salvador Ramos, a former student at the school, was also killed. It was the deadliest shooting at a U.S. grade school since the attack in Sandy Hook, Connecticut, almost a decade earlier.
In 2023, Tina Turner died at age 83. She teamed with husband Ike Turner for a dynamic run of hit records and live shows and survived her horrifying marriage to triumph in middle age with the chart-topping "What's Love Got to Do With It."

title: Spurry's big night pace Talbot in opener
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Spurry's big night pace Talbot in opener

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nathan Spurry was in a closer's role this spring for St. Michaels High's baseball team.Tuesday night he showed he's a pretty fair starter as well.
Spurry hurled a complete game and drove in Nico Nicolopoulos with the winning run in the bottom of the sixth inning, lifting Talbot Post 70 to a 4-3 victory over four-time defending Eastern Shore North Division American Legion champion Caroline Post 29 at Warrior Field.
"Just came out here trying to throw strikes; trying to produce ground balls, get outs," Spurry said.
Mixing a cutter with fastballs, Spurry allowed only two runners to reach base over the first three innings — one on an error, the other on a fielder's choice in the second inning.
Down 3-0, Caroline (0-1-1) scratched across a pair of runs in the fourth. Austin Frank drilled a leadoff double to center field. Colton Maans walked and was lifted for courtesy runner Wes Thomas. Eric Deck (2 for 3) singled to center, scoring Frank. Gavin Whitby (2 for 3) singled to load the bases before Johnny Radcliff grounded out, scoring Thomas to make it 3-2
But Spurry ended the threat there, getting a strikeout before catcher Nicolopolous alertly grabbed a ball that was chopped in front of the plate and tagged Caleb Cole for an inning-ending, unassisted putout.
Caroline rallied to pull even in the top of the sixth on Whitby's one-out RBI single. Again, Spurry escaped any further damage, retiring two of the next three batters to keep it at 3-3 heading into the home half of the sixth.
"Threw strikes," Talbot manager Albert Pritchett said of Spurry, who finished with four strikeouts and two walks. "Got ahead of every batter, mixed it up. Very impressive."
Talbot (1-0) took a 1-0 lead in the home first. Frank issued back-to-back walks to Gavin Murphy and Couper Barletta. Two batters later, Pearson Greenwood laced a double to right field, plating Murphy. Frank squelched the rally there, getting Ethan Royer to pop out and Jesus Crespo on a comebacker to the mound.
Post 70 pushed its lead to 2-0 in the second. Brennen Griffin (2 for 2) hit a leadoff single and Nathan Merchant walked. Spurry then hit an 0-2 offering into left-center field for a double that scored Griffin. Again Frank extinguished a potential big rally, striking out the next three straight batters.
Talbot made it 3-0 in the third, as Tim McGuckin worked a leadoff walk, stole second, advanced to third on Greenwood's groundout to first, and scored when Crespo singled sharply to left field.
Caroline pulled even in the sixth before Talbot moved back in front in the home sixth. Nicolopoulos worked a leadoff walk against Post 29 reliever Chase Hitchens then stole second. Hitchens came off the mound to catch Brody McDaniel's bunt attempt for the first out. Nicolopoulos advanced to third on an errant pickoff attempt. Spurry then grounded out deep in the hole at shortstop, allowing Nicolopolous to score what proved to be the winning run.
"Knocked in the winning run for himself," Pritchett said of Spurry. "Nice game.
"First game, little rusty," said Pritchett, who was without Cullen Murphy, Josh Dressler and Anthony Massaro Tuesday. "Some of the guys haven't played since high school (season ended). We could have had a few more runs, but I think the hitting will come around."

title: Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It should be easy for most of us to be thankful in Maryland. Thanksgiving has just about arrived, that special day for reflection, for sharing our gratitude and for enjoying a splendidly large meal with those we love.We've mostly been spared the political rancor that marked much of the election season nationwide. The local campaigning leading up to filling out our ballots earlier this fall was mostly crisp and clean.
So as we prepare ourselves for the Thanksgiving holiday, let's hope that peace and civility will prevail, at least for a day. Let's hope that when extended families convene for the old familiar feast, debate won't rage between red and blue, but about whether dark meat is more delicious than white meat as the turkey is carved.
Thanksgiving is a legacy of early colonial America, when European settlers thanked God for the harvest that allowed people to survive under difficult conditions. These days, of course, only a dwindling portion of our population here still has lives so closely tied to the harvest. Most of us take comfortable shelter and an adequate food supply for granted every day.
Did you know that we have a president, a secretary of state and the author of "Mary Had A Little Lamb" to thank for Thanksgiving becoming a fully recognized holiday in the United States?
Editor and writer Sarah Josepha Hale launched her campaign in 1827 to see the annual Thanksgiving tradition dating back a couple hundred years become an official holiday. She started with President John Quincy Adams — son of Founding Father John Adams — and finally found success many years later with President Abraham Lincoln in 1863. Secretary of State William Seward penned Lincoln's proclamation, which came in "the midst of a civil war of unequalled magnitude and severity."
"I do, therefore, invite my fellow-citizens in every part of the United States, and also those who are at sea and those who are sojourning in foreign lands, to set apart and observe the last Thursday of November next as a Day of Thanksgiving and Praise to our beneficent Father who dwelleth in the heavens," Lincoln's proclamation reads.
Well, 2024 has certainly been a year, but we still have so much to be thankful for, each and everyone of us.
In a way, we're all accidents of birth, and ongoing accidents of geography. We could be anywhere else in the world — and plenty of those places have more than enough misery to go around. Gratitude for our peace, safety and security here at home would be in order.
We should also be thankful for the people in our community who will be required to postpone their feasts to help others in need. We can take comfort in knowing that police and hospital staff will be on the job, and volunteer firefighters and other first responders could be pressed into service at any time if there's an emergency.
Then there are those thoughtful souls who make sure that anyone who wants to come out can enjoy an absolutely free hot Thanksgiving family-style meal and fellowship. Food banks, soup kitchens and churches around the region help make sure that happens.
For sure, this holiday season that officially kicks off next week and runs all the way through New Year's Day can stretch time, money and sometimes patience particularly thin. But let's face it, most of us have plenty for which to be thankful. And we should have little reason not to feel blessed and grateful on Thanksgiving and every day.
Our community is strong. And through the works large and small of all our friends and neighbors, we will only continue to get stronger. And for that, too, we offer our thanks.
Even in our nation's darkest times, Lincoln and Seward found much to be celebrated: "The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, others have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and even soften the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God."
We can all take their words to heart as we head into the holiday season. We can look to the good. We can focus on the positive. We can find our way forward with thankfulness and love in our hearts.
We wish you all a happy Thanksgiving.

title: Community celebrates Earth Day at Adkins Arboretum
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Community celebrates Earth Day at Adkins Arboretum

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Swinging jazz, food, ecology and crafts for kids marked the outdoor Earth Day celebration on Saturday at Adkins Arboretum. There was also bird song from the woods and the sound of bullfrogs from the pond.The crowd was large, with 300 tickets sold for the event. Multiple environmental groups and government agencies hosted information tables.
Eastern Redbud saplings were given out for attendees to plant at home by Francis Smith of the Maryland Forest Service. There were master gardeners and monarch butterfly experts. A birding trip led into the forest in the morning.
"Earth Day heightens our awareness and appreciation. It is joyful and good to get out. And it is fun to host this site to share with other local nonprofits," said Ginna Tiernan, executive director of Adkins.
"It reminds us to breathe, step out in nature. It is incredible for your soul, your brain," Tiernan said. "It is amazing how clear you can think after a walk in the woods. I took a walk the other day, and a pileated woodpecker just swooped down in front of me. There were pine warblers in my ear. It is just affirming too that we are here on Earth with all of these animals, and we are a part of them."
Adkins celebrated the global holiday a little early this year, with Earth Day actually falling on Monday.
Earth Day is an annual event on April 22 to demonstrate support for environmental protection. First held on April 22, 1970, it now includes a wide range of events coordinated globally.
Jay Falstad, Adkins Arboretum board member and Executive Director of Queen Anne's Conservation Association, was using yellow and orange chalk to create a big sun at the arboretum's entrance.
"Earth Day is the one thing that we all share. We all share the same air, water and the same planet. We should all have an investment in protecting it," Falstad said.
There were many people who have worked hard to make this event happen. Not just organizing and planning but executing a fun educational experience.
Jenny Houghton, assistant director of Adkins Arboretum, said, "We are partnering with other environmental organizations. We thought it would be nice to show people that we are all working together. We have Pickering Creek, Tuckahoe State Park, Maryland DNR, Bartlett Tree Experts, Shore Rivers, Talbot County Master Gardeners and Phillips Wharf Environmental Center."
"The highlight is getting people outside to celebrate nature together and listening to great music, eating local food and hopefully scooping up some tadpoles in the wetland. It is good to remind ourselves that the Earth is worth taking care of, because it is all that we have got," said Houghton.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren | Section: Columns 
 
 277

 Read News Document

 There are many scriptures that tell us to "fear the Lord." My early Christian experiences certainly taught me that. I remember a pamphlet that showed sinners drowning in a literal lake of fire for all eternity. Scary stuff.Author and pastor Rob Bell presents us with an interesting thought though — do we really believe that God, who loves us so much, is going to condemn billions of people, and reward only a select few with heaven? Will He really condemn these billions, throughout history, with eternal torment for things they did in a few short years of their life on Earth? It's not a question I would presume to know the answer to.
I do know this, just as well as you do — our God is a God of love. He loves us so much that He gave His only begotten Son. Therefore, I prefer to substitute "fear" with "love." For instance, Proverbs 1:7 tells us, "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge. Fools despise wisdom and instruction." I like to think that "the love of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge."
I must admit, I have no fear of the Lord. Instead, what I have is respect, reverence, awe, love and an appreciation of His love for me. The love He shows us cannot not be compared to anything else. The angels who appeared to the shepherds, in the Gospel of Luke, gave us good advice: "Don't be afraid, because a savior is born."
Jesus came to us — God in the flesh — bringing love and salvation.
If we live a life of righteousness, following Christ, what do we have to fear? Nothing.

He will be traveling to APG Chesapeake offices in Chestertown, Chester, La Plata, California, Prince Frederick, Dundalk and Elkton for the rest of the week.
Baez was APG's Southern Wisconsin regional president from August 2020 through 2022. A decade before that, he lived on the western shore of Maryland as the CEO of the Maryland Pennysaver.
In 2010, Baez entered the news industry when he took a job with Tribune Publishing Company in Newport News, Virginia.
"I joined newspapers in 2010 and have been with them ever since," he said.
As regional president, Baez will oversee the Chesapeake market.
"I'm excited," he said about his new role. "Adams is a great company. They've been really good to me."
Baez — who won the first ever APG Regional President of the Year award in 2021 — said one of his favorite company memories is when the company asked him for his opinion and they supported him.
"And they let me go do that," he said. "That speaks volumes for the kind of culture that the company has."
Before taking on the new role with APG, Baez was the CEO of TravelHost, a publication connecting businesses with travelers. He said that during his time in the news industry, he's enjoyed getting to connect businesses with audiences that desire the products and services of those businesses.
"That's the creative part," he said. "That's the energizing part."
Baez, whose family immigrated to the United States as political exiles from Cuba, said he is a big fan of free speech.
"From that standpoint I think journalism plays a great part," he said. "I think journalism has evolved a lot, and we continue to evolve it along with what people want. I think we have to get smarter about how we write (and) what we write about because it is something that we have to eventually monetize to sustain."
APG CEO and President Mark Adams said in a news release that Baez brings "familiarity and experience" to this position.
"It's always rewarding when we can have an executive like Orestes return to our organization," he said.
When he's not working, Baez can often be found on the pickleball courts. The three-time national champ is currently playing on the pickleball Senior Pro Tour.
His love for pickleball blossomed after decades of playing tennis. Since picking up a tennis racket at the age of 9, he has won over 300 tennis doubles titles. While in college, Baez played tennis for Clemson University. He also coached the Clemson team while in graduate school there.
It wasn't until he was in his 50s that Baez's friend convinced him to give pickleball a try. Since then, Baez has gone from playing the sport recreationally to playing in tournaments.
As he settles into his new role on the Chesapeake, Baez is looking for houses in Annapolis with his wife, Donna. He said he is excited to contribute to the Chesapeake team.
"It's about removing obstacles and helping guide," he said about his role.

title: Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: General Assembly 
 
 443

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Funding for the Maryland Department of Aging is expected to remain flat over the coming year, according to Maryland Secretary of Aging Carmel Roques.The secretary's comment came after Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) asked if there were concerns about the department's budget outcome during an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.
Concerns are not with losing funding, but with an anticipated inability to grow funding.
"The okay news is we don't anticipate our funding to be cut, but we're not going to have additional funding," Roques said. "And the way we're going to try and make that a better situation is the way we engage with, in a collaborative fashion, … our health and our housing agencies."
The majority of the department's funding comes from the federal government. State funding comprises a smaller portion of the dollars the department has to distribute.
In fiscal year 2024, Upper Shore Aging, the designated area agency on aging for Talbot, Caroline and Kent counties, received almost $782,000 from the state Department of Aging.
Queen Anne's County received about $333,000, and Cecil County received roughly $554,000.
MAC Inc., which is the area agency for Dorchester, Somerset, Wicomico and Worcester counties, received just over $1.3 million.
Knowing the funding was unlikely to grow, the department took steps early on to maximize the funding available to direct it more effectively at the local level, Roques said.
Those steps included working with stakeholder groups to look at three state programs — subsidized assisted living, congregate living and senior care money — to think about redesigning the long-term services and supports system in place from the state funding.
According to Roques, the work being done now will not "dramatically" change anything about fiscal year 2025, but it will in the coming years.
The Administration on Community Living, a federal agency that increases access to community supports for older adults and those with disabilities, also recently changed regulations to include guidance that will impact equity, she said.
Roques said the update to the regulations is "good news" for the rural elderly population, their families and care providers.
The state's rural communities have the highest populations of adults age 50 and older, according to data shared during her presentation.
The rural counties on the Eastern Shore have some of the highest numbers. In 2020, 50.8% of Talbot County's population was over age 50.
Maryland's overall population is rapidly growing older. In the next six years, the state will see more residents over 60 than under 18 — a first, Roques said.
"...What's being baked into that guidance is that rural communities need to be more heavily weighted in the formula for distribution of funds to recognize that their challenges are very different," she said.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season
author: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC | Section: News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Lenten season begins today, a day called Ash Wednesday.Ashes are a sign of mortality and repentance. The uses of ashes dates back to ancient Jewish tradition and often were associated with sacrifices, mourning and fasting. A person would properly express grief, humiliation and repentance sitting in ashes or placing them on the head.
At one time, during the early centuries of the church, public penitents at Rome were ceremonially admitted on this day to begin their penance.
This ceremony fell into disuse between the eighth and 10th centuries as general penance of the entire congregation began to take place. This penance was symbolized through the imposition of ashes.
Another use for ashes in the early church (second century) included a regular ceremony of public confession and penance. This use had acquired so much significance that Tertullian (a prolific early Christian author from Carthage in the Roman province of Africa) spoke of "the substitution of sackcloth and ashes for a man's usual habit."
Today, ashes symbolize the same meanings though the ceremonial customs have vanished. The one exception to this is Ash Wednesday.
The word "Lent" derives from the anglo-saxon term lencten, meaning "spring." During this time we earnestly recount all that God accomplished through the work of Jesus Christ.
We experience this period every year in the life of the church, but often, we forget, or sometimes we never knew what this time of year is about. Lent as a forty-day period of focus on penitence and preparation for the Resurrection Event of Easter. Today, we tend to observe Lent as a time of penance, by abstaining from festivals, by almsgiving, and by devoting more than the usual time to exercises of the faith. In recent years, more emphasis has been placed on these aspects than the physical fasting that marked this season in the early church.
I pray that this Lenten season would be a holy and sacred time of preparation for the celebration of the greatest day in human history; the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

 EASTON — Port Street got a distinguished visitor at the Neighborhood Service Center. Former Gov. Larry Hogan is running for the open U.S. Senate seat and stopped in Easton Friday to talk with people at the service center.He visited the facility on 126 Port Street and asked questions.
The Responsible Father Initiative, founded by Corey Pack and co-facilitated by Lou Dorsey, is an outreach program to help men become better fathers. It is a nonprofit and is all confidential. It provides food, clothing and first month's rent to people in need. These men gave Hogan the tour of the center.
Pack spoke to the governor about what they teach.
"We go over what is called the three E's. Emotion, energy and expression. And we talk about effective listening skills," Pack said. "We run through the 7/38/55 rule. 7% of the way we communicate is verbally. 38% is with our tone and 55% is with our body language."
The governor listened closely.
"I did not realize that," Hogan said. "That is an important lesson for me to learn."
He listened to more about the program.
"We try to develop more nurturing and caring fathers in this program. Most of the guys grew up in a home without a father. Some have been incarcerated with no contact with their children. It is great for them to see their children and establish a relationship with their children," Dorsey said.
Hogan recognized that a lot of men needed these services and saluted their dedication to helping these men flourish.
"It sounds like you guys are doing really important work here," Hogan said.
One of the Neighborhood Service Center workers asked Hogan to run for president. He smiled.
Hogan toured spaces intended for children. Then he went into the kitchen and in another room saw where they store clothes to give away.
At the end of tour, he was give two T-shirts and a coffee mug that touted the Neighborhood Service Center.
After his visit he stopped to do an interview in the parking lot. Hogan said his campaign is focused on the economy and crime.
"We are meeting voters every day," he said. "The people of Maryland know me after eight years of being governor."

title: Common sense degrees needed

Common sense degrees needed

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words

 This past weekend, I was enjoying my morning tea when I got a curious phone call. The gentleman knew me by my nickname, and I quickly became a good listener. Trying to place the voice it took me a few minutes to realize who it was a long-time multigenerational family friend. Let's call him Mike. I would later reflect on what an honor it was for me.For the better part of an hour, he regaled me with stories of yesteryear (none, surprisingly, set in the famed bygone watering hole of that name), featuring my father, grandfather and great-grandfather. My eyes swelled as he began to bring the good old days back to life, first in black and white, then in color. Some stories I had had a taste of, but most were new to me. What gentlemen they were.
I share that story to preface this one. While enjoying the company of "The Thursday Brotherhood" the topic of today's social climate came up. All of our comments were true and valid in their own way; I can only imagine that each generation feels the same, that in any moment in history, there are good times and not-so-good times.
The conversation brought back memories of my great-grandfather Walter Wood; he was the chief of police for then little old Easton. He called it "my town," and used his platform to serve with understanding as only he could. One quality of old Walter I heard about more than a few times was his sensible approach to life. My dad called it his C.S. (common sense) degree.
As it goes, he would leave home after supper, head to the firehouse, and open the door to the locals who needed shelter for the night. Today, we call them homeless. He would lock the door and call it a night. In the morning, the routine played out in reverse. What a novel solution.
Today, we share the same challenges as our predecessors, updated for the 21st century. How we approach them and resolve them is up to us, let's call it perspective. Sometimes what is old is what's new again. Having a bit more compassion and understanding for our neighbors can't be all wrong. Just maybe if we all use our C.S. degrees a bit more, we can all wake up and go to sleep with a smile.
ROO WOOD
Wittman

title: Caps fill void, acquire Thompson
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Caps fill void, acquire Thompson

 June 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News

 The Tampa Bay Lightning and Washington Capitals were active Saturday during rounds 2-7 of the NHL draft, each making multiple moves to shake up their rosters for next season and beyond.Tampa Bay sent two-time Stanley Cup-winning defenseman Mikhail Sergachev to Utah and depth forward Tanner Jeannot to Los Angeles in moves that cleared more than $11 million in salary cap space. That could be enough money to keep captain and face of the franchise Steven Stamkos or make a significant free agent signing, and it will go a long way to providing room to lock up cornerstone defenseman Victor Hedman with a long-term contract extension.
The Lightning got younger on the blue line by receiving 24-year-old defenseman J.J. Moser, along with forward prospect Conor Geekie and two draft picks for Sergachev, who was signed through 2031 making $8.5 million annually. A 2025 second-rounder and a fourth this year allows Tampa Bay to restock its prospect pool after making eight consecutive playoff appearances, winning two titles and reaching the final three times.
That contending window remains wide open, and general manage Julien BriseBois now has flexibility to retool on the fly with free agency opening Monday. Stamkos staying is a possibility, and now the Lightning have the opportunity to pursue one or more of the top wingers available, a group that includes Jake Guentzel, Patrick Kane and Jonathan Marchessault.
The Capitals already did their big-name hunting last week by acquiring highly paid center Pierre-Luc Dubois from the Kings for goaltender Darcy Kuemper. On Saturday, they filled that void in net by acquiring Logan Thompson from host Vegas for a pair of third-round picks.
Thompson figures to split time with Charlie Lindgren in a tandem costing less than $2 million total next season, with a year left on each goalie's contract. Thompson, 27, was an All-Star and played 37 games for the Golden Knights during their 2022-23 championship run before getting injured before the playoffs.
"I got a lot more that I can prove in this league and I'm hoping that I get that opportunity with Washington," said Thompson, who was in bed when he was informed of the trade and hurried to the Sphere for a previously scheduled autograph signing. "Actually, it was a good alarm clock. I woke up to that and then obviously get ready and come down, and I knew it was going to be an interesting day."
Long before getting his name engraved on the Stanley Cup, Thompson got his first foray into the NHL Capitals development camp in the summer of 2018. He played for Washington at back-to-back prospect showcases, went to training camp with the American Hockey League's Hershey Bears in 2019, starred for the ECHL's South Carolina and earned his first contract as a result.
"I'm thankful for the Washington goalie department every day," Thompson told The Associated Press at 2023 All-Star Weekend. "They're the reason why I'm here. They're the only team that gave me a chance three years ago. If it wasn't for them, I wouldn't be here today."
Washington also traded fourth-line winger Beck Malenstyn to Buffalo for the 43rd pick, taking U.S.-born defenseman Cole Hutson, and traded up in the third round to select Ilya Protas, the younger brother of Capitals forward Aliaksei Protas. Malenstyn, 26, is a restricted free agent with arbitration rights who had 21 points in 81 games during his first full NHL season and gives the Sabres Buffalo valuable forward depth as they try to end the league's longest playoff drought.
Looking to end the longest Stanley Cup drought, the Toronto Maple Leafs took a step toward upgrading their defense by acquiring the rights to pending free agent Chris Tanev from Dallas for a 2026 seventh-round pick. The trade gives Toronto the first crack at signing the valuable 24-year-old top-four defenseman.
Vegas moved quickly to replenish goalie depth by acquiring Akira Schmid from New Jersey along with young forward Alexander Holtz in a trade that sent Paul Cotter and a third-rounder to the Devils. Among the other moves, St. Louis traded Kevin Hayes and a '25 second-rounder to Pittsburgh for future considerations to shed the remainder of the his contract, and Boston sent Jakob Lauko to Minnesota for Vinni Lettieri in a swap of centers that also involved draft picks.
The Sabres after getting Malenstyn began the process of buying out the contract of forward Jeff Skinner, GM Kevyn Adams confirmed at the conclusion of the draft. The buyout saves Buffalo $7.5 million next season while spreading out money owed to Skinner against the cap through 2030.

Developers are seeking town approval through Easton's planned unit development process, which would allow the homes to be built on the commercial-zoned land.
The developers are Easton Sunrise Partners LLC and Scott Wagner, a Talbot County businessman and a former Republican member of the Pennsylvania State Senate. They previously aimed to build warehouses on the site, but in recent years plans shifted to residential — an effort that Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel supports, according to Wagner's attorney, Lawrence Scott.
"We are trying to build a residential community that meets the need of the hospital," Scott said Tuesday, noting that Wagner and Kozel have met to discuss the project.
In a statement Wednesday, Kozel said affordable housing availability is "essential" to recruit and retain health care workers in a rural community like Easton. The hospital is not legally or financially involved with the proposed development, Scott said.
At an hours long meeting Tuesday, Planning Commission members were nowhere near ready to provide a positive recommendation on the proposal.
"It feels like we're being the Planning Commission for the hospital and not for the town," said member William Ryall. "And that gives me a lot of concern."
Victoria McAndrews said the plans are "overwhelmingly suburban." Michael Ports, the commission's vice chair, said a lack of connectivity from the proposed development — which sits at the northernmost part of town limits — to Easton's core is a "non-starter."
Philip Toussaint, commission chair, said parts of the plan significantly fall short of meeting Easton's comprehensive plan, which sets the framework for how the town facilitates growth. That comprehensive plan is undergoing an update currently, and McAndrews said such a large project should wait for that update.
Scott said Tuesday that developers have met individually with Town Council members and Mayor Megan Cook multiple times and that the 365-unit project meets affordable housing needs that the town and its residents are asking for.
THE UNITS
Application documents show that developers are planning for a variety of units, including single-family homes, three-story townhomes and multifamily buildings, along with two commercial buildings.
The 365 units are broken down as follows: 108 single-family detached homes, 137 three-story townhomes and 120 multifamily units, the latter of which are contained in four four-story buildings.
The density is well below the maximum permitted by the town's planned unit development standards. According to developers, 185 of the 365 units would be affordably priced.
"We're doing that without even the statutory forcing of us to do it," Scott said, adding that developers have a "bidding war" from home building companies to take on the project. "The market is working on its own."
APPROVAL PROCESS
Fox Chase Estates still has a handful of steps before it is approved by Easton officials. With significant pushback already, it's likely to be a lengthy process.
In staff analysis of the application, concerns were raised about the site plan, which only includes one main vehicle access point to the 365-unit development. An emergency exit stretching west to Goldsborough Neck Road did not satisfy town staff. Scott said developers would prefer not to add that as a main access point but will consider it.
"We really want two access points to any project like this," said Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh.
Talbot County Engineer Ray Clarke criticized the project and the lack of communication between developers and the county. Clarke said it'll put an undue stress on Airport and Goldsborough Neck Roads and added concerns that the homes will be in the runway protection zone for Easton Airport.
"We need to be very, very careful when we're looking at these types of development," Clarke said. "This was general commercial as originally planned. We were told three or four years ago it was going to be warehouses."
On Tuesday, the Planning Commission opted to place a pin in the matter and revisit it on July 17. Commission members may then provide a recommendation.
Once the commission makes its recommendation, council members will consider the application and hold a public hearing before any decision. While the council may take the commission's decision into account, the five council members have the final say, with a majority required for approval.

title: Letter had no good reasoning
author: Staff Writer
content:
Letter had no good reasoning

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sometimes you publish letters to the editor that contain strong political views that are based on false information or bad logic or both.When a political view is based on good reasoning, I don't feel the need to respond. But I do feel the need to respond when a writer gets published with no good reasoning. Such is the case with Mr. Adrian's letter "Gone down a dark road," in Sunday's 14 January edition.
His letter is filled with false statements. For example, he claims that Democrats control elections to push some kind of agenda. There is no evidence for that. Quite the contrary. Mr. Adrian somehow completely missed the well-known information that Republicans are involved in managing elections. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of examples.
Even the head Republican, Donald Trump, knew that when he called the Republicans who control elections asking them to alter votes in 2020. As another example, Mr. Adrian seems to claim that harvesting crops in the fall leads to harvesting ballots. I don't think there is any evidence for that.
But what really gets me is the use of questions for arguments. This illogical method of argument is a tool of conspiracy theorists and despots for thousands of years. "When did you stop beating your spouse?" is the classic retort to that entire form of reasoning.
Mr. Adrian received a document about mail-in ballots and points out he could print it. "What could possibly go wrong?" he writes as if that question is a legitimate argument against the entire process. Without evidence, the question makes no sense, any more than me asking Mr. Adrian when he stopped beating people. Mr. Adrian should read about how the Arizona Republican Party spent millions of tax dollars on a month's-long audit of ballots that only showed Mr. Biden's votes were undercounted. Georgia audited their elections three times by hand counting ballots and found no fraud. These are just two facts out of hundreds of examples that belie the assumption underlying Mr. Adrian's question.
Mr. Adrian poses many other questions that assume evidence where none exists. And he ends his letter with the question, "Which political party controls the Board of Elections anyway?" as if that is a reason for everyone to doubt elections. It is not.
All available evidence is that elections in Maryland are fair and honest. People should appreciate that and take the time to vote.
MICHAEL DAVIS
Easton

 EASTON — The Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites has been recognized as the 2023 Hotel of the Year by Marriott out of more than 1,000 Fairfield hotels worldwide.Tucked next to Chipotle off of U.S. Route 50 and Chapel Road, the hotel is managed by Hill Hospitality, a hotel development and management company. Chad Hill, the company's vice president, said the 82-room hotel stands out in more ways than one.
"This is not a prototypical Fairfield hotel," Hill said. He emphasized its cleanliness, customer service and customized designs that give the hotel a small-town, Eastern Shore feel.
Every year, Hill said Marriott checks into each hotel for a random inspection. Marriott assesses each hotel based on a set of standards, while separately soliciting feedback from recent guests. Based on these evaluations and guest review scores, a small percentage of hotels receive the Diamond Award, a recognition from Marriott of the highest performing tier of Fairfield hotels.
Of the 1,118 hotels evaluated, the Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites was rated fourth in intent to recommend, fifth in staff service and seventh in cleanliness.
The Easton Fairfield was recognized with the 2023 Diamond Award, marking its second consecutive year and third since opening in 2015. However, this year, the hotel went a step further when Marriott recognized it as Hotel of the Year within the Fairfield brand.
According to Cristina Shockley, Hill Hospitality's director of operations, the Easton hotel is a popular destination for corporate stays and those in town for weddings.
Shockley added that many of the employees are familiar with the Eastern Shore and its history and charm, a benefit for guests that are visiting for the first time. Some team members have been at the hotel since it opened, she said.
"We're so fortunate to have an incredible team," Hill said of the team that hovers around 23 employees.
Since the hospitality group is based in Easton, Hill said it's special to have the hometown property recognized at such a high level. Hill Hospitality manages six hotels, two each in Maryland and South Carolina, and one each in Maine and New York. Two additional hotels are in the works, including one in Fruitland that will open in June 2025.
"Every guest is given the opportunity to enjoy the charming small-town atmosphere that the Easton team provides when staying at our hotel," Shockley said in a written statement. "The Hotel of the Year award is a testament to the team's unwavering commitment to give the ultimate in guest service. When walking through the front door, the hotel has a feeling of timelessness and added pride that distinguishes it from other Fairfields in the brand."

title: Local student wins national essay contest
author: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat
content:
Local student wins national essay contest

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Viana Johnston, an eighth grade student attending Lighthouse Christian Academy in Stevensville, has been recently recognized as the national middle school winner of a Bill of Rights Essay contest hosted by the Stanley M. Herzog Foundation.The Herzog Foundation is a national organization dedicated to "advancing Christian education." The foundation enriches Christian (K-12) education by creating and leading various programs.
One of these programs was the 2023 Bill of Rights Essay Contest. All middle and high school students enrolled in a Christian school or those homeschooled in the U.S. were eligible to participate. Winners were selected from one middle school and one high school. Each winner would go on to receive $250 from the Herzog Foundation. The winners' schools also received an additional $250.
Participants were asked to answer these questions in three pages or less, "What made the Bill of Rights so revolutionary and unique when it was ratified? How has the Bill of Rights shaped our country?"
In an excerpt from Viana's eloquently crafted three-page essay, the middle school winner wrote, "The Bill of Rights is famous for that little, life-changing word: freedom, but what most people don't realize is that these documents weren't written overnight. Real people struggled, wrestled, and mulled over each word and phrase that went into the Bill of Rights, until it was finally ratified on December 15, 1791. Not only was it composed through much time and consideration but it secured the rights of people today granting our blessed country to grow, expand, and enter new times of innovation. It summarized what we stood for then and stand for now. It lets a person breathe, work, and earn their way to success."
The Herzog Foundation announced Viana, daughter of George and Cathy Johnston, as the middle school winner of the contest in December. Johnston received the prize money and a trophy for her achievement.
In a release announcing the winners, Herzog Foundation Chairman Todd Graves said, "The Bill of Rights was ratified over 230 years ago and still stands as a beacon for our most fundamental rights as Americans. It's crucial that all young students understand the significance of this founding document."
Kathy Guerra, head of Lighthouse Christian Academy, stated the school was initially in disbelief, as this was the first time their school had made an entry to a contest of this magnitude. However, they were not surprised that Viana had won, as she is a gifted writer who creates masterworks of art with her words. "Viana is an inquisitive, energetic, and ambitious student," says Guerra, who "seeks to excel in all of her subjects."
To learn more about the Herzog Foundation and the programs it has to offer, visit www.herzog foundation.com.

title: rest of mike's story
author: Staff Writer
content:
rest of mike's story

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Rest Of Mikes Story
