 Read News Document

 FOCUS ON THE BASERyan Waite, a veteran campaign consultant and vice president of public affairs with northern California-based consulting firm Think Big, said the political parties and most campaigns are focused on ginning up and turning out their voter bases and don't tend to engage with low-propensity voters."They put resources where it is going to make the most difference. Typically, you are looking at people who have previously voted, who are kind in that soft middle," said Waite, who has mostly worked on Republican campaigns.
Waite said while social media can help engage more voters and could help engage nonvoters, especially young ones, the medium presents challenges.
"You are competing with everything else. The slice of time you get in front of them is very very small," he said of the social media content streams.
Negative campaigning, coarse social discourse and misinformation on key issues have also magnified on social media leaving voters and nonvoters distrustful of content and disparate and sometimes ideological information sources.
"It's hard for average voters to figure out what's going on," said Waite.
In an Aug. 26 letter to the House Judiciary Committee, META Platforms chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the Biden-Harris administration "repeatedly pressured" Facebook and Instagram to censor dissenting content (including humor and satire) related to COVID-19.
The White House defended those actions as helping protect public health from misinformation.
Recent surveys show low levels of trust in politics, the media and government, as well as plenty of economic stress stemming from the post-pandemic inflation wave.
A June survey by financial firm Credit Karma and research firm Qualtrics found 68% of Americans don't believe official economic data touting job gains and easing inflation after post-pandemic spikes in prices.
Another recent poll by Gallup and the Walton Foundation shows Gen Zers (ages 12 to 27) have little trust in the media, government and politics. But they showed strong turnout in 2020 and are expected to also show up in November, said Craig Snyder, campaign director for Haley Voters for Harris (a group that hopes to get GOP supporters of former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley to eschew Trump).
NEW ENERGY?Snyder said Harris' campaign should energize younger voters more than the matchup between Trump and President Joe Biden.
"They weren't excited about a race between two 80-year-old men," said Snyder, noting that Democratic enthusiasm for Harris will also generate GOP energy for Trump.
Harris was installed at the top of the Democratic ticket after Biden, 81, was pressured to quit the race by donors and party power players over concerns about his age.
Snyder said voting groups such as suburban women, Black and Hispanic men, along with voters on both sides of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas could tip the race in battlegrounds such as Michigan, Wisconsin, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.
Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s endorsement of Trump could also shift his voters, many of whom are disaffected by COVID policies (including vaccines), in key states.
Snyder also sees another contingent of nonvoters beyond the disaffected and those with logistical barriers.
"There's a third group," he said. "They just don't connect politics to their lives."
GOTV EFFORTSPolitical organizations on both sides do have get-out-the-vote (GOTV) efforts across the country, including some aimed at first-time and nonvoters.
Conservative groups — such as Christians United for Israel — hope to turn out evangelicals for Trump and Republicans. That includes working with churches across the country on support for Israel and voter mobilization.
Democrats look to college campuses, as well as Native Americans, Blacks and Hispanics in key races.
In Montana, Nick Marroletti, coordinated campaign director for the state Democratic Party, said grassroots turn-out efforts have included knocking on 100,000 doors and making 97,000 phone calls supporting U.S. Sen. Jon Tester, who faces a tough challenge from Republican Tim Sheehy.
'LACK OF FAITH'Mara Ostfeld, a research scientist at the University of Michigan, analyzed voting sentiments in Detroit and found Latino voters, in particular, have lower turnout propensities.
Ostfeld agrees that nonvoters, especially lower-income ones, don't see the outcome of elections impacting their daily lives.
"There is a disconnect," Ostfeld said. But she also said that doesn't mean nonvoters are not engaged or connected to their communities in other ways and don't follow politics.
"It's not like they are disinterested or disengaged," Ostfeld said. "There is just a lack of faith in the political system in particular."

title: Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 1257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is built, running and ready for the next step in the Lakeside development plan, which is transferring ownership to the town of Trappe.Two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented during a recent Trappe Council meeting. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
This controversial project has faced lawsuits, petitions and an array of public outcry over environmental concerns, but it is an essential step in moving forward with the Lakeside development.
First proposed over 20 years ago, the planned 2,501-unit Lakeside at Trappe development spans more than 850 acres off of U.S. Route 50. The development is slated to include a mix of single-family homes, townhouses and apartments, and commercial and retail spaces.
Trappe's existing plant has the capacity to take on wastewater from the development's first 120 homes. That flow will eventually be diverted to the new wastewater treatment plant serving the development, a plan approved by county legislation and via an MDE wastewater discharge permit.
Spray irrigation systemThe new plant, set with enriched nutrient removal technology, uses a spray irrigation system to discharge treated wastewater onto nearby fields.
According to the Pennsylvania Water Science Center, the sprayed wastewater either evaporates into the air, soaks into the soil or percolates through the soil and recharges the groundwater.
Robert Rauch, president of Rauch Inc., a project management and civil engineering firm for Lakeside, said spray irrigation has been recognized for years by states and the federal government as a preferred method of treated wastewater disposal.
"It is an exceptional re-use method of disposal that recharges groundwater and can provide needed nutrients to agricultural ground covers," he said. "Generally, spray irrigation does not require the highest levels of treatment, so valuable nutrients are available for plants to reduce farmers' costs for additional commercial fertilizer."
Raunch said this is based on Lakeside's developer's voluntary election to provide enhanced nutrient removal level treatment to avoid groundwater nutrient increases. The MDE discharge permit establishes strict limitations on the discharge of treated wastewater, which results in the application of a fraction of the nutrient uptake requirements of the grass planted in the irrigation field.
Raunch said that due to the high quality of the Lakeside wastewater effluent and the nutrient needs of the ground cover, there is no practical scenario in which the spray irrigation of treated effluent will negatively impact surface or groundwater.
"Ironically, the nutrient levels of the treated effluent will be so low that the farmer will have to apply fertilizer to the spray irrigation field to maintain a vigorous and healthy crop cover," he said.
Alan Girard, advocacy director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, argued that nutrients absorbed into groundwater could eventually discharge into nearby impaired rivers and streams like the Choptank River.
"I don't think people understand that the state is claiming that there will be zero discharge of nutrients to groundwater," Girard said. "The state has already demonstrated that there's a link between groundwater and surface water and surface letters that are tarred right near the discharge. So the state needs to be accountable for that issue."
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation and ShoreRivers filed separate petitions for judicial review of the permit in, citing concerns about the spray irrigation of treated wastewater and specifics of a nutrient management plan not being made available during the permit's public comment period in 2020.
Matt Pluta, Choptank riverkeeper and director of riverkeeper programs for ShoreRivers, said that the wastewater issue has been a concern for ShoreRivers due to the existing Trappe plant and how poorly it has been functioning and treating the wastewater before discharging it into Trappe Creek.
According to Pluta, the Lakeside Plant is making noticeable improvements that were not seen in the old Trappe Wastewater Plant.
"I'll go on and say that one thing that's very clear and obvious is that there will be more treatment from this new plant," Pluta said. "The wastewater will be treated to a cleaner standard. That's what we want to see. We support that. The thing that concerns us with the new plan is just the method of discharge. That's where they'll be spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields."
Pluta said the way the state permits spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields is under what he calls "legal fiction or false assumptions." When someone is spraying wastewater on a farm field, that wastewater gets taken up by the plants.
Through studying agricultural practices, Pluta has learned of the impacts of runoff and pollution on groundwater. He said there are different incentives for someone operating a wastewater treatment plant compared to farmers caring for local crops.
Pluta stated that no farmer is applying nutrients to their crops every day throughout the whole growing season. There is an incentive for wastewater treatment operators to focus on controlling their volume and not so much on a healthy crop, which Pluta said is concerning for the sake of adding too much pollution to these fields.
Each farm that receives spraying from the plant needs a nutrient management plan on how many nutrients can be put on the fields. Those plans were not public information, but because it was part of the treatment process, ShoreRiver argued to make that information public.
It was through the 2020 filed lawsuit that the permit was remanded to the Maryland Department of the Environment, which issued a new permit with fewer homes and less wastewater.
A separate lawsuit was filed against MDE by concerned residents in May 2022 asking to revoke the permit and suspend any work with a sewage system as inconsistent with the county's comprehensive plan. Though the suits was ultimately dismissed last June, MDE issued a revised discharge permit for Lakeside, approving a significantly smaller wastewater treatment plant.
The revised permit allows for an average flow of 100,000 gallons per day. A vast decrease from the 540,000 gallons per day initially requested by the developer.
OversightIn part due to the outcry and lawsuits made by residents and environmental organizations, a wave of resolutions were brought forward to better address concerns involving the Wastewater Treatment Plant.
One that stood out to many was Resolution 338, which amended Talbot County's Comprehensive Water and Sewer Plan. It requires an amendment to the comprehensive plan for any future expansion of the new Lakeside wastewater treatment plant.
Though this was deemed favorable to the environmental organizations, there were many, including members of Trappe's council, that opposed the Lakeside resolutions.
During a public hearing before the vote of Resolution 338, Brian Schmidt, Trappe Town Council president, commented opposing the resolution and stated that the county was treating Trappe differently than other towns, hurting the municipality's growth.
"We did not ask this council to intervene," Schmidt said. "MDE is the controlling authority in matters of wastewater discharge, not the county. Disguising growth legislation as wastewater discharge is not proper procedure is only impeding the town's authority to control its own growth."
Next stepsDuring the June 5 Trappe Town Council meeting, two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
According to Showalter, Once the initial phase of the wastewater treatment plant is complete and turned over to the town, the developer remains responsible for any deficiencies between the costs of operation and maintenance and the sewer revenues collected by the Town from Lakeside residents. Additionally, the developer remains responsible for the incremental expansion of the wastewater treatment plant as the capacity is utilized.
Further discussion on the transfer agreements will be discussed and reviewed during the Town Council's next executive session.

title: As avian flu spreads, local businesses grapple with increased egg costs
author: Konner Metz
content:
As avian flu spreads, local businesses grapple with increased egg costs

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 460
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Steve Mangasarian's is paying double what he used to for wholesale eggs.He says the price has been rising steadily since the pandemic. The recent spread of avian influenza virus, or avian flu, is accelerating that trend.
Mangasarian, the owner and chef of Breakfast in Easton, buys eggs from a vendor that sources locally. Due to the avian flu threatening poultry flocks nationwide, egg shortages are impacting businesses.
"The entire supply, nationwide supply, has been curtailed because of this. There's a shortage, even though I'm using local, fresh eggs," Mangasarian said. "Everybody's getting squeezed."
Mangasarian, like some other business owners, has been forced to raise prices. At Breakfast in Easton, he's added a 50-cent surcharge to an order of eggs and a 75-cent surcharge to an order of pancakes.
"It is my intention to make this temporary," signs in the restaurant read.
Avian flu outbreaks across the nation have afflicted egg supply, with the worst impacts felt in western and midwestern states. But local flocks have been affected as well.
Per the Maryland Department of Agriculture, five commercial poultry farms on the Eastern Shore have experienced outbreaks, including three just last month. Several other cases were reported in Delaware.
The virus can spread easily between flocks, though the risk for bird-to-human transmission is low at present.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the average cost for a dozen eggs was $4.15 at the end of 2024. One year earlier, the average cost was $2.51.
The current mark is nearing record costs seen during the avian flu outbreak in 2022. And U.S. Department of Agriculture projections predict a 20% increase in egg prices for 2025.
For Mangasarian, the sharp rise in egg prices has been a significant challenge. In past years, lower egg wholesale prices helped him "subsidize" a low return on bacon. That's flipped, however, as his returns on bacon now make up for tight egg returns.
At the Easton Diner on U.S. Route 50, manager Tiff Haddaway says it costs around $1,000 more per week to purchase eggs due to the recent shortage and wholesale prices. As of now, customers aren't seeing an upcharge.
"The owner is trying to not pass it onto the customer," Haddaway said.
Steve Andrews, owner of the Bagery, says customers aren't experiencing any increases since the business' local, free-range producer hasn't been hit by the avian flu.
Andrews, a backyard chicken flock owner for more than 15 years, did note that egg production costs have risen in past years due to increasing feed prices.
"We foresee that all producers, which get their day-old chicks from just a handful of operations, will all be increasing their demand to replace the culled flocks," Andrews wrote. "If any of the hatcheries themselves have an outbreak, this could indicate that egg prices have not peaked and could rise even further."

 EASTON — Both coaches obviously wanted victory, and after 80 minutes of heated, physical play in the latest installment of the Easton-St. Michaels High soccer rivalry, Warrior head coach Avery Brice breathed a sigh of relief as his team continued its late-season surge."Good game. One-oh. Got the result," Brice said after Rodrigo Fresco's goal in the fifth minute Wednesday night proved enough for a 1-0 Easton victory over the Saints.
And though St. Michaels suffered its fourth loss in five games, Saints head coach Pat Hambleton may have gotten something he was looking for as well — momentum.
"We've had a hard stretch," Hambleton said after his team's third one-goal loss in 10 days, which included a 3-2 double-overtime defeat to two-time defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne's County. "I asked them, 'Just give us momentum. Create momentum so we can move forward. Win, lose, draw, figure out a way to play well. Work hard. Find something to carry on for tomorrow (a 9-0 victory Thursday over Cambridge-South Dorchester) and then carry on into the playoffs.'"
The Saints (6-4-1 overall, 2-4-1 North Bayside) may have found that momentum, playing the game's last 35 minutes, 54 seconds a man down after one of its players received a red card while an Easton player was given a yellow.
"I thought down (to) 10 men, I felt like we had the upper hand, and I felt like we were the man up," said Hambleton, who argued Easton should have also received a red.
"Couldn't be more proud," Hambleton added of his team. "We took them out of their game. They were sitting six guys in the back for the last 20 minutes terrified of our attack and our pressure. And I thought the second half was a completely different game than the first half."
With 4:28 elapsed in the first half, Fresco got a ball on the right side and parked it past Saints keeper Lucas Greenwood for the game's lone goal and a 1-0 Warrior lead.
The remainder of the game featured a string of highlight-reel saves by Greenwood (10 saves) and Easton goalie Sam Hutchison (eight saves).
Greenwood leaped to punch a ball away with 26:10 remaining in the first half. Hutchison stopped St. Michaels' Abel Delgaudio just 50 seconds later. Greenwood lunged left to foil Luke Stanco a little over 5 minutes later. St. Michaels' Connor Wheeler then struck a direct kick that Hutchison reached before colliding with Delgaudio. Greenwood made another stop a moment later, and Hutchsion responded with another save before a second collision 5 minutes later, leaving Brice pleading with his team, "You need to wake up."
The game was mostly played between the 18s in the second half, though both keepers continued to come up big. Easton had a chance to pad its lead 9 minutes into the half, but Emmet Fox drove a shot off the left post. Hutchison picked up another save, when he knocked away a ball on a Saints corner. Greenwood maintained the one-goal difference, smothering a ball off a wild scramble with an Easton player leaping over him.
"We just need to be consistent in the back and then take care of the ball a little bit better," said Brice, his team 6-5, 6-2 after its fourth win in five games.
For Hambleton, it was a familiar theme.
"The story of the second half of our season is we're winning games off the scoreboard," Hambleton said. "And that doesn't count."

title: With some rules, a civil discussion is possible
author: DAVID REEL
content:
With some rules, a civil discussion is possible

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week, my wife and I hosted a visit from a longtime friend who I met before starting elementary school and have known ever since.Before he arrived, we agreed that because we have different opinions on issues in the political arena, we should avoid any discussion on politics while he was here.
We knew there are increasing numbers of family members, friends and acquaintances who are not on speaking terms due to strongly held and diametrically opposing political positions.
Instead of discussing politics, our time together was filled with talking about a wide range of other matters.
We talked about where he and I grew up, the schools we attended and all the changes that have occurred there.
We also discussed the challenges and opportunities we experienced with raising a family and long-distance relocations made necessary by job changes.
We talked about other childhood friends who died too soon and those who have recently died or are experiencing serious health problems.
Before his visit ended, we decided with some trepidation to discuss politics.
We did so with five rules:
Listen respectively to other points of view, even if we disagree strongly with them.Embrace the idea that listening is more than waiting for your turn to talk.End every discussion on strongly held differences of opinion with "you may be right."Not all discussions are a debate with a winner and a loser.Disagree without being disagreeable.
Following our rules was not always easy.
It was always worthwhile and meaningful.
For example, we discovered that we shared common ground with deep concerns over the steadily decreasing levels of civil discourse in our society.
As a result, shortly before my friend left to return home, we discussed Robert Putnam's book "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community."
Written 25 years ago, "Bowling Alone" is still relevant today.
The book's unusual title is based on Putnam's research showing the number of people who bowl alone had increased, but those who bowl in leagues had decreased.
He suggested that when people bowl alone, they do not have opportunities to participate in the social interaction and civic discussions that might occur in a bowling league environment.
Putnam also wrote about the measurable declines in membership and participation in religious organizations, labor unions, parent–teacher associations, military veterans' organizations, fraternal organizations and community service organizations.
Putnam did acknowledge that some organizations and issue advocacy groups had increased their membership rolls, but they rarely focus on fostering face-to-face interactions that build what Putnam called social capital. Instead, they focus instead on fund raising, collecting dues, marketing services, lobbying and sending periodic news updates to their members.
Putnam also drew a distinction between two different but equally important types of social capital.
One type is "bonding" which occurs within a homogenous demographic group.
The other type is "bridging" which unites people from different groups.
Putnam concluded a lack of social capital undermines the active civic engagement that a strong democracy requires from its citizens.
I now know my friend's visit was more than a get-together to talk over old times, catch up on current times and ponder on the future.
In all our discussions, including those with civil discourse on politics, we built social capital.
It was unexpected opportunity to think about and evaluate what I can be and should be doing to help address the lack of civil discourse and to help increase social capital in our society.
The answer is clear.
Going forward, I must consistently strive to:
Respectively consider all points of view.Listen with more than waiting for my turn to talk.Say regularly "you may be right."Limit discussions as debates.Disagree without being disagreeable.Always look for opportunities to build social capital.

title: Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety
author: PETE LESHER
content:
Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PETE LESHER | Section: Columns 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Four years ago, Talbot County voters overwhelmingly approved a temporary increase in the property tax revenue cap by an "extra penny." Our public safety operations were facing a recruitment and retention crisis because of low pay and inferior benefits compared to surrounding jurisdictions.Talbot County has made enormous progress with the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022. Sheriff's deputies' pay is competitive and sheriff's deputies now are on the state-sponsored LEOPS retirement program, allowing them to retire after 25 years. These benefits, in conjunction with solid leadership, means the Sheriff's Office can fill open positions. Deputies now retire from the department – a once-rare circumstance – rather than leaving to work in other jurisdictions.
Likewise, our Emergency Services compensation has increased.
Pay for paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 dispatchers is more competitive than in 2020 — though we need to monitor this against surrounding counties, and paramedics are now eligible for the LEOPS retirement program, a popular benefit. The county has stepped its sixth advanced life aupport ambulance crew to a seven-day, round-the-clock unit, helping us keep response times within the critical 8-minute standard.
The county is planning a new ambulance station near the Chapel District Elementary School, which will help reduce response times in the northeast corner of Talbot County, where we have struggled to meet the 8-minute standard.
Our County Detention Center has faced staffing shortages, forcing mandatory overtime to operate the facility safely. The County has responded by boosting correctional officer salaries and budgeted to convert their retirement plan to the more robust state-sponsored CORS program.
The state of Maryland mandates what we spend on our court system and the minimum that we must spend on public schools. While the state allows the county to exceed its property tax cap to fund schools, there is no state mandate to fund the sheriff's department or ambulance services or road repairs. And so these critical county services may suffer if the property tax cap restricts revenues and forces cuts.
All of the funds raised by the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022 — and more — has gone to boosting public safety. The "extra penny" runs out in 2026. The Talbot County Council unanimously authorized a ballot question to renew the "extra penny" for seven more years, out of concern public safety costs will continue to rise faster than the 2% property tax cap.
Voting for Question A allows the County Council the option to levy the "extra penny" for seven more years — through fiscal year 2033. Even with this "extra penny," over the last four years or for the next seven years, Talbot County maintains the lowest property tax rate in the state of Maryland.
If you support public safety and emergency services, vote for Question A. Do it for your family's safety. Do it for your neighbors. Do it for your own good. Vote for Question A.

St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 ST. MICHAELS — The summer tourism season comes to an end after Labor Day. For multiple businesses in St. Michaels, it could mean a slow down in business.Businesses in St. Michaels are preparing for the fall and winter months by cutting back on some costs.
"It's something that we know is coming every year," Craig Schury, owner of Pemberton Pharmacy & Gift St. Michaels, said. "This year has been a little more difficult than most, so we're prepared. We pair down our staff a little bit and we try to keep our merchandise pretty tight. If we control those cost, we know we can be alright."
According to some business owners in St. Michaels, this year's tourism season has not been as good as previous years. While data specific to this year's tourism in St. Michaels is not yet available, domestic tourism nationally has seen a slow down.
According to Bank of America, their aggregated card data showed softer lodging, tourism and airline spending in 2025.
Some St. Michales businesses plan shift merchandise to fit with upcoming seasons in hopes of keeping revenues up.
"We have less families in the fall, more couples, more anniversaries, more getaways, baby moons once the kids are back in school," said Courtney James, manager for The Preppy Redneck store.
"So, it's a different vibe in that a lot of people stop on their way to the beach in the summer and they have more families. Boating season also goes into October. So, a lot more people when it's cooler come out on their boats, um, which is a different vibe too. Each one brings kind of a different vibe."
While the shift in merchandise and savings is key for business, the one major factor business owners hope to continue to see during the fall and winter months is support from the local community.
"It's paramount," said Jay Hudson, owner for Blue Heron Coffee. "We're here for the community, so having the community support throughout the winter means the world. I look at the community as more of the sustainable business model, they're here every day, so their support means all the world. Tourism kind of comes and gos, but to have the community support, not just through the winter, just in general, means the world to a business."

title: NEW HEIGHTS
author: Bill Haufe
content:
NEW HEIGHTS

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 Words

 As March Madness is set to tip off, three of the most recognizable names in college basketball are in the women's tournament: Caitlin Clark, Angel Reese and Paige Bueckers.Clark drew record crowds and ratings all season long. Reese has LSU in contention for a second straight national championship. Bueckers is finally healthy and doing things on the court for UConn reminiscent of her freshman season when she was the AP Player of the Year.
Throw in a few stellar freshmen like JuJu Watkins and Hannah Hidalgo and the game is reaching heights it's never seen.
"One thousand percent we've seen a shift in just the perception of women's college basketball in general," USC coach Lindsay Gottlieb said. "It doesn't have to be at the detriment of men's college basketball. The increased coverage and star power these players have; they are legitimate, popcorn-worthy type of players."
For countless seasons, the buzz around the NCAA tournaments have often been on the men's game. The one-and-done stars, the juggernaut blueblood programs, the buzzer beaters and athleticism all getting more attention. The women's game has pretty much all of that too, and the ratings and attendance this season suggest casual fans are fully engaged with a game that boasts star power and an increasingly high level of play.
It helps that the women's players stick around for three, four or even five years without the chance to leave early for the pros so fans get to know them and watch them grow. Three years ago, Clark said she thought women's players should be allowed to turn pro after their freshman year, like the men can.
Instead, she stuck around and had a record-setting year that grabbed the nation's attention.
"It's really, really evident that there's stars out there in this game," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "Whereas before I think they were there, but nobody wanted to acknowledge it and appreciate it as much. ... They're just really good. Everybody is going around telling everybody how good they are. They're all visible."
ESPN said it just saw the most watched women's college basketball regular season in more than 15 years, with viewership up 37% on its platforms from last season. That doesn't really even include the Clark effect as Iowa's star wasn't on the network much this season. Iowa's ratings on Fox Sports were the highest in a generation.
ESPN plans to show all of Iowa's games, including a few on ABC, as far as the No. 1 seed advances in the tourney.
"It's not just UConn and Tennessee on TV," Auriemma said. "Those kids are on TV a lot. They're in the limelight a lot. They know how to handle it because they're used to it now."
Clark, who broke the NCAA all-time scoring record this season, has helped six different networks reach all-time viewership marks for women's basketball over the past year, starting with last season's NCAA championship game that drew nearly 10 million viewers.
"I kind of get to be in the spotlight and I get to change people's viewpoint of how they see women's basketball," Clark said before the season. "The amount of people that have come up to me and said, 'I've never watched women's basketball before before you and your team ... .' Some people could take that as a negative. But to me that's a positive. We're finally getting them to turn on the TV and watch it, but not only watch it once. They're coming back for more."
People aren't just watching, they are also coming to games too. All five of the power conferences had huge crowds for their tournaments. The SEC and Big Ten had their best attendance ever. The Pac-12, ACC and Big 12 weren't far behind.
"The big names continue to put up big numbers and people are watching and the media is paying attention," Bueckers said. "The tournament will be great and will continue the rise of women's basketball."
Fans who pack the arenas are also sticking around afterward, hoping to get a coveted autograph. The importance of the moment isn't lost on the game's stars. Clark, Reese, Bueckers, Watkins and many others spend time postgame signing and taking pictures with not only young girls, but boys, too.
"There were 400 people in the stands before she got here and now we're selling out," Gottlieb said of Watkins. "We've got NBA players who want to see her, WNBA players, musicians and actors too. Regular fans also, it's a diversified crowd. Little boys and girls who ask me if I know JuJu. Could they meet Juju? Grown men you run into in downtown LA."
Even when Clark leaves for the WNBA after the NCAA Tournament, the future of women's basketball is still strong with Bueckers, Watkins, Hidalgo and many other up-and-coming players.
"It's going to get even better. So many kids coming out of high school are just unbelievably good," Auriemma said.

title: Talbot school board dives into test score trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school board dives into test score trends

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot school officials took a deeper look at state test scores last week, indicating upward trends in math and English for some grades and dips in others.At a work session on Sept. 15, Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, presented to Talbot Board of Education members breakdowns of 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program scores by grade and student group.
The presentation showed increases from the previous year in English proficiency for third and fourth grades, but drops for fifth and eighth grades. Math proficiency spiked year-to-year for fourth, sixth and seventh grades, but the number of students proficient algebra significantly fell.
The deeper dive came after the state released test score data for the 2024-2025 school year last month. While proficiency rates increased statewide, Talbot County students saw mixed results. English proficiency dropped to 45.4%, 16th in the state and the largest year-to-year decrease (1.9%) of all districts.
In math, 18.9% of students were proficient, 18th in the state and nearly even with the previous year's mark. Other counties, such as Dorchester, saw notable gains, rising spots in the statewide rankings.
Two days after the Sept. 15 work session, Talbot Board of Ed Member Deborah Bridges said at a monthly meeting that the district's results kept her up at night.
"After our work session on Monday night, I couldn't sleep," Bridges said. "Our scores, it upset me so much. And I wondered, what are we missing? What is going on in our schools?"
Board members largely agreed that the results aren't a matter of pointing fingers at teachers or staff. Instead, they are focused finding solutions to fix some of the problem areas.
Board President Emily Jackson said at the work session that she hopes school officials can begin to pinpoint some reasons behind the data trends.
"If I look at us, and we're going down, whereas a neighboring county who has a similar population of kids and they're going up, I want to know why," Jackson said.
Einhorn said while the state tests are an "important measure," it's one of many ways to assess academic achievement and growth.
"This is one assessment given at a single period of time, which does not always accurately reflect what students know and what they're able to do overall," Einhorn said.
ENGLISH
Fifth and tenth grades suffered the largest proficiency drops of 5.6% and 10%, respectively. But fourth grade proficiency rose to 50% in the most recent results. And while third grade proficiency dipped from last year's 47.9% mark, it's still at 43.6%, an improvement over a 35% rate two years ago.
"This really speaks to the work that this board has invested in early literacy, and starting to see that trend move up," Einhorn said at the work session.
Meanwhile, most student groups followed the district's overall trend of slightly decreasing in English proficiency. Asian students fell from 68.9% to 51.2%, while Talbot's multilingual learners dropped from 8.7% to 5.1%.
MATH
One of the sharpest drops came in Algebra II proficiency: 32.8% of students passed the state test in 2023-2024; only 7.1% passed in 2024-2025.
Einhorn acknowledged that as an "area of need." She noted that new math standards for K-8 will go into effect next school year. And in two years, the district will begin integrated algebra courses, infusing geometry concepts, she said.
Fourth grade rose nearly six percentage points to 32% proficiency this past year, while seventh grade had a similar hike from 11% to 17%.
By student group, one result stood out: Black students in the district remain under 5% proficient in math. Einhorn admitted the shortcoming.
"The less than 5% is indicating that we are still underserving our Black students and that we still need to continue looking at strategies that better prepare them to show what they know and are able to do in mathematics," Einhorn said.
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry said she'd like to see the district work with community partners to specifically tackle the gap in math proficiency for Black students.
Board members thanked Einhorn for presenting the detailed trends, acknowledging that there's work to be done to get some of the numbers going in a positive direction.
"We have to do better, and we're open to hear how we're going to do that," Jackson said.

 Maryland small business owners will get help with legal, accounting and financial services under a new $10 million grant from the federal government, officials announced last week.The Treasury Department is awarding the money this fall as part of the American Small Business Opportunity Program.
The award came as good news to Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, who used to run his own small business helping underserved students navigate college.
"When people would tell me it's really hard to build a business in Maryland, my response to them was always the same: I know, I had to do it myself," Moore said in a Monday press call announcing the grant.
"This is going to help more Marylanders turn ideas into jobs and businesses," Moore said, "and turn individuals into job creators."
The money is meant to fuel local growth and provide innovative resources to disadvantaged start up businesses in the state, according to a Treasury press release.
This federal funding will go to the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, an independent instrument of the state that provides funding, insight, resources and connections to early stage companies.
"There are three 'T's' that every entrepreneur faces: they face a challenge of time, a challenge of talent, and a challenge of treasure," said Troy A. LeMaile-Stovall, CEO of TEDCO.
The program, he said, will "give them access to talent that they need to grow and scale their enterprises."

title: Julia Child's kitchen at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
Julia Child's kitchen at the library

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Monday, March 3, at 6 p.m., in the Easton branch of the Talbot County Free Library, it will be my honor to interview Paula Johnson about her newest book, "Julia Child's Kitchen: The Design, Tools, Stories, and Legacy of an Iconic Space."Full disclosure: Johnson is a lifelong friend of mine. She is also a distinguished curator at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. Among her many curatorial triumphs, it was Johnson and co-curator Rayna Green that brought Julia Child's kitchen to the museum in 2001. Almost a quarter of a century later, it remains one of that institution's most popular exhibits.
I was one of the lucky fellows who received a copy of Johnson's new book when it came out in October.
Initially, truth be told, I wasn't sure what I would think of a book about a kitchen, fool that I am. Anyone who knows Julia Child, read her books or watched her television shows, knows that a book about Julia Child's kitchen is a book about Julia Child.
It's been a long time since I've had so much fun reading a book.
And the word "fun" is apt. Again and again in the book, as people recall cooking with Child in her kitchen or a meal they shared there, the word they use to describe both their host and the place is "fun."
Which is not to say that serious labor did not take place in that kitchen.
The book makes it clear that Child and her husband Paul were both workhorses. In the early television shows, the sponsoring public television station, WGBH Boston, couldn't afford retakes or editing. Julia had to begin upon a complicated recipe, carry it through, instructing all along, and arrive at a finished product that she could take a bite out of in just 28 minutes flat. The cameras shut off at 28 minutes, and there was no going back.
To accomplish this feat of legerdemain, she and Paul would practice for hours at home before a show, choosing which elements of a recipe to demonstrate, deciding how to demonstrate those elements and carefully working out the language to use in explaining them.
The whole thing was choreographed from beginning to end and different stages of the cooking prepared in advance so that, "through the magic of TV," they could be displayed at the proper time as if just pulled from the oven.
Yet somehow, Julia always came across as relaxed and enjoying herself. And it wasn't a guise.
One of the things I found most endearing about "Julia Child's Kitchen" is the way sections on subjects such as the kitchen's organizing principles inevitably end up revealing the love Paul Child felt for his wife, the care he took in setting up that kitchen and showcasing her art. In letters to his brother, Paul sometimes referred to his wife as "Julie."
Julia called her kitchen "the soul of the house," and her nephew, Alex Prud'homme, called the table where meals were served in that kitchen "the center of the universe."
Unsurprisingly for that time and a family of their class, the Childs had a formal dining room, but Julia's preferred place to serve friends a meal was the kitchen. Julia's unpretentious attitude toward entertaining (and herself) is made clear in her explanation for the placement of that kitchen table, "I want the dining table in the middle of the room because, like a sheepdog, I need to be right there in the midst of everyone."
That statement is so characteristic of the woman we meet in Johnson's book. Julia Child never fails to charm, yet somehow she never seems to patronize or fawn.
The book itself is like a party at Julia's house. You meet fascinating people, hear terrific stories, experience a magical place, and, at the very least, get to imagine yourself enjoying extraordinary meals.
Speaking of stories, I can tell you from long experience that the author of "Julia Child's Kitchen" is a great storyteller in person as well as in her writing. And so I ask the pleasure of your company on March 3 at 6 p.m. for an evening in Julia Child's kitchen, courtesy of the Smithsonian's Paula Johnson. Trust me, you're in for a real treat.

title: Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State test scores released last month show a slight increase in math and English proficiency levels at both the district and state levels.Talbot County's Board of Education discussed that trend and others during a work session on Monday, taking a first deep dive into the test results from 2023-2024's Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
ENGLISH TRENDS"One of the things that the board is always interested in is how does Talbot County Public Schools compare to other districts in the state," said Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership, while presenting the English results. "And I wish that I could give you better news and say that we have flip-flopped the map, but if you compare this year's results to last year across the state, you will see very little change. There is not a single district in the state who is leapfrogging in improvements on this map."
Einhorn and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district internally tracks student learning levels. This is done at benchmarks throughout the year.
"I can assure this board that more than 47% of our students are mastering grade level standards," Einhorn said of the English proficiency rate. "It's just that they are not showing it across the state on this particular assessment."
Some positives for the English rates included third grade proficiency and the growth for certain cohorts and subgroups. Third grade English proficiency saw a significant jump from the 2022-2023 school year.
Einhorn pointed out that in 2023, sixth grade students were 40.1% proficient. That same group of students came in at 43.8% proficient on the seventh grade test. "For that cohort of students, it's growth," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said all student groups saw growth in English rates, though Black students had the smallest increase.
"We are reaching every student in some sense, in some capacity," Board President Emily Jackson said of the subgroups. "Maybe not as well as we could, but we're getting there, we are making growth, and that's what I want to see."
MATH TRENDSIn math, the district has many initiatives to increase proficiency. Einhorn said the number of elementary math coaches has increased from three to six, along with an addition of one middle school math coach.
The district is implementing an adaptive testing program called Measures of Academic Progress for kindergarten through eighth grade to track student growth.
In 2023-2024's state test scores, TCPS students showed increases across the board.
"We see slight increases for each one of our student groups," Einhorn said. "We have less of an increase for our Hispanic and Latino students. And we still continue to have fewer than 5% of our Black students and our multilingual learners proficient in mathematics."
For proficiency levels below 5%, the state does not indicate exact percentages. Of the 24 districts, the Talbot district is one of three below the 5% mark in math proficiency among Black students, and one of nine districts below the 5% mark in math proficiency among multilingual students.
Einhorn and Jackson each thanked the Talbot County Council for its commitment in funding education, particularly the math coaches in elementary schools.
"When you see movement like we did in third grade," Jackson said, "I think that we are making really intentional, really important, really good funding decisions that have a big impact on learning."
EXPERT REVIEWSAs required by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future, experts vetted by the Maryland Department of Education will be reviewing school districts across the state. Einhorn said state reviewers will be visiting three elementary schools in Talbot County this year.
Those schools will be Chapel District Elementary, St. Michaels Elementary and White Marsh Elementary. They were chosen for separate reasons. Einhorn stated: Chapel for reviewers to look at literacy instruction, St. Michaels to review practices for multilingual learners and White Marsh due to success in state testing.
"They had significant growth in their math achievement across all grades in this last MCAP assessment," Einhorn said of White Marsh Elementary. "So they want to know what White Marsh is doing well."
Jackson asked how the district can take lessons learned from these three schools to its largest elementary school, Easton Elementary.
"Can you speak to how we plan to address that?" Jackson asked. "How do you take what you've learned at a very small, very specific population and duplicate it or replicate it at a school like Easton Elementary?"
"One of the things that we do even though it's a larger school, we have committed the same types of resources but just on a larger scale," Einhorn said. "So while our smaller elementaries might have one math coach, we see multiple math coaches to be able to service the number of classrooms that we have at Easton Elementary."
Einhorn said other schools in the district will have state reviews in the next year or two.

title: Things to remember if buying or selling this spring
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Things to remember if buying or selling this spring

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Real Estate 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If someone is buying or selling this Spring, they may have noticed a few new ways of doing things since the last time they went through this process, noted Michelle Abplanalp, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.There are several real estate changes that went into effect in August related to showing homes and compensation.
For buyers, a written buyer agreement is now required. Buyers and their Realtors will need to reach an agreement regarding how the agent will be paid for their services and put it in writing before seeing a home. "However, don't get hung up on signing this agreement," Abplanalp said. "This agreement can be specific. It can be to see one specific home, it can be for one day or one week, whatever you negotiate."
Before signing this agreement, buyers should ensure it reflects the terms they have negotiated with their Realtor and that they understand exactly what services will be provided and how much these services will cost, the Board of Realtors said.
The buyer agreement must include four items:
A specific and clear disclosure of the amount or rate of compensation the agent will receive or how this amount will be determined must be stated.
The compensation rate must be objective and stated as an amount, a flat fee, a percentage, or an hourly rate. The compensation cannot be open-ended.
The agreement prohibits the Realtor from receiving compensation for services from any source that exceeds the amount or rate agreed to by the buyer.
The agreement must note that the Realtor fees and commissions are fully negotiable and not set by law.
These written agreements apply to both in-person and live virtual home tours but do not apply to open houses or inquiries about services. The home seller may agree to offer compensation to their Realtor, or the seller can offer to assist with closing costs or home inspections.
For home sellers, the offers of compensation (when a seller or a seller's agent shares compensation with a buyer's agent) cannot be shared on Multiple Listing Services. MLSs are local marketplaces used by both buyer and seller agents to share information about homes for sale. Offers of compensation are still an option but are now communicated off the MLS should a home seller choose to pay the buyer's agent fee.
Sellers may consider doing this as a way of marketing their home or making their listing more attractive to buyers.
Per Abplanalp, whether buying or selling, the Realtors compensation or fees remain fully negotiable and are not set by law. Realtors have agreed to abide by the Realtor Code of Ethics and to provide clear and transparent discussions with their clients about compensation.
"What's important to know is these practice changes provide consumers on both sides of a residential transaction with additional choice and transparency," Abplanalp said. "It helps to have this discussion upfront so there are no misunderstandings. I have found that my clients appreciate knowing what I will do for them, what services I provide, and at what cost."
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In just a handful of months, K-9 Knox is making an impact at the Easton Police Department.The nearly 2-year-old black lab completed training in January. In 2025's first quarter alone, she was deployed 17 times, making six drug arrests alongside her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.
"She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan," Schinault said. "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work."
Knox is part of Easton's new guard of K-9s. Last year, three dogs trained in marijuana detection were forced into early retirement due to the legalization of recreational cannabis use legalization in Maryland, which took effect July 2023.
Easton is not the only agency looking to rebuild its K-9 team in the wake of the legislation. Across the state, law enforcement agencies are working to fund and fill their K-9 units, which serve crucial roles not only in deterring crime, but also in connecting with the community.
Police officers largely agree that dogs trained to sniff marijuana can't be used to detect drug offenses any longer, nor does the dogs' expertise hold up in court.
"I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
Knox joined K-9 Waylon in Easton, and soon two other young dogs not imprinted on marijuana will fill out the town's K-9 unit. Lt. Tim Larrimore said it has been a "complete rebuild" for the unit since the law passed.
Trained dogs can sometimes cost around $14,000, Larrimore said. Younger, untrained pups are significantly less, though they require major time commitments for training and certification.
Across the state, the work of K-9 dogs — depending on their training — often includes drug sniffing, tracking of suspects or missing subjects, and explosives detection. Knox is certified in drug detection and on her way to certification in tracking.
Schinault and Knox completed more than 60 hours of one-on-one training before she was certified in drug detection. Easton opted to go with untrained dogs to save costs and build rapport between K-9s and officers.
While Maryland K-9s are no longer sniffing for marijuana, Larrimore says their work is more important than ever in combating drug offenses.
"This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," Larrimore said. "So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn't necessarily good at detecting. It's the dog that gets you there."
PLAYING CATCH UP
Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman has a passion for not just his K-9 partner, Khari, but for all police dogs across the state. He is president of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, a nonprofit that helps police agencies buy, train and protect their four-legged workers. The foundation paid for one of Easton's new dogs.
Lockerman said that after the legalization of cannabis, there was roughly a 60-40 split of agencies that could quickly get their K-9 units back on track versus those that were more affected by unexpected retirements. But he said progress is being made across all departments.
"Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," Lockerman said.
At the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, one K-9 retired early after the cannabis law was passed, while multiple dogs retired shortly before. The agency worked ahead to bring in replacement dogs not trained to detect marijuana so the state legislation didn't present too many challenges.
"We saw it coming," Sheriff James Phillips said. "It was on the horizon."
Six K-9s currently work for the Dorchester Sheriff's Office. Three can assist in patrols and narcotic detection, two work in narcotics only, and one bloodhound specializes in tracking. Phillips said the office has adequate funding to fill its seventh and final spot for a K-9 trained in detecting explosives.
Funding often comes from grants, local donations, organizations such as the K9 Foundation and county councils. Phillips said it's "mind-boggling" how generous people have been in donating dogs to the Sheriff's Office.
In addition to purchasing the dogs, agencies pay for safety equipment (like bulletproof vests) and health payments. Departments are also on the hook for vet costs incurred by retired dogs, per state law. For a retired K-9, departments could pay up to as much as $2,500 a year, capped at $10,000 per dog.
Larrimore, the Easton lieutenant, says that hasn't yet presented a major funding challenge, though it could down the road.
"It hasn't hit us yet," he said. "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy."
COMMUNITY IMPACT
When the highly-skilled dogs aren't working a case, they're often out in the community showing more of their friendly side.
In Dorchester County, Sgt. Steve Twilley says the K-9 unit bridges the gap between the Sheriff's Office and the community. The dogs especially help police build trust with kids.
"Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school," Twilley said.
Schinault and Knox attended a recent Coffee with a Cop event this spring. Schinault said they're very involved with community policing efforts.
Phillips and Twilley say the same is true in Dorchester County. Whatever dollar amount is spent on police dogs, Phillips says, comes back to the Sheriff's Office "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people."
"I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," Phillips said. "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s."

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council passed a resolution to create a Senior Citizens Task Force amid calls to address a rise in senior homelessness.Council OK'd the task force 5-0 at its meeting Tuesday after hearing from senior care and housing experts at a work session last month. Council member Lynn Mielke originally brought forth the resolution earlier this summer.
Mielke said she's pleased the task force was established and looks forward to serving on the body. Council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked Mielke for leading the effort.
"I look forward to working with the folks that we'll be calling together for that," Lesher said.
The task force will make recommendations to the County Council on housing, health care, transportation and meal services for homeless seniors.
It will consist of representatives from the following entities, among others: Commission on Aging, Delmarva Community Services, Talbot Interfaith Shelter, Neighborhood Service Center, Talbot County Health Department, Easton Town Council and County Council.
At the July 29 work session, Talbot Interfaith Executive Director Julie Lowe cited an increase in calls from seniors as evidence that homelessness is growing.
In 2023, the shelter received 15 calls from men 55 and older and 14 calls from women 55 and older. One year later, those marks increased to 30 and 23, respectively.
This year, the Easton-based shelter has already received 19 calls from men and 13 calls from women in that age range, Lowe said.
Other nonprofit and health care leaders advocated for the task force's creation at that meeting. They said it's especially needed to help align local nonprofits, county boards and the health department.
"There isn't anybody who is behind all of these organizations pushing to keep everybody connected," said Rachel Smith, chair of the county's Commission on Aging. "And that's what we found is one of the biggest problems. We have all these organizations out here that are doing so much great work, but then we've got to figure out a way to connect so we can help all these people."

title: Educators need to return to basics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Educators need to return to basics

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was glad to hear that Gov. Moore had decided to postpone implementing the experimental Blueprint for Maryland in our schools, due to the $2.7 billion deficit accrued by the state of Maryland.The Blueprint has been described as follows:
"It has taken the focus of schools off teaching students the academic and content knowledge they need to be successful adults in our society and made them 'one stop shopping' for services like medical, dental, nutritional, social engineering and mental health. It has promoted the implementation of 'restorative discipline' which has created a generation of students who are out of control and violent since there are no consequences for bad behavior. It has drained our schools of teachers as they flee to other states where working conditions are better even if the salaries are lower. These are just some of the negative impacts." (Easton Gazette, Dec. 20, 2024)
How disappointed was I to read in The Star Democrat (Jan. 15, 2025) that the Talbot Board of Education wishes to implement the Blueprint anyway, especially equity in math, with an $8.6 million increase to the school budget. With nearly 60% of Talbot County students (grades 3-8) showing a lack of proficiency in basic English language skills, while mathematics proficiency for Talbot County students stands at a dismal 17.2%, the last thing we need is for our children to be guinea pigs in yet another social experiment.
What is equity in math? According to Edutopia: "Math teachers can use short activities based on student goals related to equity in order to make classes feel more inclusive and accessible." The key words are "feel" "inclusive" and "accessible."
I was a sixth grader once, a sixth grader who hated math class. We had a strict teacher, of whom most of us were afraid. But we all learned to multiply and divide, in spite of the negative feelings, unlike, it appears, many of today's children who are not even being encouraged to memorize their times tables.
Those negative feelings can give way to feelings of confidence and assurance when a subject has been mastered. I beg our educators to return to basics and stop making our children the latest casualties of yet another half-baked, ill-conceived progressive scheme for remaking society according to the designs of Karl Marx or Saul Alinsky.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Program Open Space threatened
author: Staff Writer
content:
Program Open Space threatened

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Program Open Space was created in 1969 and was funded through of a transfer tax of 0.5 percent on every real estate transaction in the state. This new special tax was designed to directly tie development to available funding for open space and recreational facilities for the public good. Now because of the state budget deficit the Program Open Space funds are being threatened with total removal for the next four years.Program Open Space supports parks, forests and wildlife management areas and is an important contributor to the state's conservation commitments and goals. It also supports community playgrounds, ball fields, tennis courts, hiking trails, historic sites, Chesapeake Bay water access and multiple other community benefits. These programs are important for citizens' wellbeing and also have substantial economic benefit. Quality of life is a very important factor in home and business investment in a community.
I am impressed with the value of open spaces when I visit the Oxford Conservation Park and see the park being enjoyed by people of all ages and abilities. I see toddlers running around, senior citizens — some proceeding slowly with the help of a cane, dog owners with their enthusiastic pets and many others enjoying the outdoors.
I am particularly mindful of the many citizens who safely walked in the park during the worst days of the pandemic for exercise, tranquility and inspiration. The park also has become a highly valued locale for viewing wildlife with, for example, a large number of bird species identified, including recent sightings of quail.
Program Open Space provides very important benefits to residents of the Eastern Shore. I encourage you to contact our Talbot County representatives ask that they continue funding for Program Open Space.
SARAH RAMSEY
Oxford

title: Realtors work to protect themselves on job
content:
Realtors work to protect themselves on job

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A15 | Section: News 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Smoke detectors and locking doors are obvious safety techniques for homeowners, but there is so much more to keeping homeowners and Realtors safe during the buying and selling process.Real estate leads come in many ways, and a referral from a friend or family member is different than a walk-in or website referral. Realtors are in a unique position that sometimes puts them in harms way.As a buyer or seller being aware of this will make all involved have a better understanding of why Realtors ask or do certain things.Local Realtors say they feel the most vulnerable at open houses and when showing property. Nationally, 4% of agents reported being victims of assault, robbery, theft and other undisclosed crimes.Many of the incidents occurred at open houses, home showings and in the agent's own vehicle.Although locally this is rare, it is still a possibility. Each September, Realtors are reminded about potential risks on the job and are asked to review the Member Safety Report (NAR.Realtor/Safety) for themselves and their clients.Allowing strangers to enter your homes always comes with risks, noted Megan Rosendale, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors. That is why jewelry, valuables, and medicines, should be locked up or removed from the property.Some agents make use of visual recordings and posted signs that say "camera in use" to try to deter thieves. There was a situation a few years ago in Talbot County where a person was going to multiple open houses and taking prescriptions, the police and other agents were notified.Realtors also use a lock box system called SentriLock.SentiLock records the code of the agent who opened the box plus the time the box was opened and when the key was returned. A combination box does not have this protection, and once the combination code is given out there is no way to know who is entering your property.Rosendale said, "I also speak with my clients about not showing their home by themselves, not all agents, and buyers are who they say they are. We tell our children not to talk to strangers.I tell my sellers not to talk to other agents or buyers and have them refer all inquiries to me." Here are a few ways some Realtors protect themselves and their clients:▪ They take a picture of the license plate of the buyer's car and the client's identification.▪ They do not drive or ride with their clients unless they know them well.▪ They hold the first meeting with the clients in the real estate office or a public location.▪ They do not hold an open house alone.▪ They never meet a client for the first time at a vacant property.▪ They use a smart phone or application to track their whereabouts and to alert colleagues in case of▪ emergency.▪ They have their phone charged, carry a charging cord and hotspot for poor cell phone areas.▪ They carry mace and maybe even a weapon.We understand that meeting clients in private locations can be a part of our job, as well as hosting open houses and showing vacant properties in areas with poor or no phone coverage, noted Rosendale.That is why it is important to take preventative measures and be aware of the surroundings to help the agents and clients stay safe from would-be criminals.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more news and information check out the website midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

We want to go back every year and let our kids have these ideal summers, running around barefoot in the grass and swimming in the lake. It has a really wholesome feel that really resonates with us, and it's great to spend real time there.Q: How have you enjoyed working with your husband. actor Jonathan Silverman ("Weekend at Bernie's"), on A: He's one of the kindest, most generous people on the planet and if he's going to do something with me (professionally), I want our characters to be completely at odds with each other. I can't even tell you how cathartic it is.We see each other all the time, and part of a happy relationship is a healthy boundary. Many people have said to us over the years, "Why don't you guys do a show together?" Well, it's because I want us to stay married! One of the reasons The CW wanted this show is that Jonny is such a recognizable American actor, and I think that's a nice advantage.Q: How does that work for you yourself, in terms of being well-known in both the U.S. and your native CanadaftA: I think a lot of Canada doesn't even know I'm Canadian. title: BAAM Celebrates new Soccer Field and 20 Years
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
BAAM Celebrates new Soccer Field and 20 Years

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 663
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Not only did Building African American Minds mark 20 years of service Saturday, but the organization also celebrated the creation of a great space where children can play.BAAM has refurbished a soccer field for children with new Bermuda grass. They had a ribbon cutting to open the new field near Moton Park on May 11.
Located in Easton, the nonprofit provides scholarships, afterschool programing, summer camp, and more to empower at-risk youth in the community.
A white tent full of local government officials listened to different speakers at a podium set up right in front of the field.
Frank Gunsallus, president of the Easton Town Council, said, "I want to extend special thanks to everyone involved in making this project a reality. From our dedicated town staff to our numerous community volunteers and generous sponsors."
The small crowd of officials clapped as the colors were raised on either side of the podium.
"Let's continue to support and invest in our parks and recreational facilities to ensure that Easton remains a vibrant and engaging community for everyone," Gunsallus said.
Del. Tom Hutchison (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) came up to the microphone.
Hutchison said, "You have done such great things for the community. This is a great addition for the children and youths that are here."
He presented citations to BAAM for U.S. Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin honoring BAAM's 20 years of service.
Mautz said, "If you had been standing here 20 or 30 years ago, you wouldn't recognize where we are standing. I am looking forward to everybody kicking soccer balls out here."
The sound of DJ Hector could be heard in the distance as Amy Kreiner, president of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce, came to the microphone to give a glass award to BAAM.
"It is my honor to present Derek and Dina Daily with this 20th Anniversary plaque on behalf of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce and blessings for the next 20 years," Kreiner said.
Then they stepped onto the pitch for a large red ribbon cutting to open the field up.
William Ryan is president of the board of directors for BAAM. He was smiling as he wore a BAAM sweatshirt.
"We want to get our kids out playing as much as possible. It is part of the town park. It is open to all. If you want to have an event, you have to check with the town. We started out small and we have just been steadily growing," Ryan said.
There were members of the construction crew that actually built the field. It was a lot more than siting a rectangle. Lucas Lees, coastal and land designer of Unity Landscapes, had a three man crew that got the drainage on the field just right.
"We ran into water lines we weren't expecting, but since we were putting in irrigation it was convenient that the town already owned them. It really transformed this space and completed the park," Lees said.
Unity Landscape built it in 45 days.
Derick Daly, founder of BAAM, said that key is being long-term. The relationship with the town, the donors and the staff were all long-term.
"We wanted a place where kids could come and call it their own. We are opening up the soccer field with the partnership of the town of Easton developing with this field for youth soccer. Come out here and just have fun. Play and enjoy yourself, get out and exercise. This could be an incubator for kids to get exposure and take it to another level," Daly said.
Looking past the new soccer field, there was BAAM Fest going on closer to the community pool. There were 31 community partners, whose colorful tents lined a winding sidewalk.
"We started BAAM Fest to give out information about what we are doing. It turned into offering a meal to everyone. We have free lunch for everyone. We have a band as you can hear, face painting — the kids love it. We have community partners," Daly said.
