title: Stephen Harvey is bringing jazz to St. Michaels
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Stephen Harvey is bringing jazz to St. Michaels

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 718
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST MICHAELS — When Stephen Philip Harvey is playing the saxophone, the sounds that come from the horn of the golden instrument are lively, rhythmic and attention-grabbing.Harvey, a celebrated and well-decorated musician from the Eastern Shore, has a generational love for music.
Its a love he shares with those running the Windon Distilling Company in St. Michaels, who have invited the musician to be a part of unveiling their newest endeavor.
Having just finished its 11th year of production, the distillery is opening a new event space, Golden Hour, next to its staple tasting room. Harvey will be performing a sold-out show to mark its opening Friday night.
The distillery's founder Jaime Windon said in a press release, "this space is designed for showcasing the things we love the most: rum cocktails alongside brilliant and inspiring music, art and community. To be able to debut it while enjoying jazz along with our friends and neighbors in January is a dream."
Harvey was raised in a family passionate about music and would perform for their local church. Raised on gospel music, he soon expanded his repertoire into jazz and gained an appreciation for gathered sounds and instruments.
According to Harvey, it's not uncommon for someone in his family to break into song.
"My love for music is really a family love for music," Harvey said. "My whole family are singers and musicians… (there are times) we would be on a walk to meet up together in a space, and then someone would be like, 'oh, let's sing this hymn,' and then we break out into four part harmony. My wife was very startled by it the first time she was at a family event."
As Harvey grew up, his curiosity in music began to change away from gospel when his high school band director encouraged him to join the jazz band. From there, his relationship with music took several twists and turns.
When he got to college, his interest peaked in studying music education before choosing to focus on Western European art music, where he learned song styles of Italian, German and French musicians.
But it was American music through idioms of bebop, hard bop, vocal jazz and then big band jazz that made Harvey want to commit the rest of his life in exploring those sounds.
"It's this really interesting hobby/career where I feel like I can just do it forever and always discover new things, even looking back and going forward," Harvey said. "So discovering new things as I write and discovering new things as I listen to people who have performed and recorded in the idiom before me is so cool, especially since you come from this family that loves music so much."
Today, Harvey is a professional musician, composer and bandleader. He has released seven full albums throughout this career, with "Library Card" being his latest release.
Additionally, his compositions have been performed by an array of ensembles across the world including the National Youth Jazz Orchestra, ensembles at the Peabody Conservatory of Music and several universities across the nation.
Harvey sees his upcoming performance as part of an effort to expand jazz music's presence in the area, a mission the distillery's owners are also on board with.
Windon said she is a fan of jazz and was incredibly excited to host Harvey and his trio Sphinx as the first musical act at Windon's new event venue.
For Windon, Harvey has an electric presence.
"I have a great appreciation for jazz music of all kinds of styles, and so I liked that his music felt classic and familiar, but yet fresh," Windon said. "… There's a charisma, to me, that Stephen has that I think is also reminiscent of jazz musicians that I've always known and gravitated towards."
Harvey said he has performed in Easton and his concert will be his first time playing in St. Michaels. He shared that he's excited to establish himself on the Eastern Shore and share his love for jazz.
"My whole vibe since I've moved down here is seeing what a vacuum of jazz and Black American improvised music is on the Shore," Harvey said. "There's like none, and I would love to produce as many shows as possible, whether they are in conjunction with Lyon Rum and the Golden Hour or anywhere else. I'm just excited for any opportunity to play inside of this county."

title: Easton man pleads guilty to distributing child pornography
author: Maggie Trovato

Easton man pleads guilty to distributing child pornography

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime

 Words

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty Wednesday to six counts of promoting and distributing child pornography.Darian Braun, 23, said he made the decision to plead guilty because he is guilty and it was in his best interest.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel said said that in June of 2024, the Easton Police Department got a cyber tip from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children about a person possessing child sexual abuse material. She said that through investigation, the person was identified as Braun.
Endzel described the content of the videos Braun pleaded guilty to distributing, which all included underage girls. Endzel said that when police executed a search and seizure warrant at Braun's residence, Braun told police that he knew he messed up.
After Endzel detailed the case, Braun's attorney Holland Brownley, who is with the Talbot County Public Defender's Office, said she had no additions or corrections to Endzel's summary.
Before entering into a plea agreement with the state, Braun had received 34 charges. Seventeen of those charges were for promoting and distributing child pornography, and the other 17 charges were for possessing child pornography.
As a part of the plea agreement, the state will enter nolle prosequi for the remaining 28 charges Braun did not plead guilty to, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
The six counts Braun pleaded guilty to each carry a maximum sentence of 10 years and a maximum fine of $25,000.
Braun was not sentenced during the plea hearing, and a sentence hearing date has not yet been set.
The state recommends Braun receive a sentence of 25 years with all but six of those years suspended. The state also recommends Braun serve five years of supervised probation and be added to the sex offender registry as a tier II sex offender.

title: The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The beloved Blue Crab Coffee Shop in St. Michaels has reopened under new ownership, but they're not new to many on the Eastern Shore. Bagery owner Matt Andrews has expanded his reach from Easton to St. Michaels with the Blue Crab.Andrews took ownership of the establishment in May, and he says he's excited to honor the history of the space.
The Blue Crab building was a formerly Odd Fellows Lodge, built in 1867. It was originally named the Shealtiel Lodge No. 1024. Four years after the Civil War ended, the building was renamed to the Freedom's Friend Lodge No. 1024, and is the oldest Odd Fellows Lodge remaining in Maryland.
"All the plates that we use are from former Odd Fellows Lodges around the country," Andrews said.
He wants to pay homage to the building's former use by learning and preserving its history through social media videos, interviews with members of the historical society, and by getting footage of some of the artifacts.
"We're anxious to learn more and tell people about it," he said.
Along with the interesting history that comes with the establishment, Andrews is excited to expand service beyond breakfast and lunch. He said they plan on testing out dinner service soon but want to get their footing at the new location first.
Andrews says the community response has been overwhelmingly positive with strong feedback on the organic bread products made from scratch in Easton.
"All the feedback has been good about the food and the coffee and service," Andrews said.
Former Blue Crab owners Helen and Brian Herman stepped away from the restaurant in mid-April so Helen could focus on her architecture practice, Brian on his recording studio and so the two could spend more time with their three children, according to a Facebook post made by the Blue Crab in early April.
Andrews said the Herman's still own the building and he has a good working relationship with them. "We've had a good relationship with them over the years," he said. "They have been buying bagels wholesale from the Bagery since we opened in 2018."
According to Andrews, a majority of the menu uses the products they make in house at the Bagery and has an array of vegan options.
Blue Crab baristas Anna Szwaja and Alyssa Skinner said the transition in ownership has been smooth. Szwaja worked for the Blue Crab's previous owners last summer, and Skinner started at the Bagery a year and a half ago.
"We all get along really well," Szwaja said. Skinner agreed, saying she really enjoys her co-workers.
"I like getting to know customers and people that come in regularly," Szwaja said as she gestured to the knitting club in the back of the restaurant.

title: Doncic learning it takes awhile to win
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Doncic learning it takes awhile to win

 June 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 861
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Michael Jordan needed seven seasons to win his first title. LeBron James needed nine seasons and two futile trips to the NBA Finals before he became a champion. Shaquille O'Neal got swept in his first finals. And the newly crowned champion Boston Celtics lost the finals in 2022 and lost in the Eastern Conference finals last year before breaking through now.The lesson, as everyone knows: Winning the biggest prize almost always takes time. Not always. But usually.
Such is the reality for Luka Doncic. At 25, he already is one of the best players in the world, if not the very best of the bunch. But he's not a champion. Not yet.
The wait for his first championship will extend until at least 2025, which really shouldn't be all that surprising. Doncic and the Dallas Mavericks weren't a logical pick in this series against the Celtics; one was a 50-win team that caught fire at the end of the regular season, the other was a 64-win team that was better than everyone from the very beginning. The smart money said Dallas would fall in these finals, and that's what happened. It ended Monday night in Boston, the Celtics winning 106-88, an 18-point margin for their record-setting 18th title.
"They're a great team. They have been together for a long time, and they had to go through everything, so we just got to look at them, see how they play, the maturity, and they have some great players," Doncic said when it was all over Monday night. "We can learn from that. We've got to fight next season."
Let's be clear: Losing these NBA Finals should in no way be an indictment of Doncic. He could have played better, of course. Smarter at times, for certain. He spent some of the finals arguing too often with referees. He knows that. That said, letting a finals loss take anything away from the first six years of his body of NBA work would be ridiculous.
He's scored 11,470 points so far, 15th most of anyone through their first six NBA seasons. Throw in his 3,472 rebounds and 3,317 assists, and Oscar Robertson is the only other player with such stats from Year 1 through Year 6. James came close. Jordan came close. But they didn't have those numbers.
It's not like this needs explaining, but just in case: Doncic — already a five-time All-NBA first-team selection — is on an absolute Hall of Fame trajectory.
"He's played as best as he can despite the circumstances, just injuries and stuff," Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving said earlier in these finals. "He's been giving it his all."
Doncic played through knee and ankle issues in the playoffs. He had a thoracic contusion that required painkilling injections to get through the NBA Finals. He wasn't at his best, and he would have had to be otherworldly for Dallas to have had a real chance in this series.
He finished the playoffs as the leader in points, rebounds and assists anyway. Not the Mavs' leader, the NBA's leader.
"He's one of the best players in the world, and so I think the biggest thing for him is that we all would like to be healthy, but there's going to be bumps and bruises along the way," Mavericks coach Jason Kidd said. "So, for him at the age of 25 to get to the finals, to be playing his basketball at the level that he's playing, now it's just being consistent. ... When you have one of the best players in the world, you should be always fighting for a championship."
The Mavs felt that Doncic was the real MVP of the league this season, and their argument was compelling even though it didn't resonate much with voters. Kidd says Doncic's greatness gets taken for granted, which may be true. When Doncic gets it going, it's must-watch TV. He makes scoring look as easy as anyone has in this generation. He's not a high-flyer like Jordan, not someone who plays with the force, flair and power like James does. But when he's on, forget it.
He might not be "the" face of the league. But he's in the conversation, especially globally. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver watched Doncic closely on the day before the finals started and, in his own words, came away with yet another "example of how international this league is."
"Someone who grew up in Slovenia and trained in Madrid and Spain was doing interviews in three different languages," Silver said. "Again, many of you spend time with him, but he's an exemplar of the modern NBA."
The Mavs bristled at criticism Doncic took during the finals, but in some ways, that's welcome-to-the-club stuff. Jordan heard doubters. James still does. The Celtics, until Monday night, did as well. They don't doubt nobodies. Comes with the territory, and Kidd hopes Doncic converts it into fuel for his future.
"When you're on the biggest stage, someone's got to poke a hole," Kidd said. "This will only make the great ones better. When you look at … LeBron, Michael, the greats, the GOATs, they all were poked at, and they came back stronger and better. I truly believe Luka will come back stronger and better."

 TRAPPE — On Tuesday evening, the Trappe Planning Commission met and approved a minor amendment and Phase 1D subdivision revision plat for the Lakeside development. By approving this, they have cleared the way for the Trappe Town Council to vote on this phase of the Lakeside development.The commissioners approved Phase 1D of the subdivision revision, with the notation that the areas identified as public open space on the plat would be clearly labeled as such.
Trappe Attorney Lyndsey Ryan stated that open space is defined as active and passive open space for public use and enjoyment.
Robert Rauch, president of Rauch Inc., the engineering, architecture, and environmental firm constructing the Lakeside development, told the commission that there may be some confusion about the distinction between public open space and private space.
Rauch wanted to ensure that the areas labeled as public open spaces were properly understood to be used by the public.
The open space would not be within stormwater management. Rauch explained that the areas in the exhibit will be green open areas for "throwing frisbees." The exhibit has two parks: Lakeside Public Park and Wooden Public Park. There is public access to the sidewalks between the two areas by trails.
Open space areas would be under the homeowner's association's mandate and management, regardless of whether they are designated as public or private. Rauch clarified that for any areas designated as public open space, the HOA would have the obligation to provide a permanent and perpetual public easement for access and use.
The development agreement states that the public shall have a permanent and perpetual easement to use and enjoy the open space, which may not be limited by the petitioner or any HOA.
The commission voted to approve the revisions of the subdivision to make sure that all designed public spaces were clearly labeled.
Cannabis
Ordinance 1-2024, an ordinance for the town of Trappe to establish reasonable zoning regulations for cannabis businesses, was also approved by the Planning Commission and will be recommended to the Town Council for approval.
Margaret English, a resident of Trappe, was a vocal advocate against approving the zoning regulations for cannabis businesses.
"I don't think you should recommend it," English said. "I don't want drugs in my town, and I ain't moving."
Commissioner Edgar Harrison noted regardless of whether or not he agreed with her; he didn't think the state would permit the town to outlaw the introduction of cannabis businesses into town. After the meeting, he sat down with English and listened to her concerns regarding cannabis.

title: St. Michaels Commissioners bid farewell to duPont, approve ordinances
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels Commissioners bid farewell to duPont, approve ordinances

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 At the Commissioners of St. Michaels meeting Wednesday evening, leaders discussed Commissioner Thomas "Tad" duPont's resignation. The board also approved an ordinance establishing zoning regulations for cannabis businesses and approved the proposed contract with International Computer Services Incorporated for IT work.DUPONT RESIGNATIONCommission President David Breimhurst announced the resignation of Commissioner Thomas "Tad" duPont. Breimhurst stated that duPont's resignation was due to health reasons.
DuPont submitted a letter of resignation on Feb. 6 that Breimhurst read to those at Wednesday's meeting. In the letter, duPont recounted the "challenging" three years and nine months the board had while he was in office. Among the challenges duPont listed were navigating the pandemic, creating budgets and many other efforts.
"It has been a pleasure to serve, and (I) wish all continued success," stated duPont's letter.
DuPont was most recently elected to serve as a town commissioner in July 2020. He first served as a commissioner from 2010 until resigning in August 2013 over concerns with an ethics ordinance, according to prior Star Democrat reporting.
The vacancy on the town commission came three months shy of the town's upcoming election. Three seats, including duPont's, will be up for grabs on May 6.
But because duPont's resignation came within 90 days of the next regular election, the vacancy will remain unfilled until the election, according to the town's charter.
When Breimhurst finished reading the letter, he added a personal note on how grateful he was to serve alongside duPont.
"I thank Tad for his dedication and devotion to the town of St. Michaels. His love for the town is never ending," Breimhurst said.
CANNABIS BUSINESSES ZONINGThe Commissioners unanimously approved an ordinance changing zoning regulations for cannabis businesses that would permit cannabis dispensaries and processing facilities as a special exception in St. Michaels' general commercial zoning districts.
These changes would allow the zoning board to review each application based on factors such as noise, parking and compatibility with the neighborhood.
A nine-month cannabis moratorium, which temporarily blocked applications, site plans, permits, construction, processing and approval for businesses looking to manufacture or sell recreational or medicinal cannabis in St. Michaels will run its course at the end of the month.
ICSI CONTRACTThe Commissioners voted to renew St. Michaels' contract with International Computer Services Incorporated to assist with the town's IT services. ICSI is the town's current IT consultant and is under contract for another year and a half.
Town Manager Rob Straubel recommended the approval of the ICSI proposal because it will avoid issues with having multiple service providers and separate maintenance contracts.
OTHER TOWN BUSINESSMike Bibb, a member of the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, presented an annual review of actions taken by the Accountability Board, established in January 2023.
This board comprises two parts — the Policy and Procedure Committee and the Accountability and Charging Committee.
The Accountability and Charging Committee reviewed 50 complaints filed, and Bidd stated that no cases were made against law enforcement from St. Michael's.
The challenges faced by the Police Accountability Board included police recruiting and retention and new juvenile justice laws that make it more difficult to charge juveniles for crimes, Bidd said. He advocated for improved police training and changing laws regarding the statute of limitations for police misconduct charges.
The commissioners then discussed reviewing the town's ethics code.

title: VFW plans parade to welcome Vietnam veterans home 50 years after end of war
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
VFW plans parade to welcome Vietnam veterans home 50 years after end of war

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When Kenley Timms returned home from the Vietnam War, he did not receive a warm welcome."I was never spit on, never thrown trash at, but when I landed at National Airport in Washington, I walked into the airport, and there was a lady and her child, probably 5, 7 years old, and I spoke to the child, and that woman picked that child up like I was the devil," Timms said.
Other returning soldiers faced even more hostile receptions upon returning to a country where political tides had turned and the Vietnam War, unbeknownst to those deployed, had become deeply unpopular.
"And at the time, I didn't know about it because when I was in Vietnam, I didn't know what was happening back in the United States," Timms said.
Now, 50 years after the war ended, Timms, the commander of VFW Post 5118, and a collection of other veterans at the post in Easton are seeking to give their fellow service members the welcome home they never got.
On March 30, the VFW post plans to hold a wreath laying ceremony before a parade through downtown Easton and a short program in honor of Vietnam veterans.
"I'm hoping that we'll have a couple thousand people standing in the streets, waving to us," Timms said. "You'll see a lot of veterans walking or riding, ones that are able to walk, tears rolling down their face."
The parade route, which has already been approved by the Town of Easton, will begin at the intersection of Dover and Washington streets, then make its way down Washington Street and Glebe Road to the VFW. Event organizers plan to distribute American flags for spectators to wave.
But beyond event attendance, the Vietnam veterans behind the event are hoping to gather parade participants and gain assistance with transportation for veterans who are unable to walk the parade route.
"We need transportation, but we don't want a bus. We want something where people can see them, the public can wave to them," Timms said.
"What we're looking for is people to participate," added Wayne Hall, president of the VFW's Vietnam Veterans Chapter. "If anybody has any military vehicles, the collectors, we'd be glad to have them."
Those who wish to be involved in the event can contact 410-310-5748.

 EASTON — Special Olympics Maryland athletes joined with police officers on Tuesday to carry the torch through Easton.Beginning on Dover Street, a group of around 100 athletes, families, law enforcement officers and community members participated in Talbot County's leg of the Law Enforcement Torch Run, an annual tradition to raise money for the Special Olympics. They brought along the Special Olympics torch, called the Flame of Hope, as they traversed the downtown streets of Easton.
Officers from the Easton Police Department and Talbot County Sheriff's Office, as well as local officials such as Easton Mayor Megan Cook and Talbot County Council member Dave Stepp, participated in the event. Some local organizations stood outside to cheer on the athletes, including employees from the Town of Easton offices and Rauch Inc.
Walking down Harrison Street, athlete Hannah McNiece beamed with joy alongside Easton officer Cordero Proctor, as the two each placed a hand on the torch and led the entourage of athletes to the finish line at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Some officers and athletes took a running route through town and caught up with the walkers toward the finish.
Jill Garvey, management assistant for the Easton Police Department, helps organize the torch run. She said it means a lot when the athletes interact with law enforcement and build relationships with the officers.
Other counties across the state participate in the torch tradition. Also on Tuesday, Queen Anne's County police officers joined with Kent Island High School students for the Law Enforcement Torch Run.
"This event is about more than a run, it's about promoting inclusion, dignity, and respect for every athlete," said Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann in a press release. "We're honored to be part of this tradition and proud to stand alongside our partners and students in support of such a meaningful cause."
The Summer Games for Special Olympics Maryland athletes is set to take place this weekend at Towson University from Friday to Sunday.

title: National Night Out connects cops with community
author: Tom McCall
content:
National Night Out connects cops with community

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A crowd in Moton Park joined communities all over the country in celebrating the 40th annual National Night Out Tuesday.National Night Out connects different branches of law enforcement with the community. The goal is to prevent crime and have people know the officers and emergency services personnel who serve their area.
Megan Coxon, a sergeant with the Easton Police Department, has been a primary force in organizing the event.
"We are here for First Night Out, which is a nationwide event. It happens the first Tuesday in August. I probably know half the folks here just because we interact on a daily anyway," Coxon said. "It is like a mini reunion. We get to hang out for a night, and of course you get to meet new people. If I don't know you, I will come talk to you and if I have seen you before, we will reconnect."
She said she got a lot of help from Jill Garvey, an EPD management assistant, and Lorraine Gould, director of Easton Parks and Recreation.
Coxon pointed out the law enforcement representatives in attendance.
"We have at least ten from EPD. We have sheriff's office, fire marshall's office, Natural Resources Police, Talbot Sheriff's office and MSP. There are about 40 people," she said.
Over a smoking hot grill with about 50 burgers were members of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
"We are cooking some good burgers. We got some good hot dogs. We got a decent crowd of people, it is its a good time," Aiden Lowery, a firefighter and EMT said.
Mayor Megan Cook was also present, immersed in community.
"Talking to people? That is the best part of my job," Cook said. "The sense of community is what is important tonight. I think to see the police department as partners and to get them visible in the community so our neighbors know that they are a resource and they are there to help."
John Grothe of the state's fire marshal office had a full kevlar and ballistic shield bomb squad suit and special helmet on display. He is a bomb tech and said the suit weighs 100 pounds.
"In the event that there is a device or suspicious package, we try to stay as remote as possible. We try to utilize our bomb robot, but every once in a while, we have to put on the suit and go downrange in person. Night Out is a great opportunity to meet people and have them come up and touch the equipment. We get to explain what we do. It puts a face to the agency," Grothe said.
There were over 100 community members wandering around, getting food, visiting with friends and getting information from the community service booths.
Jessica Carter, who was sharing an shaved ice with her daughter, said the National Night Out event gives her family an opportunity to see what resources are available to them.
"We come every year. The resources. Giving back to the community. Some people may not know what resources are available to them. So it is good. I like the health department and Chesapeake Voyagers," Carter said.
Garvey said she has been working on this event for over a month. She had two massive sheet cakes from Cordova Bakery in her air conditioned vehicle.
"It falls into place. I have been planning these for 18 years. It is a free fun family event. The pool is open. Come out and enjoy. There is free food. It is a good community event," she said.

title: Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat

 July 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 753
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every Sunday when I was a child, we eagerly awaited the delivery of the Sunday newspaper. It always included a feature with riveting pictures from previous editions.They were not just a collage of all the pictures from previous editions.
They were selected by the newspaper's editors thinking not so much on how timely they were at the present, but how timeless they might be going forward.
If that program were still in place today, two pictures that most certainly would be selected would be from the 2024 presidential election campaign.
One is of former President and current presidential candidate Donald Trump after an attempted assassination at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.
In that surreal picture, Trump is being taken with a bloody hand on a wounded ear, blood on his face and his other hand raised as a defiant fist from the event stage by Secret Service agents.
Another picture would be from the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.
In that picture, Trump is standing alone on a stage next to the helmet and bunker coat of Corey Comperatore, who was a volunteer firefighter and Trump supporter who attended the Pennsylvania rally.
Corey died shielding his family from the fusillade that almost killed Trump and seriously wounded two other rally attendees.
Prominently displayed next to Corey's bunker coat and helmet is an American flag.
Trump appears to be gazing with deep contemplation of and reverence for the memorial for Comperatore.
In deeply divided America, both pictures are generating widely different reactions.
Some Trump detractors claim the assassination was preplanned to generate support for the Trump campaign. They have implied Trump exiting the stage largely under his own power was done to show a stark contrast to a former opponent who often stumbled and needed assistance while walking.
Some Trump detractors claim the picture of Trump looking at the Comperatore's memorial was staged for nothing more than scoring political points. They question if Trump's hand on the shoulder of the turnout coat was orchestrated and insincere.
Sadly, a significant number of seriously deranged Trump adversaries have posted messages on social media with messages like "sorry the shooter missed" and "hope he [Trump] is killed the next time."
I found the vileness and hate in those messages so disturbing I couldn't read all of them.
Not all those adversaries are radical fringe malcontents.
They include a wide range of elected officials, celebrities and political commentators who have regularly characterized and continue to characterize Donald Trump as a Nazi, a neo-Nazi, a fascist, a dictator wanna be and an existential threat to America.
Some Trump supporters believe the attempted assassination was a deep state conspiracy.
They maintain the spectacular failure of security at the event was by design.
They also believe constant inflammatory comments from Trump's many adversaries created an environment where the question on an assassination attempt was not if, but when.
I am not going to engage a debate on the credibility on either side on these deeply held beliefs.
I am more concerned such debate affirms that an alarming and steady decline of civil dialogue in our society is the greatest existential threat to democracy in America.
In today's intensely polarized political environment, it is considered normal and acceptable to disagree by being viciously disagreeable, to listen only to those who share and affirm that their views are the right views. Worst of all, we expect and accept the practice of demonizing anyone, and everyone who doesn't agree with us on every issue all the time.
We desperately need a renewed national commitment to critical thinking, listening to others, avoiding group think, respect for differing opinions and acceptance of a system of government where the majority rules, even when that can and does result in public policy decisions that do not have universal agreement.
Much easier said than done.
The underlying reality of where we are as a society is best captured by the cogent observation of veteran political communications consultant, Frank Luntz: "It's not what you say or write, it's what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
In other words — my mind is made up. Don't try to persuade me otherwise with facts.
When dealing the deep divisions caused by the issue of slavery and the American Civil War Abraham Lincoln said, "A house divided cannot stand."
America has been and is a house divided.
If we do not change course soon, we will not stand.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it
author: RIVERA SUN
content:
Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RIVERA SUN | Section: Columns 
 
 688
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm tired of the violence. Aren't you?Some days, it seems relentless. A mass shooting at a school. Another youth killed by gun violence. A family on the street after fleeing an abusive partner. A genocide halfway around the world. Brutal wars displacing millions.
When will the violence stop?
The answer is: When we take action to stop it, together.
It's not impossible. Communities across the country and around the world are showing us how. Violence may be everywhere, but so are the people trying to stop it. And many of them have powerful antidotes to the violence we face.
During the Campaign Nonviolence Action Days, Sept 21-Oct 2, tens of thousands of people will show everyone that another world is possible.
What does a nonviolent world look like? It's not all roses. Conflict happens — but we have better ways to respond without resorting to violence. Many of these strategies will be on display during the upcoming Action Days: Neighborhood safety patrols to prevent gun violence. Unarmed peace teams de-escalating tension in hot conflict zones worldwide. Anti-bullying programs aimed at preventing the next school shooter. Centers that help mothers and families get back on their feet after leaving abusive situations. Protests pushing banks to divest from weapons.
More than 4,438 actions and events are planned across the United States and around the world to "build a culture of peace and active nonviolence, free from war, poverty, racism, and environmental destruction."
An 11-year-old movement, Campaign Nonviolence aims to end violence in its many forms. This includes direct or physical violence (fights, bullying, war, gun violence) and it also includes systemic violence (houselessness, hunger, mass incarceration and the climate crisis). Going even further, the effort seeks to transform cultural violence as well, the beliefs, attitudes and values that lead to harm and destruction, such as militarism, racism, sexism, xenophobia and homophobia.
Instead, Campaign Nonviolence rallies hundreds of groups and organizations who use nonviolent action and promote nonviolent solutions. Sandy Hook Promise trains thousands of schoolchildren in how to counter social isolation — a factor in mass shootings — with Start With Hello Week. The Nobel Prize-winning International Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons coordinates hundreds of actions to move money out of nukes. The Global Silent Minute synchronizes thousands of people for a moment of prayerful silence for peace on the International Day of Peace, Sept 21. Nonviolent Peaceforce and Cure Violence use de-escalation techniques in conflict zones worldwide to prevent attacks.
Local community groups take powerful action in their neighborhoods. Nonviolent Opelika, Alabama, (part of the nationwide Nonviolent Cities Project) offers trainings and talks on their neighborhood patrols to prevent gun violence. Groups in Honolulu reaffirm their Zone of Peace and Nonviolence in a low-income public housing complex. An elementary school in Little Rock, Arkansas, holds a peace march with all the children. In Detroit, Meta Peace Team trains an entire high school in de-escalation skills.
There are street theater protests at military bases and teach-ins on nonviolent history, such as M.K. Gandhi or Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers. There are peace art contests and concerts in public parks. There are marches for ceasefires in Gaza and Ukraine. There are actions to stop environmental destruction and the climate crisis.
Campaign Nonviolence is gearing up for its largest-ever Action Days stretching between the International Day of Peace Sept 21 to the International Day of Nonviolence on Oct 2. In 2023, more than 5,000 actions were held. With weeks to go, there are already 4,438 actions planned for 2024, and hundreds more expected to be added. The campaign calls for a range of nonviolent actions to be used during the 12 days, including labor strike solidarity, divestment from fossil fuels and weapons, racial healing circles, nonviolence teach-ins, peace demonstrations, and violence de-escalation trainings.
When the violence of our world weighs on your heart, connect to the people working to change it. They bring practical solutions and real-life experience. They persist in showing that something else is possible. They invite you to be part of the solution.
Rivera Sun has written numerous books. She is the editor of Nonviolence News, program coordinator for Campaign Nonviolence, and a nationwide trainer in strategy for nonviolent campaigns.

title: History is filled with many 'what if' questions
author: DAVID REEL
content:
History is filled with many 'what if' questions

 July 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who study history regularly ask the question — what if? What if certain watershed events in American history had never occurred or had occurred much differently?One such watershed event was the war in Vietnam.
Historians to this day ask what if decisions made on escalating or de-escalating that war had been made by President John Kennedy and not by President Lyndon Johnson.
Military historian Fred Kaplan makes a compelling case that if Kennedy had not been assassinated in November 1963, the outcome and duration of that war would have been much different.
Kaplan makes his case based on Kennedy's actions and decisions during the biggest crisis of his presidency — the Cuban Missile Crisis.
Prior to that crisis, Kennedy's leadership capabilities were challenged regularly by his opponents. They were especially scornful of his disastrous Bay of Pig's invasion of Cuba in April 1961 and his disastrous summit meeting with Russian Premier Nikita Khrushchev in June 1961. Following that summit Kennedy privately acknowledged "he just beat the hell out of me."
Perhaps those two events emboldened Khrushchev to place Soviet medium- and long-range nuclear missiles in Cuba in October 1962.
That decision resulted a 13-day period where World War III between America and the Soviet Union was more likely than ever before or since.
The fact that it did not is a testament to Kennedy's masterful leadership skills.
When Kennedy was made aware of that grave threat to from nuclear missiles less than 90 miles from America, he assembled a group of civilian and military advisors to evaluate and oversee an appropriate American response.
Those advisers included the eight members of the military's Joint Chiefs of Staff, National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy, Defense Secretary Robert McNamara, Secretary of State Dean Rusk, Undersecretary of State George Ball and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.
With one exception (George Ball), Kennedy's advisers strongly supported direct military action including bombing the missile sites and invading Cuba.
After 13 days of a tense standoff between the two superpowers, Khrushchev secretly and unexpectedly offered a deal to end the crisis. The deal terms were Russia would remove their nuclear missiles in Cuba that were pointed at American targets if America would remove American nuclear missiles in Turkey pointed at targets in the Soviet Union
Kennedy's advisers with one exception (Ball) vehemently opposed the deal. They continued to support plans drawn up by the military and Defense Secretary McNamara that called for 500 conventional bombing sorties of the Soviet missile sites and air bases daily for seven days, followed by an invasion of Cuba.
Following receipt of the Khrushchev offer McGeorge Bundy bluntly told Kennedy — "I think we should tell you … the universal assessment of everyone in the government who's connected with the alliance problem (NATO) is if we appear to be trading the defense of Turkey for the threat in Cuba, we will face a radical decline." Secretary McNamara ended his review of suggested next steps with "before we attack Cuba."
After listening to his adviser's opinions Kennedy, told them "I'm just thinking about what we're going to have to do in a day or so. … Five hundred sorties … and possibly an invasion, all because we wouldn't take missiles out of Turkey. And we all know how quickly everybody's courage goes when the blood starts to flow, and that's what's going to happen in NATO … when we start these things and the Soviets grab Berlin, and everybody's going to say, 'Well, this Khrushchev offer was a pretty good proposition."
Kennedy knew that the American missiles in Turkey were rapidly becoming obsolete and had no long-term military value to America.
He told his advisers calmly but resolutely he was sending his brother Bobby (who bitterly opposed the deal) to tell the Soviet ambassador to the United States that America was accepting the Khrushchev proposal.
It was a moment reminiscent of a Cabinet Meeting in the White House 100 years earlier when President Lincoln polled his cabinet members on his proposed new battle strategy for the Civil war. Every member of Lincoln's Cabinet voted no. Lincoln said "I vote aye. The ayes win."
Kennedy obviously knew that as commander in chief he could overrule his advisers when he chose to do so.
Following Kennedys assassination, Lyndon Johnson was either unwilling or unable to overrule his advisers on their repeated calls to escalate the war in Vietnam. Ironically, many of those advisers (except again George Ball) repeatedly advised Johnson for escalation in Vietnam were the same advisers overruled by Kennedy during the Cuban missile crisis.
Kaplan's answer to the "what if" question on the course of Vietnam war is LBJ plunged deeply into the war and JFK would not have.
Based on Kaplan's analysis of what if JFK had lived, America would have avoided the great tragedy of a futile and immensely divisive war that resulted in more than 58,000 American deaths and countless veterans returning home with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
I agree.
David Reel is a public relations and public affairs consultant who lives in Easton.

title: When life gives you tomatoes
content:
When life gives you tomatoes

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A11 | Section: News

 Too many tomatoes are never a problem. Perhaps the only challenge is maintaining self-control when passing the colorful piles of peak-season tomatoes at the market.Admittedly, they are hard to resist. Cherries, heirlooms and Early Girls in vibrant shades of the sun and summer challenge restraint. It's easy to be greedy and fill the basket with an array of these beauties without a plan for how to use them. While I am not here to judge or to advise you on any indulgence issues, I do have a recipe to help you use your exuberant surplus.This recipe is a wonderful summer salad with ingredients that scream "garden-fresh." You might be tempted to call it a pasta salad, but as you can see, the emphasis is on the vegetables rather than a carbladen bowl of pasta interspersed with a few green leaves. Dainty orzo steps into the pasta role. Its petite rice shape won't overwhelm the bowl, allowing the tomatoes and greens to shine as they should. Fresh, creamy mozzarella and zippy Parmigiano-Reggiano round out the flavors, with a balsamic drizzle that binds the salad with a sweet and puckery kick.Serve the salad slightly warm or at room temperature.You can cook the orzo in advance and refrigerate until assembling the salad.TOMATO, ARUGULA AND ORZO SALADActive time: 20 minutes Total time: 20 minutes, plus cooling time for the orzo Yield: Serves 4 Dressing:2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar 1 garlic clove, minced 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil Salad:1 1/3 cups orzo 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 3 ounces baby arugula, about 4 packed cups 6 ounces fresh mozzarella, cut or torn into bite-size pieces 8 to 10 ounces cherry tomatoes, halved 1/4 cup pitted Kalamata olives, halved 1/4 cup fresh basil leaves, plus more for garnish 2 tablespoons finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese Freshly ground black pepper Whisk the vinegar, garlic, salt and pepper in a small bowl. Add the oil and whisk to emulsify.Bring a large saucepan of salted water to a boil. Add the orzo and cook until al dente, about 7 minutes.Drain. Transfer the orzo to a large, shallow serving bowl and stir in the oil and salt.Cool to lukewarm or room temperature. (Alternatively, refrigerate the pasta until use. Let stand at room temperature for 15 to 20 minutes before assembling the salad.)Spread the arugula over the pasta, then add the mozzarella, tomatoes, olives and basil. Drizzle half of the dressing over the salad and gently mix to combine. Garnish with additional basil, the Parmigiano-Reggiano and a generous grind of black pepper. Drizzle with additional dressing to taste. Serve immediately.Lynda Balslev is an award-winning writer, cookbook author, and recipe developer based in northern California.Visit TasteFood at Taste-Foodblog.com.© 2023 LYN DA BALSLEV DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION

Gunsallus leading in race for town council president

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones And Tom Mccall; njones@chespub.com and tmccall@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News

 EASTON - After a steady stream of voting Tuesday, Frank Gunsallus was leading in the race for the Easton Town Council's next president.According to election supervisor Carlene Phoenix, Gunsallus had earned 835 votes at the close of polls Tuesday evening.Former Easton Mayor Robert Willey received 696 votes, and former Ward 1 Councilman Al Silverstein received 348 votes. Kevin Bateman received 30 votes.Phoenix said 140 absentee ballots remain to be counted Wednesday afternoon. Gunsallus holds a 139-vote lead over Willey.A steady flow of voters poured into Easton's firehouse Tuesday as residents cast their ballots for the next president of the Town Council. Just over 1,900 ballots were cast during in-person voting.Early in the morning, candidates for Easton Town Council president stood beneath tents as a stream of voters passed them by. There wasn't a hard sell, it was more of a morning greeting as the light slanted onto the firehouse. Voters went in and did their civic duty. There weren't big lines at 9 a.m.Turnout at the polls was busy and steady as election day progressed, Phoenix said.But in this contentious election cycle, agitation simmered just beneath the surface between some of the candidates.Al Silverstein sat alone while the other three - Frank Gunsallus, Kevin Bateman, and former Mayor Robert Willey - spoke amiably. There was even a minor turf war when Gunsallus placed a sign too close to Silverstein's camp. Within seconds it got moved back and replanted.Willey, a former town council president and mayor himself, has been running for office in Easton since 1992. He brought doughnuts.As a longtime local politician, Willey knew there would be a lot to do early on election morning. He knew the day would be long as well, especially in waiting on a vote tally."But this election has gotten to be a little more demanding than some in the past," he said. "I hope (when) it is over with everybody (can) still talk to each other when they leave." "This is my 10th election," he said. "This has become the most pointed, the most mean-spirited. I would not want to go through this again." Willey said win or lose, this was his last run.Leaning on a tent pole was Bateman."It is a relief to have election day here, especially after the last two weeks. All the hate mailers and hate speech have gone forth," he said."I want to see that Easton is governed equally for all of Easton - not just certain communities, but that all communities are included." Gunsallus said he was feeling good about the election, mentioning that he heard positive feedback from the community."I am thankful to everyone who has shown support and for all the amazing people I have met along the way," he said. "Irregardless of what happens, I am happy to have had this experience." Silverstein stood up to greet each voter as they passed. Some stopped to voice their support.A former councilman serving Easton's Ward 1, Silverstein said it's exciting to be outside the polls on election day and to thank the electorate for coming out."I would encourage anybody who wants to change their community for the better to throw their hat in the ring," he said. "I congratulate all my opponents for getting out there and getting their positions known. I think it is the greatest part of the American system." One community member, Shari Wilcoxon, was fired up enough to hold a Gunsallus sign in front of her car."What happens in the Town of Easton matters greatly to Talbot County," she said. "I think it is time for some new leadership." Carol Voyles of Easton was happy to vote and do her civic duty."It troubles me that our communities are so divided," she said. "When it is over, we are going to celebrate."

title: Art exhibit in Easton uses small items to explore larger themes such as war, homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
Art exhibit in Easton uses small items to explore larger themes such as war, homelessness

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new art exhibit in Easton uses small-scale items like twigs to tell large-scale stories involving war, poverty and conflict.Inside the Academy Art Museum, "To the Edge of Your World" by Dutch-Irish artist Anita Groener welcomes viewers into a peaceful setting of grid-like drawings and bird-chirping sounds.
Two main displays — Cradle and Shrapnel — are sculpture works by Groener. They include materials like twigs gathered from walks with her dog that she started collecting more than 10 years ago.
Groener hopes the sculptures help people understand some of "their own baggage" and history.
"Everything's very small, which creates a psychological distance," said Groener, who lives in Dublin, while inside the Easton exhibit space last month. "And that's important because we witness all these world events."
For her, the exhibit is largely motivated by time she spent in the southern United States visiting civil rights monuments, as well as Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
Its meaning continues to evolve today, Groener said.
"Like we in Ireland watch what's going on in America," she said. "But it's such a distance, and I'm not taking part in that. Yet it affects us all. Everything that happens in the world, in our lives, affects us and is connected."
The Ireland-based artist doesn't want people to walk in thinking the art will yield certain takeaways. Rather, Groener hopes her art is open to interpretation.
"I like ambiguous readings, because as an artist, you can't be prescriptive," she said.
Groener's exhibit is the Academy Art Museum's first ever international exhibit. Charlotte Potter Kasic, the museum's executive director, said it took "many hoops to jump through" to make happen, but she's happy it panned out.
The opening weekend for the exhibit and a sister documentary film last month drew more than 250 people, Kasic said. They watched "Shelter," a 30-minute short film addressing homelessness on the Mid-Shore. Groener, the Talbot Interfaith Shelter and filmmaker Matt Kresling collaborated on the project.
At the front of Groener's exhibit is the main shelter structure, which is shown at the end of the film. She took around 10,000 pictures of the structure to make the stop-motion scene possible.
Groener said the scene is a "coming together of people" and all about community. Kasic said the audience on opening weekend was captivated by the film.
"No one moved," Kasic said. "They were all very engaged."
The film is slated to show at the Chesapeake Film Festival on Oct. 10 at the Ebenezer Theater in Easton. Groener's exhibit is open at the Academy Art Museum through Oct. 27.

1. Why are you running for the Ward 2 seat on the Easton Town Council?
Running for Ward 2 is an honor. I am running because we need a voice for the day-to-day people who live in Easton. The hardworking backbone of our society. Your neighbors, servers, police, grocery store workers, those struggling on social security, etc. I see and hear the struggles.
2. What issues will you prioritize if elected?
I will prioritize the accountability of the Town Council, transparency and accountability with "your" money, smart growth for our special town.
We need to keep our next generation. People with and without children are from moving away from the Shore because they can't afford to live here and raise a family.
3. What changes would you make to the town's budget, and what budget items should not be cut?
The town budget is not transparent enough. We need to see more details instead of just line items with no explanations. It's hard to see exactly where our money is going.
4. While the town has grown, affordable housing remains a challenge for residents. How should the town build more housing, in particular affordable housing?
It is funny the Census has Easton population growth of only 101 more people since 2020. We all can see there has been much more growth. Either that or are we just congested because of workers commuting who live in more affordable towns.We need starter home neighborhoods for the first responders, teachers and people not making six figures. We can think outside the box — barndominiums, tiny homes or prefab housing neighborhoods, which are much less expensive to build.
5. What are your plans for public safety in Easton? What can be improved?
Safety is key for everyone in Easton. We need to treat our neighbors with kindness. Introduce yourself and watch out for each other. We have exceptional first responders, including police, EMS and volunteer firefighters, working a tough job just out of their heart for the people of their community. They are doing a great job even though they are running with short manpower.
With the area growing, we need to make sure we keep them equipped with proper needs.
6. In addition to serving the Town of Easton as a whole, what are your plans to improve your ward specifically?
I love the Ward 2 area where I live and volunteer. The Rails to Trails is a huge part of linking neighborhoods to the downtown area. Keeping that a positive and safe trail is always a concern for everyone.
Also, Idlewild Park is the most used park in Easton, so we need to keep it updated for everyone. The play area needs some attention, and why not do a pickleball court, since its popularity has grown 52% since 2019?

 EASTON - On Saturday, June 24th, 2023, in Easton, Maryland, our beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, Ruth Emma Dietrich Santucci, gently passed away at the age of 94 years old after years of declining health. Her passing was peaceful as she was comforted and held by her youngest daughter, Anne.Ruth was born on August 21st, 1928, to Annie Elmira Eckert and Nevin Emanuel Dietrich in Fleetwood, Pennsylvania. Ruth loved and cherished her sister, Agnes Breidegam and her three brothers, Ivan, Ray, and Lloyd Dietrich, who preceded her in death.After graduating from high school, Ruth attended Mansfield State Teacher's College, in Pennsylvania. A devoted student, Ruth, earned a BA in Education, with French as her minor.She completed a graduate degree at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.She was a believer in attaining education and she so enjoyed learning, especially foreign languages.She was fluent in German and French.Ruth was a teacher for several years in New Bloomfield, Pennsylvania.Ruth married the late Hubert Chester Santucci on August 22,1953, in Hershey, Pennsylvania.Upon their move to Easton, Maryland, Ruth continued teaching for several more years at St. Michaels High School. Following the births of her daughters, she focused on raising her children and supporting her husband, Hubert, as he continued his employment as principal of Easton High School, and later as Supervisor of Instruction at the Talbot County School Board.Ruth was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She always said she would "fight tigers for her daughters". She was a nurturer, a protector, and provided calm council for her family. As her husband's health declined, she was his strength. A quiet sentinel at his casket, gently placing his sleep toboggan on his head, so he wouldn't feel cold. A calm enduring presence following his death to give comfort to all the family who were grieving.Ruth was of the Depression Era. She never asked for much and was content with what she did have. She always put others feelings ahead of her own and it was most important for her to conduct herself in a ladylike manner. She never wanted to cause distress or inconvenience for anyone. A resilient lady, calm in a crisis, always lending emotional support to others.A member of St. Peter and Paul Catholic Church, Ruth had a strong faith. She did not fear death. She was confident she would be surrounded by her loved ones when she passed.Ruth is survived by her daughters, Lisa Santucci Dunphy, Amy Santucci Parrish, and Anne Kay Santucci; granddaughter, Kathryn Taylor Raver and her husband, Adam; grandson, William Chester Parrish, and his wife, Arianne; her great-grandchildren James Hubert Raver and Peyton Louis Raver; her sons-in-law, John Dunphy and Randy Parrish. Ruth will be cremated and her remains will be buried with her cherished husband, Hubert Chester Santucci, at the Eastern Shore Veteran's Cemetery.As Ruth had a love of learning and teaching, in lieu of flowers, she would have appreciated a donation to the Talbot County Free Library of Easton, Maryland.

title: Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While the Chesapeake Film Festival's focus this year largely dealt with environment and women's empowerment, the "rhythm, motion and meaning" section shown at the Academy Art Museum on Saturday afternoon veered into something different.There were two screenings: a documentary feature called "Lives Beyond Motion," directed by Keith Glassman, and a documentary short called "100 Foot Photo," directed by Matt Kresling.
The festival's Executive Director Cid Collins Walker said she chose to show these films together to balance the festival's commitment to films about women's empowerment with stories about men.
Walker said this was the best attended year in the festival's 18-year history.
"Every year, we see an increase in the amount of support we receive for all the programming," Walker said.
Committing life to art
After the showings Saturday, there was a Q&A with the director and producer of "Lives Beyond Motion."
The film explored Glassman's existential question of why he and other men committed their lives to dance.
The film began as a low-budget, long-term project around 2008 with major progress starting in 2015 after bringing producer The Angel on board. Glassman interviewed around 20 dancers who, without knowing it, shared common loves, struggles and difficulties.
Glassman's own career as a dancer ended 30 years ago after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. This prompted his quest to understand why dancers commit their lives to the artform for such a long time.
"I decided their answers should be heard by a wider audience, which was the impetus for the interviews," Glassman said. "Their specific answers about their experiences adjusted my perspective beyond my own, bringing in topics relevant to the whole dance community over the years, like the HIV epidemic."
"Lives Beyond Motion" is Glassman's first documentary, and he said he's been submitting it to every film festival possible.
Audience members went around the room describing what about the film resonated with them most. Multiple people spoke of the authenticity and vulnerability of the interviewees, which they said made this film personal and emotional.
An Eastern Shore connection
Matt Kreslings short film follows the journey of 20th century American artist Robert Rauschenberg's trip to China in the 1980s, his creative relationship with long-time Eastern Shore resident Donald Saff and, ultimately, his creation of a long, scroll-like photograph he named "Chinese Summerfall."
The 10-minute film explored the painstaking process of printmaking at a time when artists were physically cutting negative images and didn't know if they were done properly until the images were processed.
"I want my work to make you care because I care," Rauschenberg said in the film.
The Academy Art Museum will celebrate Rauschenberg's 100th birthday with the exhibit "Rauschenberg 100: New Connections" opening Dec. 11 and running through May 3, 2026.
The exhibit will include "Chinese Summerfall," which is rarely exhibited due to its size and fragility, according to the Academy Art Museums website. It will also feature showings of Kresling's short film, "100 Foot Photo."
"Receiving the support that we do from the community, from our sponsors, our partners, our patrons, makes such a huge difference for us," Walker said. "We simply couldn't do it without you."

Women to Watch event recognizes more than 200 local leaders

 April 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News

 EASTON — More than 250 women gathered at The Avalon Theatre Wednesday to celebrate the unveiling of the annual Women to Watch magazine. From lawyers, to entrepreneurs, to nurses, to educators, a wide swath of the Mid-Shore was represented at this APG Chesapeake event.The women honored at the event were selected through community nominations, with criteria like community service, professional accomplishment and personal achievement being considered. More than 200 women from the Mid-Shore region were nominated.
"I think it highlights all the work that everybody in the community does and just how powerful our community of women are," said nominee Kari Mielke Clow, principal at Chapel District Elementary.
Of the nominees, 16 women were selected by the Women to Watch committee to be featured in this year's Women to Watch magazine, which profiles impactful work being done by women in the Mid-Shore community.
There were three featured speakers at the event — Ivette Furneisen, lawyer; Sharon Pepukayi, superintendent of Talbot County Public Schools; and Meisha Amia, nurse, author and entrepreneur.
Furneisen is from Barcelona. She used her native language, Spanish, to help the Hispanic immigrant community navigate the legal system. Being from Spain, she too had to wrestle with visas, employment authorization and becoming a resident, she said. Already a lawyer in Spain when she moved to the U.S., she had to go to law school a second time to practice as a lawyer in Maryland.
"During COVID I had this clever idea, with a 6-month-old at my house, to go back to law school," she said. "So I did it. I have been able to help a lot of people."
Furneisen recently opened her law practice, Campbell and Furneisen Law Firm, in Chestertown.
In closing she said, "It is on all of us to make sure the next generation of women are as strong as we are."
Pepukayi, who spoke after Furneisen, talked about what motivated her on her path to her position to superintendent.
She said she learned from the courage, confidence and communication skills of strong women who surrounded her.
"The courage for me to take risks, to fail forward, to laugh at my mistakes, to dust myself off and get back up when I got knocked down, to apply for jobs that I knew I would have to work really, really hard for," she said.
"The confidence to share my far-fetched ideas, to walk into a room where I was the only person that looked like me, but to know I could contribute and make a difference," Pepukayi continued. "And being communicative to share my vulnerable stories, to be transparent even when it is not good news and to meet and mentor other young women… to seek to understand rather than to be understood."
She extolled the audience to help each other and to not let jealousy get in the way. She asked them to mentor younger women as they had been mentored.
The final speaker was Amia, a writer, labor and delivery nurse, and entrepreneur.
As a travel nurse with over 40 assignments, "I treated my road trips like a 90-day evaluations on the job. I am getting things done, and I am like, 'Girl you have got to grow,'" Amia said.
"The most important thing I am going to tell you today is do not be afraid to wander. Just because your path is different, it doesn't mean that you are lost. Your path is preparing you for purpose."
There were many sponsors of the event, including Easton Economic Development, Easton Utilities, Pohanka Automotive Group, Wye Financial Partners, Queenstown Landing, Shore Legal Access, Parker Counts, The Ivy, All in the Mix Bakeshop and Ruby's.
APG Chesapeake made a $5,000 donation to Foundation of Hope, a nonprofit organization providing cultural, spiritual, social and educational trainings to girls in middle school through an after-school program aimed at helping girls to become leaders.
"The event really came together early this year — we sold out a week prior," said Betsy Griffin, assistant regional manager for sales at APG Chesapeake. "The speakers were fascinating and each offered snappy pieces of solid advice. How fun to watch the nominee's stand with a cheering section behind them during the event.
"Next year we hope to incorporate a level of mentoring for young people and are so appreciative of Foundation of Hope, as they do this type of important work," Griffin continued.

title: Frederick Douglass' Valentine's Day birthday honored by his family
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Frederick Douglass' Valentine's Day birthday honored by his family

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Frederick Douglass never knew his exact birthday.Like many born into slavery, the exact date was never recorded. Douglass knew it was sometime in February but not the exact day.
Douglass chose to celebrate on Valentine's Day because his mother called him her "little Valentine."
"Yes, he celebrated his birthday on Valentine's Day," Douglass' five-time great nephew Tarence Bailey Sr. said. "Feb. 14 through Feb. 20, you can say it's the most important week of Black History Month because that's the week of Frederick Douglass' birth and death."
Douglass has strong roots in Talbot County and throughout the Eastern Shore.
Born in Talbot County in 1818, Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey Douglass was enslaved for 20 years in Baltimore and on Talbot County farms. He fled north in 1838 and changed his name to Frederick Douglass. His brilliance, eloquence and courage, quickly brought him to the forefront of the abolitionist movement.
He was known for his skills as an orator, with many of his speeches remembered to this day.
"He spoke in Denton on Halloween 1883, and Douglas took the train from Wilmington to Denton," author and historian John Muller said. "Then when he was leaving and he spoke in front of the County Courthouse in Denton... there was so many people they didn't fit inside. The crowd had to go outside."
According to Muller, Douglass also spoke in Cambridge, St. Michaels, and many more Eastern Shore locales.
Douglass and his work are inspirational to many Americans, but it goes deeper than just inspiration for the Bailey-Groce Family Foundation, Bailey said.
The Bailey-Groce Family Foundation is run by multiple Douglass family members who grew up on the Eastern Shore. It is one of two family foundations operated by descendants of the Douglass bloodline.
"I think for my family here from Talbot County and from Eastern Shore as a whole, it's a whole lot different for us," Bailey said. "Being raised on the Shore and then having the relative like him, you look at it differently than the average person does."
Three years ago, the foundation started hosting a birthday celebration for Fredrick Douglas between Feb. 14 and 20, close to his birthday and the anniversary of his death. This year's celebration will be held on Feb. 22 due to a scheduling conflict.
The birthday celebration is held to help fundraise for an African American Cultural Center and an African American Historical Society, institutions the foundation plans to establish in Talbot County.
The event will begin at the historic Avalon Theatre at 3:45 p.m.
This year's event will feature a homecoming performance by Ayla Dennis, who was featured on American Idol.
"She's actually a Bailey family descendant," Bailey said. "So it's going to be a history making to have her singing at the Avalon, which was a formerly segregated theater down the street from where the slave auction once was, right there by the courthouse where Frederick Douglass spoke, having his relatives actually headlining for his birthday in a formerly segregated theater."
Other entertainment for Douglass' birthday celebration includes a county group from Atlanta, Georgia; a concert violinist from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; a featured poet from Brooklyn, New York; and many more.
After the performances, the foundation will host a VIP dinner at the Waterfowl Building in Easton. The foundation wants everyone to wear African-style clothing to honor Douglass' heritage.
"Frederick Douglass was a very classy dude. We like to keep his birthday the way he would want it," Bailey said. "He was John Q when it came to his clothes. Everything he wore was Brooks Brothers. So he was always dressed to the nines. So I know that at his birthday party, he would want everybody in there dressed as well as him."
The Foundation continues to host these types of events not just to raise funds, but to keep Douglass' legacy alive, Bailey said.
"Uncle Frederick is the main reason, the only reason that I that keeps me going, that keeps me pushing," Bailey Sr. said. "The goal is much bigger, Fredrick Douglass himself is the inspiration, because if it wasn't for him I don't know if we would have made it this far."
For more information about the celebration or to purchase tickets, visit avalonfoundation.org/events.

title: Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police
author: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service
content:
Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Top state officials approved a $2.75 million settlement on Wednesday after a federal investigation turned up evidence of discriminatory hiring practices by the Maryland State Police.The U.S. Department of Justice conducted a two-year investigation into state police hiring practices for a violation of Title VII, which prohibits discrimination against employees or applicants based on race, color, religion, sex and national origin.
The investigation found that the state police engaged in discriminatory practices against Black and female applicants, agency officials acknowledged in a meeting of the Maryland Board of Public Works on Wednesday.
The DOJ said that MDSP written tests disproportionately impacted Black candidates, while their physical fitness tests disproportionately impacted female candidates. The tests discriminated against candidates while failing to "meaningfully distinguish between applicants who can and cannot perform the position of Trooper," according to a Department of Justice press release.
"Discrimination in any form has no place within the Maryland State Police, and it will not be tolerated," Col. Roland Butler Jr., superintendent of MDSP, told the board Wednesday. "We're committed to making meaningful and lasting change … [and] to develop new policies and procedures that ensure equitable treatment for all applicants."
The board — made up of Gov. Wes Moore, state Comptroller Brooke Lierman and Treasurer Dereck E. Davis — signed off on the settlement. The agreement must also be approved by a federal court before moving forward.
In response to the investigation, MDSP will change its current testing methods to prevent future discrimination in hiring, but the new practices will not be ready until after the next two MDSP classes start, Butler said. To adapt, he said, MDSP intends to change existing standards, including eliminating time requirements from different portions of the physical fitness tests.
Members of the Board of Public Works raised concerns about this interim period, with Davis questioning whether the unclear guidelines would lead to more discrimination.
"Now it becomes subjective, so doesn't that lend itself, potentially, to be more discriminatory?" Davis asked. "Now we don't know what's good or what's not as it relates to that time."
Butler assured Davis that strict monitoring of who passes and fails the tests would be in place, allowing MDSP to monitor areas of improvement.
"We won't have the other test in place at this time," Butler said. "However, we're relaxing the standards that we have … We will be allowed to use those tests under the condition that we provide strict monitoring to see what the results are, to see who's passing, who's failing and we do think that we'll get a larger pool of applicants when we start to look at how we measure that test and how we evaluate it."
Officials said the new tests would emphasize fairness while maintaining safety requirements, including a test that would receive ongoing validation to guarantee it was modern, fair and relevant, as well as an aptitude test to look for integrity, self-motivation, critical thinking and judgment skills.
The settlement involved 48 Black and female individuals who were prevented from becoming state troopers due to the discriminatory practices, according to Butler.
Since his appointment in 2023, Butler said, he has worked to evaluate and modernize the agency's practices.
"I remain steadfastly committed to cultivating a culture that will ensure inclusiveness," Butler said, "one that allows the fulfillment of our mission, of values centered around integrity, fairness, and service."

title: Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News
