 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Securing funding for the new regional medical center and addressing local impacts of last year's juvenile justice reform laws are priorities for Mid-Shore lawmakers heading into the 2024 General Assembly in January.During a Tuesday meeting with the Talbot County Council and local stakeholders, the three Mid-Shore legislators, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Reps. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson, tackled a number of issues affecting the district, discussing ways to advance their progress in the upcoming legislative session.REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTERSecuring financial support for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center has long been a top priority for local legislators.The proposed 147-bed hospital and medical office building are slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S.Route 50 in Easton.The start of construction is dependent on the project receiving a Certificate of Need from the Maryland Health Care Commission.The hospital system filed the CON application in January and anticipates a response in December or January, said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health.In a separate process, the hospital system is working with the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the state's rate-setting authority, to see if rate relief can be obtained to offset the cost of interest and depreciation for the project.However, MHCC will first need to hear from HSCRC to determine if the project is financially viable before making a decision on the application. Uncertainty lies in how much the HSCRC decision will weigh on the health care commission's answer, Kozel said.That relief, along with government funding, is key to moving forward with the regional medical center.Former Gov. Larry Hogan earmarked $100 million last December for the project in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget.During this year's legislative session, lawmakers secured $10 million in the budget for the new medical center, which the hospital system must spend by June 30, 2024, Kozel said.There's also a pledge for $20 million in fiscal year 2025, though it's subject to change, so the hospital system is asking Gov. Wes Moore to solidify that allocation, along with the remaining $70 million, he added.The county council and lawmakers can write letters of support to help ensure the governor is aware of the project, Kozel said.Del. Chris Adams (R-37B) expressed his vote of confidence and support."We want this project to happen as much as you do and as much as every elected official does," he said, "And most importantly, as much as every citizen that will stand to benefit from the delivery of the services that are possible in a brand new facility and the quality that you get from your organization."JUVENILE JUSTICETalbot County Sheriff's Office Capt. John Bollinger and Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised concerns about the significant impacts resulting from the passage of juvenile justice reform measures last year.Bollinger said the legislature was "wrong" for passing the laws last year, highlighting a 42% increase in youth crime in schools and two provisions of the laws that have been particularly burdensome for local law enforcement.One provision bars police from being able to charge a child under 13 years old with a crime unless it's a violent crime, such as murder, attempted murder or rape."The worst part is that these kids know that, and the criminals know that," Bollinger said, suggesting that 12-year-olds could be implicated in illegal activities and not be punished for their involvement."They can do it in front of our face, and we can't do anything other than tell them, 'That's bad, you shouldn't do that,'" he said.Under another law, police are not allowed to interview a child after they're arrested until the child has an attorney to represent them, even if it's to get more information or to find out if others are involved."I'm here to tell you that there's not a lawyer anywhere that's going to say, 'Sure, tell the police everything,' - they're going to shut them down on the phone without even meeting them, knowing nothing about the case, and then our hands are tied," Bollinger said.The increase in crime in schools is mainly from the county's middle and high schools, and the majority of the crimes are assaults, he said. And out of 114 reported assaults in the schools in the last year, 40 of them involved children under 13.However, Talbot County is experiencing less youth crime than some other Shore jurisdictions. In Dorchester and Wicomico counties, the number of assaults on both students and staff are "dramatically higher" than previous years, said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B)."The good newsis every county is now talking about it," he said. "The county executives on the western shore are talking about it, butis anybody going to want to make a change?"COUNTY INITIATIVESWhile there are no specific Talbot County bills being proposed for consideration by the state legislature so far, the county is supporting the Maryland Association of Counties' 2024 legislative initiatives.Those initiatives include launching forward-thinking firefighter and emergency medical services incentives, providing transparency in education spending, modernizing local revenue structures and advancing comprehensive housing solutions.

title: Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During Wednesday's meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education added a day onto the end of this year's school calendar following last week's snowstorm.Talbot County Public Schools was closed Monday through Friday last week due to snow that blanketed the Mid-Shore. However, the 2024-2025 school calendar only had four inclement weather days built in, meaning an additional day was needed to comply with the state's 180-day requirement.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, recommended that a day be added in June, moving the last day of school for students to Friday, June 13.
The last day for teachers would be Monday, June 16. Einhorn said that historically, most teachers complete mandated training that affords them with not having to come in on the last day.
The board unanimously passed the adjusted calendar for this year.
2025-26 CALENDAROn Wednesday, the board also chose the district's calendar for the 2025-2026 school year.
At last month's meeting, Einhorn presented a draft calendar with two days off in March and a five-day spring break, which was the recommendation of the calendar committee. Board President Emily Jackson, however, expressed frustration there weren't multiple options posed.
This month, Einhorn returned with three draft calendars. The first was similar to what the board saw in December, with a four-day weekend in March and the shorter spring break. The second draft removed the off days in March and had an eight-day spring break.
A third draft included both the March break and an eight-day spring break, pushing the last student day back to June 10, 2026.
All three drafts included the typical days off in November for Easton's Waterfowl Festival, as well as a winter break from Dec. 20, 2025, to Jan. 4, 2026.
"There is no calendar that we're going to create that is best for every single person," Jackson said.
Jackson said it's clear — based on previous polling and community input — that most families favor the extended spring break. Board Vice President Amy Dodson suggested the board move forward with the second or third calendars.
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry said she preferred the first calendar with the shorter spring break.
"You're losing a lot of school time for eight days off for students," Wieland-Cherry said. "You're losing a lot of momentum. And plus you're concerned with providing day care. Not all employers are going to allow that. That's quite a long time to take off of work and find day care and so forth."
She added that not all families are looking for a longer spring break.
"My only concern is that if 59% of our students are at the poverty level, we're really talking about more of a smaller group who are really going to financially be able to afford an Easter holiday," Wieland-Cherry said. "… You really could possibly potentially be causing more hardship for something that's more an elitist type thing, quite honestly."
Jackson said while she agrees with Wieland-Cherry's point, she has "to go with what the community is saying."
"We have asked again and again, and the majority of the respondents to any time we've asked this have said they like that spring break," Jackson said.
Following board discussion, Jackson motioned for approval of the third calendar featuring two off days in March and five days for spring break. Her motion included an amendment to the calendar that the March days off serve as two of four inclement weather days for the district.
By a 6-1 vote, with only Wieland-Cherry voting against, the board approved the 2025-2026 school year calendar.

title: Orioles sending nearly $8.5 million to teams involved in trade-deadline deals
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Orioles sending nearly $8.5 million to teams involved in trade-deadline deals

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 855

 Read News Document

 Baltimore will be sending nearly $8.5 million to four teams as part of five deals made ahead of the trade deadline.The Orioles will give San Diego $3,324,300 along with All-Star first baseman Ryan O'Hearn and outfielder Ramón Laureano, who were dealt last week for right-handers Tyson Neighbors and Tanner Smith, left-hander Boston Bateman, infielders Brandon Butterworth and Cobb Hightower and infielder/outfielder Victor Figueroa.
O'Hearn was owed $2,537,634 of his $8 million salary and Laureano $1,268,817. Baltimore will pay two installments of $1,662,150 on Sept. 15 and 30, according to trade details obtained by The Associated Press. The money reduces San Diego's expense to $482,151, which comes to a prorated share of the $760,000 minimum for each.
Baltimore will send Detroit $2,758,065 on Sept. 30 as part of the trade that sent right-hander Charlie Morton to the Tigers for minor league left-hander Micah Ashman. Morton was owed $4,758,064 of his $15 million salary, and the cash reduces his cost to the Tigers to $2 million. In addition, the Orioles will send the Tigers $100,000 on Aug. 15 as part of the trade to acquire left-hander Dietrich Enns.
The Orioles also are sending Toronto $1.75 million on Sept. 30 as part of the July 29 trade that sent right-hander Seranthony Domínguez to the Blue Jays for minor league right-hander Juaron Watts-Brown — a deal announced between games of a doubleheader between the teams. Domínguez had $2,645,161 left from his $8 million salary at the time of the trade.
Baltimore is giving Houston $520,000 along with infielder Ramón Urías, who was dealt for minor leaguer right-hander Twine Palmer. The money is due in equal payments on Sept. 15 and Oct. 15. Urías was owed $1,016,129 of his $3.15 million salary.
Money in the five trades totals $8,452,365. Baltimore opened the season with a $169 million payroll, 15th among the 30 major league teams.
Minnesota is paying $33 million to Houston in the July 31 trade that returned All-Star Carlos Correa to the Astros for minor league left-hander Matt Mikulski, by far the largest amount among 14 deadline trades involving cash transactions. That covered a significant portion of the $103,419,355 remaining in the contract of the three-time All-Star, who left the Astros to sign with the Twins ahead of the 2022 season. Houston gets $3 million this year and $10 million each in 2026, 2027 and 2028, with installments due each Dec. 15.
Arizona will pay Milwaukee $5,258,000 as part of the July 31 trade that sent right-hander Shelby Miller and left-hander Jordan Montgomery to the Brewers for a player to be named or cash. Arizona will send the money in four installments of $1,314,500 on Aug. 15, Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30. Montgomery was owed $7,137,097 of his $22.5 million salary and Miller $317,204 of his $1 million salary.
Milwaukee is sending San Diego $2,169,000 as part of the trade that sent left-hander Nestor Cortes and minor league infielder Jorge Quintana to the Padres for outfielder Brandon Lockridge. That offsets part of the $2,410,753 remaining from Cortes' $7.6 million salary. The Brewers will send $361,500 each on Aug. 15 and 29, Sept. 12 and 26 plus $723,000 on Oct. 10.
Cincinnati is paying Pittsburgh $1,935,484 as part of the July 30 trade that sent left-hander Taylor Rogers and minor league shortstop Sammy Stafura to the Pirates for third baseman Ke'Bryan Hayes. The cash covers half the $3,870,968 Rogers was owed from his $12 million salary, and the Reds paid $435,484 on Aug. 1 and owe $500,000 each on Aug. 15, Sept. 1 and Sept. 15.
Rogers was dealt the following day to the Cubs for outfielder Ivan Brethowr, and Pittsburgh agreed to give the Cubs $1,903,226. That offset half the $3,806,452 then left on Rogers' salary after the $64,516 he earned during his one day with Pittsburgh, for whom he never threw a pitch. The Pirates pay $423,226 on Aug . 15 and owe $500,000 installments on Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30.
San Francisco will give Kansas City $1,934,100 as part of the trade that sent outfielder Mike Yastzemski to the Royals for right-hander Yunior Marte. Yastzemski was owed $2,934,140 of his $9.25 million salary, and the Giants will make four payments of $483,535 on Aug. 15. Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30.
Tampa Bay is sending Milwaukee $1.1 million in the July 28 trade that sent catcher Danny Jansen to his hometown Brewers for minor league infielder Jadher Areinamo. Jansen was owed $2,833,333 of his $8.5 million salary. The Rays will make six payments of $183,333, on Aug. 1, 15 and 29, Sept. 12 and 26, and Oct. 10. Tampa Bay agreed to send an additional $500,000 if a $12 million mutual option for 2026 is declined, which carries a $500,000 buyout.
St. Louis agreed to pay Atlanta $2.28 million as part of the July 27 trade that sent right-hander Erick Fedde to the Braves for a player to be named or cash. Fedde was owed $2,455,645 from his $7.25 million salary. The Cardinals will make equal payments of $1.14 million on Aug. 11 and Sept. 22.
Detroit will pay Texas $100,000 on Aug. 15 as part of the trade to acquire right-hander Codi Heuer.

title: Talbot County removes DEI statement amid funding concerns for airport
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County removes DEI statement amid funding concerns for airport

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 752
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council voted Tuesday to remove the diversity, equity and inclusion statement from the county's employee handbook, reversing course from March, when the council upheld the diversity statement.Tuesday's decision came amid concerns for millions of dollars in federal funding for an ongoing Easton Airport project. Those worries stem from an April directive from U.S. Department of Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy outlining the Trump administration's view that DEI programs violate federal law.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher and council member Dave Stepp sponsored Tuesday's resolution, which passed 4-1 with council member Keasha Haythe opposing. Haythe, Lesher and council member Lynn Mielke had voted down Stepp's attempt to remove the DEI statement in March.
Lesher, a Democrat, said it was a difficult decision, noting he changed his tune on the measure due to a "vindictive and maleficent federal administration."
"The risk is that some incompetent political appointee will read only the title of our statement, misconstrue it as an illegal policy and deny a federal grant on that basis," Lesher said. "In an event like that, even if we win on appeal, it could leave us in a state of construction limbo for an unacceptably long time."
Lesher added, "We simply need to ensure that we are using none of the language that could trigger some snowflake in Washington."
Mielke, a Republican, said she agreed with Lesher and that Talbot County has always been a merit-based employer.
Stepp, a Republican, said council members "fell short" and put the county in a vulnerable spot when they rejected his original proposal in March.
"It's very frustrating that we even need to be discussing this here today. It should've been dealt with months ago," Stepp said. "This matter has been highly politicized and turned into something it is not."
"Today's action is fiscal in nature," he added.
Council President Chuck Callahan, a Republican, voted to remove the statement in March and did so again Tuesday. He said the controversial topic — which garnered strong resident opposition and led to two heated meetings — has been "tough on council."
"I know we all have our own beliefs, one way or the other with the DEI stuff," Callahan said. "But at this time I think we've made the right decision and the right statement."
Haythe, the council's only non-white member and a Democrat, asked county attorney Patrick Thomas about an opinion letter he provided on the DEI statement and Duffy's directive. Duffy's directive to all DOT funding recipients referenced the U.S. Supreme Court's 2023 rejection of affirmative action programs at Harvard University.
"I do not believe that the statement is discriminatory, and I do not believe that the Supreme Court (case) being referenced in the secretary of transportation letter applies to that statement," Thomas said.
Tuesday's resolution, effectively immediately, voids Talbot County's DEI statement. Two 2020 diversity resolutions are also "of no further force and effect," according to the newly approved resolution.
Those resolutions had facilitated the creation of the diversity statement and required the county manager to provide an annual diversity training report to the council, respectively.
The new resolution states nothing in it "shall be construed as a repudiation of the intent and desire" of the county to ensure a "welcoming workplace" in which employees are treated fairly based on race, sex, national origin, etc.
Lesher asked county staff to work on a "replacement welcoming statement" for the county's employee handbook.
AIRPORT PROJECT
Easton Airport's ongoing modernization project — which will relocate and expand the airport's main runway — is 90% funded by the Federal Aviation Administration, an organization within the Department of Transportation. The airport is owned and operated by Talbot County.
Airport Manager Micah Risher said he consulted with county staff after the April DOT letter. In an interview Tuesday, Risher said he has "absolute faith" in the council's support of the airport. Risher added that the airport ensures it is always abiding by federal and state laws.
"To have Easton Airport have any sort of funding at jeopardy, it's a bigger deal than the average person may think," Risher said, citing the airport's large economic impact on the community.
According to Risher, the airport received around $17 million from the FAA for the first two phases of the project. Estimates on the remaining federal funding for the rest of the project aren't available since bids are out, he said, but over $30 million of work remains.
"We're up here against our greatest milestone that is really going to ensure that we have a viable airport, and this great economic engine, succeed here in Talbot County for another 80-plus years," he said.

title: Easton election cycle has been charged, political in nature
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton election cycle has been charged, political in nature

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton saw a heated election the last time the council president seat was up for grabs. This year's race is no different.Since campaigns for the three open Town Council seats began this winter, there have been stolen and vandalized campaign signs, tense debates on campaign finance transparency and, most recently, political mailers from Republican-endorsed candidates calling out Mayor Megan Cook.
The tenor of the election cycle — which culminates with voting Tuesday — is largely influenced by the race for Town Council president between incumbent Frank Gunsallus and current Ward 2 representative Don Abbatiello.
At a town hall Tuesday, both candidates offered thoughts on civility.
"In the past two years, the council members overall, have been almost always conducting themselves in a civil manner," said Gunsallus. "There are times where debate may get heated. That is the nature of democracy."
"Arguing is fine, I get it. Disagreements occur," Abbatiello said. "But it needs to be done in a respectful manner."
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry, who has endorsed Abbatiello, said the charged nature of this election isn't normal for Easton. And it's hurting the town, she says.
"Anytime you create an environment based on animosity, it becomes counterproductive, fairly quickly," Curry said. "And I think that's sort of where we are today."
Talbot County Republican Central Committee vice chair Shari Wilcoxon believes a reason the race is so intense is that it's a fight to preserve Easton's charm.
"People love our little town. It's a jewel," she said. "And we had a lot of people move here during COVID because they wanted to get out of the crud to come to this little town. A lot of us want to preserve that."
ENDORSEMENTS
As Gunsallus and Abbatiello square off, they have racked up endorsements from local politicians and even fellow council members.
Abbatiello received endorsements from Curry and, in a surprise to some, Ward 3's David Montgomery, who had sided with Gunsallus on several contentious matters discussed by the council in the past year.
"It would be very hard for us to move forward productively for the next four years under that kind of leadership," Montgomery said of Gunsallus.
Curry says Abbatiello's experience and knowledge make him the best candidate. "He has the right temperament," she said.
Meanwhile, Gunsallus' main endorsements come from Republican leaders — the Republican Central Committee, Sheriff Joe Gamble, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Dels. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson.
Wilcoxon said the committee looked at values — not necessarily party affiliation — when endorsing Gunsallus and mother-and-son newcomers Lynn and Cameron Keefe, who are running in Wards 2 and 4, respectively.
"To me he's a phenomenal leader," Wilcoxon said of Gunsallus, citing his thoughtfulness and transparency.
"He's not afraid to ask questions," Mautz said. " ... Sometimes, the questions may seem silly. And other times, they may reveal things that most people aren't aware of."
Abbatiello and his supporters have denounced the involvement of political parties in the town's election, which is nonpartisan and doesn't list candidates alongside a party.
"I do not think that the Republican Party platform has anything to do with the issues that we face here in Easton, and so I don't understand why the party has decided to intervene so strongly in a local election," Montgomery, a Republican, said.
Mautz said while the election is performed as nonpartisan, it is political in nature. "Every election has got politics baked into it," he said.
"I think that everybody fools themselves if they say it's nonpartisan," Wilcoxon said. "Everybody knows. Everybody knows everybody's party. We can just cut the pretending, right?"
Flavio Hickel, an associate professor of political science at Washington College, sees both sides of the argument.
"Broadly speaking, I don't think it's a good idea to allow for local party endorsements or to make nonpartisan elections partisan, because you are allowing partisanship to interfere in local town government," Hickel said.
However, Hickel said knowing which parties candidates align with is informative for voters, especially at a local level.
"Most voters probably aren't familiar with the candidates running," he said. " ... What party identity does at all levels of elections is it provides a very quick information shortcut for voters."
Curry and Montgomery's endorsements have raised questions, too.
Wilcoxon said she views Montgomery's opposition to Gunsallus as personal and said she believes Montgomery and Cook's sponsorship of a campaign finance ordinance was "100%" an attack on Gunsallus' campaign.
At the town hall Tuesday, Gunsallus spoke of council endorsements: "I would not want an endorsement from a fellow council member because I believe that that is out of bounds," he said. Then he made a remark seemingly concerning Montgomery.
"And especially one of them, I would not accept it."
Montgomery disputed that claim, telling The Star Democrat Friday that Gunsallus asked for his endorsement a few months ago, but that he declined.
Curry said she hadn't before made an endorsement as a sitting council member, but that she gave a "great deal of thought" in endorsing Abbatiello.
In her eyes, the discourse around endorsements and political sides are making the campaign heated, instead of what she'd rather the election be centered on: issues such as growth and housing.
"There's too much of the 'he said,' 'he said,' and he's backed by this guy and he's backed by this guy," Curry said. "The issues have taken a back seat, and that's wrong."

title: Legislators, local officials differ on unhoused individuals bill
author: Konner Metz
content:
Legislators, local officials differ on unhoused individuals bill

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A bill filed in Annapolis to enshrine rights for homeless individuals is drawing differing opinions from advocates and local officials.House Bill 487, and its paired Senate Bill 484, would protect the ability of homeless individuals to partake in "life-sustaining activities" such as sleeping, eating or drinking, in public places so long as traffic is not obstructed.
If passed, any civil or criminal punishment against an unhoused individual who is on public land without an "adequate alternative indoor" space would be considered cruel and unusual punishment.
According to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's most recent data, Maryland's homeless population in 2023 was 5,865 individuals, both sheltered and unsheltered.
Del. Bernice Mireku North (D-Montgomery), the bill's sponsor, and other advocates say the proposed legislation comes in response to a Supreme Court decision last June that ruled it was not cruel and unusual punishment for local governments to civilly and criminally penalize homeless people for setting up encampments on public land.
Mireku-North wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat that the proposed bill has "brought to light the heart-led efforts" of local governments to support unhoused individuals. An emphasis of the bill is to prevent immediate arrests, she said.
"At a minimum, we are asking law enforcement to prioritize inquiring whether an alternative indoor space exists for unhoused people engaging in life-sustaining activities before resorting to arrest," Mireku-North wrote.
The delegate said legislators are "committed" to working with local officials and stakeholders on the bill.
Allie Post, director of development and communications for The Women's Law Center of Maryland, said the bill would be a measure in which the state "(stands) up for folks proactively" following the June Supreme Court ruling.
"Especially for survivors (of domestic violence) and survivors of color, homelessness is often a price of leaving an abuser," Post said. "And folks who have less financial means and less flexibility in those means are really put between a rock and a hard place, and this is an opportunity for Maryland to step up and start taking seriously the homelessness problem that we have."
While advocates say it's a needed step forward in the path to address Maryland's homelessness crisis, some Easton and Talbot County officials say the bill is endangering the efforts already being taken.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and the Sheriff's Office released a video on Facebook last month depicting what they believe a potential encounter could look like with a homeless individual if the bill is passed.
"If these were to pass, we could have homeless encampments in Idlewild Park, (the) courthouse," Gamble said in a separate video the department shared. " … You literally could set up a tent on the 50-yard-line at Easton High School before an Easton football game and call it your home, and we would not be able to move those people."
Gamble said the homelessness issue is serious in Talbot County and that he's not against addressing it. However, he believes the bill as written will strip away authority of locally elected officials.
"They will not be able to follow the zoning laws that they've put into place to make downtown Easton the place it is, or downtown St. Michaels or downtown Oxford to be those nice places that people want to come to visit and spend their hard-earned money," Gamble said in an interview. "They will have absolutely no control over it."
Easton Mayor Megan Cook addressed the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee in a Feb. 5 letter opposing the bill.
Cook wrote that the bill "would supersede local ordinance and policies that have been carefully crafted to address the needs of both unhoused individuals and the broader community."
"By prohibiting local and state officials from enforcing reasonable regulations on the use of public spaces, the bill could lead to unintended consequences that compromise public safety, hinder economic development, and create significant enforcement challenges," Cook wrote.
In her letter, Cook asked legislators to instead focus on policies that would provide funding for housing assistance, mental health and job programs.
"Our community is committed to addressing homelessness with dignity and care—through outreach, support services, and housing initiatives—while also ensuring that public spaces remain accessible and safe for all," Cook wrote.

title: Local chef nominated for James Beard Award
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Local chef nominated for James Beard Award

 February 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although Bas Rouge is getting national attention, it is a local restaurant at its core.On its menu, passion for the Chesapeake takes center stage, says Executive Chef Harley Peet. His efforts to celebrate the Eastern Shore's people and ecology have helped land him on the shortlist for one of the culinary industry's most prestigious awards.
The James Beard Foundation has named Peet as a semifinalist for best chef in the Mid-Atlantic region. Just getting considered is a "huge deal" for the team at Bas Rouge, the executive chef said.
"I have never pursued it because I was so intimidated by it. But then I built this amazing team, and Mr. (Paul) Prager, the owner, helped me build this amazing team and put this amazing restaurant together," Peet said. "... Then we started getting the influx. Going for the James Beard built a lot of confidence in myself and in my team."
Established in 1990 and first awarded in 1991, the James Beard Foundation's Restaurant and Chef Awards recognize exceptional talent and achievement in the culinary arts, hospitality, media and broader food system, as well as a demonstrated commitment to racial and gender equity, community, sustainability and a culture where all can thrive, according to the James Beard website.
Nominees for the award will be announced on Wednesday, April 3, and winners will be announced at the James Beard Restaurant and Chef Awards Ceremony on Monday, June 10.
The Bas Rouge team draws inspiration from the endless bounty of the Chesapeake to inform its menu, which offers European-style dishes made with local ingredients.
"Every year, every turn of the season it absolutely floors me with something that tastes even better," Peet said. "The natural shift of final products that are coming out of the Bay or coming out of the fields in the summer, they continuously always get better. The purveyors, and the growers and the foragers that we deal with are constantly trying to find something better, something more mind blowing."
"This is a miraculous thing about this area. It never disappoints," he said.
These local ingredients are transformed into elegant dishes in Bas Rouge's kitchen, including the restaurant's lunchtime favorite wiener schnitzel, an array of oysters and, when the chefs have it in, a Dover sole that Peet says draws diners from as far as D.C.
"It is food that we love and have a passion to cook and eat," Peet said. "I think the idea of taking a raw ingredient from the Chesapeake Bay or from a field delivered to the back door by a forager. What do you do in these small towns? You fish, you hunt, you gather because it is fun. It is part of the lifestyle here. So as far as what the food is about and has to say, the food is about myself and my team taking as much local (as we can), accented with fine imported ingredients because of course you have to have some diversity."
"We have a hyper focus on what we have right here," he said.
But beyond the Chesapeake's flora and fauna, Peet said that he has decades of lived experiences on the Eastern Shore from which he draws inspiration.
He recalled one time 20 years ago when he was just out of culinary school and his first assignment was on Tilghman Island. He was using oysters in a dish, but he wanted to know where the ingredients came from.
There was a bus boy who also worked as a waterman. Peet got an invitation to go oystering.
"So I am up there in my sailing gear. And these watermen are laughing at me. They are in white rubber boots and Grundens, and I am out there in Haley Hansen and Patagonia. They said, 'You know we are about to get dirty?' And I said, 'Alright, let's do it.'"
He learned by doing. He learned how oyster tonging works, how dredging works and how patent tonging works. He even learned how certain boats are rigged.
"If you don't understand that, then preparing (the ingredient) and serving it lacks a little passion. We have a round-about 360-degree connection with that. Terroir is a number one," said Peet.

title: Easton leans away from annexing new land in comprehensive plan update
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton leans away from annexing new land in comprehensive plan update

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 728
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As planners draft Easton's new comprehensive plan, the town's direction on annexing new land is becoming clear: slow down.At a workshop Monday, the Easton Planning Commission chose to retain language in the comprehensive plan update that discourages new annexations in the next 10 years.
As recently as last year, Easton annexed around 17 acres of county land east of U.S. Route 50 between the Royal Farms and Unitarian Universalist Fellowship. It's expected to become an affordable housing project, though the developer will still need town approval on an application.
Town Council members have indicated concerns about annexing additional land into town, especially as Easton deals with the question of whether it's maxing out on residential growth.
The comprehensive plan, last updated in 2010, is undergoing revisions before potential council approval later this year or early next year. It outlines how the town aims to grow in the next decade, touching on areas such as annexation, population growth and traffic.
On Monday and at a workshop last month, commission and council members noted that there may be exceptions to the no-annexation rule.
"I would have a hard time with being absolute about annexation, saying that that's not happening," Ward 2 Councilmember Robert Rankin said on Aug. 25. "Because there may be exceptions."
The main exception to completely halting annexation seems to be Easton Point, the development project that seeks to revitalize Port Street and the area around the Tred Avon River. The effort hasn't significantly progressed in recent years, council members say.
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said at last month's meeting that Easton Point's redevelopment is "an enigma." She advocated that annexation of the county land in that area be excluded from any no-annexation directive in the new comprehensive plan.
"The Easton Point development project's been on the board for almost 20 years," Curry said. "We have to find a way to move that forward if we can."
Town leaders largely agreed that a project like Easton Point rises to the level of an "extraordinary" annexation that should be permitted under the comprehensive plan's guidance.
Still, the plan should emphasize that annexation generally is "not a priority for the town," said Planning Commission member Victoria McAndrews on Monday.
GROWTH RATE
Hesitation to approve future annexation requests stems, in part, from the town's growth. From 2000 to 2010, the town's population increased 36%, according to census data. In the next decade, growth slowed to 7%, bringing Easton's population from 15,945 to 17,101.
When commission and council members met for a joint workshop in August, the council maintained that the comprehensive plan should include a target growth rate for population. The 2010 version has a 1% annual growth rate, which for the most part hasn't been exceeded. Bumping it up to 1.75% was discussed.
Michael Ports, the commission's vice chair, said Monday that 1.75% "makes the most sense." But other commission members leaned toward a 1.14% annual growth rate, which is based off of historical trends.
Commission Chairperson Phil Toussaint agreed with the 1.14% rate, emphasizing that it needs to be at a mark so the Town Council feels comfortable approving the plan as a whole.
TRAFFIC
When housing projects come to the commission or Town Council for approval, they include traffic impact studies. Developers typically hire a traffic engineering firm to conduct the study of the development's potential impact on traffic backups.
Planning Commission members said moving forward, the comprehensive plan needs to demand more thorough traffic reviews. Klein said studies often choose a few intersections next to the project and ignore the town's main arteries, where traffic is already an issue.
Easton Planning and Zoning Director Miguel Salinas said the best way to expand the scope of a traffic impact study for a development is if town engineers or the State Highway Administration request a larger scope during meetings with the project's traffic engineer.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said he wants to continue requiring developers' traffic studies to include a percent change in traffic based on if the development were to be built.
Toussaint said he wants the studies to include more consideration on the impact to pedestrians, not just vehicles. He added that studies should be framed around the town's ongoing Complete Streets study, which is assessing Easton's roads on a large scale.
"What we've received in the past as a traffic impact study is going to be worthless for us going forward," Toussaint said. "It's propaganda at this point, prepared by the applicant's engineers."

title: Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 710

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A move by Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus to continue a hearing on a proposed cannabis moratorium drew strong reactions from other council members.A tense back-and-forth exchange between Gunsallus and Ward 3 Councilman David Montgomery toward the end of Monday's council meeting stemmed from the council president's executive decision to delay a vote on the moratorium for an additional three weeks.The nine-month moratorium on cannabis businesses, introduced this summer, was originally slated for a public hearing and vote at the council's Sept.18 meeting. The matter had been tabled until Monday so all five council members could be present to vote.The moratorium, if passed, would place a pause on applications, approval, construction, expansion, processing or issuance of building permits for a business that grows, processes or sells cannabis within the Easton town limits.The moratorium would also allow the town to consider and adopt a revised zoning ordinance.Easton's existing zoning ordinance already contains definitions and permitted zoning districts for medical cannabis dispensaries and growing and processing facilities, but does not include language on standards for recreational facilities.Montgomery strongly objected to Gunsallus' continuance, saying the council president did not have the authority to do so. Gunsallus affirmed that he did."Sir, you will contain yourself please," Gunsallus said, speaking over Montgomery, who started to make a comment.Gunsallus reaffirmed he had the power to continue discussion on the moratorium until the next meeting, explaining that he wanted to wait until the town's planning commission made an additional recommendation later in the week.However, in August, the commission unanimously gave a favorable recommendation to approve the ordinance.Montgomery called for a vote on the continuance, questioning Gunsallus' authority."The fact that four of us could reveal that we want to vote now means nothing to you, that you will override the wishes of the council because you are sitting there as the town council president," he said.Town Attorney Sharon Van Emburgh chimed in, saying the council can override the president's action. But in the past, the council has typically given members additional time to vote as a courtesy.Montgomery pointed out that the council had already given an additional month for consideration.Gunsallus reemphasized the upcoming planning commission meeting would provide more clarifying information."Excuse me, what information will that be?" Montgomery said."(The planning commission's) recommendations, as I've stated, so please contain yourself - you've already spoken more than permissible," Gunsallus said.Montgomery motioned to overrule Gunsallus and vote on the ordinance as presented.Ward 2 Councilman Don Abbatiello interjected, saying while he understood Montgomery and "definitely" disagreed with how the decision had been handled, he agreed that granting additional time to decide was in line with past council actions.Mayor Megan Cook, a former council president herself, interrupted the quarreling, calling for the councilmen to settle down."I agree that we are a group of five where you all are independent and you all have various opinions - absolutely.We must respect ourselves - the fighting, we need to" she said, trailing off and moving her arms to motion to calm down."Please." Ward 4 Councilman Rev.Elmer Davis Jr. initially seconded the motion, rescinding his vote just minutes later to agree with Abbatiello's stance on the council's precedent. He voiced worry with how the situation was handled."We have never had such a dialogue that we had tonight regarding issues and concerns," he said. "That dialogue - I'm quite concerned about things that have been said, I've never seen this on this council in all my days." The council will again table voting on the ordinance until its Monday, Nov. 6, meeting.Uncertainty still remains on the moratorium. During Monday's meeting, council members and town residents raised questions on the moratorium's duration, specifics on licensing for both recreational and medical facilities and zoning laws for both types of establishments.The Easton Planning Commission will discuss zoning requirements for adult-use cannabis dispensaries at its Thursday, Oct. 19, meeting.

title: College junior feels jealous of friend
author: Harriette Cole
content:
College junior feels jealous of friend

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am a junior in college, and I'm struggling with feelings of jealousy toward my friend. It seems like everything comes so easily to her, and it's hard for me not to compare our paths.Recently, my friend received a $10,000 scholarship for a study abroad program in Japan and landed an internship at one of the top investment banking firms in the United States. She applied to only one internship and only one scholarship, and things fell into place effortlessly. It's as if a fairy comes in every night while she's sleeping and throws magic pixie dust at her to make everything work out. Meanwhile, I feel like I have to fight tooth and nail just to make half as much progress. Every day is a continuous struggle to accomplish the goals that I have. I try hard to be positive, but obstacles pop up constantly. How can I deal with these feelings of envy and move forward with a more upbeat outlook on life? - Jealous DEAR JEALOUS: It is understandable that you would be envious of your friend for what appears to be an easy life. As you also know, it is toxic to dwell on what other people have. No good will come out of that longing. Instead, you must focus on yourself. Do your best to view your life as your perfect challenge. You are gaining resilience as you live through each experience.Claim your small victories.To keep on track, create a vision board. Look through magazines and newspapers for images that reflect the things you want for your life. Cut them out. Brainstorm words and ideas that represent your dreams.Write them down. Next, on a large piece of cardboard or paper, place the images and words together. Make a simple art piece out of this collection of ideas to create your vision board. When thoughts creep in about your friend's success - or anyone else's - wish them well and pivot back to planning your own life.

title: Port Street housing project nearing completion
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Port Street housing project nearing completion

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nine affordable housing units and a new headquarters for a local nonprofit organization are nearing completion on Port Street. The Port Street Commons, a project led by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, is slated to finish construction in October.The project includes nine apartments — seven two-bedroom units and two three-bedroom units — and approximately 10,000 square feet of space for The Arc's new regional headquarters, featuring offices and a behavioral health suite.
On Tuesday afternoon, Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc, gave a tour of the 24,000-square-foot space to Jake Day, Maryland's secretary of housing and community development.
Construction workers were in action on the site, and drywall and insulation was installed on the first and second floors of the three-story building. Day called it a "great looking building."
Rondeau pointed out the importance of bringing immediate assistance to those in need of housing in the Easton area, which is why his team has worked to aim for completion in under four years. The site was identified in July of 2021, and construction began last June. "We want to move quickly," Rondeau said.
$6.5 million of the project's approximate $11-million price tag has been raised, and The Arc is nearing the end of its capital campaign. Rondeau told Day that The Arc is financing the gap of around $4.5 million.
"If we wanted to raise the full $11 million, that would've taken us about eight years," Rondeau said.
Day was impressed with the pace of the Port Street project, asking Rondeau, "can we set you up with lots of other developers to help guide them through the process as speedily as The Arc has gotten through?"
A ribbon cutting is planned for Nov. 7. Rondeau said the first batch of tenants will move in Dec. 1, with a second batch coming in on Jan. 2. The Arc's headquarters will open in January.
Eight of the nine units will accept tenants based on a public lottery system. The ninth unit is designated to the Talbot Interfaith Shelter to house someone transitioning out of the shelter.
"Because of the site plan, all nine units are slightly different," Rondeau said, "which was not the most economical, but it was the only way we could maximize getting nine units into the available square footage."
All of the units will feature free Wi-Fi and appliances including a microwave, along with "solid surface countertops" and carpet in bedrooms to save money in the back end for property management. The units will be managed by Chesapeake Neighbors, a housing subsidiary of The Arc.
Rondeau said two of the units on the first floor are "universally designed," with accessible bathrooms and appliances meant to accommodate those with disabilities.
As Day and other members of the Department of Housing and Community Development toured the space, Rondeau pointed out how the office spaces will support The Arc's overarching goal of providing counseling and assistance to those with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
The headquarters are expected to add around 35 jobs to the area. Rondeau said employees at the Easton site will have health insurance. A full-time nurse will also be in the building.
"Three years ago, The Arc decided to self-insure our health insurance for our employees," he said. "And we have a partnership. We provide free urgent and primary care to all of our employees."
Rondeau is excited for The Arc's services to continue expanding outside of Anne Arundel County, which is where the organization was founded and has the largest presence.
"We've grown significantly over the last 25 years here in Easton," Rondeau said. "We wanted to have an Eastern Shore headquarters."
The project is the first building in Easton to fall under the town's mixed-use waterfront zoning district regulations, Rondeau said. Passed in 2019, the zoning code emphasizes connecting the Easton Point waterfront to the town's downtown area. Rondeau said The Arc made sure to have the front doors of the project facing Port Street as part of the zoning expectations.
After the tour, Day thanked Rondeau and expressed his support for The Arc's fast-moving efforts.
"It's an awesome project, it's an incredible project," Day said.

title: Don't throw a tizzy. Come to Tilghman
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Don't throw a tizzy. Come to Tilghman

 August 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — When walking into Gina's at the Bridge, it is immediately clear who Gina Lee Werner is.Simply looking at the decor and tasting the unique blend of flavors on the menu tells the tale of the fun and eclectic restaurant owner who makes her staff feel like family, signing each check with a heart or "love, Gina."
Her husband, Michael Joseph Werner, calls it "Ginafying."
Gina Lee Werner been a restaurant owner for over two decades, and the Werners opened Gina's at the Bridge in November. Now eight months in, the Werners have learned that getting out to Tilghman Island — miles past St. Michaels, where tourists usually stop — is worth the drive.
"I hear people all the time. They're like, 'oh, my God, it's so far. I just can't do that drive.' It's the extra 10 minutes passing St. Michaels, and it's just something about that drive," Michael said.
In an effort to encourage people to come to Tilghman and connect more local businesses, the Werners are purchasing a shuttle van, which can hold around 14 people. They plan to provide shuttle services from St. Michaels and beyond.
The current proposed name of the shuttle is "The Tizzy." It will begin operation in next week.
In addition, the Werners are planning to purchase a center console boat to provide shuttle service on the water.
Ginafying Tilghman
Gina opened Gina's in St. Michaels in 2011, which she still runs. But she always wanted to buy the property she could operate out of.
The new restaurant is situated on Knapps Narrows right next to the historic Tilghman Island Drawbridge.
It is the busiest drawbridge in the nation, and on a nice summer day, the bridge could be raised up to 50 times, according to PropTalk Chesapeake Bay Boating.
The restaurant sources crabs, oysters and fish directly from local watermen, emphasizing extreme freshness while fostering strong community relationships on the island. Along with local seafood, the Werners make a point of collaborating with local artists and businesses like the Tilghman Island County Store and the Little Big Market.
Gina firmly believes in a "rising tide raises all ships" mentality.
She was inspired to open her first restaurant, Gina's Cantina, after a bad experience at a restaurant she formerly worked in where she didn't feel supported after returning from maternity leave.
"I was working all the way up until eight months pregnant, but I went back and everything changed," Gina said. "It just fueled me."
20 years later, that fuel remains ignited, but not out of spite. Her motivation is fostered through an environment where staff are happy yet hardworking and the customers love the food but also feel at home.
To Gina, it is more important to prioritize a relaxed customer experience, where guests can enjoy the view.
"I definitely believe that the restaurants have been such a way for me to put my heart out there so I can still do my art and I can also make a living because I'm not selling my art," Gina said. "The art is when people come in and they're like, ah, yeah."

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1093
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After four and a half hours of testimony and deliberations, the Easton Board of Zoning Appeals denied Aspire Apartments' request for a special exception to use a property off of Mathewstown Road as a multifamily apartment complex.Almost every seat was full in the meeting chambers Tuesday evening as supporters and opponents waited for a chance to weigh in on the contentious proposed complex - and to hear the long-awaited decision on the project's requests.Brought forth by Aspire Outdoors LLC, a company owned by Easton resident Derick Daly, the project proposed a six-building, 162-unit apartment complex with 27 units in each building.The property is situated on the south end of Camac Street, southwest of the existing Hunters Mill neighborhood and adjacent to the Gannon Range, previously known as the Estates at Gannon Farm, planned unit development. It's also located within the R-10A zone, a residential district within the Town of Easton.A multifamily apartment complex within the district requires a special exception granted by the Board of Zoning Appeals, which prompted Daly's request.Daly also requested a variance to allow reduction of the rear setback dimension for the apartment buildings and parking area to be reduced from the town zoning code's required 75 feet to 50 feet due to the unusual size and configuration of the area.The project first came before the town planning commission last December, where Hunters Mill residents voiced concerns about traffic and accessibility.The proposal was initially slated to be heard by the Board of Zoning Appeals in April, but was delayed by 180 days to address ongoing concerns.Within the last few months, both town planning staff and the planning commission recommended approval of Daly's application with conditions, which included project phasing, addressing traffic mitigation and ensuring adequate wastewater capacity.The proposed phasing suggestion, which was incorporated into plans shown at Tuesday's meeting, indicated that access to the first phase of buildings would be via Camac Street.The second phase of construction would include access to the complex via Gannon Range and Camac Street. An additional entrance for the third phase of development was yet to be determined.To Daly, inspiration for the apartment complex was drawn from the opportunity to provide "much-needed housing" to Easton. About 25% of the profits are going to another one of Daly's ventures: Polaris Village Academy, a free private school located in the Port Street area.Daly said the complex was intended to be a higher-end property to serve employees of the new regional medical center, which has yet to begin construction.Board of Zoning Appeals member Gary Molchan questioned why Aspire Apartments couldn't have its own entrance like other complexes instead of running through residential neighborhoods. Daly said he was limited by wetlands, which would require a different set of approvals.Questions were also raised about the number of parking spaces for the entirety of the complex, the possibility of parking spilling over onto Camac Street and adequate public facilities.A significant portion of the meeting was spent discussing traffic - a primary concern of Hunters Mill residents.Betty Tustin, a senior project manager for The Traffic Group, said once fully developed, the apartment complex would generate 875 average daily trips. The number was one she deemed as sufficient for what was permitted under town standards.But to Troy Brestel, a professional engineer and project manager with Traffic Planning and Design, Inc. who testified on behalf of the project's opponents, said that he agreed with the number of average daily trips listed in the developer's traffic study, but disagreed with amount of average daily trips on Camac Street once the apartments were developed.John Franczak, the vice president of the Hunters Mill Homeowners' Association, led opposition to the apartment complex on behalf of the neighborhood."We feel that the town comprehensive plan should be followed, no variances or exceptions," he said. "The rules are there to protect people."The Town of Easton is also installing a long-promised park in the neighborhood, which means more young children and families out walking - a dangerous situation if there's heavy traffic flow from an apartment complex, Franczak said.Several members of the public took the opportunity to comment at the end of each side's presentation.The board's discussion on the variance request was brief, with members acknowledging its minimal impact - the property's use was more important. Approval of the variance request was unanimous.More detailed deliberations ensued on the special exception request.Molchan voiced concerns about the change in character of the surrounding area and traffic congestion."I would support that the Town of Easton needs apartments like this, but these apartments should not affect a community that already exists," he said. "What we're doing to the people on Camac we're turning a quiet residential neighborhood into a bustling thoroughfare for cars and delivery trucks and contractor vehicles, and that's after the apartments are built, that's not while they're being built. Who knows what that will be?"Board member Zakary Krebeck raised similar points, speaking about the "unrealistic" provision of parking spaces and the impact it would have on Hunters Mill.To board chairman Peter Cotter, traffic and congestion were the two main issues he was grappling with."I don't see how it's currently configured, how I can get to a yes using Camac Street," he said, "because I just think that regardless of how the plan is, that's going to be what is used."A motion to deny the special exception was promptly voted on, earning a unanimous consensus.In a phone interview Wednesday afternoon, Daly said he was "disheartened" by the special exception's denial, but understood why the board chose to do so. Looking forward, he plans to make adjustments to his proposal and come before the board again.Because the board denied the application, Daly must wait a full year before returning with the same proposal, per the town's zoning ordinance. A revised plan could be heard in less than a year if it's substantially different from the previous application. The denial can also be appealed in the county circuit court.In spite of the denial, Daly expressed gratitude to the board for hearing him out, along with thanks for positive recommendations from the planning commission, Easton Utilities and town staff.Franczak said while he didn't think the apartment proposal was bad, the project didn't go well with the adjacent single-family house neighborhood. The opposition wasn't personal; Franczak felt he was allowed to defend his house, neighborhood and the safety of both."Bottom line: no hard feelings," he said.

title: Filing auto insurance claims
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Filing auto insurance claims

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Car insurance is a funny thing. You pay a small fortune to get it and keep it.Then, if you have the blatant audacity to actually file a claim, the company either increases your premiums or cancels you altogether.OK, that may be a bit extreme, but you get my point.While the world of insurance can at times be so confusing as to be maddening, going without basic automobile coverage is simply not an option. The financial risk is just too great. But there are some things you can do to make sure you don't stand out to the company as an intolerable risk.You should file an auto insurance claim if: There are injuries, even minor ones. It's crucial to report the incident to your insurer to ensure your coverage applies, preventing unexpected bills and safeguarding you from potential lawsuits by injured drivers.Another driver is involved.Contact your insurance company whenever you're in a crash with another driver, especially when fault isn't clear. Reporting the incident to your insurer helps make sure the blame is assigned fairly and shields you from excessive liability.There is damage to vehicles or property. Insurance is there to help you with costs when things get damaged, so you don't have to pay a big lump sum. That's why you pay monthly premiums.You shouldn't file an auto insurance claim if: You are the only person involved. If the incident is your fault and does not involve injuries, not telling your insurance company will help protect your premium.There is only a small amount of damage. Even if you have collision coverage in your car insurance, you might decide not to file a claim if your car has only minor damage.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services.Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/, "Ask Mary." title: Bucs, Sabres set sights on titles
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Bucs, Sabres set sights on titles

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The postseason is a long ways off, but Saints Peter and Paul High's boys lacrosse team has already faced its toughest competition this season.The Sabres' first five games of the regular season featured Calvert Hall, which is ranked No. 2 nationally in the latest USA Lacrosse Magazine poll, and No. 1 in the state. Sts. Peter & Paul also has had games against three other top-20 ranked teams in Maryland — No. 5 Bullis Prep; No 16. Good Counsel; and No. 19 Severn.
"It's everything I wanted," Sabres head coach Todd Wolters said of the opening gauntlet. "I'm very happy with what we have."
Though Sts. Peter & Paul lost its first five games before routing James M. Bennett 17-1 last week, Wolters said he's not concerned with his personal record, but is focused on preparing his team for another run at a Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference title after falling shy in last year's championship game.
Though Kent Island has yet to begin its regular season, head coach Bobby Woolley has also been impressed with what he's seen from his team during a tough preseason slate that included dates with No. 18 DeMatha, No. 22 Broadneck and No. 23 South River before Monday's final exhibition against Springside Chestnut Hill Academy of Philadelphia.
"We put our necks out there right away and just started learning about ourselves," said Woolley, whose preseason also included Sherwood, Fallston, Cape Henlopen and Archmere Academy. "I feel like we got a lot of what it takes."
Easton will look to send longtime head coach Dennis Keenan off as a winner. The Warriors graduated the majority of their firepower from a year ago, but look to have the goods for another solid season, along with Queen Anne's and North Caroline.
While Keenan begins his farewell tour, two Mid-Shore teams welcome new head coaches, with Ben Joiner taking over at Kent County, and Teddy Peyton at Gunston. There is also a new kid on the block, with North Dorchester beginning its first year of varsity play under the direction of veteran head coach Steve Hurley.
"We don't have much experience so we're going to learn a lot of game this year and next year," said Hurley, who has 18 out for the team. "We're having fun; kids are learning."
Here's a look at this year's teams.
CAMBRIDGE-SD
Head Coach: Brendan Bromwell.
Who's Where: Goalie: Andrew McMichael (Sr.); Defense: Christian Dockins (Sr.); Jeffrey Sellman (So.); Juan Slaughter (So.); Midfield: Gavin Weber (So.); Tabrion Watts (Sr.); Kimir Lake (Sr.); Attack: Charles Spedden (Jr.); Gibby Robinson (So.); Nate McClaren (Sr.).
Outlook: The Vikings are fast and athletic defensively, led by four-year man Dockins. Bromwell applauded McMichael, who has stepped in at goalie.
"I'm proud of him," Bromwell said. "We didn't have anybody and Andrew came to me and said, 'Hey, I know we're kind of struggling in this spot, I'll give it a try.' And he's done good."
There is also athleticism at the midfield with Watts and Lake. Bromwell likes Weber's old-school style of play and will have him facing off.
Spedden, whose growth in the game is "insane", according to Bromwell, quarterbacks the attack.
EASTON
Head Coach: Dennis Keenan.
Who's Where: Goalies: Mason Quicke (So.); Randall Mills (Sr.); Defense: Eddie Whelan (Sr.); Ethan Finlay (Sr.); Max Smith (So.); Nathan Lapp (Sr.); Ethan Ballance (Jr.); Darren Foxwell (Sr.); Midfield: Spencer Gunshenan (So.); Conner Hensley (Sr.); Logan Friend (Jr.); Cole Murphy (So.); Finn Gunshenan (Sr.); Landon Chaney (Sr.); Blake Royer (So.); Colin Keenan (Sr.); Luke Stanco (Jr.); Grayson Buritsch (Jr.); Miles Chaney (So.); Blake Newton (Jr.); Attack: Campbell Taliaferro (Sr.); Jackson Wieland (Jr.); David Rogers (Jr.); Trace Haddaway (So.); Miles Abell (Jr.).
Outlook: The Warriors lost the bulk of their scoring with the graduation Drew Schmidt (54 points) and Hudson Royer (43 points), who are both at Lynchburg (Va.), and Tyler Rardin (50 points).
While there looks to be plenty of offensive options, Keenan said defense is the team's strength, and was impressed with Quicke's 12-save effort against North Caroline in Friday's opener.
"We're building," Keenan said. "They listen. They're willing to be taught."
KENT ISLAND
Head Coach: Bobby Woolley.
Who's Where: Goalies: Quinn Burns (Fr.); Chris Lemme (Sr.); Cody Jones (Sr.); Defense: Gavan Henry (Sr.); Ryan Austin (Sr.); Robert Hottel (So.); Eric Hofmann (Sr.); Grayson Corn (So.); Connor Byrne (Jr.); Finn McGrath (So.); Midfield: Keegan Green (Sr.); Connor Gardner (So.); Marshall Dandy (Jr.); Aidan Henry (Sr.); Attack: Mark Rees (Sr.); Brian Rees (Jr.); Colton Schneck (Sr.); Liam Dermer (Sr.); Face-off: Ricky Verger (Sr.); Roy Scott (Jr.).
Outlook: The Bucs' bid last year for a third consecutive Class 2A state title was foiled in the semifinals by eventual state champ Glenelg. All-North Bayside Offensive Player of the Year Tucker Claxton graduated along with fellow first-team all-North picks Owen Wynot and Micah Quinn.
But Woolley thinks this squad is in a more stable place heading into this season compared to last year, when he and his staff seemed to be forever patching holes. A strong returning cast, including all-North first-teamers Gavan Henry and Green, St. Mary's transfers Hottel and Dandy, and promising freshman class figure to have the Bucs challenging for a 10th Bayside Conference title in 13 years.
But nobody has thrilled Woolley more than the return of Hofmann, who missed all last season with an injury.
"Having Eric back is a game-changer, as far as controlling the field between the restraining lines and putting pressure on people to get the ball into their offensive zone," Woolley said.
There's been a three-way battle for starting goalie between Lemme, Jones and freshman Burns, who has really turned heads.
"All in all, I feel like we're more of a complete team heading into this year than we were last year," Woolley said. "We're positioned with high expectations and talent to back it."
NORTH CAROLINE
Head Coach: Gavin Houseman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Koen Jackson (Sr.); Defense: Derek Jones (Sr.); Gabe Holt (So.); Sam Heimbuch (Fr.); Midfield: Jimmy Cohoon (Jr.); Owen Walstrum (Jr.); Dylan Robinson (Jr.); Charlie Fleshman; Attack: Jake Hoofnagle (Fr.); Mason Ratcliff (Jr.); Corey Bunce (Sr.)
Outlook: The Bulldogs finished .500 in the regular season a year ago, and after a solid outing in Friday's opener against Easton, Houseman thinks there's potential to improve.
"We thought we'd have to take a step back with having younger guys taking more of a senior role but we really haven't had to," Houseman said. "We've picked up pretty much where we left off last year. We played pretty strong against Easton. We had minor hiccups, which I think are easy to fix."
QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY
Head Coach: Brad Niesz.
Who's Where: Goalie: Brian Maleski (Jr.); Defense: Brett Bast (Sr.); Ethan Hahn (Sr.); James Rath (Jr.); Conner Cheezum (Sr.); Ryan Lee (Sr.); Brian Patrick; Midfield: Tanner Lyon (Sr.); Conlan Nagle (Sr.); Carter Hercher (So.); Casey Ryan (Jr.); Midfield-Attack: Tyler Crist (Jr.); Charlie Schmidt (Jr.); Jackson Shiley (Jr.); Sam Yetman (Jr.); Attack: Jamison Kendall (Jr.).
Outlook: The Lions graduated a lot of experience, particularly on the defensive end. Gone is first-team all-North Bayside goalie Dino Blue. Niesz said the loss of defenseman Hunter Kelly will also hurt, but the return of Lee, a first-team choice a year ago, should anchor the defense.
"We've had to move around a number of players," Niesz said. "We are a relatively small program in terms of numbers so we're going to ask guys to fill multiple roles."
SAINTS PETER & PAUL
Head Coach: Todd Wolters.
Who's Where: Goalie: Hank Wolters (Jr.); Defense: Porter Bishop (Jr.); Daniel Schwaninger (Jr.); Jackson Jancosko (Fr.); Langdon Anderson (Jr.); Cole Philip (Fr.); Drake Stolba (Jr.); Midfield: Grant Messick (Jr.); Lane Williams (Sr.); Mason Roland (Fr.); Jamir Demby (Fr.); Eddie Albright (Fr.); Attack: JJ Rardin (Jr.); Noah Zimmerman (Sr.); Andrew Steinhardt (So.); Liam Durnbaugh (Jr.).
Outlook: The Sabres lost in last year's MIAA B Conference final to Archbishop Curley, but may be stronger this season.
The defense could be among the conference's best with Hank Wolters back in goal, fronted by Bishop, who Coach Wolters has called one of the best in the country, Schwaninger, Jancosko and Anderson.
The offense also appears loaded with the return of Rardin, Zimmerman, Steinhardt and Durmbaugh. The biggest concern — other than staying healthy — may be between the restraining lines where the midfield struggled through the first five games.
"We're nowhere near full strength," Todd Wolters said. "But they've seen what good teams are like. I'm here to win a B Conference championship and these are the games that will help us."

title: The IRS deserves good leadership
author: Staff Writer
content:
The IRS deserves good leadership

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Was anyone surprised to learn that the latest IRS commissioner — Billy Long — has left his position after being on the job for only two months?(Mr. Long is now expected to be nominated as the U.S. Ambassador to Iceland.) He was the fifth commissioner or acting commissioner in a period of seven months.
You have to wonder why the president would have chosen Billy Long to serve as the IRS commissioner in the first place.
He was a congressman from Missouri from 2011 to 2023. His background was as an auctioneer and real estate agent. According to news sources, the only tax credentials he had ever received were a designation as a "certified tax and business adviser," a title given after taking a short class from a business in Florida.
After getting his certificate, he was involved with companies that assisted businesses and nonprofits in applying for the Employee Retention Tax Credit, a credit available in 2020 and 2021 for employers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
From my own experience as both a tax preparer and taxpayer, I have found the civil servants who work for the IRS are some of the smartest and most competent in the federal government. It makes me wonder how these tax professionals kept up their morale with Mr. Long as the commissioner.
Add to that the effects of the DOGE project on IRS employees. Since January of this year, thousands have left the agency.
More than 266 million tax returns were filed with the IRS in fiscal year 2024, collecting more than $5 trillion in tax revenue and $98 billion in enforcement revenue.
Given the enormous, looming debt we are facing, tax revenue is crucial to keep the government functioning and to pay the interest due on this debt.
I feel fortunate to live in a country where, at least until now, I can file my tax returns and feel confident that they will be processed by an agency that abides by the rules, keeps my records confidential, sends me refunds or credits my payments in an orderly and efficient manner.
Stability and consistency in tax administration are also necessary for a thriving American business community.
The IRS deserves good leadership in order to maintain public trust. A healthy U.S. financial system depends on a well-functioning Internal Revenue Service.
ELAINE TAMA
Easton

title: Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sen. Arthur Ellis (D-Charles) introduced a bill on the first day of the General Assembly that would create something that Maryland has never had before — a state fruit.Native to Maryland, persimmons can be found just about everywhere in the state, with the exception of Garrett County due to the mountainous nature of the region.
In May and June, persimmon trees flower, but the fruit isn't ready until the fall, leading to many seasonal recipes and drinks. Persimmons have especially been used for fine wines, jams and baked goods.
The trees are known for their resilience, being able to thrive for years when they are below the canopy of a forest.
Prices for persimmons have gone up significantly in recent years, reaching about $6 per pound, and many have not heard how easy it may be to source their own, according to Ellis.
"I have persimmon trees in my yard," Ellis said. "They grow naturally, and they're beautiful and delicious."
Ellis introduced the legislation to raise awareness for the fruit, as many Marylanders do not realize it is a part of their state and its history.
Indigenous people of the region used the fruit not only for food but medicinally as well. Sore throats and indigestion were common ailments that the use of persimmons attempted to treat.
Throughout the Civil War, persimmon seeds were used as a coffee substitute when trade routes were impacted.
The usefulness of the persimmon tree doesn't end with the fruit. The wood of the tree is extremely strong, and is commonly used within shoes, golf clubs, flooring and musical instruments.
If Senate Bill 74 makes it through both state legislative houses and is signed by the governor, it would become effective Oct. 1.
