title: From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy
author: Konner Metz
content:
From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — John North was more than just a well-respected judge.The former Talbot County state's attorney and judge of the District and Circuit courts wore many hats during his professional and retired life, serving as a protector of the Chesapeake Bay, log canoe racing aficionado and vintage automobile enthusiast.
In recent days, family, friends and the Talbot County community have remembered North for his roles in all of those capacities and more.
North died in St. Michaels on Sept. 19. He was 94.
Oldest son David North remembered his father as "competitive with compassion." He was supportive and thorough in everything he did, his son said.
"Right through the end, he was showing us how to have fun under not very good circumstances and how to stay competitive," David North said. "And how to laugh."
North was Talbot County state's attorney from 1962 to 1971. He then served as judge for 12 years in District Court and five years in Circuit Court before his appointment as the first chairman of the Maryland Critical Area Commission, the state agency responsible for protecting the health of the Chesapeake Bay and enforcing laws at a local level.
Pete Lesher, current Talbot County Council vice president, reflected on North's impact with the commission and as one of the founders of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in the 1960s.
"He lived and played on Chesapeake waters," said Lesher, also the museum's chief historian. "He valued the health of these waters and I think relished that role of caring for them in the capacity of the Critical Area regulation."
Ren Serey, former executive director of the Critical Area Commission, worked closely with North for many years. "The Judge," as North was widely known, brought the necessary judicial expertise and temperament to chair the commission, Serey said.
North was responsible for implementing local critical area programs at a time when the Bay's environmental needs clashed with rural growth and development patterns, Serey said. But North struck the perfect balance in adjudicating such matters.
"Having Judge North up there at the head of the table facing 29 people who were debating these issues was just the perfect role for him," Serey said. " ... He knew how to listen, he knew how to interject, he knew how to keep the discussion without certain boundaries."
Those that worked closely with North said he was widely trusted for his fairness and loyalty.
Lesher recalled a time in the early 2000s when the state committed funds for repairs to the Chesapeake Bay's skipjack fleet. But the state didn't fully lay out how the money would be doled out among skipjack captains in Tilghman Island and Deal Island.
Judge North, though, stepped in.
"Who was going to be the trusted arbiter if it came down to a Deal Island versus Tilghman Island? It was Judge North," Lesher said. "He was trusted by these watermen."
North's wife of 64 years, Ethel Towers North, died in 2019. He is survived by sons David and Daniel and their wives Joan Hoge-North and Margaret Enloe-North, along with grandchildren Drew North, Dylan North, Campbell North, William Spencer North and Nathaniel Vivian, and former daughters-in-law, Sallie North and Carrington North. He is also survived by Comber McHugh, a companion of later years.
In addition to his esteemed roles with the courts and the Critical Area Commission, North was a local log canoe captain. He wrote a book on sailing log canoes, which was published by the Maritime Museum in 2018.
"The Judge" skippered Island Bird, the 27-foot-4-inch log canoe built by North's great-grandfather in 1882.
David North said his younger brother Daniel took up his dad's sailing hobby. They both have kids who continue sailing on the Chesapeake Bay.
"It's a piece of our family. It's a piece of our heritage," David North said.
In his spare time, "The Judge" was a lover of feral cats, a keen reader and a sculptor. Some of his sculpting works are displayed at The Trippe Gallery in Easton.
David North said he followed his dad's footsteps in the world of automobile restoration and car shows. Judge North especially loved Bugattis and Duesenbergs.
North was a founder of the St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance, an annual car showcase nearing its 20-year mark. Luke Phipps, the festival's current chair, said it began as simply an oyster roast at North's house in St. Michaels, where friends of "The Judge" would bring their vintage cars to his front lawn. Then, the tradition grew into a solidified event.
The 18th St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance was hosted Sept. 26-28 at the Kent Island Yacht Club. Despite heavy rain the night before the festival's last hurrah on Sept. 28, Phipps said it was a "beautiful" and sunny Sunday.
Phipps said all he could think of was North — a close friend and valuable mentor — smiling down on Sunday.
He recalled North as a "sharp" and an "eloquently spoken" man.
"There'll never be another one like him," Phipps said.

title: Trappe Planning Commission approves changes to Lakeside plans
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Trappe Planning Commission approves changes to Lakeside plans

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — Last Tuesday evening, Trappe's Planning Commission approved the changing of three lots set aside for spray irrigation into one parcel for the Lakeside Wastewater Treatment Plant. This change will help the plan meet requirements from the Talbot County Health Department.Ryan Showalter, Lakeside's attorney, said new representatives of the Health Department had waited to provide comments on the preliminary and final plans for Lakeside until they receive approval from the Maryland Department of the Environment.
MDE requested two changes to the final plan. The first relates to the Health Department's signature approval block. The approval block before referenced the parcels that are associated with the treatment plan. According to Showalter it basically said they're approved as lots for development purposes.
The second change pertains to the lots for the spray irrigation field. According to Showalter, there were three lots for the spray field, which was everything north of the treatment plant, the storage lagoon and the reserve spray field was a lot.
MDE is requesting all the lots to be on a single parcel, essentially erasing boundary lines on the plan.
"And so that's the only change, is to remove those internal division lines so that what was three lots is now Lot C."
According to Robert Rauch, this change in no way alters the boundaries or acreage of the parcels.
"We had three parcels associated with the spray field they wanted to incorporate into a single parcel," he said. "Didn't change any of the boundaries. Didn't change every acreage, but we had to switch them to a single parcel instead of three separate ones."
The planning commission unanimously approved a motion to authorize Commission President Edgar to sign the revised plats when they are approved by the Health Department and MDE.
Rauch shared with the commission that the wastewater treatment plant is now meeting effluent requirements and the Health Department and MDE approved that the treatment plant can start discharging to the lagoon starting last week.

title: Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories
author: LINDA EVANS
content:
Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS | Section: Columns 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Editor's note: This column originally appeared in the Star Democrat on Oct. 17, 2021. It is repeated here after Jimmy Carter celebrated his 100th birthday this week.It was the mid-seventies and I was a young Washington, D.C., Republican staffer with the rare opportunity to work as a personal assistant for the Honorable and Mrs. George Romney (Mitt Romney's parents).
Pretty exciting for a farm girl from the Eastern Shore of Maryland. When the Romneys invited me out to formal occasions, as a member of their staff, I was occasionally mistaken for Mitt's sister, Lynn.
It was cherry blossom time, and a longtime friend who drove me to the Tidal Basin that day happened to be an employee of the Secret Service. As we walked around the Tidal Basin, a long, black limousine pulled up and my friend yelled, "It's the president."
I nonchalantly responded, "The President of what? What company?"
He repeated, "It's President Carter! It's Carter!
As a government employee, he knew to position us near where the president's car door would open, with the idea of taking a photograph of the president, if possible. When President Carter emerged from the limousine, I was indeed one of the first in line, and even though I was a staunch Romney Republican, I did what any American would do, outstretched my hand and shook the hand of the president of the United States. Many would be lost for words at that point, but I somehow found the presence of mind to say sincerely, "Thank you for being our president."
President Carter, apparently touched by my sincerity, thanked me. My friend had his old Polaroid camera with him and asked the president if he would mind posing for a photo. The president quickly agreed, and then said to no one in particular: "Isn't she beautiful?"
What a compliment for me. I smiled for my friend's camera and that was the end of the exchange; my friend and I were off to tour the cherry blossoms with hundreds, possibly thousands of others that evening.
The Polaroids turned out so-so, but my friend, being politically minded, said he had seen White House photographers there. In fact, since I had my new black velour jacket over my arm, he said he felt the Secret Servicemen were carefully watching me for the president's safety.
"Why don't you call the White House and see if any of them got you on film?" he suggested. What an outlandish thought, but tempting. The next day, I looked up the White House switchboard number and hesitantly dialed 212-456-1414, and asked for the White House press secretary, as I had been instructed by my friend.
"Hello, this is Karl Schumaker," the voice on the phone answered with a German accent. Since I am also of German descent, we had something in common. I said, "Sir, you won't believe it, but the president of the United States told me I was beautiful yesterday at the Tidal Basin. "
Pause.
"What were you wearing?" he asked.
"I was wearing a pink jumpsuit and pink scarf."
"You are beautiful," Karl said. "I have three photographs of you. Would you like me to mail them to you or would you like to come to the White House and pick them up this week?"
I chose the date of Thursday that week because my sister would be in town, and we not only got autographed photos that day, but a tour of the Oval Office and presidential memorabilia. I showed the photos to our parents and then I filed them in my big, old file cabinet, with only one of the photos on my office wall, seen by almost no one. I'm still a Romney Republican and always will be, but also a Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter fan.
And a fan of someone else in the White House, the Press Secretary Karl Schumaker, who would teach the importance of customer service and taking extra time out to make memories that have lasted over 40 years. It was President Carter's birthday on Oct. 1 (he turned 100), and he received the Nobel Peace Prize also on Oct. 11 (in 2002), which reminded me of this occasion.
"To this day, Jimmy Carter looks back on a life of faith and service, and ahead to a more peaceful world," Mark K. Updegrove wrote in an article titled "Building a Better World," found in in Parade Magazine, Feb. 18, 2018.

title: Easton considers ordinance to crack down on seafood processing odors
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton considers ordinance to crack down on seafood processing odors

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 811
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Amid resident concerns, the Easton Town Council is considering an ordinance to adjust zoning and place restrictions on seafood processors.The legislation, sent to the council for review following approval from the Planning Commission, was created in response to odor complaints from residents living near the business Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue.
At Monday's Town Council meeting, councilmembers heard mixed reviews on the ordinance from residents and business owners, opting to leave the public hearing open and explore options such as moving the business out of a residential area.
Under the ordinance's proposed definition, seafood processing would be defined as "harvested seafood" being "cleaned, cut, eviscerated or otherwise prepared or cooked for sale in bulk, with a resulting by-product."
If approved, seafood processing would remain permitted in the industrial zoning district but only allowed in business commercial through a special exception. That exception would require that by-products are "stored within a closed or refrigerated vehicle," with operators required to install "odor control technology" so "no odor from any product or by-product can be detected outside the building."
Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis, who said he's heard the complaints from many of his constituents, took issue with the fact that the proposed ordinance requires existing businesses to comply by Jan. 1, 2026 instead of sooner.
"I don't think it's fair for the individuals who live in that area to have to go through another summer dealing with the odor," Davis said. "It's unfair. So I'm going to advocate that it be six months."
Davis added he doesn't think seafood processing should be allowed in business commercial zoning at all. Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello agreed with Davis' perspective but asked that the council consider the legislation's potential impacts on other seafood businesses.
"My only concern would be that we have several other seafood facilities in town who don't have these issues," Abbatiello said. "And I would hate to see them get caught up in a similar scenario, where they're getting, for lack of a better term, punished."
Council President Frank Gunsallus asked if the town had a plan to aid smaller seafood businesses if they're forced to comply with the costly odor mitigation requirements.
"If we're going to be potentially imposing regulations on businesses that have significant financial impact to the point which some have claimed would put them out of business, I think we should take pause with that," Gunsallus said.
"I'm not quite concerned about that, personally," Davis responded. "I'm more concerned about the constituents in the neighborhood. … What you're just saying (makes) it seem like it's a hardship on the business when they probably haven't even tried."
Zach Smith, attorney for Chesapeake Brand Seafood owner/operator Mitchell Hughes, provided a letter to the council to be read aloud during the public hearing on the ordinance.
If passed, the ordinance "will put Mitchell out of business and will cause significant economic harm to him, his families, his employees and the local watermen that he supports," Smith wrote.
The attorney said Hughes has taken "reasonable steps" to mitigate the impact on residents as they have brought up concerns. However, he says buying new equipment isn't doable.
"While Mitchell has tried to be a good neighbor, he cannot reasonably install equipment that prohibits any smell from being detected outside of his building," Smith wrote. "Mitchell has looked into what will be necessary to satisfy this proposed regulation, and such technology is not feasible and will be extremely cost prohibitive."
RESIDENT CONCERNSDuring the public hearing, many residents voiced impacts Hughes' business has had on their quality of life. Resident Philip Bernot said he's lived next to grain processors, metal fabricators and plumbers at the site since 2001, never before experiencing any issue that brought him to a town meeting.
"Not a single one of these businesses has ever brought me up here to complain," Bernot said. "Not a single one of these businesses has repeatedly caused a gut-wrenching stench to take over the entire neighborhood."
A representative for Sea Watch International said the business on Glebe Park Drive would be "swept up into new legislation." Bruce Cole, owner of Cole's Seafood House & Deli, echoed this, saying the ordinance would negatively impact his operation on North Washington Street.
"(The) impact that he has is going to impact me," Cole said, noting equipment may cost around $100,000. " … I don't have any complaints."
Following the public hearing, Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry asked the council to pause on taking action. She emphasized the operation of the business under scrutiny is different from businesses like Cole's.
"They're not doing it for retail, they're doing it for wholesale and to push out a product," Curry said. The council left the public hearing open for the Nov. 18 meeting.
Curry added that she hopes the council can work toward a "best case scenario" in which Chesapeake Brand Seafood moves out of its current location to a more appropriate one away from residents.

title: Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As many regions in the United States prepare for a significant heat wave in the coming days, Maryland's Mid-Shore could see temperatures nearing triple digits next week.According to the National Weather Service, Easton is projected to see highs around 95 to 97 degrees beginning Sunday through Wednesday. Highs are expected to remain in the 90s later in the week across Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.
The Dorchester County Health Department is encouraging people stay out of the sun when temperatures peak in the late mornings and early afternoons.
A press release from the department noted the following groups should take added precautions: babies, young children, pregnant women, older adults, outside workers and those without air conditioning.
Local health officials recommend regularly hydrating, limiting time outdoors and monitoring for signs of heat exhaustion — heavy sweating, cold skin, cramps, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, etc.
The Maryland Department of Health said in a press release this week that Maryland saw 26 heat-related deaths last year. The state department added that parents and guardians should never leave children in cars.
"Remember to check on those who are particularly vulnerable to heat, including young children, senior citizens, and people with chronic diseases — and confirm that they have the resources they need to stay safe during the hottest months," said Maryland Secretary of Health Dr. Meena Seshamani in the release.
EASTON FIRE PREPARES
As temperatures heat up, volunteer fire departments across the Mid-Shore remain on call. Due to the physically intensive work of firefighting and the heavy gear that must be worn, some departments are asking for water donations from the community.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson says his department has received enough cases of water from thoughtful community residents and businesses to get through next week's heat wave. Dobson is encouraging residents to contribute to other fire departments in need in Talbot County.
Whether it's lending bottled waters or assisting with manpower on a call, Dobson says local fire departments work together well.
"The other fire chiefs talk a lot, and we're always here to help one another," Dobson said.
The fire chief noted that as farmers in the area start to cut their wheat, field fires could pop up, a risk fire officials are keeping their eyes on.
Weather projections are accurate as of Friday afternoon.

title: James saves U.S. from big upset
author: Bill Haufe
content:
James saves U.S. from big upset

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LeBron James saved the U.S. from what would have been a stunning loss.James' layup with 8 seconds left was the go-ahead basket Saturday, and the U.S. Olympic team that'll soon head to the Paris Games escaped with a 101-100 win over South Sudan in London, rallying from a 16-point deficit to avoid perhaps the biggest upset in the program's history.
South Sudan, the African nation that gained its independence just 13 years ago and is about to play in the Olympics for the first time, led for more than half the game and had a chance to win at the end. But Carlik Jones' runner off the glass missed with about 4 seconds left, and the Americans survived.
"I'm going to be honest: I like those better than the blowouts," James said as he walked off the court. "At least we get tested."
Oh, they got tested — by a team that came into the game as 43.5-point underdogs , according to BetMGM Sportsbook.
"A good reminder that when we play against teams, it's the biggest game of their lives," U.S. coach Steve Kerr said. "We have to expect everyone to play like that."
Down by 16 at one point, the Americans dug out of that hole with an 18-0 run in the second half — then needed heroics at the end anyway. JT Thor's 3-pointer with 20 seconds left gave South Sudan a 100-99 lead, then the Americans called timeout and put the ball in James' hands.
He made it look easy: He waited, waited, waited, then drove and laid it in with ease to put the U.S. back on top, and the Americans got the stop they needed at the end.
James finished with a game-high 25 points, six rebounds and seven assists for the U.S., which improved to 4-0 with one game left — Monday vs. World Cup champion Germany — on its pre-Olympic exhibition tour. Anthony Davis added 15 points and 11 rebounds for the Americans.
Marial Shayok had 24 points for South Sudan and Jones had a triple-double — 15 points, 11 rebounds and 11 assists.
The teams will meet in group play in the Paris Olympics on July 31.
"It's basketball. It happens," U.S. guard Stephen Curry said. "You want to play perfect every game; it doesn't happen. But can you dig deep and do the little things that help you win? Offense can come and go, but defense is the thing that helps you win championships, medals, all that stuff."
It should have been a mismatch, and for the first half, it was — just not in the way anyone would have expected.
The U.S. roster has 12 players, all of them All-Stars or NBA champions or both, with a total of 189,038 points in their regular-season careers, with 7,832 combined starts. South Sudan has four players who have appeared in an NBA game. They've scored a combined 1,228 points and started 19 games.
Didn't matter. It was 8-0 U.S. after 2 1/2 minutes. The rest of the half: South Sudan 58, U.S. 34. The Americans allowed South Sudan to shoot 61% in the first half and got outscored 21-3 from 3-point range in the first 20 minutes.
"I did not do a great job preparing our team," Kerr said. "We did not focus enough on what they're capable of, and that's on me. I think that really allowed South Sudan to gain confidence early. ... They were great. They played a wonderful game and the ending was good for us, just to feel that, to feel what it's going to be like in Paris and Lille."
An 18-0 run in the second half — James involved in most of it — was what really saved the U.S., turning a 76-65 deficit into an 83-76 lead.
South Sudan led by 16 late in the first half — 58-42 — before the Americans got the last basket to cut the deficit to 14 at the break.
But the 18-0 run was key. James had four assists during the spurt and Curry, from about 35 feet, connected on a 3-pointer late in the third that gave the U.S. its first lead since the first quarter at 79-76.
Wenyen Gabriel banked in a 3-pointer to get South Sudan within 85-84, but James — his former teammate with the Los Angeles Lakers — connected on a 3 on the ensuing U.S. possession, and the Americans would eventually pull through by the slimmest of margins.
"Today we were able to represent our country with pride and we put up a good fight and showed the potential of our country," Gabriel said. "I think it was a proud moment for a lot of people."
Davis said the team got to the arena late, thrown off by standstill London traffic, and that routines going into the game were disrupted. Maybe so, but South Sudan showed the U.S. that nobody at the Olympics will concede anything to the four-time defending gold medalists.
"Doesn't matter when it comes to how close the game is," James said. "We went out there to get better."

title: Limits on how much a drug should cost
author: Susan Estrich
content:
Limits on how much a drug should cost

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Susan Estrich | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. government last week released the list of the 10 medications that will be the first to be the subject of the new price negotiations under the Medicare reform bill, and my arthritis drug, Enbrel, made the list.To make the cut, you either had to be taken by millions of people, like Eliquis, or cost a fortune. Enbrel costs a fortune.I'm one of 47,000 Medicare recipients lucky enough to receive a drug that my old rheumatologist, who originally prescribed it for me, described as a miracle.When he was a young doctor, he told me, his waiting room of patients with rheumatoid arthritis was full of crippled people. With the advent of "biologic" drugs like Enbrel, the crutches and wheelchairs are gone. I count myself very lucky to be mostly symptom-free, which, with RA, is saying a lot. As I say, I'm lucky and blessed. And well-insured.And able to cover the out-ofpocket costs. Which are also substantial.This is the hard part of medical miracles.One month, when I was switching insurance companies, I ran out of Enbrel. I made the mistake of thinking I could actually pay for my weekly shot out-of-pocket if I couldn't get the insurance situation straightened out. "How much would it be?" I naively asked the pharmacist. Enbrel is a SureClick pen; it comes in a pack of four. That would be $1,700 for one pen and $7,000 for the pack.Excuse me? Who can afford that?I managed to get a sample from the doctor's office to tide me over and never asked again. Every month when the specialty pharmacy calls me to renew my Medicare prescription, they confirm my $350 co-pay and I don't so much as murmur a word of complaint, because what can I say? The drug saves my life. But I'm lucky I can afford it. That's why Enbrel belongs on the list.Medicines like Enbrel cost billions to develop, and it is only fair that those costs be recouped. But there are limits, and there is no reason that the market should be foreclosed from working freely when it comes to the prices for these prescription drugs. Enbrel costs too much, but there is nothing that I, one consumer, can do about it. We need to stand together, which is to say, we need government to stand up for us and negotiate for us and give voice to our needs.What is stunning about these negotiations is that it took an act of Congress to authorize the government to use the power of the people on behalf of the people to negotiate fair drug prices.The power of the pharmaceutical industry was so great, so much greater than the power of the American people, that it was literally the law of the land that Medicare could not use its bargaining power on behalf of the American taxpayer.When the bill allowing price negotiation passed last year, the Congressional Budget Office predicted the program would save Medicare more than $100 billion during the next 10 years.Just stop and consider that for a moment: the biggest purchaser of health services unable to use its bargaining power, on behalf of you and I, leaving the industry's power to set prices unchecked. And yet this is precisely what government is for, precisely what government is meant to do, to stand up for and give voice to we the people. The pharmaceutical industry continues to fight against negotiations in the courts. "Today is the start of a new deal for patients where Big Pharma doesn't just get a blank check at your expense and the expense of the American people," President Joe Biden said in announcing the list.It's about time.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 824
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the tavern of a formerly demolished village, a group of brave adventurers is approached by well-dressed, albeit frail-looking, elders who offer a reward of 700 gold to whoever is brave enough to investigate the lizard folks lair in order to gather information on their military weapons.Lauren Fierman, a board member of the Delmarva Pride Center and host of the center's Dungeons and Dragons program, moves around the conference room of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship in Easton.
With every sentence, Fierman provides history, landscape and heart to the world the group of players has carefully developed.
Delmarva Pride Center hosts an open-for-all Dungeons and Dragons, a fantasy tabletop role-playing game, on the fourth Saturday of the month.
What started as a small game event has turned into a growing community, providing a safe environment during a heightened political climate for members of the LGBQT+ community and allies to explore gender identity, sexuality and imagination.
Fierman, who acts as dungeon master (game organizer and participant in charge of creating details and challenges for the game), said the game understands and respects the personal boundaries of its players.
From allowing players to choose the character's pronouns to deciding whether or not they will act out in regional accents, the comfortability of players is key to a successful game.
In Fierman's experience, Dungeons and Dragons provided the first space for them to use different pronouns.
"I'm playing with gender, (and) I'm playing with sexuality in my characters, and it's just such a wonderful avenue to explore different identities and sexualities," Fierman said. "As a fluid person myself, it was very healthy for me to be in a very safe space with people that I trust to express those parts of me through this game."
Allie Silver, one of the local group's players, said historically Dungeons and Dragons has had a white, straight, male focus. But in recent years, the game has been claimed by LGBTQ+ people who have found the fantasy and community aspect comforting, especially if they feel isolated.
"Just creating that space of safety for yourself and for the people at your table is so important because it can become such a beautiful thing," Silver said. "And it's OK if it's not transcendent. If you just play a silly game and kill a bunch of goblins, that's fun.
"But just the joy of friendship at the table of community collaboration is what makes this game so good. Especially now more than ever, community is what we need."
Though character building is an important aspect of the game, other players said the game provides an opportunity for them to create LGBTQ+ representation that is frequently left out in the media.
Zack Parreco, a player, said often LGBTQ+ characters' stories use "queerness" as something that is othering and aimed at larger audiences to gawk at. In Dungeons and Dragons, LGBTQ+ people can build characters and stories where they can control what is important and what is normal.
"There is no pressure for queerness to be a performance for others. It is allowed to just exist," Parreco said. "Maybe we make it big or maybe it's just a normal trait in the world. Either way, we get to fully control our queerness and its expression."
Outside of the game world, players are able to take aspects of their fictional characters into their real lives. Some bring with them new pronouns, and others, like Silver, bring back more courage.
Silver shared that when she started playing, she was "an anxious little mouse," and, when she was comfortable, she began playing a bold character whose main trait was being able to stand up for everybody.
"It was a really fun character, and in the process it gave me permission to find my own courage in my real life and now, in my professional life," Silver said. "I'm an adviser for a Pride group. I volunteer in a bunch of different spaces, and I work to help people and I think that's something eight years ago I would have been terrified to do."
According to Fierman, this space is particularly important due to the rise in policies rolling back LGBTQ+ protections since President Donald Trump's inauguration. These policies include executive orders prohibiting gender-affirming health care for those under 19 and designating that the country recognizes only two sexes.
Fierman said now more than ever community and joy needs to be prioritized. This game provides a space to escape from the pressures of the outside and create a physical, mental and emotional space for anyone that needs to get away.
"The goal of a lot of these anti-LGBTQ policies and misinformation is to take away our joy. They want us to go away, and I think combating hate with love and combating hate with joy is the most powerful thing you can do because that's what's going to keep us going. That's what kept our community fighting back for generations."
Delmarva Pride Center hosts monthly events including Gender Expression Movement, Elder and Intergeneration Social and Parents and Allies Groups.

title: The Zebra Gallery: a place for 'evolutionary' artists
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The Zebra Gallery: a place for 'evolutionary' artists

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For Susa Schauer, art has stayed consistent in her life no matter her career. Whether it was being a professional woodturner or a neuroscientist, her heart has kept its love for creativity.Schauer's The Zebra Gallery has provided Easton with a collection of "evolutionary" art and artists.
Her journey to opening the business began during the COVID-19 pandemic, when she was diagnosed with cancer. She described her diagnoses as a wake-up call. It pushed her to make her dream gallery a reality.
"I thought if I'm ever going to open a gallery, maybe I should (now)," Schauer said. "Life is short. So this beautiful spot across in the Tidewater came open, and I kind of leapt into it."
Schauer's decision to not wait allowed her to create a place that would not only help her through the pandemic and her illness, but also helped her establish a community she loved.
Schauer said her choice in name for her gallery came as a bit of surprise to her. She did not have a particular connection with zebras growing up, but one day she received a text from her daughter-in-law saying her grandson, who was 3 years old at the time, had just been diagnosed at Johns Hopkins with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, an illness that affects the skin, joints and blood vessels.
After some research, she learned the symbol for Ehlers Danlos Society is a zebra. The symbol called to her and she decided to name her gallery after the animal. Additionally, she made a commitment to give 10% of proceeds to Ehlers Danlos research.
"So I took the name Zebra Gallery, and thought it was destined to be," Schauer said. "It has made just perfect sense for me in terms of where I am in my life, making this more than just about me, selling other people's art, but in fact, also giving back to some degree. So it feels like a really nice circle."
Now, Schauer's gallery features local and international artists. Schauer said when looking for artists to feature in her gallery she seeks art that is evolving, risk-taking and intriguing. Though she has a love for traditional art, she said she wants to help foster high-end art with a contemporary spin.
In her own work, she has worked in a variety of media including portrait painting, woodturning and thread painting.
Ingrid Matuszewski, a featured artist at the Zebra Gallery, said she had been a long time admirer of Schauer's art and it has been a pleasure to work with Schauer in her gallery. Matuszewski, who got into portrait painting later in life, said working with Schauer has established a community of growth for her and her art.
"I think Easton has amazing galleries, so I think the Zebra Gallery complements the other ones in a way that maybe hasn't been there before and represented before because it's more of a contemporary take on art," Matuszewski said. "I think Susan tries to get in touch with artists who just kind of have different viewpoints on things."
Adam Himoff, a muralist at the Zebra Gallery, said Schauer's gallery is the first gallery he had been featured in. Her excitement for his work was magnetic, and her love for art in general drew him in.
"I met Susan, and she lights up a room and has some amazing energy," Himoff said. "And we talked about my art and her art, and I shared photos of my other work. She had seen the mural before. And she was amazing. She just lit up, and without a millisecond passing just expressed so much excitement and interest in the work. And so it just seems clear that energy was very convincing."
Schauer said she loves the people on the Eastern Shore, and the opportunity to have her gallery feature local talent, she said, has been wonderful.
"There really are so many spectacular people in this town and visiting this town, it's why I came here from grad school and never left 40 years ago," Schauer said. "It's a beautiful area, and we have a remarkable group of both artists and buyers, and they're all wonderful people who have great stories to tell. So every day is a kind of learning and creating."

'A testament to our shared values' - Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast marks 40th anniversary Oct. 26

 EASTON - For 40 years, the prayer breakfast hosted by the mayor of Easton has brought local leaders together to break bread, support each other and invoke the help of God, with inspiring messages from those living out their faith in the community.Celebrating this milestone Thursday morning, Oct. 26, were about 150 Talbot County elected leaders, county and town administrators, law enforcement officers, clergy and citizens.They prayed, sang along to familiar songs and hymns, and connected over a buffet breakfast at the Tidewater Inn.After Easton Police officers presented the colors and led the Pledge of Allegiance, Katherine Tooley of Immanuel Lutheran Church in Easton led the singing of "God Bless America." Amy Steward served as mistress of ceremonies, and Mayor Megan Cook greeted the attendees."Gathering together each year is a testament to our shared values and our dedication to fostering a sense of community," Cook said."It allows us to celebrate our friendships, nurture new ones and reinforce our duty to support one another." Also attending the event were former Mayor Robert Willey and his wife Betsy, who, representing the First Baptist Church, read scripture from the New Testament.Both Cook and Willey were honored with official citations from the Maryland General Assembly, delivered by State Sen. Johnny Mautz, R-37, and Del. Chris Adams, R-37B."When you look at the news and walk down the street, you know now, more than ever, we need prayer amongst the business community and our political leaders," Adams said.Mautz said the morning was "very significant" and called for applause to mark the occasion.The guest speakers were two local servant-leaders who work primarily with youth and are active in their local churches. They shared very different testimonies of how they see God working in their lives and the lives of others.Claudia Reyes emigrated from Guatemala as a child and serves in Hispanic youth ministries with her husband Eliud, the pastor of First Hispanic Baptist Church in Easton. They have been married for 29 years and have four children.Her ministry in the Talbot County Detention Center, where she hears stories of addiction and exploitation, has convinced her that "evil is all around us." "We live in bad times, and if you saw the news last night or have seen the news for a couple weeks, you know exactly what I'm talking about. I can assure you that God sees the evil and through God, lives are being transformed," Reyes said. "As much as we have seen evil and destruction here in our community, we see more of God's grace and mercy." Referring to the rise of drug addiction and sex trafficking she is aware of, Reyes said, "Our youth here in our community are not for sale for evil. They are to be rescued.They are to be saved." Reyes encouraged attendees to pray because "prayer is very powerful," to become aware of the problems youth face and to "do something." Raised on a farm near Cordova and active in the 4-H program, Linda Saathoff Brown is a lifelong member of Immanuel Lutheran Church. She called herself a "farm girl, teacher, wife, mother and Nana." She has been married to Wesley Brown for 46 years and has taught in Talbot County Public Schools for 47 years.Sprinkling her talk with Bible verses and contemporary praise song lyrics, Brown shared "My Story, God's Glory," borrowing a title of one of her favorite songs by Matthew West.On the exact one-year anniversary of a surgery following a life-threatening fall that could have left her paralyzed, Brown shared ten miracles she said were evidence of God healing her through the prayers of friends from Cordova to Trinidad.Despite dire indications that she may never walk again because of five vertebrae that were either "crushed or cracked," Brown was able to return home without a walker and celebrate Thanksgiving with Amish friends from Lancaster, who brought a van load of food and the greeting, "Our fervent prayers are answered," she said."Thanksgiving took on a whole new meaning" and she "has been blessed beyond measure," Brown said.Local clergy reading scripture and leading prayers were the Rev. Demetrius Price of Union Baptist Church; the Rev. Elmer Davis, a district superintendent in the Peninsula-Delaware Conference of The United Methodist Church; Kennedy Siaw, youth minister of Oasis Church; and C.B. Nagel of Cru, formerly Campus Crusade for Christ International.Before leading a prayer for leadership, Siaw challenged attendees to reflect on their reason for attending the breakfast and reminded them that "true leadership is to become the servant of all," after the example of Jesus Christ.The Rev. Christian Jensen of Denton has been chaplain of the Maryland General Assembly for 23 years and attended the first Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast and "most of the intervening 40," he said.He is also the Maryland representative for the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C."It's a blessing to see an important tradition like this carry on through, regardless of what changes there are in political administration," Jensen said. "To see something like this continue on is a good reflection on everyone's ability to get along with one another and understand what's important."

title: Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1051
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump is intensifying his push to eliminate federal funding for National Public Radio (NPR) and Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) stations."NPR and PBS, two horrible and completely biased platforms (Networks!), should be DEFUNDED by Congress, IMMEDIATELY," Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform Thursday.
"Republicans, don't miss this opportunity to rid our Country of this giant SCAM, both being arms of the Radical Left Democrat Party. JUST SAY NO AND, MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!!!," Trump said.
Earlier this week, Trump also said from the Oval Office he backed eliminating federal funding for public media.
Congressional Republicans are looking at funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which helps fund PBS and NPR stations nationwide.
CPB received $535 million in the most recent annual federal budget. The nonprofit was created by Congress in 1967.
"Reducing or eliminating CBP funding would save the federal government little (maximum of $535 million) while having dire though not universally fatal consequences for public broadcasting," said Michael Montgomery, a political scientist and professor at the University of Michigan-Dearborn.
Montgomery contends the funding elimination push from Trump and conservatives is about their objections to what they see as NPR's and PBS' liberal slants.
"Make no mistake, if it happens, killing CPB will not be about saving money - this is about quieting voices and content that those on the right find objectionable or inconvenient," Montgomery said.
Some of Trump's most ardent supporters in the GOP-controlled Congress also want to eliminate government money for public media.
"We will defund NPR and PBS!!," said U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia, in a social media statement responding to Trump. "The American people will NOT pay for disgusting Democrat propaganda anymore!!."
Greene is critical of PBS' coverage of LGBTQ communities, including saying at a congressional hearing Wednesday that it promotes a "trans agenda" pointing to a local affiliate's airing of a segment featuring drag artists.
During the same hearing on CPB funding Wednesday, U.S. Rep. Brandon Gill, R-Texas, grilled NPR President CEO Katherine Maher about her progressive social media posts on white supremacy, reparations and civil unrest in 2020 and 2021.
Maher became NPR boss in 2024.
She said her views have evolved, that NPR was working to offer a wider variety of perspectives in its coverage and had created new protocols to avoid bias, stressing the need for editorial independence.
Maher also stressed the need for public media in rural and lower-income communities.
"Public radio is very often the only news service in places where market economics does not support the expense of local news," she told the House panel.
Montgomery said NPR gets approximately 1% of its funding from CPB compared to roughly 14% for PBS.
"At the local level, an end of CPB funding would hit public TV harder than radio but public broadcasters of both types are likely to cut back, consolidate, or go silent," he said.
Public TV and radio stations and programs they produce would have to backfill any lost federal funding with money from other sources including donors, foundations and corporations.
Rick Ellis, founder and managing editor of Minnesota-based AllYourScreens.com (which tracks media news and industries), said defunding has been a desire of conservatives who either don't like government money for media outlets or "what they consider to be liberal programming."
"They haven't been able to eliminate the spending in the past in large part because the areas that would be most impacted by the cuts are rural areas that are also Republican strongholds. And overall, government financing for public media is pretty popular with voters," he said.
Ellis points to a Pew Research Center poll released Wednesday showing 24% of respondents favor nixing government funding for PBS and NPR, while 43% support public media funding and 33% are not sure.
"In theory, it would probably be politically less complicated for public media to move away from government funding. But while it is overall a small slice of public media financing, it's tough to replace any other way," Ellis said.
He said larger public media outlets in bigger, more affluent cities will survive the funding loss.
"But it would be enough of a loss to decimate outlets in Alaska, Hawaii and a number of Midwestern and Southern states, which are smaller and already struggle to get funding from foundations, viewers and listeners," Ellis said.
A number of local and statewide NPR and PBS stations have not yet responded to requests for comments about defunding and how they might navigate a new financial landscape, including their ties to universities and community colleges (which are also under fire from Trump).
The Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 has called for defunding CPB in its austerity blueprints, citing liberal biases and questioning the necessity of government outlays.
Elon Musk, who owns the X social media platform and runs Trump's Department of Government Efficiency efforts, has also echoed conservative calls to defund public media, in particular NPR. Trump said earlier this week DOGE efforts could also target public media funding.
Irina Tsukerman, president of New York-based Scarab Rising Inc. (a geopolitical consulting firm) said funding cuts could result in public media jobs cuts, less local programming and potentially station closures.
She also sees wider media impacts.
"Public media plays a unique role in the media ecosystem, providing high-quality, in-depth journalism that is free from the commercial pressures faced by corporate media," Tsukerman said, pointing to investigative, cultural and educational content that might not be pursued by other outlets.
'The removal of federal funding would push these stations to rely more heavily on private donations and corporate sponsorships, potentially influencing editorial independence and leading to content shifts that prioritize profitability over public service," she said.
Trump and his populist backers are vehement critics of many traditional media outlets, accusing them of liberal bias.
Trump routinely calls journalists "enemies of the state," frequently characterizing critical coverage of himself and his administration as fabricated or "witch hunts."
A number of major U.S. media outlets and social media platforms are owned by conglomerates such as the Fox Corp. and Walt Disney Co. or some of the wealthiest persons in the world such as Musk, Amazon founder and Washington Post owner Jeff Bezos and Meta/Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg.
The latter trio were all front and center at Trump's inauguration in January inside the U.S. Capitol.
"A weakened public media sector benefits those who prefer a media environment dominated by private interests, where corporate-backed outlets and partisan networks can exert greater influence over public discourse," Tsukerman said.

title: Celebrating Hispanic art and artists with poster contest
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Celebrating Hispanic art and artists with poster contest

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 456
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From iconic Hispanic icons like Frida Khalo, to colorfully rich portraits of Guatemala landscapes, to a tree with all the Hispanic flags hanging from its branches, the Academy Art Museum was filled with a variety of portraits.In celebration of Hispanic cultural heritage, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center hosted a poster competition and invited community members to rejoice in the submissions.
Every year, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center asks the Hispanic community to participate in choosing a theme for the annual celebration. Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director for Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said the theme for this year is "Ser Hispano, es Ser Valiente," which translates to "Being Hispanic is Being Brave."
The top three posters win prizes, and the first place poster will be used as the official poster for the 2025 Hispanic Heritage Month in Easton.
Roxana Tapia, judge of the competition, said the first, second and third place winners this year came from various ages and ethnicities. But they all had the common goal of celebrating Hispanic heritage.
"You don't even have to be a Latina in order to participate," Tapia said. "What I liked about this year is that we have people from all ethnicities. So if for any kids, I invite them to come over and participate, it's always fun. (Artists) should be proud of their work."
The winners of this year's competition were Piper Hambleton and Ellis Williams for their collaborative work. Their poster portrayed a large tree with flags from every Latin American and Hispanic country attached to its branches.
Alberto Gamez, a judge and ChesMRC board member, called the colorful art piece "The Tree of the Nations."
"I love that it was like a tree of life, but each branch had a different nation, and they covered a lot of them. So I love that it included everybody," Gamez said.
Gamez said he enjoyed all the art submitted this year and the various stories attached to the works, including third place winner Ahias Murillo, whose portrait "I Paint My Own Reality" showed Frida Khalo with an array of Latin American flags behind her. According to Gamez, the piece spoke on the identity and growth of Latinos.
The second place winner Majo Arrivillaga, whose portrait of two faceless individuals was meant to depict the different faces migrants have while traveling to the United States, also included a colorful landscape of Guatemala.
Arrivillaga said she loves drawing because it allows her to show people the beauty within the Latino community and encourages Latino artists of all ages to take the leap and share their work with their community.
"Being Hispanic, for me, is being a person who works, studies and centers their family," Arrivillaga said. "We are multifaceted and we can do it all. That's what makes us brave."

title: 25-year-old set to bike from Easton to Canada
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
25-year-old set to bike from Easton to Canada

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hayden Kessinger, 25, is set to bike from Easton to Canada beginning Saturday. It isn't his first cross-country bike ride.In 2023, Kessinger biked from Baltimore to San Francisco in 70 days.
Kessinger's motivation for biking across the country came from a book called "The Happiness of Pursuit" by Chris Guillebeau.
"I kind of initially had an idea to do some sort of long-distance bike ride and specifically bike across the country after reading a book," Kessinger said. "... It just sort of inspired me to think about doing something kind of crazy in the eyes of the most people or embarking on some sort of adventure or just exploring more."
Shortly after reading the book, Kessinger learned about the Ulman Foundation, a company the specializes in supporting young adults with cancer. The foundation participates in holds a bike-riding fundraiser, and Kessinger signed up.
The group raised $161,828 during their 2023 ride to San Francisco. Kessigner raised $7,431.
With new hopes on the horizon and used biking gear, Kessinger's sets his eyes on biking from Easton to Montreal, Canada this summer.
Although Kessinger will not be raising funds during this ride, his friend Keisuke "Jima" Nakajima, who will be joining Kessinger from Baltimore to Montreal, is raising funds for the Ulman Foundation.
Nakajima then will take transportation back to Baltimore from Montreal, leaving Kessinger by himself for the grueling bike home.
"The decision to go from my home in Easton to Canada is sort of born out of like being able to go somewhere that I've never been and do it all under my own power," Kessinger said.
During Kessinger's trip in 2023, the other bikers on the trip had built relationships in the past to find places for the group to stay the night. They also had help from the foundation.
But for his trip this summer, Kessinger plans to coordinate sleeping arrangements, showering and food through meeting new people and an app called Warm Showers.
"It's specifically for cycle tourists, so people doing long-distance bike rides, and you can make an account, and you can be a host on there. And so you can connect with these hosts who are all over all over the world," Kessinger said.
Kessinger's job as a dog sitter, gave him opportunity to train for the grueling bike ride. He biked from client to client. Kessinger established a savings with money from high school work and an internship after he graduated from the University of Maryland.
Kessinger's message to anyone scared of taking on new opportunities or trying something different is to just "give it a go."
"Try it," Kessinger said. "Say say when all of those reasons come up of why you know this can't work or you shouldn't do it. Just see what it feels like to ignore those and what it feels like to to say yes, because you'll figure out the rest later."
To follow along with Kessinger, follow is his blog at teamtahoe.substack.com/.

title: Easton minister detained by ICE
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton minister detained by ICE

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 507
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A beloved Easton minister was detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, taken to Salisbury and is now at the Baltimore ICE detention center where he is awaiting his next transfer, according to his daughter.Honduran born Daniel Fuentes Espinal has lived in the United States since 2001 and has served as the minister of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015. According to his daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, Espinal was arrested by ICE agents early Monday morning after stopping by Lowe's to pick up material for a job site.
"He didn't see anything suspicious. He put the material in the car, but then when he went to McDonald's to get something for breakfast, he saw a car behind him that looked kind of weird," Cordero said.
ICE agents followed Espinal to the Easton pool, ultimately arresting him on Route 322. He was taken to the Salisbury holding center. "He preached to them all the way to Salisbury," Diaz said.
From 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., Espinal's family had no clue of his whereabouts. "We were about to do a report on a missing person because we didn't find out until almost 12:30," Diaz said.
Diaz said Espinal had no criminal record.
Since President Donald Trump took office in January, immigration arrests have doubled in the state of Maryland. More than 600 immigrants arrested during this time had no former criminal charges, according to the Deportation Data Project.
Espinal has three children and a large extended family that he cares for, Diaz said. Tred Avon Strategies principal Len Foxwell referred to him as a pillar of the community.
Earlier this month, Espinal spoke at Foxwell's son Darren's funeral. Diaz said Darren and her brother were best friends and his death has been hard on Espinal and the family.
Diaz said she has received over 10 character letters on her father's behalf since his arrest yesterday morning, including one from Foxwell.
"It wasn't until I got to know him, however, that I saw how he honors and embodies the values of Christ in every aspect of his life," Foxwell wrote in a letter to ICE.
Espinal's family has tried obtaining citizenship legally for years, but due to backlogs and expenses, Espinal remained undocumented, Diaz said.
"He's contributing to this country, and we're just trying to do it the right way," Diaz said. "You know, unfortunately, with everything going on, everyone's a criminal apparently, but we're just hoping for the best and just to get him out of there."
Diaz said each phone call Espinal makes from the detention center costs $50 for a 20-minute call and bond amounts for release currently range from $10,000 to $15,000.
"I've heard stories that people say, 'But why didn't you do it the legal way? Why aren't you doing it the legal way?' It's not easy," Diaz said. "You know, if you're not in that person's shoes, you shouldn't be judging, and you shouldn't be criticizing."
Espinal's family is relying on their faith and are hopeful that he will return home.
ICE could not be reached via phone to comment on this incident.

title: Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 517
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Up before dawn, the team came with pallets of salt, ready to get their jobs done and help local businesses stay open, despite icy weather.Darrell Doupnik, the owner of Greenshore, an Easton-based landscaping company, has been providing salt and snow plow services in the winter for 40 years.
He met with his crew Friday morning to discuss their strategy for keeping walkways and parking lots ice-free for the company's roster of commercial clients.
Some members of the team, like foreman Jerry Widener, have years of experience with winter weather.
"I have been doing this for 15 years," Widener said. "I got up at 5 this morning. It's no big deal. I am used to it."
"In the winter we are clearing snow. When it snows, we are out here pushing snow. I am a pushing guy today, but I will do whatever it takes," he said.
According to Widener, Friday's temperatures, though frigid, were high enough to keep the workload manageable for the team.
"If it gets too cold, the salt doesn't work," Widener said. "I am the foreman today. I have five guys working for me. But for this, today, it is not too cold, and the salt works well."
Rock salt, lots of it, gets put in a spreader, which is attached to the back of a pickup truck for crews to drive around clients' roads and parking lots.
Doupnik said the team used over 100 40-pound bags of salt to handle Friday's workload, purchased from Site One landscaping supply.
"It is not cheap. Salt costs $450 a ton," he said. "We get them in 40-pound bags. You can put six bags at a time in the tailgate salt spreader."
Friday's storm brought upwards of three inches of snow to Easton and upwards of four inches to the town's north and east, according to the National Weather Service.
In more intense winter weather, Doupnik said, the team requires even larger quantities of salt, and staying ahead of the icy roads can be a strain on their bodies.
"This (storm) is a piece of cake. It is not really blowing. The six- to 10-inchers, you are out for two days. It sucks. You go home and try to get some rest, and then you are back out fixing it up. You just go back out there," he said.
In his 40 years of plowing snow, Doupnik has learned the value his team's hard work provides to not only his customers, but to the community as a whole.
"For commercial clients, you kind of have to provide it. They like an all-inclusive package," he said. "We do a lot of banks, we do these private schools and the churches. People still go to church. People still bank, and they have got to go to school. These places have to be open — especially the banks. We were out early this morning getting the banks opened up. Since schools are out, we do them last."
Doupnik said the community often shows appreciation for what his crew does.
"My guys get treated very well. My customers give them stuff a lot — especially at Christmas time," he said. "These are good guys, hard workers."

title: Songs about the water - Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum continues Changing Chesapeake series
content:
Songs about the water - Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum continues Changing Chesapeake series

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 703
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Back in the early 1990s, Peter Panyon was taking part in a weeklong workshop for college professors focused on the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries when inspiration struck while cruising the Patuxent River."It occurred to me: Wait a minute, there's a story to tell here," Panyon remembered."I was thinking, 'Man, somebody should write a song about that, and nobody's going to do it if it's not me.'" A biology professor by trade, Panyon would write and re-write the song over the years on the way to perfecting "Can't Work the River." The ballad tracing a watermen's struggles was included on his band Big Tribe's debut album in 2014, and its music video is now part of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's special exhibition The Changing Chesapeake.At 7 p.m. on Sept. 28, Panyon and his Big Tribe bandmates Bonnie Eyler and Joe Huette will present "Songs About the Water," an evening of songs and stories with a dose of science at the museum's Van Lennep Auditorium.This "Changing Chesapeake Coffeehouse" concert will feature fare provided by Blue Heron Coffee of St. Michaels and highlight songs drawing inspiration from local rivers to the Gulf oil spill and hurricane disasters.The suggested ticket price is $15 per participant for this event, which is sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center. To register and get more information, visit cbmm.org/SongsAboutWater.Panyon has married two of his passions in coming up with a catalog to fill a concert like this.The Calvert County resident is now retired after a lengthy career teaching biology at the University of Maryland, Catholic University and Prince George's Community College.As a musician, Panyon has written hundreds of songs, dating back to his teenage years. Recently, he's catalyzed Big Tribe, which has released two albums of eclectic rock tracks with a new one, "Postcards from the Mission," due out later this year.Those experiences have helped Panyon carve out a unique lane as a songwriter with something to say."Your normal rock and roll about cars and girls, that's not what we do," Panyon said. "What we're really up to is trying to hit people with music that, while they're having fun with it, there's a message in there that hopefully we get them to think about." The "Can't Work the River" video debuted in 2016 at a conference on teaching science through alternative media at the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center.Now, the 5-minute, 25-second video that features two watermen from different generations grappling with the realities of working the Patuxent River is finding a new audience as part of The Changing Chesapeake, which is on exhibit through next March."I want to at least crack open the door that leads to thinking about this scientifically," Panyon said. "Yes, it's a story about a guy, and he lost his woman, and he's having trouble making a living, but when you dive beneath the surface of that story, there's this other story about what's actually going wrong. Why is this way of life that's millennia old getting more and more iffy?" In concert, Panyon aims to expand on these important themes.While Big Tribe's albums feature big sound from a full band with bass drums, electric guitars, and an array of complementary instruments, its acoustic shows with Panyon, Eyler, and Huette are more easygoing, free-flowing, and even interactive."It's not just music," Panyon said. "We're going to throw a little science in, and we're totally open to having a dialogue." The set list for these live shows goes in different directions with various meditations on the importance of valuing our waterways, including another track with roots in the 1990s and a literal earnestness to its title, "We Are the River." As he prepares for his CBMM gig, Panyon is excited that he's found a perfect partner to help him share these songs that mean so much to him."Most bands are looking to play big venues like stadiums," Panyon said with a chuckle."For us, it's museums. We want to do as many museums as possible, and once we've conquered the museum world, then we're going for the stadiums."

title: Be careful what you vote for
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be careful what you vote for

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Be careful what you vote forLast Sunday, Easton resident Larry Pifer's piece on "authoritarian government" was published in the Star Democrat. He spoke to real impacts of authoritarian governments of the past, but also to those currently taking hold, around the world and potentially, right here in America.
Larry's thoughts, observations and quotes, particularly this one, from Trump, himself, "I will be a dictator but only for a short time" should give all Americans reason to carefully consider who steers Good Ship America in the upcoming four years.
We do not have to rely on what other people say about who, or what, Trump is; he, himself, tells everyone that tunes in to national media many opportunities to hear it, directly from his own mouth. Granted, there are many, many other media outlets and pundits that will spin who and what he is, and what he will do for you, if you vote to elect him. However, many of the promises he made during his first presidential run, were never fulfilled, for example:
I'll build a great wall and Mexico will pay for it. NOPE.
I'll repeal Obamacare and give you better, cheaper health care, NOPE.
I'll bring manufacturing back to America, NOPE. Under his watch manufacturing jobs remained relatively flat, until they fell off the cliff as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
I'll grow the economy by 4% per year, NOPE. Actually, his best year was 2018, when the economy grew by 2.9% over the previous year.
I'll cut taxes for everybody, NOPE. While many, but not all, benefited, marginally, from Trump's tax cuts, the vast majority went to the rich and to corporations, some of them not even American.
I'll terminate Obama's executive orders on immigration, NOPE. While one program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, (DACA), was challenged in our courts, it remains in effect, yet today. A second program, Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), never was implemented, so Trump could not terminate it.
If you listen to Trump now, he is regurgitating some of the same promises he failed to fulfill during his first term in office, even though he enjoyed Republican majorities in both the U.S. House and the Senate for his first two years in office. Which brings me to a word, or two, of caution to those who choose to vote in the upcoming elections.
Be careful of those who don't keep their promises and be careful of the would-be dictator you vote to elect; you don't always get the kind of dictator you think you will, when you voted, based on what he and his minions tell you, and it is very hard to get rid of dictators.
WILLIAM C. KEPPEN

title: 'Heartbeat of Easton Utilities' legacy lives on
author: JOHN ENGLEHART
content:
'Heartbeat of Easton Utilities' legacy lives on

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHN ENGLEHART | Section: Columns 
 
 1208
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Jan. 13, Vicki Petro retired as vice president of human resources at Easton Utilities after 31 years of dedicated service. To some, this may seem like the closing chapter of just another HR career. But to those of us who had the privilege of calling Vicki a colleague, a mentor or a friend, this marks the end of an extraordinary era in the Mid-Shore community.Vicki began her journey with Easton Utilities on Nov. 2, 1993, as the organization's sole HR professional, reporting to the business manager. Over the past three decades, she has shaped the careers of countless employees, directly overseeing the hiring of 324 individuals during her tenure, guiding many through the retirement process and supporting the training and development of many more.
She's ensured payroll ran seamlessly more than 750 times, served as a trusted adviser to two CEOs and been the go-to resource for employees seeking guidance to navigate their careers. She has served as mentor to many at Easton Utilities and in the Mid-Shore community, having a profound impact on them both professionally and personally.
I first met Vicki in 2021 when I interviewed for a position with another organization. She had been invited to serve on the interview panel to lend her expertise and help them make an informed decision. From the moment she spoke, I was struck by her professionalism, warmth and rare passion for HR — a field where such genuine excitement can sometimes feel scarce.
I remember thinking, If I ever have the chance to work for her, I'll take it, because there's so much I could learn from someone like her. That opportunity came in 2023, and over the past two years, I've grown immensely—not just as an HR professional, but also as a leader and as a person—thanks to her guidance.
Easton Utilities, like any organization, can be thought of as a living body. The linemen could be viewed as the muscles, the water/wastewater operators perhaps viewed as the backbone, the customer service representatives perhaps the face, and—if you ask the engineers, they might claim to be the brain. But at its core, Human Resources is the heart. It keeps the organization alive and thriving, circulating energy and support to every part.
For 30 years, Vicki was Easton Utilities' heartbeat, sustaining the organization through storms, challenges, and triumphs alike.
Her impact reaches far beyond Easton Utilities' walls. If a gas technician safely resolved a leak in your home, it's likely Vicki played a role in hiring them. If a Velocity technician helped you as a rural customers get connected to much needed high speed internet, chances are Vicki was there to interview them. When linemen braved ice storms to restore power to your neighborhood, she likely contributed to their onboarding. And when you've interacted with our professional and compassionate customer service staff, you've experienced the result of Vicki's discerning eye for talent.
In sum, if you've been impressed with Easton Utilities' service over the past 30 years, it's because Vicki had a hand in it — not only by selecting individuals who embody Easton Utilities core values but also by shaping the training that helped them excel. She has also been a great mentor to others through her Leadership Maryland classmates, impacting professionals around the State of Maryland.
Vicki's influence wasn't confined to hiring or compliance—it was deeply human. She understood that when employees face challenges, they carry those burdens home to their families. Time and again, she offered them support, showing them how to navigate their struggles so they could be present for their loved ones.
As her retirement approached, Vicki demonstrated the same grace and foresight that defined her career. This graceful departure reminds me of a lesson from sports. As a Baltimore football fan, I think of the legendary Johnny Unitas. He was the greatest quarterback of all time, but even he struggled to hang up his cleats. In a twist few like to remember, Unitas ended his career not in Baltimore but in a San Diego Chargers uniform, a move that seemed out of place for such an icon. It's a lesson in knowing when it's time to step aside. Vicki, however, has shown impeccable timing. She embraced the evolving needs of the organization, mentored her successors, and made way for the next chapter—all while ensuring Easton Utilities' heart continues to beat strong. Some leaders struggle to step aside, holding onto their roles even as the times and needs of their organizations evolve. But not Vicki. She embraced the opportunity to mentor and prepare the next generation, ensuring Easton Utilities' heart continues to beat strong long after she steps away.
One of my favorite movies is The Dark Knight. A memorable quote from that movie is Harvey Dent's reflection on heroes: "You either die a hero or live long enough to see yourself become the villain." In my years of observing HR leaders, I've seen this sentiment play out. Many HR Directors depart their roles amid controversy or burnout, others retiring from their organization leaving behind employees that are happy to see them go rather than admiration. But Vicki defied that trend. She is retiring on her own terms, as a universally respected leader—beloved by employees, admired by executives, and deeply respected throughout the mid-shore community.
After Jan. 13, as the days, weeks, months and years go by, Vicki's name will be heard less and less around Talbot County and Easton Utilities. New employees will join, and those who knew her best will retire. The stories of the great things she achieved as the heart of Easton Utilities will fade, as the stories of legends often do. But I can guarantee her name will be spoken one more time, 20 years from now …
When my time comes to retire, and I am the "old-school" HR director trying to understand the up-and-coming HR leaders looking to replace me, I'm sure I will observe them make some kind of mistake — fall flat on their face in a way that only experience can teach to avoid. And just like Vicki, I'll be there with some kind of sage advice to help them learn from it. When they ask me, "Who taught you that?" my answer will be simple: "Vicki Petro taught me that."
And with that the legend of Vicki Petro will continue.
No one asked or paid me to write this. I did so because some contributions deserve recognition, and Vicki's story is one of them. Over the past two years, I've had the honor of working with her and witnessing her remarkable leadership firsthand. Vicki has been an exceptional HR professional, a trusted advisor, a compassionate mentor, and an inspiring leader. She has not only shaped Easton Utilities but has left it stronger and better for the next generation in our mid-shore community.
For now, Vicki rides off into the sunset to begin the next chapter of a legendary life — as a grandma spending time with her grandbabies, traveling with her husband to new places across the globe and enjoying the fruits of her labor. And I'm sure in those new adventures, she will be the heartbeat of those moments, just as she has been the heartbeat for so many years at Easton Utilities and the Mid-Shore community.
Enjoy your grandbabies, Vicki. Thank you for everything.

Lesher withdraws name from Easton Utilities Commission consideration
