 EASTON — Following lengthy discussion of his potential appointment last week, Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher has withdrawn his name from consideration for the Easton Utilities Commission, according to Easton Mayor Megan Cook.Lesher, originally appointed to the commission by Cook, was not confirmed by the Easton Town Council last week. Some town councilmembers raised concerns over Lesher simultaneously serving on the County Council and utilities commission.
Town officials said the legality of serving on both bodies would depend on if the utilities commission is considered a "trust and profit" office, since state law doesn't allow someone to hold two such positions.
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh said at the March 3 meeting that while the town "would probably get to the conclusion that it is not a second office of trust and profit," it would be best to first review case law and attorney general rulings.
The appointment was made to fill the role of current commission member Buck Duncan. His time expires this May, leaving ample time for a new appointment, the mayor said.

title: Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words

 EASTON - Talbot County is seeing increases in juvenile crime, along with upticks in petty thefts and some violent crimes, according to the county's top law enforcement officials.Updates on local crime trends from each law enforcement agency in the county dominated discussion at Talbot County's latest Police Accountability Board meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 14.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble reported a 19% increase in calls for service and a 13% increase in reported crime handled by the sheriff's office, including some small increases in assaults and drug charges. Crimes relating to fraud of older residents are likely the biggest financial loss in the county, he added.Gamble identified juvenile crimes in schools as a particular issue for the sheriff's office, which has uniformed officers serving in most of the public schools.Recently implemented state juvenile justice reform laws have barred police from charging anyone under 13 with most crimes.Gamble said Easton High School and Easton Middle School are where police see most of the incidents involving children, and over 30% of this year's reported incidents involve children under 13."We have 12-year-olds that are punching other kids in the face time and time again in the schools, or assaulting other kids, and there's no services for them," he said.Police Accountability Board members acknowledged the concerns, asking what officers can do to better handle issues with youth under 13 and if police can work with the schools.Gamble said the school system doesn't have leverage to handle discipline other than resorting to suspensions.Looking forward, Gamble hopes to see movement within state leadership in Annapolis during the upcoming General Assembly session to push legislation to tackle issues with the juvenile reform laws.Outside of juvenile crime, those at the meeting discussed several recent local incidents.In Easton, two homicides occurred within town limits in the last few months - one on Blake Street in early August and a second at the Sidetracked Saloon in late September.Several thefts and robberies have also occurred in town, said Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey. Those include a series of burglaries at vape stores where individuals are seeking Delta-8 THC cartridges, a non-regulated and legal psychoactive substance with effects similar to recreational cannabis.Another issue of great concern to Easton residents is crime on the Rails to Trails pathways throughout town, Lowrey said, citing a serious assault on the trails in the summer.To alleviate those concerns, the town's police department is increasing patrols on the trails and issuing more citations, Lowrey said. Those efforts include repopulating the department's bike unit, which is down due to lower staffing levels.In St. Michaels, Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald didn't note any specific crime trends, though he did mention two car thefts, which are "extremely unusual" for the town, he said. The town's tourist season is coming to a close, which means St. Michaels will have a lower population and more shops closed up for the winter.The small St. Michaels Police Department is down a few officers, though two new officers are starting soon, Oswald said. The department was also able to secure higher starting salaries and increases for current officers."Things are looking up. It's just going to be a little while," he said.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner did not report any major issues, adding that Oxford is a "very safe little town." The town's three-member police department was fully staffed until a few weeks ago, but Oxford's town commissioners recently agreed to increase the department to four full-time officers, Kellner said. The town is now looking to hire one additional officer.

title: 'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The tall, welcoming windows in the classrooms of Building African American Minds Inc.'s new academic center in Easton don't just bring in sunlight. They connect the surrounding residents to new opportunities.Three stories high and nearly 25,000 square feet, the center will house classes, tutoring, youth programs, community gatherings and more. It sits on Jowite Street, next to the BAAM Athletic Center and across from a large residential area.
James Bell, director of instruction, academic support and community wellbeing for the nonprofit, believes the space fits within the organization's mission of creating an educational and social space for underserved children in the area.
"The excitement really is looking out of the windows and seeing the potential," Bell says. "So when you see the community, out of every window here in the facility, it lets you know that it's an opportunity for them as well."
Saturday, Building African American Minds will cut the ribbon on the academic center, which is expected to be up and running in January. The center will allow the nonprofit to significantly expand how many children it serves in after-school and summer enrichment programs.
There is a library, media center and multipurpose dining room on the first floor. Above are eight classrooms, as well as speciality rooms for esports, art and music.
Classrooms are designed with desks situated for full-group, small-group and individual learning.
Dina Daly, executive director of Building African American Minds, pointed out a wellness wing, which will be a private space for health, counseling and more. She added that BAAM's sister agency, private school Polaris Village Academy, will operate out of the academic center in 2025.
While the organization's focus has been serving under-resourced youth in the nearby neighborhoods, its reach isn't limited to children or Talbot County residents, Daly says.
Adult workforce programs will be hosted in the new academic center during the day. On the third floor, Chesapeake College will begin hosting GED and English second language classes in February.
"We had a vision from the beginning," Daly said. "So we're just following up on our vision for what we thought needed to happen, not just for the youth."
In its 20th year, Building African American Minds has long hoped for an academic center like the one that sits on Jowite Street today. Its previous hub, the athletic center next to the new building, isn't going anywhere either.
However, the new academic center was about a $10 million project, Daly said, more than double what the athletic center cost. Private donors, community donations, and state and federal funding made it possible.
"We build for the future," Daly said. "From the inception of BAAM, we always talked about building a school and academic center. It's more than a school now. It's more like a community center, really."
Daly said it's been a long process, but she knows the wait was worth it. Starting small and meeting a select group's needs instead of going too broad, such as when the organization began as a boys-only nonprofit in 2005, was the path to success.
Reflecting on the fact that a 20-year goal is finally coming to fruition, Daly hopes the journey of Building African American Minds can inspire others to start small and dream big.
"That's why I tell people, 'don't give up on your dreams,'" Daly said. "Make smaller goals, make them achievable, and then just keep building it up. And look at what we've accomplished."

title: No end to this game?
author: Staff Writer

 With the introduction of the latest resolution by the Lesher/Melkie team, we again find ourselves at a new beginning in the ongoing attempt to control the growth in the Town of Trappe. Unfortunately, this "new" resolution is nothing more than a repackaging of the same resolutions we have watched the county wrestle with for more than a year with no outcome in sight.Changing a few numbers and giving it a new title does not in any way change the obvious intent of all this legislation, which is to keep the Lakeside development under the control of a minority group with their own agenda. What that agenda is has been unclear but obviously their intent is to drag out the process in any way they can to buy time for more interference.
A recent letter to the Star Democrat went so far as to imply that the Town of Trappe needs to be ready to build schools for the new students from Lakeside. Since when did small towns begin building and paying for their own schools? Isn't that a county function? I thought that's what we pay county taxes for?
The implication was that citizens in Talbot County shouldn't have to educate Trappe children. Does that mean Trappe taxpayers shouldn't pay for schools in other parts of the county? That is not how government works. What next? Does Trappe need to build it's own hospital?
I have paid county taxes for the 25 years since retiring here. I would like to know what my taxes go for. I see many expenditures approved at County Council meetings using funds that include my taxes. Why should I feel guilty when I expect to be treated like any other county citizen?
The Lakeside development is simply Trappe's attempt to make up for years of lackluster or nonexistent growth so that our town can enjoy a tax base that can provide the funding needed to function as a modern, financially stable municipality. The county also will benefit in the long run with additional residential and commercial taxes, more housing for county residents, not to mention jobs to reduce unemployment in the area.
Why doesn't anyone want to look at the positives of a planned development instead of focusing on the negatives? This whole situation has dragged out long enough and doesn't need new legislative smoke and mirrors in an attempt to drag it further. All of this waste of time and resources is an unnecessary cost we should not be forced to bear.
And on a final note, I really want to express my disbelief that Mr. Lesher and Ms. Melkie would insult the intelligence of their constituents by their attempt to blatantly force their old legislation through as something new, just by making such a minute change, which will only add one to three years more to an already time-consuming process.

title: It's time for Mid-Shore regional planning
author: DAVID REEL
content:
It's time for Mid-Shore regional planning

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Activate 
 
 588
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, the Greater Baltimore Committee (GBC) released a new 10-year strategic plan calling for (in their words), a "sea change," to boost economic opportunity in Baltimore city and five Maryland counties adjacent to Baltimore — Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Carroll, Harford and Howard.Founded in 1955, GBC is a not-for-profit organization with approximately 400 members.
Their membership includes large, mid-size and small businesses, not-for-profit organizations, foundations, educational providers and health care institutions in the Baltimore region.
All the geographic areas served by GBC are unique, but all recognize the value of mutually beneficial collaborative efforts on economic development matters.
In an ever-changing world, GBC 's new strategic plan acknowledged a pressing need for changes on a better definition of their traditional purposes and their traditional goals.
Accordingly, their new plan includes new purposes and new goals to guide private and public investment and regional collaborations designed to result in transformational positive change in the Baltimore region.
Specific GBC goals are included in three broad areas of economic development. They are:
Industry and innovation.Place and community.Talent and people.
Ultimately, GBC's vision is to position the Baltimore region's residents, businesses and quality of life amenities, as a globally recognizable and competitive brand.
The overall success of GBC's new plan is based not only on new purposes and new goals. It also depends upon on a continuing commitment to collaboration from businesses, political leaders, developers, educators, workforce providers, nonprofits, entrepreneurs, current economic development organizations and other key stakeholders in Baltimore City and the five surrounding counties.
Based on past measurable successes with GBC, they understand they do best by not competing against each other but by working together to compete globally for current and emerging economic engines that provide good jobs, good wages, good benefits and economic stability.
They also understand the needs of the leaders such economic engines. These leaders are much less interested in artificial human-made geographic boundaries that delineate county and municipal borders and are much more interested in what a region can provide in terms of a long-term, reliable and positive business environment along with a supply of skilled workers.
No doubt any discussion of any changes leading to a new regional approach to economic development for the Mid-Shore region may be unsettling to some. It is new, and it is different.
I suggest now is the time for the leaders in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties (at a minimum) to immediately engage in meaningful discussions on the feasibility and benefits of launching a Mid-Shore version of a regional economic development organization comparable to the GBC.
The key words are comparable to the GBC, not identical to the GBC.
I am not suggesting Mid-Shore leaders adopt GBC's purposes and goals without modifications that work best for the Mid-Shore now and going forward. I further suggest we already have an outstanding organization in place to serve as a new leader in regional economic development.
That organization is Chesapeake College.
The college has served the Mid Shore region with distinction since it was chartered as Maryland's first regional community college in 1965 and opened in 1967.
Offering a wide range of adult learning opportunities, they have extensive experience in developing and conducting workforce-training programs. The availability of these programs is great selling point for economic development prospects.
I also suggest that in addition to a new regional economic development organizational model, the Mid-Shore must have an open and transparent process for developing regional economic development goals based on citizen input to maintain and advance the Mid-Shore's position in Maryland as the "Land of Pleasant Living."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 782
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent flash flood tragedy in central Texas resulted in seeing the best and the worst of American society.The best has been an outpouring of sympathy, caring and support for the flood victims, their families and the survivors. There have been countless reports of selfless rescue and recovery efforts by first responders and volunteers, some from well beyond the immediate flooded area.
The worst has been numerous messages on social media and other media platforms — e.g., a newspaper editorial cartoon — that were vile, hateful and some of which were vulgar.
Many of them chose to blame Trump supporters or policy decisions of the Trump administration for this tragedy.
Far too many did not include expressions of sadness or sympathy for the deaths of innocent children and adults or compassion for the lifelong impact on all the flooding survivors.
The level of vitriol in these messages is so offensive, I will not repeat any of them in this column.
The only thing they have in common is they are devoid of any sense of decency and civility.
Somewhat surprising has been dismay and even outrage expressed from unexpected sources over these vile messages.
Nina Turner is a former national co-chair for the Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign.
She recently said, "It takes a serious lack of humanity to see children to be in a politicized discussion and respond something like lines of "that's what they [voters in Texas] voted for."
Turner's closing one word comment says it all — "Shameful."
John Favreau and Tommy Vietor are co-hosts on the left of center, Pod Save America.
Both worked for Barack Obama prior to and during his presidential administration.
Both have condemned social media posts that blame local Texans and the Trump administration for all who died as a result of the recent floods.
Favreau said: "I think the really gross stuff was, I saw some people be, like, 'Well, Texas, you voted for Trump, and this is what you get.'"
Favreau has challenged suggestions that staffing levels at the National Weather Service in Texas had anything to do with the tragedy. Favreau has said, "It seems like the National Weather Service, like I said, did send out a timely warning, it just didn't get to people. And that's, you know, not the Trump administration saying that; independent meteorologists and experts have all said this."
Vietor has said that while questions about the effect of weather services cuts could be "an important question going forward, I could have done without the, like, instant, you know, leap to blame name-your-political-opponent for this tragedy on Twitter."
The "blame your political opponent" campaign on this tragedy is already well underway.
Shortly after news broke on the flooding, Sen. Chuck Schumer demanded the Commerce Department's inspector general investigate vacancies at National Weather Service offices and whether the purported vacancies resulted in a higher death toll in in Texas.
Schumer has suggested that proposed but yet-to-be-implemented Trump budget cuts resulted in unfilled weather service positions in Texas were to blame. Sen. Chris Dodd has said likewise.
Schumer proclaimed: "The American people deserve answers."
Yes, we do, but not from you two or anyone who wants to advance a political agenda from this tragedy.
We deserve answers only if the following investigative guidelines are agreed to, in advance of, and are strictly adhered to during every phase of any investigation. At a minimum, the investigation must focus less on assigning blame for what happened or did not happen with regard to timely and effective flash flood alerts.
The laser like focus must be on what can be done going forward to help ensure it never happens again.
Differing opinions must be welcome and considered provided they follow the timeless observation of former U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who once said, "Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but not their own facts."
One new previously unreported fact comes from a recent Washington Post article headline — "Camp Mystic's leader got a 'life threatening' flood alert. They evacuated an hour later."
We also need to accept that we never have and never will live in a risk-free world.
We can only anticipate risks and take prudent steps to try to avoid them or deal with them if and when necessary. Accidents can never be totally avoided despite plans and best intentions.
Going forward, we desperately need a renewed universal commitment that when tragedies strike, to make sure social media posts and other public reactions reflect common decency and respect for each and every person impacted in any way by that tragedy.
This is especially vital in dealing with those who hold different political party affiliations or different views on a wide range of public policy issues.
We must do so if we have any hope of reversing the steadily declining levels of decency and civility in our society.

title: Suicide of a superpower
author: Staff Writer
content:
Suicide of a superpower

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 209
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm not sure that it's clear to everyone that one of Trump's cost-cutting measures is doing serious damage to our military power."Suicide of a superpower" is underway, to quote Max Boot in a recent Washington Post column.
Trump's attack on universities and other government-funded research programs is surrendering America's most powerful weapon, our scientific ability. With the help of scientists from abroad (immigrants like Einstein who spent the rest of his career as a physics professor at Princeton), the University of Chicago, Columbia, and Berkeley were major players in developing the atomic bomb that made us a superpower in the first place.
Not only have our scientists given us satellite radio, smart phones and the internet, which we rely on in Talbot County, they have also given us missile shields, drones and other smart weapons. Future conflicts will be fought with high-tech systems — not yesterday's weapons — and we must keep up with their development.
I can understand a certain amount of animosity toward the stereotype professor or scientist, but I can't understand why one would want to harm our research programs and universities, which are the envy of the world. We need to urge Andy Harris and other Eastern Shore leaders to push back against Trump's terrible mistake.
RALPH MEYER
Easton

 Mark Twain, or Samuel Langhorne Clemens if you prefer, had the right idea when he wrote, "Tell the truth or trump - but get the trick." Sometimes, though, strange as it sounds, you might have too many trumps. If so, you must do something to reduce the number. Today's deal features one such play technique.Against four spades, West led the club ace. When East signaled with the 10, West continued with the club king and a third club. East exited with the spade three: two, eight, king. How should South have continued?South's three-spade rebid was invitational. North, with the two top trump honors, had an automatic raise to game.With all of the side suits safe, declarer's only concern was the trump suit. If that was breaking 3-2, he would have no trouble, but what if East had started with four spades including the jack?(If West had jack-fourth, the contract was beyond resuscitation.) The only chance would be a trump coup. To reduce his trump length to the same as East's, South made the farsighted play of immediately cashing dummy's heart ace and ruffing a heart in his hand.After declarer had played a trump to dummy's ace, getting the bad news, he ruffed another heart in his hand. Then South cashed his three diamond tricks, ending in the dummy. Luckily, East had to follow suit throughout.South was left with the Q-10 in spades, and East had the J-5. title: States apart, Waterfowl artists build lasting friendships
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
States apart, Waterfowl artists build lasting friendships

 November 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 517
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jim Green and his wife, Kara, traveled from Hermosa, South Dakota, a small town with less than 400 people, to Easton this weekend. He's been bringing his wildlife sculptures to the Waterfowl Festival for around a decade.The South Dakota couple was stationed inside of the Waterfowl's main building for the Art at the Armory display. Directly across sat Carol Heiman-Greene and her husband, all the way from Orange, California.
The two artists and their respective spouses aren't just acquaintances. They're friends, or better yet, family.
"I come back year after year, and these are like my families," Heiman-Greene said of the fellow artists she's come to know. Kara Green used that exact same word — family — to describe her and her husband's friendship with the Heiman-Greenes and others.
Carol Heiman-Greene, who's been an exhibitor at the Easton festival for about 20 years, says there's a "core" of artists who have been at Waterfowl and other festivals for a long time. She said when new artists come, it's a joy to welcome them into the family, too.
On Saturday, Heiman-Greene pointed out her painting of a California condor vulture, laughing since Jim Green had a sculpture of a California condor for sale.
Through the ups and downs of travel, sales and weather, Heiman-Greene said artists have "all sorts of tales (they) can share" with one another.
"You come to these (festivals), and you see your friends from last year and years previous," Jim Green said. "It's so nice to connect with people."
Green says he loves those friendships with fellow artists not just for the relationships, but also to expand his work in an environment rich with creative ideas.
"You have a tendency to think of the world as built on artists when you come to these, because you see so many of them," he continued. "And then you get home and you're in this desert of nobody else around you that does this. So it's really nice to have that creativity, that creative aspect of things to bounce ideas off of other people."
For the Green couple, it's not a competitive environment. Last year, Jim Green said someone stopped by to let him know they recreated his raven coat rack sculpture.
"I know there are other artists that would kind of take that the wrong way," he said. "But I was like, 'Yeah, where are the pictures? I love that.'"
Both Carol Heiman-Greene and Jim Green said the people, atmosphere and weather at Waterfowl combine to make the festival one of their favorites. While Green said his sales are typically solid at Waterfowl, even if they weren't, the three-day event is still his "favorite one of the year."
"I love coming here to see the atmosphere and everything there is about Maryland," Heiman-Greene said. "It's really fun. It has such a small-town atmosphere."
Despite living states and plane rides apart, the annual Waterfowl Festival tradition has helped bring the Greens and Heiman-Greenes together as artists and friends. It's a trend Jim Green hopes continues for years to come.
"Art sells art," Jim Green said. "If you can't have all boats rise, you shouldn't be in the boat."

title: Drivers need patience on roadways
author: Staff Writer
content:
Drivers need patience on roadways

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a senior driver of 70 years driving experience I have finally reached my frustration point in what I (correctly or incorrectly) perceive as unwarranted impatience, if not absolute rudeness and discourtesy, on the part of drivers in Talbot County.I am a competent, not perfect, operator of a motor vehicle, and I do not understand the needs of many other drivers, younger ones in particular, to honk their horns, pass on the right side, ride your bumper or even pass on a double line when I take a needed extra second or two to double check when I am making a turn, entering an intersection, leaving a stop light, or driving at what I consider a safe 40 mph on the narrow, winding and crowned blacktop roads here, many of which have no shoulders only ditches.
You drivers who are speeding and tailgating in our county — and you, in my experience are many —will get where you are going without putting me or yourselves in danger. An absolutely unneeded honking horn is startling and rather than achieving its likely objective of hurrying me along and making me drive in the manner in which you think I should be driving actually slows me down when I look once more to reassess the situation around me before I move away from that light or stop sign or turn against traffic.
You will be senior drivers someday yourself, and you will understand certain facts — namely your reaction time slows a touch, your hearing and vision, though adequate for the task, are not what they used to be and your trust in your own cognition in discerning what is happening around you is quite naturally slightly diminished.
Talbot County and the town of Easton today present challenging driving conditions. The sheer volume of traffic, the narrow streets in town with double parking, and the plethora of large sized pickups and SUVs plying streets and roadways here that were not designed for these types of vehicles are factors, as well as the presence of some dangerous intersections lacking traffic controls — one of these is one I use daily, the intersection of the Parkway and Tristan Drive. I do not need an accident at my age, whether my fault or not. This is a major reason I (and many others of my age) need that extra moment of time to cope safely and competently with the driving situations already mentioned. And I can cope if I get just a minimum amount of cooperation from all of you others on the road.
JOEL S. STROBECK
Easton

 A new atrium exhibit at the Academy Art Museum debuts Friday, Sept. 15, and runs through August 2024.The exhibition is from South Dakota-based Oglaia Lakota artist Marty Two Bulls Jr.The exhibition "Marty Two Bulls Jr.: Dominion" examines America's "consumption culture, using the metaphor of the American Bison," according to a release from the Easton art museum."We are looking forward to welcoming visitors to Two Bulls, Jr.'s Atrium commission, which serves as a layered acknowledgment of the oppression Native American people have endured in their homelands as well as a critique of consumer culture. The breadth of Two Bulls, Jr.'s practice is incredible: from the immersive, floor-to-ceiling hand-cut prints he amasses on top of one another for his wall-mounted work, to monumental sculptures made from found objects such as bottles and trash cans, Two Bulls, Jr. conjures a mimesis of a crucial sociopolitical reality. We are excited for the interactive dimension of the exhibition, which will allow visitors to scan QR codes to learn the histories of some of the elements Two Bulls, Jr. incorporates into his work, such as barbed wire and the American bison," said AAM Curator Mehves Lelic.AAM's 2022-2023 Atrium Commission is supported by Carol Gordean, Joe Minarick in memory of Carol Minarick, and Mary Ann Schindler.For more: https://academyartmuseum.org/

title: Crusaders extend mastery over Sabres
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Crusaders extend mastery over Sabres

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 702
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Sam Gerdano really doesn't have an answer."I've never been able to beat St. Paul's," Saints Peter and Paul High's head ice hockey coach said. "I don't know what it is. I'm just haunted by that team."
Mason Kaplan netted a hat trick and helped set up both of Casey Burkom's goals Friday, as the Crusaders defeated the Sabres, 5-2, at the Talbot Community Center to clinch the second seed in next week's Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference playoffs.
St. Paul's (6-2-1) is scheduled to host third-seeded Sts. Peter & Paul (5-3-2) on Monday at 4 p.m. in an MIAA B semifinal at the Patterson Park Ice Rink in Baltimore.
"This has been a really fun season," Gerdano said. "We have a really young team. We have 11 freshmen out of 22 rostered. So it's not surprising that maybe they're lacking confidence at times."
The Crusaders controlled the neutral zone through the first period, and put half a dozen shots on goalie Maddie Maloney in the opening 3 minutes.
"It's exactly what we were asking for; a fast start," St. Paul's head coach Sean Baker said. "We wanted to get pucks behind their D, play down in their end at the beginning of the game to set the tone early."
Despite that dominance, Maloney (25 saves) didn't let anything past her until 3 minutes, 24 seconds remained in opening period, when Andrew Breslin and Burkom set up Kaplan's first goal.
St. Paul's extended that lead to 2-0 just 38 seconds into the second period, when Kaplan fed Burkom, who slipped the puck inside the left post.
"Goals in the first minute of the period and the last minute of the period are always big," Baker said. "You want to keep momentum for the beginning of the period and the end of the period. It's something that we talk about; first and last minute. We want to be the ones that score. We don't want to give anything up."
The Sabres cut their deficit to 2-1 with 3:44 left, as Drew Watson scored off a dish from Mason Roland. Sts. Peter & Paul went on the power play a little over a minute later, but put little pressure on St. Paul's goalie Andrew Dugas (13 saves). The Crusaders killed off the 2-minute minor. then immediately restored their two-goal cushion, as Kaplan — the MIAA B's goal-scoring leader with 21 — scored off Burkom's assist with 30.2 seconds left in the period.
"Obviously that's a big momentum shift, Gerdano said. "You cut the lead in half and they get one right back. That's a little bit of a gut punch. But it's a long game and we're always telling our players you just got to keep fighting to the end."
St. Paul's widened its lead to 4-1 with 1:53 elapsed in the third, as Kaplan and Nigel Wilson-Phillippi set up Burkom's second goal. That lead ballooned to 5-1 with 8:32 remaining, when Brendan Townsend and Burkom connected passes to set up Kaplan in the slot for his third goal.
"We seem to be peaking at the right time," said Baker, whose team has won three straight. "We're looking pretty good right now."
After a brief skirmish with a little under 7 minutes remaining left the Crusaders down a man, Sts. Peter & Paul's Buel Jenson scored unassisted with 6:45 to play. But the Sabres couldn't cut any further into their deficit.
"We absolutely came out flat," Gerdano said. "We were throwing the puck away like crazy. I think we were a little afraid to have the puck on our stick, not quite confident enough with the puck. A little uncharacteristic and it's something we can improve on going into next week. If we find that confidence and find good energy we can absolutely take it to that team.
"When they have that confidence you can tell, and we're really hard to play against," added Gerdano, whose team tied St. Paul's 2-2 earlier this season. "We have great goaltending. We're hard to score on and we got great defense. We just need to find ways to score. And if we do that we're going to be really hard to beat against anybody. We have the recipe."
Note: The Sabres have tied St. Paul's three times under Gerdano's direction.

title: An age in America comes to an end
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
An age in America comes to an end

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Columns 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The small town of Oroville, California, drifted into the 20th century as a shadow of its former self.Back in 1848, when gold was discovered in the area, prospectors had poured into the place. But by 1900 the vein had long since petered out, and the town had become little more than an agricultural backwater.
Meanwhile, the modern world marched on. In Los Angeles, California's first movie theater opened for business in 1902. The next year, the Wright brothers made the first heavier-than air flight at Kitty Hawk. And in 1908, Henry Ford brought the automobile within reach of everyday Americans when he introduced the reliable, relatively inexpensive Model T.
Still, news of these wonders would have arrived in Oroville as little more than rumors of a wider, more sophisticated world.
Then, on Aug. 29, 1911, a teenaged layabout named Floyd Hefner strode into the corral of the local slaughterhouse, intending to hitch up a team of horses, and found a nearly naked man leaning unsteadily against a fence-post. The last living member of a Native American tribe had come in from the cold.
Perhaps not surprisingly for the time and place, guns were drawn, dogs were held at bay, and someone used the telephone in the slaughterhouse to call the law. By the time the sheriff arrived, a butcher's cloak had been thrown over the shoulders of the man, who spoke no language anyone understood. The sheriff handcuffed the man, drove him into town in a wagon (the first time in his life he'd ever ridden in a wheeled vehicle), and locked him up in the county jail.
It wasn't long before newspapers throughout the state were reporting the discovery of America's "last wild Indian." Learning of the news, Alfred Kroeber, a renowned professor of anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley, sent a colleague, Thomas Waterman, up to Oroville.
Meeting with the prisoner in his cell, Waterman thought he might be speaking a language related to the Yana tongue. Waterman knew a little Yana, and when he tried it out on the prisoner, the man's face lit up.
For the first time since the only other members of his Yahi band had died, he had heard another human being speak a word or two he understood.
Waterman was able to ask the man his name. Using a combination of gestures and simple Yahi, the man explained that in his culture it was taboo to speak his name aloud to someone else until another member of his tribe had formally introduced him. As this was now impossible, Waterman ended up simply calling him "Man" in the Yahi tongue.
And so it is that this Native American man comes down to us in history under the false name of "Ishi." We will never know what his real name was.
Waterman's fellow professor at Berkeley, Alfred Kroeber, was a remarkable man. He had earned his doctorate in 1901 from Columbia University, studying under Franz Boaz, the father of modern anthropology. Kroeber took Ishi in and gave him a place to live in the university's museum, where Ishi worked as a janitor. This allowed Kroeber and the other anthropologists in his department to study Ishi closely over the remaining five years of his life.
You might expect that much of what Kroeber and Waterman learned from Ishi would have been horrifying. This was a man who, from boyhood, watched his tribe and immediate family whittled down by ceaseless slaughter. Norman Kingsley, an eager participant in one of the last massacres, later recounted that, in the middle of his attack, he exchanged his .56 caliber Spencer rifle for a .38 caliber pistol, because the rifle "tore them up so bad," especially the babies.
But after his introduction into modernizing California, accounts say Ishi didn't speak of the horrors he'd witnessed, nor did he give in to melancholy or despair. He adapted with grace to his new life and embraced many of the changes happening in the world around him.
I learned of Ishi from Alfred Kroeber's wife and fellow anthropologist Theodora Kracaw Kroeber, who, in 1961, wrote "Ishi in Two Worlds," now considered a classic of modern anthropology. I first read the book 40 years ago, and rereading it recently, I found myself placing Theodora Kroeber in the same league as Claude Lévi-Strauss. Without ever leaving any of her anthropological principles behind, she consistently writes clear, compelling prose.
It isn't easy reading the first part of Kroeber's book, watching as Ishi and the remaining members of his band are forced to withdraw further and further from the whites encroaching upon their world; until, finally, they retreat into that world's last untouched cañon, and, ultimately, its last bushy slopes.
But Kroeber's description of the way Ishi handles the world he is then brought into, the way he maintains his Yahi dignity in the face of that world's awesome power (while never losing his ability to see through its sometimes absurd idiosyncrasies) is somehow reassuring. It gave me hope for humanity at large.
I reread "Ishi in Two Worlds" thanks to an Inter-Library Loan, but a copy of the book has now been placed in our collection at the Talbot County Free Library. You'll find it in the Easton library on the Biography shelves under the call letters ISHI. If you're in St. Michaels, you can place a reserve on the book and it will be sent down there for you.

title: Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 981
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Pew Research Center survey reports that 95% of teenagers in America have a smart phone or have access to one. It also reports that 45% of teenagers say they are online nearly all the time.Many have suggested this has resulted in a measurable and serious negative impact on the learning environment in middle and high school classrooms. Others have suggested this has resulted in a serious negative impact on standardized student achievement test scores.
As a result, countless school districts in America have put or will be putting new or more restrictions on student smart phones during the school day. Two-thirds of schools in Maryland have already. Talbot County is joining them. Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will will require students to lock their phones in secure pouches during the school day.
These restrictions have significant public support. Surveys conducted by the Talbot County school district reported 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
While I understand and respect these opinions, I suggest restrictions in schools are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts among American youth.
I understand and respect these decisions. At the same time, I suggest they are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression, and suicidality among American youth.
In his book Haidt references research showing a measure of anxiety for individuals between ages of 8 to 25 has increased 139% between 2010 and 2020.The measure for depression during the same period, often the result of an inability to resolve interpersonal conflicts or relationship difficulties, has increased 106%.
Haidt suggests three reasons why.
The first is the decline of the what Haidt calls play-based childhood. He maintains children need lots of free play time to prepare them for success as an adult. Out of fears for their safety, many American parents and guardians have reduced children's access to unsupervised free play. The loss of free play and the rise of continual (some may say "smothering") adult supervision has deprived children of what they needed most to overcome the normal fears and anxieties of childhood: the chance to explore, test and expand their limits, build close friendships through shared adventure and learn how to judge risks for themselves.
The second is what Haidt calls rise of the phone-based childhood, which began in the late 2000s and accelerated in the early 2010s. Haidt notes this was precisely the period during which adolescents traded in their flip phones for smartphones. These smartphones were loaded with social media platforms supported by the new high-speed internet and unlimited data plans that has drastically reshaped the social media landscape for adolescents.
The third is what Heidt calls an over reliance on technology that has all but eliminated unstructured face to face interactions from the lives of children and adolescents.
Heidt concludes the negative impact of all three reasons was made worse by many well-intentioned parents, including himself. He writes: "We did not fully understand what was happening in children's virtual worlds and did not grasp that tech companies had designed their online products to be addictive."
As a result, Haidt asserts that all these trends combined, have robbed entire generations of opportunities to develop the resilience, coping skills and independence needed to navigate everyday stressors, and in turn, created unprecedented levels of anxiety at a societal level.
He says these generations have not learned from valuable opportunities to engage in and learn from manageable risks, typical setbacks, failures and healthy social challenges.
What can be done going forward?
Haidt offers the following proactive suggestions for parents and guardians of children in elementary, middle and high schools.
Instead of a giving younger students a smartphone as their first phone, give them a basic phone.
Do not give them a smartphone until high school. Delay the opening of accounts on nearly all social media platforms until the beginning of high school, at least.
Will his suggestions be popular with students? Not likely, especially given the immense power of peer pressure that characterizes life for students in schools at all levels.
One school in Maryland recently surveyed seniors on a new more restrictive smart phone policy to limit the overuse of smart phones during the school day. The questions and answers were: "Do you know overuse of cell phones is harmful? Yes. Do you want to give it up? No."
Are Haidt's suggestions still necessary since efforts are underway when an increasing number of schools are adopting on new or more restrictive rules on smart phone access? Yes.
Despite best intentions and best efforts, schools alone cannot address this problem. One Maryland school district superintendent has observed with thinly disguised frustration — "Students are in school for just 20% of their week. We can't control the other 80% of the time that we don't have them."
Those with some control over most of the other 80% of student's time outside of school are parents and guardians.
Going forward, parents and guardians need to fully embrace two concepts. Success for them is not based on winning a popularity contest with those whom they are entrusted with their care and upbringing. Success for them is measured in part by a willingness to make sometimes unpopular, but necessary decisions on reasonable limits for a young person's own good.
In preparing all our young people for success, they, and our society deserve nothing less.

title: Annual Back to School Resource Fair: Preparing students for success
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Annual Back to School Resource Fair: Preparing students for success

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, over a thousand people gathered at Idlewild Park for the annual Back to School Resource Fair hosted by For All Seasons.For All Seasons partnered with the Talbot County Department of Social Services to provide families with hundreds of backpacks pre-stuffed with supplies for students. This event not only contributes to the care of students of all ages, but it creates community for residents throughout Easton.
Beth Anne Dorman, president and chief executive officer at For All Seasons, said the resource fair has become one of the largest community events in Easton, bringing together over 25 different organizations and over 1,700 people.
"We are really taking care of all of the kids in the ways that set them up for success," Dorman said. "For school, mental health isn't just about our mental health and talk therapy, but it's also about making sure that children have what they need to be able to show up at the school year authentically and with some safety."
In addition to the school supplies provided by For All Seasons, dozens of organizations set up tables and provided rulers, pens, dental care kits, notebooks and over a hundred children's books.
Marilou Russ, assistant director for Appleseed Books, said the organization provides free children's books to families across the Eastern Shore by collecting donated books.
"We come to programs and events throughout the counties on the mid shore, which would include Caroline, Talbot and now even Dorchester County, and then we give the children out the free books so that they have books," Russ said. "Our belief is that they have their own collection of books that they can call their own."
Included in the event, families had the opportunity to enjoy games, free Rita's Italian Ice, and arts and craft activities.
Mayra Casillas, an event attendee, said she just moved to the area and learned of the fair on Facebook. For Casillas, it seemed a great opportunity to engage with her new community and for her children to have fun.
"It's also great to have backpacks and a bunch of other school supplies," Casillas said. "It helps families that don't have the income to buy for their kids."
Dorman said the event has grown significantly since its origin six years ago. It has reached the point where For All Seasons will be expanding the venue for next year since it has become too crowded for Idlewild Park. Dorman said she is proud of this event and the amount of people it assists.
"There are times where we have an opportunity to dig in a little bit deeper as a community," Dorman said. "This is an example of when we think outside of the box, and we really think about the whole person when we're thinking about mental health. It gives us an opportunity to make a difference in a way that maybe is not going to happen in the four walls of an office, but this is real community outreach and community connection and partnership."

title: Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum celebrates 60 years
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum celebrates 60 years

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 737
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST.MICHAELS — A staple of St. Michaels, the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum is celebrating 60 years.Volunteers spearheaded the creation of the museum, which opened in 1965 at Navy Point and was accredited in 1978.
"The museum really started out by a community effort," said Pete Lesher, chief historian and ambassador at large at the museum. "The collections were built with an outpouring from the community over the idea that the place is changing and we need to establish a museum to remember the way it was."
Lesher, came to the museum in 1991 as a curator. He said the museum was created in a "series of themes" to represent the Bay and people around the it.
MUSEUM HISTORY
The museum started in May 1965 with two buildings that had been on the grounds since 1850 the Higgins house and the Dodson house. The eagle house building arrived in 1870. The three buildings now serve as administrative buildings after serving as exhibit buildings for nine years in the early days.
According to Lesher, the land where the museum's lighthouse and other exhibits now sit was reclaimed from the Bay.
"This was just a shallow part of the park," Lesher said. "You would have been standing probably knee deep sinking into mud about 150 years ago.
"This area started with actually a sawmill and grist mill but moved beyond that to seafood packing houses, and by the height here in the 1930s and 1940s, there were four different seafood packing houses out on this point. Every time they wanted to expand, they simply discarded more oyster shells, which they end up on themselves, pushing them into the harbor and built more land."
William Coulbourne and Frederick Jewett were two African American business owners who owned one of the four businesses on the land.
"They were early 20th century Black entrepreneurs from Crisfield, Maryland, who moved up here," Lesher said. "They learned the business and managed to get somebody to sell them land and managed to get somebody to give them a bank loan — a remarkable success story."
The museum plans to honor Coulbourne and Jewitt by renaming its education building after the two entrepreneurs.
The lighthouse, which is featured in the museum's logo, is the first historical structure the museum collected. It was acquired in 1966 when the Coast Guard was demolishing lighthouses "left and right" because of vandalism, according to Lesher.
The museum bought the lighthouse from the demolition company and moved it 50 miles north to the museum site.
"It was so early in our history, it became our logo," Lesher said. "The lighthouse is sort of what identifies the museum."
One of the new changing exhibits at the museum is the Sailing to Freedom exhibit, which highlights the Underground Railroad on the water.
"So we think of the Underground Railroad like the Harriet Tubman story of running up the Delmarva Peninsula to get to Philadelphia and freedom," Lesher said.
"Well, a lot of people made it by boat, whether they got a ticket on a steamboat, got away that way or stowed away on a coast-wise schooner, so many of them on the Chesapeake Bay, while the Chesapeake Bay forms a natural watery highway to the north. This was a route to freedom for many of those freedom seekers," he said. "That's what we try to show with this exhibit."
HELPING THE COMMUNITY
In addition to exhibits for museum-goers, the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum uses some exhibits to help with the curriculum in Talbot County schools.
An exhibit displaying the Maryland Crab Meat Company sits where the museum holds the Chesapeake's Best Crab Cakes program, in which third and fifth graders receive math, reading and social studies credits in the curriculum.
"The Chesapeake's Best Crab Cakes program meets learning goals for for math, for reading and for social studies in the Maryland curriculum," Lesher said. "Every Talbot County third grader and fifth grader has an experience tied to their curriculum, tied to their learning goals right here in the museum."
The museum also conducts an apprenticeship program where museum staff work with an apprentice for two years, ultimately leading to a state credential.
According to Lesher, the museum has hired some of these apprentices as permanent shipyard crew.
The museum has partnered with the St. Michaels Community Center on multiple occasions.
"We're working to do more community collaborations with them because both our missions align, and we want to enrich the lives of people who live in St. Michaels," said Amy Horne, executive director of the community center.

title: St. Michaels Police Chief says salaries need to be raised for officer recruitment, retention
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels Police Chief says salaries need to be raised for officer recruitment, retention

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — During the St. Michaels Commissioners meeting on Wednesday, St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald said the police department will lose an 18-year veteran officer to another municipality. The officer, he said, is leaving for better pay."I'm coming up on my 24th year here, three as chief, and during this time, I've seen 43 officers come and go in our agency," Oswald said. "Obviously, there are several factors that contribute to some of the turnover, but the prominent and consistent driver from the exit interviews has been paying upward mobility."
Starting on Thursday, the St. Michaels Police Department will be operating with only four officers, excluding Oswald.
Oswald mentioned one of the reasons that officers leave besides salary is opportunities larger departments can provide.
"They have criminal investigation divisions, they have training divisions dedicated solely to ensure officers meet certifications, qualifications and criminal updates… and remember, each of these on their own is a full-time specially trained position," Oswald said. "... Every St. Michaels Police Department (officer) must be able to perform every one of these rules at any given time, and therefore, after a few years, an officer builds a strong resume and they take it to another agency who's more than happy to pay them some extra money."
Oswald suggested potentially hiring a police recruiting firm and raising wages commensurate to officers' total years of service.
"We're a good place to have an opportunity to do a reset because there's only four of us remaining," Oswald said.
According to Town Manager Don Richardson, the police department has four openings with two each at the corporal and sergeant level.
With potential salary raises, the cost would be north of $200,000 for the town to properly recruit and retain officers, Richardson said.
Commissioner Alexis Roiter mentioned accommodation taxes, which are paid by tourists who stay at hotels or rental properties, as a potential revenue source for police department needs. Commissioner David Wojciechowski mentioned allocating funds from town events.
The commissioners agreed to draft legislation allowing for salary amendments so the St. Michaels Police Department can become competitive in hiring and retention. The measure would have to go through the town's typical legislative process, which would include public hearings, before it can be adopted.
"Thank you for supporting this important need for the town of St. Michaels and our community," Richardson said. "It will ultimately require some level of budgeting amendment that will absolutely go through a public comment period and a legislative ordinance."
The town encourages anyone interested in joining the St. Michaels Police Department to contact the town for further instruction.

title: 'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After nearly a year without a permanent town manager, Easton will welcome Andy Kitzrow next month.Kitzrow, the current Salisbury city administrator, was tapped by Mayor Megan Cook to assume the post from Police Chief Alan Lowrey, the interim town manager since August. Kitzrow begins July 7.
During an interview in Salisbury last week, Kitzrow said he instantly noticed opportunity in Easton.
"The more I looked at Easton, the more I started to fall in love with where they're going," Kitzrow said.
The new town manager is Cook's most major appointment in her two years as mayor. Kitzrow will oversee town operations, lead department heads and town staff, and be a point of contact with the mayor and Town Council members.
After whittling down a list of around 12 semifinalists, the town conducted full-day interviews with four finalists. It was an intensive but worthwhile process, Cook said.
She felt Kitzrow rose above the others, as he was up to speed on what's happening in Easton and meshed well with her and with town employees.
"(Staff) really thought of the candidates, he could get up and running the fastest because he had the background of Maryland politics," Cook said.
Kitzrow, 42, served as Wicomico County recreation superintendent before becoming Salisbury's deputy city administrator in 2017 and city administrator in 2023.
In Salisbury, Kitzrow worked under three different mayors, including Jake Day, now the Department of Housing and Community Development secretary. Day noted Kitzrow's oversight of city permit and procurement operations as especially impactful.
"It's not easy work, but he's a proven leader," Day said of Kitzrow. "Somebody who can do it."
Cook says while the Day connection didn't factor into her decision, it will benefit Easton as the town tackles its own housing challenges and initiatives.
"Having that relationship, I think, is great. It's key," Kitzrow said. "A lot of this is about relationships, whether they are elected officials or state officials."
A BETTER FIT
Working under three different mayors, Kitzrow says he's experienced three very different visions.
In early 2023, Day left Salisbury with then-city administrator Julia Glanz to head up the state's housing and community development efforts. Jack Heath served as mayor until current Mayor Randy Taylor won an election later that year.
During Day's tenure, Salisbury undertook a number of efforts to redevelop its downtown through programs providing tax incentives to developers, such as "Here is Home" and HORIZON — the latter aimed at bringing multifamily residential and hotel units, an initiative which Kitzrow championed.
"(He was) the mastermind behind the HORIZON legislation that we passed locally," Glanz said.
Taylor and developers have clashed in recent months over the stalling of downtown projects, some of which were approved by former mayors and councils. In April, DelmarvaNow.com reported that developers of a downtown project filed a $40 million lawsuit against Salisbury and Taylor.
While Kitzrow believes the change in vision is OK and can be solved through compromise, he acknowledges it factored into his choice to accept the Easton post. Neither Taylor nor Heath could be reached for an interview.
"Professionally and personally, the town that Megan wants to run and her goals align more with what I value and what I want to be part of," Kitzrow said.
GOALS IN EASTON
Salisbury's population is nearly double Easton's, but Kitzrow sees similar challenges and opportunities in the two areas.
He said he wants to "move projects forward in a smart way." In Salisbury, he's dealt with a housing pipeline of around 5,000 units and led a focus on building "from the inside out." Easton's pipeline has recently hovered around 1,000 units.
Kitzrow is hoping to bring a focus to Easton's Rails to Trails network, given his parks and recreation background, as well as get "under the hood" in the human resources department.
Cook said she's excited to bring on a consistent leader during what she says has been a year full of change in town. "I'm looking forward to a steady ship ... and some calm seas ahead," Cook said.
Working for the mayor, Kitzrow emphasized that strong relationships with the Town Council will be crucial in completing the work that will make Easton a better place.
"We are working together, not against each other, and I think that's important," Kitzrow said.
Kitzrow will remain living in Salisbury with his wife and kids. He owns Escape Salisbury, a downtown escape room business.
But he's looking to learn as much about Easton as possible. He said he's especially excited to meet business owners, nonprofit leaders and community members in his first 60 days on the job.

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III is planning to enter a plea deal in August rather than standing trial for charges related to a fire at his home on Peach Orchard Road in Easton.At a virtual status hearing Tuesday, Judge Thomas G. Ross scheduled a plea hearing for Aug. 19, the first day of when Rider's trial was supposed to begin, and a sentencing hearing for October.
Rider is accused of setting his house on fire in November 2022.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary. According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put more than 45 firefighters who responded in danger as they suppressed the fire.
At the status hearing Tuesday, Talbot County Assistant State's Attorney Jennifer Wilson said Rider plans to plead guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment. She said the state plans to enter nolle prosequi for Rider's remaining nine charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
Rider's attorney Christine DuFour, who took over from attorney Stephanie Shipley in April, said Rider's divorce proceedings with Kari Rider are happening parallel to this case. She said it would be helpful to know the outcome of the divorce before Rider is handed a sentence because the divorce will have an affect on the sentencing.
The sentencing was scheduled for Oct. 4, a little over a week after the final hearing in Rider's divorce process.
Wilson said the state is not opposed to Rider being handed suspended consecutive sentences for the reckless endangerment counts. DuFour said the state could seek restitution in the plea agreement, but that has not been determined.
Rider was supposed to stand trial March 4, but at a status hearing that morning, Ross said Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning. After getting discharged, Rider was granted a request to be transferred to an alcohol and drug rehab facility for 60 days, with the condition that he return to the Talbot County Detention Center upon completing the program.
On May 14, the detention center was ordered to release Rider on a previously posted $20,000 unsecured bond. Rider was released on conditions including that he surrender his passport, he reside in a sober living home in Pasadena, he attend Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and he enroll in mental health services.

title: Easton planners: amid affordable housing shortage, inclusionary zoning may be useful
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton planners: amid affordable housing shortage, inclusionary zoning may be useful

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1134
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Through her work at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, Daisy Aguilar interacts with many prospective first-time homebuyers. Of the many challenges they face, housing prices in Easton and Talbot County are at the top of the list."The houses, they're not affordable right now," Aguilar, the center's housing coordinator, said. "And most people that are buying, they're buying in Dorchester County because it's more affordable than it is in Talbot County."
An inclusionary zoning ordinance in the works could pave the way for more affordable homeownership and rental opportunities in Easton. It would require residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable, defined separately for ownership and rental.
Inclusionary units in ownership developments would need to meet an affordable price for households making up to 100% of area median income, while rental developments would need to meet prices affordable for households making up to 60% of area median income.
According to Jim Bent, chair of the Affordable Housing Board, Easton's area median income was around $98,000 last year.
While similar legislation has faced hurdles in the past, town leaders and affordable housing proponents are hopeful the time is now for inclusionary zoning to be implemented.
EASTON'S WORKFORCEEaston Mayor Megan Cook is well aware of the fact many can't afford to live in town, including essential workers, town employees and police officers.
"When you're sworn to protect and serve a community, yet you can't even live in the community that you're dedicating your life to, that says something," Cook said. "That's not quite the message we should be sending people."
According to the draft ordinance, Census data shows that 42% of around 17,000 Talbot County workers commute into the county. Cook and others are hoping the ordinance can lower that percentage.
"A lot of the people who work in those fields earn wages where they have been priced out of the Easton market, and so their only option is to find housing in adjacent counties," said Miguel Salinas, Easton's director of planning and zoning.
For homebuyers, the local market is a significant challenge. According to the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors, the average home price in Talbot County in 2024 was $856,000.
Town staff's calculation of the maximum affordable home price for a family of four making the area median income is $292,000.
"There was a time, a couple years, not too long ago, that houses were affordable," Aguilar said. "I mean, they were selling fast, but they were affordable. And at least you had the possibility of actually getting a house."
THE ORDINANCESalinas, who has led the town's efforts to create the ordinance, recognizes it is just one piece of the puzzle. But it's a critical step, he said.
"This is one tool in the toolbox. And it's been discussed for 20-plus years," Salinas said.
Since it was initially presented in February 2023, Salinas said the ordinance has endured many revisions, along with being viewed by the town's Affordable Housing Board, Attainable Housing Task Force and an outside contractor.
Town planners looked at similar provisions in jurisdictions such as Queen Anne's County, Annapolis and Frederick when drafting the ordinance.
A draft version of the inclusionary housing ordinance was passed 4-1 by the town's Planning Commission last November.
Planning Commission member Michael Ports, speaking for himself and not the commission, said the inclusionary zoning ordinance would do two things particularly well. It would push the "cost burden predominantly away from existing residents" and incentivize developers to build inclusionary units.
In addition to the requirement that 15% of units fit the inclusionary definitions, the ordinance would grant developers that provide inclusionary units on the same site as market-rate units with a 20% density bonus.
Such aspects of the ordinance encourage mixed-income projects, which town leaders believe can help to reduce housing inequities.
"Housing segregation opens the door to other types of segregation, and you can certainly see that in many, many communities," Salinas said. "But not just racial and ethnic, but also age."
Tom Klein, the Planning Commission's sole vote against the ordinance, says he is a proponent of more affordable and workforce housing. He believes inclusionary zoning is not "necessary nor a cost-effective way" to achieve that goal.
"For the past two years that I have been on the Planning Commission, just about every new development proposal has come with a component of affordable/workforce housing," Klein wrote in an email.
Recent developments that provide the town with affordable housing include projects from The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, such as Port Street Commons, a multi-use property with nine affordable apartment units that opened in December, and Silo Square, a mixed-income housing project greenlit in October.
Revitalization of the Doverbrook Apartments complex in Easton is underway and will feature an additional 14 affordable units on top of 50 existing ones. On Elliott Road, more than 100 apartments are under construction, a portion of those affordable.
Last July, the town approved the annexation of 17 acres of land for a housing project on the east side of Route 50. In the annexation agreement, developers agreed at least 50% of the project's apartment units will be affordable.
Given the number of ongoing projects, Klein says he feels inclusionary zoning would not "provide a significant number" of additional affordable units.
But Ports believes the ordinance will ensure that the limited supply of undeveloped land in the town is being used properly.
"It's really the biggest asset any community has," Ports said. "If we want to allow someone to potentially change it forever, we need to make sure that they're investing in the community in some way."
REGULATIONAt the November Planning Commission meeting, Klein and other commission members expressed concerns of overregulation prior to voting on the ordinance.
"I think that the market's taking care of it," Klein said. "I think that we're putting a lot of regulation here. Like I said, I think there could be a lot of unintended consequences that come out of that and a lot of cost for what we get out of it."
Salinas and Bent both said the market hasn't been able to address ballooning home and rental costs in recent years.
Bent said he's heard from planning commissioners in the past that a "tool" is needed to point developers toward what the town wants in terms of affordability.
While proponents of inclusionary zoning are confident it can be this tool, they recognize the housing problem in Easton is complex.
"If we got into this hole of housing deficiency over the course of decades, it's impossible to fix that in one year, let alone even 10 years," Ports said. "It will be a game of playing catch-up."
Cook hopes Easton residents, along with the Town Council, see affordable housing as a top challenge to tackle.
"I do hope that they see the importance of this issue, and I also hope that the community itself sees the importance of the issue," Cook said. "For the longevity and the vibrancy of the Town of Easton, it's an important issue."

title: Free family fun to ring in the new year at First Night Talbot
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Free family fun to ring in the new year at First Night Talbot

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 667
 Words

 EASTON - This year will mark three decades of First Night Talbot.And for the event's 30th year, First Night Talbot is sparing nothing to make Dec. 31 a special night for everyone.
Deena Kilmon, director of strategic initiatives at Easton Economic Development, said the event, which starts at 6 p.m., is "amazingly fun," inclusive and free.
"All the venues are handicap accessible," she said. "It's alcohol-free, drug-free. So if you wanted to go to a family-friendly happy, fun celebration out in your community, that's what this is." This year, even the buttons for participants are free. Kilmon said that while the collectable buttons have been something for purchase in the past, they are free of charge this year.
"A lot of people collect them, and this is the 30th-year button," Kilmon said.
The buttons are available at the Easton Visitor Center on Harrison Street. They can be picked up the day of the event or anytime before that. The center is open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Monday through Friday and 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Saturdays.
This year will be Improv Easton's first time performing at First Night Talbot.
Kilmon said that aside from the crab drop, Improv Easton is a can't miss experience.
"They have been practicing and practicing and practicing for months," Kilmon said. "I think that's going to be a great show." Kilmon said there will also be more arts and crafts activities for children at the Waterfowl Building this year.
And although this is not Mike Elzey's first rodeo at First Night Talbot, this will be his first year at the Town Hall venue.
"It's kind of like a private concert venue versus being out in the open," Kilmon said of the change.
From 6 p.m. to 8:45 p.m. at Town Hall, there will be a student showcase from Mike Elzey's Guitar Studio students. From 9:15 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., Elzey will host an air guitar competition with prizes.
Along with the Waterfowl Building and Town Hall, there will also be performances at the Avalon Theater throughout the night.
But the main event of the night is the crab drop - an 8-foot-wide Maryland blue crab sculpture created by Rich and Suzanne Hood 19 years ago - that will drop at 9 p.m. and at midnight.
First Night Talbot Program Chair Carolyn Jaffe said that when the crab reaches the bottom of the rig, it lights up the numbers for the new year.
"It's just the greatest," Jaffe said. "Everybody loves it - to take pictures of each other in front of the crab drop when it's lit up like that." This year, USA Today ranked First Night Talbot's crab drop the 6th best New Year's Eve drop in the nation.
"They actually had the New York City drop included in that," Jaffe said. "But they weren't in the top 10." At an Easton Town Council meeting Monday, Jaffe was honored for her many years of contributions to First Night Talbot.
Kilmon said making the entire First Night Talbot event free gives everyone the opportunity to enjoy the event.
"All the stuff that's happening is going to be no charge to the families," she said. "We certainly just want them to come out and enjoy their community." More information on First Night Talbot can be found on Facebook@FirstNightTalbot Inc. on on Discover Easton's website.
Questions can also be directed to the Easton EDC at 410-690-7348 or welcome@discovereaston.com.
