title: Museum seeks information on mystery device
author: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com
content:
Museum seeks information on mystery device

 August 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 426
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE - Volunteers at Trappe's Rural Life Museum are puzzled and looking for answers after an antique device was recently left on museum grounds.The mystery is twofold, said museum board of directors President Elizabeth Ferguson, and includes questions about the device's original purpose and who brought it to the facility.The item in question is a wooden implement that appears to have been used as some kind of press, as it includes an arm that raises and lowers a wooden punch into a metal reinforced hole.The implement does have some metal hardware, and it includes a large block of wood used as the base.The round house is between one to two inches, and there are non-structural boards nailed to upright supports under the punch area, possibly forming an area that was easier to clear of punched material.Ferguson said the antique was left in the museum's Carriage House building a few days ago. The ancillary building is under renovation, and the wooden device was put in before locks were installed on the new door.She posted a picture on social media on Wednesday seeking information on the bifurcated conundrum of source of donation and original use.Unravelling riddles is not the only mission underway at RLM - the building the device was deposited in is in the final stages of renovation.Ferguson said the building has had many purposes over the years, but probably not for the storage of a carriage. The building, damaged in a 2020 storm, saw the renovation begin in 2021.The building was a notion shop at one point, and it was moved to its current location on Backtown Road from Trappe's Main Street around 1900.It also served as housing for migrant workers, who slept in the loft, and was also used as an office and possibly a garage for the canning facility previously located on what is now the museum grounds.Anyone with information on what the device is or where it came from is asked to email rurallifemuseum@gmail.com or call 410-476-4857.More information about the Rural Life Museum is available online at trapperurallifemuseum.org.

 ANNAPOLIS — News organizations across the region were recognized with awards for work they produced over the past year. The editorial and marketing staff of APG Media of Chesapeake garnered 19 awards in 16 categories.The awards were announced during the Maryland-Delaware-DC Press Association's annual ceremony Friday, May 3, in Annapolis. The association represents over 100 member news media organizations in the region. The contest recognizes the best print and online work completed in 2023.
The contest, governed by the MDDC's editorial and advertising committees, admitted over 1,550 entries among 86 categories. There are seven divisions in the contest, which group member publications into daily and non-daily print and online-only categories, then further group them by circulation. The entries were judged by news media professionals at the New Jersey Press Association.
The Star Democrat took home a total of nine awards in the Division C category.
Reporter Maggie Trovato took home first place in the Business Reporting category. Reporter Connie Connolly won the top prize for the Series category. Reporter Tom McCall came in second place in the Breaking News Photo and reporter Natalie Jones took home second place in the Breaking News category.
Designer Meredith Moore took home the top prizes in the Advertising-driven Special Section and News-driven Special Section categories. The Star Democrat's marketing team took home the first place in the Special Niche Website category, and the newspaper's marketing, advertising and editorial teams were recognized with second place wins in the Advertising-driven Special Publication and News-driven Special Section categories.
The Star Democrat also took home this year's Best Move award, a top award given across all divisions, for last year's Women to Watch Summer Speaker Series. The award highlights the most important thing MDDC member organizations did in 2023.
APG Chesapeake's other newspapers also took home prizes.
In Division C, the Cecil Whig's Matt Hubbard came in first place in the Education Reporting and Medical/Science Reporting categories. Whig Sports Editor Patrick LaPorte took home second place in the Sports Story category, and Whig reporter Carl Hamilton came second in the Feature Story: Profile category.
In Division E, Southern Maryland News' Mike Reid took home second place in both the Series and Feature Story: Profile categories.
In Division F, The Newark Post's editor, Josh Shannon, won first place in the Continuing Coverage category and second place in the Religion Reporting and General Website of Excellence categories.
"I am proud of the work our staff has done over the past year," APG Chesapeake Executive Editor Jim Johnson said. "The awards are a nice culmination to the year, but we have great stories, photos and advertisements in our newspapers and on our websites every day. The real winners are our readers."

title: Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday afternoon, the HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton was filled with hums and songs.The annual holiday concert led by TiShawna Jordan, a local musician, was an effort to provide holiday cheer and acted as an intervention to benefit those living with loss of memory.
Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton partnered with the Chesapeake Center in order to provide support for elderly individuals through volunteer-led events such as the holiday concert.
Erin Lewis, director of career services at Chesapeake Center, said TiShawna Jordan's concerts have provided holiday cheer and positive memory recollection to those in the Bridge to Rediscovery program.
"Watching her perform throughout the year with the people in the memory clinic. She brings them back to life," Lewis said. "They start singing, they start dancing, they remember all the words to each one of the songs. It's wonderful to see how she can interact. It's almost like a different way of communicating."
According to Northwestern University, musical intervention has therapeutic benefits for people with dementia or Alzheimer's disease and has been proven to decrease a patient's agitation and improve communication.
Megan Pinder, director of sales and marketing for HeartFields Assisting Living, said HeartFields had begun partnering with the Chesapeake Center about two years ago. The volunteer-led programs began with a bird club where volunteers come to the Heartfields and fill up the 41 bird feeders every week for the residents to enjoy.
Then TiShawna, an active volunteer at the Chesapeake Center, began to come and play music for residents at HeartFields.
According to Pinder, the first holiday concert was a resounding success, and TiShawna Jordan was presented with roses by the HeartFields Resident Ambassador because her playing had moved many attendees to tears.
Elsie Jordan, mother of TiShawna Jordan, said her daughter was always musically inclined. As a child she would play the keyboard, and Elsie Jordan said she would help her daughter learn new music through humming songs.
During the concert, Elsie Jordan sat next to her daughter humming and singing along to classic Christmas songs such as "White Christmas" and "Jingle Bell Rock." At some points they would both sing, encouraging the crowd of attendees to raise their voices and fully enjoy the memory of the holidays.
"God gave her that gift, and I want her to share her gift with other people," Elsie Jordan said. "Because if it wasn't for God, she wouldn't have the gift she has. I feel like it's a gift and you shouldn't have to be paid for something you love doing. And she loves playing."

title: All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure
author: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 4A | Section: News 
 
 950
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The pumpkin spice lattes are flowing, and post-Halloween pumpkins are getting chunked.But there's still interest in family road trips, especially to destinations where the annual changing of the leaves is at its peak.A study by lawn care specialist LawnStarter reveals the top states for leaf peeping and other fall-related activities. Beyond Oktoberfest and Halloween, many cities offer harvest festivals as local crops come into season. Others organize arts and crafts shows or music festivals, while local wineries debut their latest releases.The allure of fall foliage may put cars on the road, but the states on LawnStarter's shortlist have found creative ways to reward visitors for their interest.TOP FIVE STATES FOR VIEWING FALL FOLIAGECaliforniaCalifornia ranks at or near the top in virtually every metric used in the LawnStarter study. It has the most national parks, the most scenic drives, and the most Fall-related attractions. Outside of Sacramento, Apple Hill features over 50 local farms and a fall festival with apple cider donuts and u-pick pumpkin and apple venues. The Napa Valley is famous for its fall foliage, along with wine tastings and grape stomping adventures.New YorkOne measurement used in the LawnStarter study was the number of peak days for the leaf-watching season. New York ranked highest, with a total of 31 days of ideal leaf peeping available. New York is also home to the Finger Lakes, renowned for their cideries. Other points of interest include the Adirondacks and the Catskills for hiking and historical towns such as Sleepy Hollow for ghost chasing.WashingtonWashington State's mountainous and forested terrain offers adventurous foliage seekers over 12 weeks of peak viewing time. Besides a generous number of hiking trails and national parks, visitors to Washington State can also visit the alpinethemed village of Leavenworth for its Autumn Leaf Festival and enjoy adult beverages at local wineries.MichiganMichigan's extended foliage viewing season of 12 weeks makes it very appealing for Midwesterners who seek a more local destination than coastal states. Michigan also has a high number of cideries, ranking second overall in the Lawn-Starter study. A scenic drive north of Harbor Springs is known as the Tunnel of Trees and offers travelers breathtaking views of hardwood trees and their colorful leaves. The Pumpkin Train is another popular Fall-related attraction located in western Michigan.PennsylvaniaPennsylvania's abundance of undeveloped forests helps land it in the fifth position on the Lawn-Starter survey. The view of tree-covered hills and rolling pastures has enticed visitors for literally hundreds of years. The Pocono Mountains host the annual Jim Thorpe Fall Foliage Festival, a ghost tour, and a scenic train ride.THE BEST TIME TO GO LEAF PEEPINGWhile the first leaves may start to change as early as mid-September, the peak Fall foliage season doesn't generally arrive until the middle to late part of October, when air temperatures also begin to drop in many regions. The most colorful part of the transition is often over by Thanksgiving, as leaves fade to brown and trees become bare.Min Park, Ph.D., Academic Program Coordinator School of Sport, Recreation, and Tourism Management at George Mason University, says, "In general, fall foliage peaks in most parts of the nation in mid-October through mid-November.Some mountains in the northwest are often at their most colorful in mid-September to early October."As I live in Virginia, Virginia's Shenandoah National Park is one of the best for fall colors. The best time to experience gorgeous fall colors in Shenandoah National Park is in October. Visitors can make the scenic cruise along the 105-mile-long Skyline Drive, which offers 70 overlooks where travelers can hop out of the car for a better view of foliage with red, yellow, and orange leaves.".FALL FESTIVALS AND OTHER ATTRACTIONSEven if fall foliage is not at its peak or travel options are limited, there are still many Autumnal activities individuals and families can enjoy. In many areas of the country, the temperatures and climate are still favorable for camping, hiking, and attending outdoor festivals.Rosa Abreu, Assistant Professor, Hospitality Management, New York City College of Technology, offers her suggestions for a satisfying fall-related excursion. "Stay in a place that has a fire pit and roast marshmallows. Have a few drinks by the fire. Go glamping. Pumpkin and apple picking is always fun." Other fall-related festivals and destinations you might want to check out include: Morton Pumpkin Festival, Morton, Illinois The village of Morton, Illinois, produces almost all of the canned pumpkin products in the international market. The village considers itself to be the pumpkin capital of the world and celebrates annually with the Morton Pumpkin Festival in September.Salem, Massachusetts, Haunted ToursThe small coastal city of Salem, Massachusetts, has become a popular fall destination because of its association with the Salem witch trials. The city hosts several festivals throughout the fall season and guided tours of local landmarks.Vermont's Sugarhouses and Maple SyrupThe state of Vermont supplies over half of the country's maple syrup, and the fall months are the best time to watch the process unfold. Numerous sugarhouses in Vermont provide guided tours of their facilities, and guests also enjoy a taste of small-town New England life.World's Largest Corn Maze, Spring Grove, Illinois Corn mazes, hayrides, and harvest festivals are always popular destinations for families, and Richardson Farm in Spring Grove, Illinois, offers over 9 miles of hayride trails and mazes on its 28-acre cornfield.This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks.

There are plenty of places locally, across Maryland as well as travel spots nationally to check out autumn leaves and fall events.

title: A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Environment 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — On Wednesday evening, Andrew David Thaler carried a large wooden device with yellow cords piled in its interior and a yellow and black top into the St. Michaels commissioners meeting.Thaler, a member of the St. Michaels Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission, smiled as he eagerly presented the "smart buoy."
With the permission of the commissioners, the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission will put the buoy in the harbor to monitor water levels and flooding.
"What this buoy will do is it measures sea state, so we get sea surface temperature, we get wave action on the surface," Thaler said. "And then we'll also have a pressure gage at the bottom of the mooring, which we'll be able to use to assess tidal head. So that'll give us both the actual tidal cycle coming into the harbor, as well as any storm surges coming up from the bay."
According to Thaler, one of the long-term goals of the commission is to look into the viability of having the town's own tide gage.
The reasoning behind this goal is to gather specific data of St. Michaels tide pH. Currently, the data gathered for nuisance flooding, tidal surges and storm surges come from three sites. The sites are gages from Cambridge, Annapolis and Clayburn. Which are too far from St. Michaels to accurately gather information for the town.
Thaler said last year the commission applied for an equipment grant from So Far Ocean, a company that makes smart buoys. The presented device will gather data in real time and is solar powered.
Thaler said the location of the smart buoy will not interfere with boat traffic and will be located in the lagoon between Honeymoon Bridge and Mill Street. It comes at no cost to the town.
After the presentation, the St. Michaels commissioners thanked Thaler and the Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission for all their efforts. Commissioners will vote on the use of a smart buoy during a future meeting.

 EASTON — Shawna Payne issued a reminder to more than 100 people gathered in the Avalon Theatre April 9 — "You have been chosen."The phrase was a call to action. Despite any self-doubt, Payne said, those gathered in the theater that evening were there to celebrate their own accomplishments and honor their potential to initiate positive change.
In the crowd were some of more than 200 nominees for this year's Women to Watch magazine, an annual publication by APG Chesapeake recognizing the contributions of women to Mid-Shore workplaces and communities.
The women, who were nominated via an online portal by coworkers, friends, spouses and loved ones, represented a wide swath of Mid-Shore change-makers.
"It was a wonderful evening to celebrate the power, success and perseverance of women to watch in the Mid-Shore," said Orestes Baez, regional president of APG Chesapeake. "Everyone had a great story to tell and a great energy to share. APG Chesapeake did a wonderful job putting all the pieces together. We are thankful for the opportunity to share it with the public."
The event marked the launch of the fifth Women to Watch magazine, a preliminary printed version of which was unveiled at the Avalon that evening. The magazine will be inserted into the Star Democrat and available online April 23.
Payne, who works through her nonprofit The BE Academy to empower women entrepreneurs, is one of 14 women featured in this year's edition. She was the first of three speakers to offer advice to those gathered April 9.
Yixin Qiu, co-founder of Apollo's Dream Foundation and a technical project manager for Qlarant, shared how she has worked to generate positive change in the Eastern Shore community that welcomed her as an immigrant a decade ago. Qiu helped found a nonprofit aiding senior citizens with digital literacy.
Jackie Wilson, senior vice president at Burke and Herbert Bank, shared advice for women experiencing change or uncertainty in their careers. She encouraged women to embrace change and rely on their expertise and the expertise of their teams to navigate challenges.

title: Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie

content:
Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D12 | Section: News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the way that popular series of the past have been recycled - even in the streaming era that has added so much content - the second coming of "Monk" may not be that huge a surprise.As it happens, streaming is the avenue by which Tony Shalhoub is reprising his multiple-Primetime Emmy-winning portrayal of obsessive-compulsive detective Adrian Monk. Peacock premieres "Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie" on Friday, Dec. 8, with the hugely phobic title character on a very personal mission to help his journalist step-daughter Molly ("Home Economics" alum Caitlin McGee) when tragedy strikes as her wedding nears. The film might claim that this is Monk's final investigation, but of course, a ratings triumph for the picture can change that notion easily. (Consider that there have been three movie sequels to another former USA Network series, "Psych," and a fourth has been under discussion.) Also an executive producer of the new film, Shalhoub isn't the only "Monk' veteran returning for it. Series creator Andy Breckman ("The Good Cop") wrote the script and returns as an executive producer as well (with "Hit & Run's" David Hobernan also reprising the latter job), and Randy Zisk ("Midnight Caller") - who directed many of the original show's episodes, including the finale - calls the shots again on the movie.Other familiar faces from the "Monk" cast also are back. Traylor Howard ("Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place") again plays Natalie Teeger, who was Monk's second assistant on the show; Ted Levine ("The Silence of the Lambs," 1991) and Jason Gray-Stanford ("A Beautiful Mind," 2001) return as the police-connected Leland Stottlemeyer and Randy Disher; Hector Elizondo ("Last Man Standing") resurfaces as psychiatrist Neven Bell; and Melora Hardin ("The Office") resurfaces as Monk's late wife Trudy."Monk" premiered on USA Network in 2002 and enjoyed an eight-season run, with Shalhoub earning three Primetime Emmy Awards for it along the way. John Turturro ("Barton Fink," 1991) and Stanley Tucci ("Big Night," 1996) each picked up an Emmy for guest stints on the show, and Randy Newman ("Toy Story," 1995) won two of the honors for his musical contributions to it. Shalhoub also won a Golden Globe and two Screen Actors Guild Awards for the program.The series brought stardom to Shalhoub after his tenure as a respected supporting actor on stage and screen. When "Monk" began, he was known to viewers largely as Antonio on the sitcom "Wings," and he also had gained notice for roles in such movies as "Big Night" (1996, with the aforementioned Tucci) and "The Siege" (1998). He also had earned the first of what would be his four Tony Award nominations to date, for "Conversations With My Father" (1992); his others have been for "Golden Boy" (2013), "Act One" (2014) and "The Band's Visit" (2017), and he won the honor for the latter play.For now, though, it's back to "Monk" territory for Shalhoub's - and though "Last" is in the movie's name, don't necessarily bank on that being the fact.

title: Colonel tops Easton, evens slate

Colonel tops Easton, evens slate

 AMERICAN CORNER — Easton High's wrestling team is rebuilding this season.Colonel Richardson?
Colonels head coach Bryan Hall winces at the idea of a rebuild, preferring to say, "We're filling in."
Colonel filled in quite nicely Wednesday night, scoring the first takedown in eight of the 10 matches wrestled en route to a 58-24 victory over Easton.
"It hurts 'cause we thought last year we had eight sophomore starters, three freshmen starters, and only one senior," Hall said. "But we've lost four of our starters from last year. One transferred to North Caroline. One is injured. Two decided not to come out. We lost some guys we were going to be counting on as part of our season, so we're filling in."
One of those filling in for Colonel, 120-pounder Elisee Pierre-Louis, won by injury default. Pierre-Louis was taking Otto Perez to the mat, when the Easton freshman injured his arm while trying to brace his fall. Perez was taken by ambulance to have the injury treated.
"That was a momentum punch in the gut for the guys," Easton head coach Jason Biringer said of losing Perez.
Easton (0-3) had built an early 12-0 lead on Skye Matthews' forfeit win at 106, and Esteban Velasquez' 1:59 pinfall over Brody Omohundro at 113.
The injury default cut Easton's lead in half, but Colonel (2-2) won the next three matches. Jayquan Wilkins crafted a 17-2 technical fall over John Seymour at 126, pulling Colonel within 12-11. Zy Nichols (132) and Evan Alexander (138) each won by forfeit, pushing the Colonels' lead to 23-12.
The Warriors stopped that streak when Adonis Schmidt pinned Trynton Parks in 59 seconds of the 144-pound match, drawing the visitors within 23-18.
But Colonel Richardson won six of the final seven matches, scoring bonus points in five of the bouts.
Anthony Alexander (150) started Colonel's roll, pinning Matthew Bravo just as the first-period buzzer sounded. Gary Koeneman (157) followed, working a 19-4 technical fall over Vlad Oslam. Colonel's Ethan Thomas then got turned to his back, yet rolled through on the way to a 2:47 pinfall over Darren Foxwell at 165, stretching the Colonel lead to 40-18.
"They wrestled amazing," Hall said of his team. "We've been shocked by Ethan Thomas. He's a freshman, just started wrestling last year in a middle school club. He's wrestling up a weight class and has been huge.
"Other guys we expected to win, won," Hall continued. "Other guys we're expecting to go out there and wrestle hard, are. It's been a good season so far."
Tony Melendez got Easton back in the win column with a 1:07 fall over freshman Brox Meissner at 175. But the Colonels closed the match, with Richard Taylor (190) pinning Wahaab Popal in 2:15, Wilson Clough (215) winning by forfeit, and Chatydrick Pickrom (285) pinning Matthew Brunner in 2:45.
Still, Biringer was encouraged by what he saw.
"We are seeing some better habits," Biringer said. "We're also seeing some self-destructive moves, where it's, 'Don't make up your own moves. Do the moves you're taught.' Usually when something bad was happening they were trying something that wasn't a fundamental move. So it's beginner's mistakes, but at the same time a lot more effort, and progress is being made."
Colonel's girls earned 39-22 victory in what was Easton's first girls dual meet. Each team won two of the four matches wrestled.
Colonel's Luna Infante-Reyes (115) pinned Leah Gonzalez-Reyes in 3:38, and Estelle Lima (190) earned a 7-0 decision over Khadija Popal.
Easton's wins came from Shiza Gondal (135), who pinned Lizzy Hesson, and Thanh Mai Pham (140), who earned a 10-2 major decision over Aiyanna Groce.

title: Dubois readies for another fresh start
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Dubois readies for another fresh start

 June 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The life Pierre-Luc Dubois envisioned for himself a year ago no longer exists.Back then, he had requested and been granted a trade from Winnipeg to Los Angeles, signed a contract for $68 million over the next eight seasons and thought he would be a big part of the Kings' future.
Instead, Dubois endured a disappointing, underproductive season and was traded again last week to the Washington Capitals for goaltender Darcy Kuemper.
Dubois turned 26 on Monday and has already been traded three times since 2021. After the first and second were wanted by him, the latest forced him to change his perspective quickly upon joining his fourth NHL organization.
"I don't think there's any time for anybody to feel sorry about themselves," Dubois said on a video call with reporters Wednesday, one year short of the anniversary of signing his current contract. "You learn in the hockey world teams will do what they think is better for their team, and there's no hard feelings. For me, I could take it multiple ways, but I'm choosing to take it as extra motivation and to just get myself ready for next season."
Dubois acknowledged he probably did not need more motivation after putting up just 40 points, the lowest of his career in a full, 82-game season. Kings general manager Rob Blake took responsibility for Dubois not being put in the right roles and the situation not being a great fit.
The trade gives Dubois, picked third by Columbus in the 2016 draft and traded to Winnipeg five years later for Patrik Laine and Jack Roslovic, another fresh start. Dubois is the Capitals' latest reclamation project, two summers after signing another center who was a No. 3 pick and already on his second team.
That one worked out swimmingly, with Dylan Strome establishing himself as an important part of Washington's evolving core in the final years of the Alex Ovechkin era. Strome and Dubois were actually roommates when they played together on Canada's world junior team in 2017.
"I'm sure that we'll push each other, and he'll teach me what he's learned already," Dubois said. "To be able to play with him again will be really fun and get to know him again. Obviously, we're in different stages in life, but it'll be exciting."
Dubois is at the stage of trying to get back on track. On three previous occasions he scored 27 or more goals in a season, and GM Brian MacLellan when acquiring him said Dubois had immense potential to be a top-tier player because of his size, skating and hockey IQ — in part because he's expected to have a bigger role than in L.A.
"It was exactly what you want to hear as a player: How excited they are, how I can help in a lot of ways for this team," Dubois said of his first conversation with MacLellan. "You want to feel welcome. You want to feel like you're a part of it."

title: Final Four beckons Bueckers and Clark
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Final Four beckons Bueckers and Clark

 April 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1167
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CLEVELAND — Their memories are blurry.Of AAU tournaments and Team USA practices. Of gold medals and deep 3s. Of the girl with the brown ponytail with the unlimited range who always seemed to know what was coming next and the blonde who never got rattled with the ball in her hands, by opponents or the sea of eyes constantly transfixed on her.
Yet ask Iowa's Caitlin Clark and UConn's Paige Bueckers their earliest impression of the other and you get generalities, light on details if heavy on respect.
Maybe because those years shadowing each other on the travel circuit across the Midwest or teaming up for the occasional international competition seem so long ago. Maybe because in some ways — in the most meaningful of ways — they are.
The NCAA Tournament that Clark grew up watching in Iowa and Bueckers took in from the outskirts of Minneapolis doesn't exist anymore. Back then, the inequalities between the men's and women's versions of March Madness were massive, from facilities to swag to TV ratings, even the branding.
It's not that way anymore.
Not with Clark and Iowa selling out everywhere they go. Not with Bueckers finally healthy after spending the better part of two years recovering from knee injuries that left her fearful the generational skills that made her the first freshman to win the AP Player of the Year award would never return.
Only they have. Just in time for the two players who have helped propel interest in the women's tournament to an all-time high to take center stage.
When Clark and the top-seeded Hawkeyes face Bueckers and third-seeded UConn on Friday night in the Final Four, they'll do it not in some anonymous gym with nothing but parents, scouts and college coaches watching.
They will play in front of a packed arena with millions watching on television and millions more keeping track on social media, an ever-growing group that includes LeBron James and Steph Curry and Luka Doncic and aspiring ballers from all over.
It's not that women's basketball hasn't had stars before. It has. Just never quite as many as this who play quite like this.
And while Iowa coach Lisa Bluder made it a point on Thursday to say she didn't want the national semifinal to be pitted as "Caitlin vs. Paige," everyone else involved seems to be OK with the arrangement because of what it means for not just their respective teams, but the women's game in general.
"It's a star-driven society that we live in," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "It's a celebrity-driven, star-driven, influencer-driven world that's been created."
One in which both Clark and Bueckers are comfortable traveling, perhaps because it's the only world they've ever known.
BIRD VS. MAGIC 2.0? YES AND NOThe parallels to the rivalry between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird that began when Johnson and Michigan State faced Bird and Indiana State in the 1979 NCAA championship are obvious.
"All of a sudden those two particular players came on and it just lit everything up, and it just took off from there," Auriemma said. "So it needs some stars. It needs people that have the right personality, the right game. And we have that now."
Thing is, Bueckers and Clark don't view themselves as rivals. Not in a traditional sense. If anything, they believe they're simply riding the crest of a wave that's been building for years, long before they reached a first-name-only level of fame.
Ask Clark why interest in women's basketball has spiked and she doesn't point to her record-setting career or her "did she really shoot that" range or even her team's success but simple exposure.
To Clark, the women's game has always been great. It's just taken a while, a long while, for the world to catch up.
"It's the platforms that (we're able to have now) that should have been there for a really long time," Clark said. "We've had some amazing talents come through our game, over the last 10, 20 years."
Talents that haven't quite connected in the way that Clark and Bueckers have connected. The easing of rules surrounding name, image and likeness compensation has allowed them to market themselves and their game in ways once unimaginable.
FOLLOWING LEGENDSIt's a history not lost on either of them. They understand and embrace the responsibility of being a role model, knowing they were once on the other end, looking up to the likes of college and WNBA stars Maya Moore and Lindsay Whalen.
"They were everything that I wanted to be like," Bueckers said. "And they won."
A trait that has followed Bueckers seemingly from the first time she picked up a ball. It's telling that when asked about Bueckers' game, Clark didn't talk about her impeccable court vision or precise midrange jumper but what the scoreboard says after nearly every game in which she plays.
"She's always been dominant," Clark said. "Every team that she's ever been on, she's led them to great success. It's just what she does. She's a winner."
That hasn't changed, though the dynamics around the way Clark and Bueckers are perceived have flipped over the last three years.
ROLE REVERSALIt was Bueckers, not Clark, who was the top recruit in the Class of 2020. It was Bueckers, not Clark, who was recruited by the Huskies, though Auriemma did point out this week "if Caitlin really wanted to come to UConn, she would have called me." It was Bueckers, not Clark, who won that first meeting in 2021 and became the "media darling," as Bueckers put it Friday.
Clark is in that position now. Setting the NCAA Division I scoring record and playing with a fearlessness that is equal parts thrilling and accessible will do that.
Security people had to clear a path deep inside Rocket Mortgage Fieldhouse on Friday to make sure she could make it from one media opportunity to the next. When UConn and Bueckers came through an hour later, the throng was half the size.
Even for a player who says on the court she can see things before they happen, it's been a lot. The 22-year-old Clark welcomes the attention because she understands it has brought new people to her sport. Yet she's not here to be The Star, as much as people want to thrust that moniker on her.
Three years ago, it was Bueckers. The last two years, it's been her. Next spring it might be Bueckers during her redshirt senior season. Bueckers is leaning toward this year's blockbuster freshman class, a group that includes USC's JuJu Watkins or Notre Dame's Hannah Hidalgo. A decade from now, it might be some young woman who didn't pick up a ball until she watched Clark hoist it from deep and Bueckers weave through traffic in the lane.
In that way, Clark doesn't see herself or Bueckers as the end result of something, but simply the latest links in a chain growing ever stronger with each passing season.
"It doesn't need to be one end-all, be-all (star) just like I think there doesn't need to be one end-all, be-all team," Clark said. "The young talent, it's only going to get better."

title: Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548

 EASTON — A draft version of a calendar for the 2025-2026 school year drew varying opinions from Talbot County Board of Education members on Wednesday evening.The calendar committee, which plans the district's upcoming calendars, put together the draft that was shown Wednesday. It included two days off in the second week of March 2026 for students and a five-day spring break for students from April 2 to April 6, 2026.
"The thinking of the committee was to put some days off in March, and then to do the April holiday," Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, said. "Dividing the break would also minimize the impact on our students who rely on the support of our schools for their meal support."
Board President Emily Jackson, who serves on the calendar committee, expressed confusion with the draft calendar that Einhorn presented.
"It was a surprisingly contentious group, with a huge set of ideas that ran the gamut," Jackson said of the committee. "So what I am seeing presented today, to me, does not accurately reflect what I took away from the discussions that were had."
Jackson said she was expecting multiple draft calendars, not just one. She added that past surveys have indicated there are strong opinions on extending spring break and having "time for teachers in their classrooms without students."
"Personally, I come back to wanting to give our community what they're asking for," Jackson said. "So I'm looking for a calendar that has an actual spring break on it."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said she liked the two days off in March.
"I think the March break is wonderful from a mental health standpoint, because March is long, dreary," Bridges said. "And everybody — kids, parents and teachers — need a little break, and I think that's a really good thing to do."
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry raised concerns that the shorter spring break could increase chronic absenteeism in April. Vice President Amy Dodson said while the draft calendar "looks good," an off day in March could possibly be moved to extend spring break.
Jackson also brought up the possibility of staggered starts for students in "transition" grades that are starting at new schools. Einhorn said that she is waiting on direction from the state to understand how other districts do staggered starts while still complying with 180-day requirements.
Feedback from Wednesday's meeting will be taken back to the calendar committee and discussed before a draft calendar is presented for second reader at the board's January meeting.
Einhorn said it'd be possible for the committee to look at keeping the two off days in March, as well as extending spring break, by moving the last day of school back.
Jackson vouched for "consistent breaks" in order to accommodate student needs surrounding mental health, travel needs, college tours and more.
"There are ways to put this together that do make sense and don't look like this," the board president said.
"I think we have to put everything out on the table because we have constraints," Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said. "We can't have it both ways.
"And while I know we want extra days off, I hear loud and clear from parents (about) child care. But we also want to balance, because I also hear from staff, more planning time. We just have to find out, what is that balance?"

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education on Wednesday approved contracts for two upcoming projects: auditorium lights at Easton High School and windows at Chapel District Elementary School.New auditorium lights at Easton High will be installed in the summer of 2026, Director of Operations Kevin Shafer told board members. The $1.1 million contract was passed unanimously.
Shafer said some preliminary work will be done this spring before school ends. The school play and other concerts or events won't be impacted, Shafer said.
Over in Cordova, the under-renovation Chapel District Elementary School will receive glazing for its new windows. The window glazing is a security film, Shafer said, a safety measure that "prevents easy access to the school building."
All other schools in the district have the window glazing.
Chapel District Elementary is currently under renovation, a multimillion endeavor expected to be done sometime in 2026.
The contract is through a Maryland Center for School Safety grant in the amount of $132,000 for the window glazing. Shafer said the district couldn't move forward with it during construction of the renovated school building due to cost limits during the bidding process.
Shafer said he hopes the window security upgrades can be completed this summer. The board unanimously approved the contract.
Board President Emily Jackson added that she has "slight hesitations about privacy" as it relates to windows in classrooms and libraries at Chapel District Elementary and other schools.
Jackson asked that the board hear more about potential school safety grants in the future, particularly "in the privacy arena to provide more screening for our students."

title: Former 1st-rounders Toney, Farley cut
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Former 1st-rounders Toney, Farley cut

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1124
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kansas City receiver Kadarius Toney and Tennessee cornerback Caleb Farley, both first-round picks in the 2021 NFL draft, were among the cuts Tuesday as teams trimmed their rosters for the regular season.Toney, who figured to be on the roster bubble, was on his second team since the New York Giants drafted him 20th overall three years ago. The Titans took Farley two picks later.
Teams had to cut their rosters to 53 players from the training camp maximum of 90. Toney, Farley and hundreds of others will be eligible to return on practice squads that allow up to 17 players, including a spot allocated for the International Player Pathway Program.
Miami receiver Odell Beckham Jr. will begin the season on the physically unable to perform list, meaning he'll miss at least the first four games. Beckham has not seen the field with the Dolphins since signing a one-year contract in May.
San Francisco's initial roster is missing a big piece with holdout All-Pro left tackle Trent Williams remaining on the reserve/did not report list as he seeks a new deal. Star receiver Brandon Aiyuk is on the roster but has refused to practice unless he gets a new contract or is traded.
Injuries shortened both of Toney's first two seasons, and he was traded to the Chiefs during his second year with the Giants. The 25-year-old never displayed his dynamic playmaking skills consistently, but did have a big role in the first of the two Super Bowl rings he got with the Chiefs.
In a three-minute span in the fourth quarter of Kansas City's 38-35 win over Philadelphia in Super Bowl 57, Toney made two monumental plays. First, he caught a 5-yard TD pass that gave the Chiefs a 28-27 lead. Then, he returned a punt 65 yards to the Eagles 5-yard line to set up another TD.
But Toney couldn't build off that success. He struggled last season, was inactive from Week 15 through the playoffs and sat out when the Chiefs finished their repeat against San Francisco.
Kansas City added veteran wideout Marquise "Hollywood" Brown and drafted Xavier Worthy in the first round to go with Rashee Rice. The Chiefs also have Skyy Moore, Mecole Hardman and Justin Watson.
The Titans drafted Farley out of Virginia Tech after he was the first player from a major college to opt out of the 2020 season because of the pandemic. Farley was drafted weeks after a second surgery to repair a back injury from college.
Farley started just twice as injuries limited him to 12 games over his first two seasons. Farley had another back procedure in 2023.
The 25-year-old never played last season. The Titans kept him on the physically unable to perform list after his father was killed last August in an explosion that destroyed Farley's home in North Carolina.
Arizona released quarterback Desmond Ridder, which means Clayton Tune will be Kyler Murray's backup. Ridder started 13 games for Atlanta last season before being traded to the Cardinals in the offseason.
Jacksonville released eight-year veteran quarterback C.J. Beathard with an injury designation, presumably clearing the way for Mac Jones to back up Trevor Lawrence. Jones started 42 games over the past three seasons with New England after the Patriots drafted him in the first round in 2021.
Receiver JuJu Smith-Schuster was cut by the Chiefs after re-signing with them following his release by the Patriots this month.
The Cowboys put CeeDee Lamb on the commissioner exempt list a day after the All-Pro receiver agreed to a $136 million, four-year contract extension that ended his preseason-long holdout. Lamb signed the contract Tuesday.
The move allowed the Cowboys to put offensive lineman Chuma Edoga on the 53-man roster for a day. Lamb would take the place of Edoga, who could return from injured reserve sooner than four weeks.
Seattle had outside linebacker Uchenna Nwosu on the active roster, a sign the Seahawks believe the three-year starter can be ready in fewer than four games. Nwosu injured a knee in the preseason finale.
The New York Jets waived safety Jaylen Key, who was "Mr. Irrelevant" as the last pick in the draft. The former UAB and Alabama standout had a solid training camp, but was buried on the depth chart behind starters Chuck Clark and Tony Adams and veteran reserves Ashtyn Davis and Jarrick Bernard-Converse.
The Minnesota Vikings kept recovering tight end T.J. Hockenson on the physically unable to perform list, meaning the two-time Pro Bowler must miss at least the first four games. Hockenson is working through the final stage of his rehabilitation after tearing an ACL against Detroit last Dec. 24.
The Vikings waived safety Lewis Cine, the final pick of the first round two years ago in the first draft directed by general manager Kwesi Adofo-Mensah.
Cine badly broke his leg on special teams in a game early in his rookie year and never made much traction on the depth chart last season. He played a total of 10 defensive snaps in two seasons.
Denver let go of receiver Tim Patrick, whose TD in the second preseason game was his first in 974 days. Patrick, who sustained season-ending injuries at start of training camp in 2022 and '23, had a solid summer but was victim of the Broncos' depth at his position.
As expected, Cleveland placed star running back Nick Chubb on the physically unable to perform list as he continues to recover from two surgeries last year. The club is optimistic Chubb will play this season.
The Browns released running back D'Onta Foreman, who overcame a scary neck injury in training camp. With Nyheim Hines on the non-football injury list, the Browns currently have only Jerome Ford and Pierre Strong Jr. at running back.
Washington released veteran receiver Martavis Bryant, who is in his second season of trying to end a long hiatus from the NFL.
The oft-suspended 32-year-old, who last played in the NFL in 2018, spent most of last season on Dallas' practice squad and could land in the same place with the Commanders, who signed him Aug. 13.
For the second season in a row, the Saints are making a change at punter, and again, they're going with an Australian rookie. This time it's 27-year-old Matthew Hayball taking over for 31-year-old Lou Hedley, who surprisingly won the job a year earlier.
The Buffalo Bills released receiver K.J. Hamler, their primary preseason returner, and filled the hole on special teams by acquiring defensive back Brandon Codrington in a trade with the AFC East rival Jets. The teams swapped late-round picks in next year's draft.
Safety Ronnie Harrison (Colts), linebacker Deion Jones (Bills), running backs Matt Breida (49ers), Joshua Kelley (Giants) and Boston Scott (Rams), quarterbacks Mike White (Dolphins), Ben DiNucci (Bills), Matt Corral (Vikings) and Ian Book (Chiefs), wide receivers Sterling Shepard (Buccaneers) and Greg Ward (Colts) and defensive back Terrell Edmunds (Jaguars) also were cut.

title: Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As sure as bumblebees circling blossoms, the opening of Mid-Shore farmers markets is a sign of spring.The fresh and local offerings will start this weekend in St. Michaels and next weekend in Easton.
The Easton Farmers Market, opening on April 20, will be open on Saturdays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.
According to Marie Pierre Nuthall, the outdoor event manager for the Avalon Foundation, which runs the Easton Farmers Market, the weekly event is about supporting local artisans, bakers, farmers, watermen and more.
"Farmers markets are important because they support local small businesses," Nathall said. "The money is kept in the community. Everything you see is either grown here or produced here. Nothing is flown in. It is supporting and sustaining our own food production on the Shore."
The full scale market opening on April 20 will be an expansion of the Avalon Foundation's Winter Market, which it has run in the off-season. The full market will run until the second week of December, after which the Winter Market will pick back up.
"This year was the first that we went all year round with some vendors. This constitutes the opening of the Spring Market in its full glory as we expand to fill the entire municipal lot," Nuthall said. "We have lots of vegetables because many of our farmers are growing in high tunnels. We do have vendors there this Saturday, but the full market won't open until April 20."
The market is located in a municipal parking lot on the 100 block of North Harrison Street in downtown Easton.
Some of the vendors include Triangle Acres, Cottingham Farm, Honeybee Flower Farm, The Federal Brewing Company, CD Produce, Quarter Acre Farm and Gingersnap Farm.
The market will have several bakeries, produce growers and local honey. It will have woodworking and textile crafts for sale, along with other locally-made goods. There will be live music every Saturday starting at 10:30 a.m.
An interactive map of vendors is available at maps.managemymarket.
Nuthall said in addition to being able to view the roster of vendors for the duration of the calendar year, those who visit the link can also view vendor contact information, the types of items they sell and their location in the market.
There is parking available at Brewer's Lane, or the lot on the corner of Washington and Bay Streets. There will be a marked accessible parking space for those with disability parking needs.
The St. Michaels Farmers Market will be open from April 13 to Nov. 23 on Saturdays from 8:30 to 11:30 a.m. It is located on 206 S. Talbot Street.
"(St. Michaels Farmers Market) is in its 27th season and is the small town, producer-only farmers market of Maryland's Eastern Shore," said Market Manager Sandy Lawler. "We are also the only market on the Eastern Shore that has a SNAP dollar for dollar matching program."
Like Easton, the St. Michaels market has a wide array of bakers, farmers and artisans. Some of these include Little Fields Floral, Tilghman Island Baking, D&D Dog Treats, Scottish Highland Creamery, Chesapeake Mushrooms and Lyon Rum. There is also a weekly changing community and education tent and weekly musicians. Building African American Minds will be in the community and education tent on opening day.
For veggies, vendors include Shaky Wheelbarrow Herb Sales, Krieder's Tomatoes, Oksana's Produce Farm, Vintage Family Farm and Mindful Acres. Cottingham will have organic vegetables.
Night Kitchen Coffee Roasters, Casa Carmen Wines, Willwaw Farm, Fat and Happy Farms and Agave Juice and Elysium Farm will all be offering their creations.
Lawler put her finger on why this market is so enduring.
"Farmers Markets are important for so many reasons," she said. "... The biggest one is the support of our own community. Neighbor feeding neighbor with minimal transport, which means fresher healthier products including a lower environmental impact. Knowing your farmer means you are buying from someone who is a steward of the land."
Opening day, the market will have Talbot County Public Schools students playing from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m., followed by WabiSabi to close.
For more information, call 410-713-0507.

title: Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — On Wednesday, the Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General released the body-worn camera footage from the fatal officer-involved vehicle pursuit that occurred on July 22 in Easton.The preliminary investigation revealed deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop. The car did not stop, and a pursuit ensued.
Body-worn camera footage was released from four officers: Talbot County Deputies Brittanie DiMichele, William Barnett and Owen Joseph, and Easton Police Department Officer Nicholas Lange.
DiMichele led the pursuit as Joseph drove a second county police vehicle with Barnett in the passenger's seat. The driver of the car being pursued did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. Officers pursued the vehicle for several minutes, sometimes reaching speeds over 100 MPH.
"We looked at our policy and we looked at the body-worn camera footage," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview. "We listened to the dispatch record of our deputies as well as the communication behind the deputies, and our deputies followed proper procedure and policies."
In the video, officers can be seen taking a left turn onto Black Dog Alley just before stopping and exiting to approach the crashed vehicle at the 8300 block at 7:14 p.m.
"Let me see your hands. Let me see your hands," DiMichele shouted. The armed deputies asked for the people in the car to put their hands out the window.
DiMichele approached the rear passenger door on the left side, slightly opening it as repeated asks for "help" can be heard from inside the car. The rear passenger pressed his hands on the window, as Barnett repeatedly asked the driver, a juvenile male, to stick his hands out the window.
"If you keep reaching, you're going to get shot if you pull something out, you understand me?" Barnett said.
Gamble said it is "totally appropriate" for the officers to draw their weapons while approaching the vehicle.
"For their safety, they drew their weapons, ordered the people out," Gamble said. "Once they realized the injuries and there was entrapment, then they holstered their weapons and tried to assist."
Barnett asked the driver if he had any weapons, then began to attempt to help the driver exit the car at 7:16 p.m.
"We're here to help you now, okay, I need you to climb out this window," Barnett said.
The two rear passengers, a juvenile male and an adult woman, exited the car with assistance from the officers.
Officers were unable to extract the adult woman from the front passenger seat. "She's just agonal," an officer said of her breathing. One officer noted she "definitely wasn't wearing a seatbelt." EMS arrived on the scene at 7:22 p.m., the video shows.
The driver and the front seat passenger were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The front seat passenger was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the attorney general's office said.
The decedent was previously identified as 18-year-old Yemaya Wilson.
The two rear passengers were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries.
In an August interview, Gamble said after the crash, police learned the vehicle had been stolen from Montgomery County.
"We suspect the criminal charges will be brought at some point in the case, against, at the very least, the driver of the stolen vehicle, if not more," Gamble said on Wednesday. "But that's going to be in the hands of the (Maryland) State Police and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office."
The Independent Investigations Division will generally release body-worn camera and dashboard camera footage within 20 business days of an incident. The release of body-worn camera footage in this incident was delayed to allow additional time to conduct witness interviews, the Attorney General's Office said in a press release.
The Independent Investigations Division continues to investigate the circumstances of the fatal pursuit.

title: Pelosi, Biden: A fractured political friendship
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Pelosi, Biden: A fractured political friendship

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 687

 Since President Biden withdrew from seeking re-election in late July, there has been speculation about the individual or individuals most responsible for that happening.On a nationally televised address, Biden said, in part, "So, I've decided the best way forward, is to pass the torch to a new generation."
That announcement followed a series of Biden's emphatic denials that he would step down from running for a second term despite almost universal agreement that his debate performance against Donald Trump was a disaster.
On June 28, Biden acknowledged his poor debate performance but vowed to "fight on."On July 5, Biden said, "If the Lord Almighty came down and said, 'Joe, get out of the race,' I'd get out of the race. The Lord Almighty's not comin' down."On July 8, Biden said, "I'm not going anywhere."On July 11, Biden said, "It's essentially a toss-up race."On July 21, Biden announces he is leaving the presidential race.
Since then, there has been widespread speculation on the role of Nancy Pelosi on this outcome. Despite no longer serving as speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi is proof that power and influence in politics is not always based on a position.
Some believe strongly that Pelosi played a key role, if not the key role in convincing Biden to abandon his re-election campaign.
When asked if she helped apply pressure on Biden, Pelosi initially responded with, "I didn't call one person." She later acknowledged she did make a call to one person and that was President Biden. On that call she opined that based on polling his re-election prospects were dismal and that would have significant negative impacts on Democratic candidates in competitive down ballot races.
She has also admitted she took calls from key Democratic Party power brokers and opinion leaders where she expressed the same concerns she raised on her call with Biden.
When Nancy Pelosi talks about politics, most people listen. When she doesn't talk, most people notice her silence especially on matters like the viability of a Biden bid for a second term.
Now that Biden has stepped down from running, she has been somewhat more forthright.
At a recent roundtable with reporters, she still insisted she did not lead a behind-the-scenes effort to pressure President Biden to drop his re-election bid. The operative word here is "lead." While she may not have led those behind-the-scenes efforts there is increasing evidence she was very involved in them.
Like so many past and present events in politics, we may never get the full story.
We do know that this chain of events reinforces the brutal reality of politics. Whenever a candidate becomes unelectable, they become expendable.
Ultimately, who Pelosi called or did not call, did or did take calls from, exactly what was said or not said on any of those calls, a mission she was involved to some degree to replace Joe Biden as the Democratic presidential nominee became mission accomplished.
Achieving that mission formerly viewed by many as "mission impossible" has been a game changer in the 2024 presidential election and beyond. It has energized, galvanized, and mobilized a previously despondent Democratic Party. It increases the odds for Democrats to control at least one or both houses of Congress starting next year.
It has also forced the Trump campaign to explore adjustments to a campaign strategy that did not ask the question — what if Biden is not the opponent?
This change is not without some residual turbulence in the Democratic Party.
Politico recently reported Biden is angry with Nancy Pelosi. Their report includes the following quote from an anonymous senior White House official: "Biden views Pelosi as 'ruthless' and willing to set aside long-term relationships in order to keep her party in power."
As a result, Pelosi has said she and Biden have not spoken since July 19.
Based on the late scheduling and even later delivery of Biden's speech at the DNC convention it is clear the Democratic Party has no time for him going forward.
I suggest Joe Biden needs to heed advice attributed to former Democratic President Harry Truman: "If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After roughly five hours of deliberation Thursday, a Talbot County jury found a Tilghman man guilty on all but one count relating to the sexual abuse of a child earlier this year.The jury found Eric L. Werner guilty of 16 counts, including sexual abuse of a minor, third-and fourth-degree sex offenses, second-degree assault and displaying obscene matter to a minor.However, the jury did not convict Werner on one count of sexual abuse of a minor.The verdict comes after a four-day jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court.The child's mother, whom the Star Democrat is not naming to protect the victim's privacy, expressed gratitude for the guilty verdict."Justice has been served today," she said in an email. "We can't thank the Talbot County Sheriff's (Office), and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office enough for their dedication to this case and the support that they've given my daughter and our family these past 8 months." She continued: "I'd also like to express how important it is that parents, and guardians educate themselves and their children on the statistics and signs of sexual abuse and grooming. Empower your kids to speak up if someone is hurting them, being inappropriate with them, or making them feel uncomfortable. If your child discloses abuse to you, believe them, support them, and report the abuse to authorities or a mandatory reporter." "What happened to my daughter was horrible, but it could have been a lot worse if she had not spoken up when she did.She will carry this trauma with her for the rest of her life, but we all hope that because she spoke up, it will help encourage another child to do the same and stop their abuse." Defense attorney Philip Cronan said he was disappointed in the verdict, but would see what comes next with sentencing, which is yet to be scheduled.Detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office began investigating Werner, 61, in February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents that occurred at a home in Tilghman that month.Police investigation revealed that Werner sexually assaulted a preteen girl through inappropriately touching her on three different occasions in February.Werner showed the child pornographic videos, which the child remembered in detail during the trial. Police testified to a specific adult website appearing in Werner's phone's search history.In closing arguments Thursday, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel highlighted the testimony and evidence presented during the trial as concrete proof that Werner established an inappropriate relationship with the child, grooming her, she said.Numerous text messages between the two, plus the child testifying to Werner initiating sexual conversations with her, further illustrated the inappropriate relationship, Endzel said.Later, Werner, asking the child to delete messages, indicated that he continued to coax the child into becoming comfortable with sexual contact, she added.Endzel also pointed to recordings of calls Werner made to his wife while in the county jail as additional corroboration for his guilt. During one call, Werner said the truth would get him "into some trouble." And during another, he attempted to discredit her, telling his wife they needed to give a reason why she would lie, Endzel said.Countering the prosecution, Cronan acknowledged that the allegations against Werner would bother any juror, but questioned what the prosecution presented as facts.A point of contention between both attorneys Thursday morning was whether or not Werner had permanent or temporary care or custody or responsibility for the supervision of the child - criteria that needed to be met to move forward with the sexual abuse of a minor charges.Though Talbot Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe ruled that the prosecution had provided evidence demonstrating that Werner had temporary responsibility for the child during the incidents, Cronan still questioned if there was a change in responsibility between adults during his closing arguments.Cronan also questioned the consistency of the child's statements made to police compared to what she testified to on the witness stand, urging the jurors to find Werner not guilty if they only thought he "probably" or "maybe" touched the child inappropriately.In her final remarks to the jurors, Endzel said the child had no incentive to lie. She turned attention back to Werner, again highlighting his request for the child to delete text messages and pointing to the jail calls attempting to discredit her story."If that's not consciousness of guilt, I don't know what is," she said.

title: Talbot County passes 1-cent resolution for 2024 ballot
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County passes 1-cent resolution for 2024 ballot

 June 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Voters in Talbot County will see a familiar question on November's ballot.The Talbot County Council passed a resolution Tuesday to place a question on the 2024 ballot to amend the county's charter to raise residents' taxes for public safety.
The amendment would allow, but not require, the council to add up to 1 cent per $100 of assessed value above the revenue cap for an additional seven years beginning July 1, 2026.
After the council passed a similar 1-cent resolution in 2020, a majority of Talbot County voters in the 2020 general election approved the charter amendment.
Martha Sparks, the county's finance director, said the 1-cent resolution has allowed the county to add 26 public safety positions, including paramedics, EMTs, school resource officers and 911 operators. County Manager Clay Stamp vouched for the 1-cent resolution funding.
"In the last number of years, this additional funding has allowed us to see the best of our services," said Stamp, who is also the county's former emergency services director. "We've stabilized our workforce. We've been able to attract quality individuals as paramedics, correctional officers, deputy sheriffs. We've enhanced our technology, we've enhanced our coverage."
The original resolution from 2020 amended the charter for five years up until July 1, 2026. Resolution 359, which was passed Tuesday, adds an additional seven years.
Originally, Resolution 359 was introduced as extending five years. Council Vice President Pete Lesher proposed an amendment Tuesday to tack on the two additional years.
His reasoning for the amendment was to ensure any future extensions can be voted on by the public during presidential elections, when the ballot is more "uncrowded" than other elections. County council and gubernatorial elections are set to be in 2026 and 2030, meaning that if extended to only 2031, the 1-cent question may have appeared on a crowded 2030 ballot.
"By adding another two years, rather than having this expire in a council election year (or) a gubernatorial election year, this will extend it to the next presidential election year so that should this need to be renewed another time, it can be done when there isn't such a crowded ballot," Lesher said.
Council members unanimously approved the amendment 4-0 before passing the resolution by the same vote, with Council Member Dave Stepp absent.
Sparks said she's seen where the additional tax revenue has been spent, which is in "the areas that the public has supported," noting the new positions and increased funding to volunteer fire departments.
"It's very important for the public to know that they're doing good things to help us," Council President Chuck Callahan said.

title: Local author encourages 'choose love'
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontragerchespub.com
content:
Local author encourages 'choose love'

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontragerchespub.com | Section: News 
 
 725
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Kitty the Goat and the Puppy" is the third book of what will be a five-part series from local kid's author Abraham Keys, who resides in Rock Hall.All of Key's children's books are based on his real-life farming experiences growing up in South America with eleven siblings, and all his books involve relationships not normally found in nature which teach lessons of acceptance and love.
For example, his first book is about a hen named Donkey...(it's already starting out confusing) and Donkey is a little glum and depressed. In the story, farmer Abe allows Donkey (the chicken) to not only sit on chicken eggs, but also duck eggs.
Well, Donkey ends up with a new lease on life, and when those ducks hatch, she cares for those ducklings like they are her very own.
Farmer Abe learns a valuable lesson from that. If a chicken can learn to love something so different, he can love people different from him too.
And "writer Abe" can instruct people that a chicken and duck cannot interbreed, and the chicken is simply incubating the duck eggs then loving the ducklings as her own.
This kind of love transcends, and is repeated again in Abe's second book: "Moo Moo the Dog Adopts a Baby Pig," published in December 2023.
The theme is, you guessed it, Moo Moo the dog taking care of a baby pig, even more different than a duck and a chicken, and offers another powerful lesson about acceptance to Farmer Abe.
Key's third book, "Kitty the Goat and the Puppy" has been delayed in shipment, but he is hoping for an Easter release. For his other books, you can find them on Amazon and some local book stores or contact him directly.
This time around Farmer Abe will learn from Kitty the goat, taking care of a puppy.
The story goes, Kitty the goat lives on a farm. He's a prize goat, but retires and like many in the limelight, gets depressed. And like many of us, depression gives way to mischief. Kitty is eating up the flower beds and gnawing on the clothesline as goats often do.
What breaks Kitty from those bad habits is raising a little puppy, and through this puppy, Kitty finds purpose again.
The lesson?
Choose love.
It's a lesson that resounds with many readers to the joy of Keys, especially in schools where love and acceptance is a key focus, he said.
Writing with no expectations, his first book did amazingly well. Within weeks of publishing he had schools waiting to buy 300 books and since then has sold 3-4,000 copies of the book.
His foray into writing began with a challenge from friends, and he is glad he went through with it, Keys said. Finding a local artist to complement his stories, he discovered a very special niche combining children's books and agriculture along with a message of love and acceptance.
With plenty of source material too, drawing from his family owning farmland in Canada, South America and Montana, he's creating the fourth book, where the animal theme will continue. The last book of the series will explore Farmer's Abe's past with a very special horse.
Keys success has continued to grow. He has been featured in four newspapers, including a story in Montana the place of his birth, a paper in Canada, and television broadcasts in Salisbury, Maryland in addition to being invited to several local schools.
As many story tellers will say, there are all kinds of ideas running around in his mind, but he is focusing on finishing out the series first.
And he is honing his craft, drawing inspiration from others like Jay Miletsky, author of 14 books including "Ricky the Rock Who Couldn't Roll."
Keys will further challenge himself as he prepares to attend his first writer's summit in Nashville, Tennessee. He will have the chance to connect with fellow authors, pitch his ideas to professionals and learn from longtime experts.
Thrilled with the possibilities ahead, he takes with him lessons from his latest book. "Farmer Abe was reminded that when given the chance, to always choose love. Because you just never know if the love you give to others might also change your life forever," Keys wrote.
Based on his whirlwind author's journey so far, it seems like he's on to something rather special.
For information about his books, Keys encourages you to contact him directly at 410-708-5164, or find him on Facebook under Abraham Keys.

title: Was Biden's health cover-up worse than Watergate?
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Was Biden's health cover-up worse than Watergate?

 June 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 646
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In today's 24-7 media coverage of current events in the political world, stories are regularly introduced as "breaking news with more details to follow."That will most certainly be the case after the recent release of the book "Original Sin: President Biden's Decline, Its Cover-Up, and His Disastrous Choice to Run Again," coauthored by CNN's Jake Tapper and Axios reporter Alex Thompson.
Not surprisingly in today's deeply divided society, the reaction to the book has been mixed.
Some have said elected officials, and their staff lie regularly. They say it is and always has been the way of the world in which we live.
It has also been said that the public should not be surprised or upset when details emerge on behavior by elected and appointed government that is illegal or unethical.
Others have said illegal and unethical behavior is never acceptable.
They say the media has an obligation to report it, and those who engage in such behavior must be held accountable and punished to the maximum extent of the law.
Some have said, while such behavior is bipartisan, more often than not, it is overlooked or excused by some of the national media when it involves Democratic presidents.
They cite the levels of reporting by the national media on Bill Clinton's involvement with Monica Lewinsky, compared to Richard Nixon's involvement with Watergate.
Until recently, Nixon has been almost universally viewed as the least ethical and least honest president in U.S. history.
John Kass, a former Chicago Tribune political reporter and columnist has challenged that view by writing "… this one about Biden is much worse than the Watergate break-in. In that one the White House covered up the lawbreaking and the media uncovered it."
Even Jake Tapper has suggested that may be true in saying publicly, the "cover-up of the former president's mental decline may be a worse scandal than Watergate."
With that in mind, Congressional investigations are already underway on Biden's levels of awareness of and involvement on decisions made during his presidency.
More are likely to come.
It will be most interesting to learn answers given under oath to three questions:
Was there at any point during the Biden presidency, when, as a result of Biden's physical and mental health conditions, decisions that are the exclusive responsibility of an elected president were instead made by an individual or individuals other than the elected President?
If so and perhaps without President Biden being aware of it, did these individuals break the law, that is, by using autopen signatures on executive orders and pardons?
Was the media complicit if they ignored or did not follow-up with due diligence on these matters?
Other questions will not be answered until next year's midterm elections.
How many decisions were made by voters based on their support for or opposition to President Trump's agenda?
How many decisions were made on whether or not there was conclusive evidence of a coverup of President Biden's levels of engagement during all four years of his presidency?
Will the latter reflect an increasing loss of voter confidence in national news media outlets?
There are already signs of significant loss in that confidence in some of the national media.
Tapper's own CNN show had its lowest-rated month since August 2015. That should put every member of the news division of the national media on notice.
There are measurable and profound consequences on ignoring and disrespecting what Americans expect from national political news providers.
Going forward, American voters deserve three things from the national media.
Fact-based news with no hidden agendas.
Vigorous pursuit and continuous exposure of verifiable unethical and/or illegal behavior by every elected and appointed government official.
No group think — a psychological phenomenon when conclusions are not the result of a lack of information, but because of a conscious decision to put conformity above critical thinking.
Until that happens, all the excuses and explanations from the national media who failed to do their job during the Biden presidential years will be nothing more than too little, too late.
